WRESCHNER-RUSTOW, Margrit. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of long-time Board member, Margrit Wreschner- Rustow. A Holocaust survivor, Margrit used her professional expertise as a psychoanalyst to help others to heal. She will be warmly remembered for her exceptional strength, determination, and unwavering commitment to Selfhelp's historic mission of providing Holocaust survivors with comfort and dignity. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO 1/3

WRESCHNER RUSTOW-- Margrit, PhD. 14 May 1925 -19 December 2014. A great and rare woman who triumphed over the Nazis, survived three concentration camps and devoted her life to tell her story and heal survivors. Daughter to Leo and Friederike (Klaber) Wreschner, sister to Renee Herman and Lotte Salzberger, and widow of Dankwart Rustow. Born in Frankfurt am Main, fled to Amsterdam, survived Westerbork, Ravensbrueck and Theresienstadt. Graduated from Columbia University, worked for many years as a psychoanalyst, researched and lectured on the psychological experiences and healing of holocaust survivors. Told her story to young persons on three continents. Lovingly remembered by her nieces and nephews: Gaby Salzberger and Eli, Fania (Oz), Dean and Nadav Salzberger. Burial Tuesday 12 noon, at Center Cemetery, New Milford, CT. 1/3

SILVER--Bernard "Al," beloved husband, father, and grandparent, passed away Sunday, December 21st. 98 years, 3 months and 21 days . . . not a bad run. He had a unique ability to make people laugh and feel better about themselves, and was a heck of a dancer. A Veteran of World War II, he built B.A. Silver & Co. into a premier accounting firm for coffee shops, candy stores, delis (including the famous Carnegie and Stage delis in New York City), and other businesses large and small. Back in the day when accountants were sometimes considered consiglieres to their clients, Al Silver was among the best. He will be greatly missed, and leaves behind his loving wife Jinx, son Jonathan (husband of Ellen), daughter Barbara Slaine, grandchildren Brandon, Caroline, Spencer, and Danielle, and many friends and fans. Rest in peace, Al. We love you. Services will be held Tuesday, December 23 at 1:45pm at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 11115 Jog Rd., Boynton Beach, FL. 1/3

SILBERMAN--Fred, died peacefully on December 21, 2014. Loving Husband of Rita. Father to David (deceased) and Deborah (David Edelstein). Adored "grampy" to Alex, Spencer and Dani. Cherished brother and uncle. A self-made man and a true gentleman. His humor, intellect, wit and loving nature will be missed (also his beautiful blue eyes). Services 1:30pm Tuesday, December 23, 2014 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

LaGRUA--John Alfred, Jr. John Alfred LaGrua, Jr.,of New York City, died October 4 after a long illness. His death saddened friends and relatives, leaving the community depleted by the loss of a strong and sensitive individual. The cause of his death was heart failure, according to members of his family. The son of John A. LaGrua, Sr. and Mary Arbuthnot LaGrua, John was born in 1930 and grew up in Queens and Manhattan, attending for one year Columbia College before transferring to Princeton, where he joined Tiger Inn and graduated with the Class of 1952. A long career in Wall Street banking followed, eventually leading to his service as president and CEO of several international banks. He led a joint venture of Deutsch Bank and the Union Bank of Switzerland, which later became a part of UBS, the largest bank in Europe. He also served as president and CEO of Scandinavian Securities Corp, an investment bank responsible for the Wallenberg Interests in Sweden. John lived for a number of years in San Francisco and Chicago and travelled extensively in the latter phases of his career, acquiring broad cultural experiences and many friends abroad. He worked for several years for the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and was especially proud of his work teaching the United States banking system in St. Petersburg, Russia. John was a member of the Links Club and the River Club in Manhattan and the Meadow Club of Southampton, L.I. Since retirement, John was especially drawn to Central Park where he made many friends while walking his dog each day. He contributed regularly to the upkeep and improvement of the Park and also authored an article about the Park for a local publication. John is survived by a sister, Gloria Dugan, of Naples, FL, a niece, Barbara Beuerlein, of Huntington, NY, a niece, Pamela Dugan, of Naples, FL, and a grand-nephew, William Beuerlein, of Huntington. He will be missed by them and his many friends. A Memorial Mass for John will be held at the Lady Chapel, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave, New York, on Tuesday, December 23 at 1:30pm, Father George Witt presiding. 1/3

KILGALLEN--Eleanor Esther, formerly of New York City, passed away on December 20, 2014. Eleanor was the daughter of journalist James L. Kilgallen and Mae Ahern. Sister to TV, radio personality and journalist, Dorothy Kilgallen. Eleanor was a graduate of the Berkeley Carroll School and attended the Juiliard Institute of Musical Arts. Her career began as a casting director for NBC radio, CBS radio and she later worked for Young & Rubicam. Eleanor with business partner, Monique James, opened Casting Consultants. It was purchased by MCA where Ms. Kilgallen represented English clients: Dame Judith Evans, Sir Alex Guiness, Sir Laurence Olivier and Sir Michael Redgrave. As Vice President of East Coast Talent for 28 years at MCA TV and later Universal TV. Eleanor along with Monique were instrumental in launching the careers of: Warren Beatty, Kim Cattrall, Jamie Lee Curtis, Jack Klugman, George Peppard, Katherine Ross and Susan St. James. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Snaper-Shousha, son-in-law, Victor Shousha of Paramus, NJ. Grandchildren: Charles Shousha and his wife, Kathleen and Catherine Shousha. Neice: Jill Kollmar and Nephews: Richard and Kerry Kollmar. Donations in Eleanors memory may be made to St. Anne School, 1-30 Summit Avenue, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410. Services by the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, vpfh.com, Wyckoff, NJ 07481. 1/3

Erskine. Robert loved chamber music and was a loyal presence at CMS concerts and lectures for many years. We send heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. James P. O'Shaughnessy, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Suzanne Davidson, Executive Director 1/3

COLLERY--Helen Cassilly, 87, on December 17, 2014, in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Helen was raised in Baltimore and graduated from Vassar College. She married Arnold Collery in 1957. They lived at Amherst College, where Helen was a librarian, and in Manhattan, where Arnold served as Dean of Columbia College. She is survived by her brother Thomas Cassilly, her children Peter and Elizabeth Collery, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on January 9, 2015. Contact her children for details. 1/3

CASHEL--Robert. On Tuesday, December 16, Robert "Bob" Cashel died peacefully at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 37 years Lemina, his son Rob, daughter Maya and grandchildren Camarron, Courtney, Connor and Shannon. May he rest in peace. 1/3

CANTOR--Dr. Arnold, husband of the late Meriam (nee Teichner). Father of five. Grandfather and great- grandfather. Interment Rochester, NY. Friends who wish may contribute to the Dr. Arnold Cantor Memorial Fund c/o The Cleveland Music School Settlement. 1/3

BROCKMAN--Alan. 1931-2014. The Fire Island Pines Property Owners' Association will sadly miss our former President of 26 years. Alan was instrumental in shaping Fire Island Pines into the community it is today. He will always be remembered for his devotion to the Pines and FIPPOA. He will live on in his many accomplishments for the Pines. There will be a celebration of Alan's life on May 9, 2015 at 2pm at Whyte Hall, Fire Island Pines. FIPPOA Board of Directors 1/3

BROCKMAN--Alan, 83, on December 20, 2014, after a brief illness. Alan was an attorney at Tenzer Greenblatt Fallon & Kaplan and Blank Rome LLP for nearly 60 years, having joined Tenzer Greenblatt in 1957 and having been elected as partner in 1968 and ultimately serving as Senior Counsel. Alan was a graduate of Amherst College and Columbia Law School. He served in the armed forces upon his graduation from law school, prior to commencing the practice of law. Alan was the long-time President of the Fire Island Pines Property Owners' Association. Although primarily a corporate and a real estate attorney, Alan's practice encompassed many areas of law. Alan was a meticulous lawyer and a wonderful friend. He will be sorely missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to the FIPPOA Charitable Foundation, Inc., P.O. Box 5305, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782. There will be no funeral service. A celebration of his life will be held at Whyte Hall in Fire Island Pines on Saturday, May 9, 2015. 1/3

BING--Cynthia. Trevor Day School shares heartfelt condolences with Sandy, Cynthia, Alexander, Virginia, and the entire Bing family. Cynthia was a devoted Trustee and Board President who led selflessly and with great acumen and humor. She was a generous and compassionate friend to many and she will be profoundly missed. Sally Rocker,Board President Scott Reisinger, Head of School 1/3
Menkes--Andy (12/23/13) I'm so sorry I couldn't get you out. Remember "...but I love you the most." Always, Cyn

STIMMEL--Barry, MD. The faculty and staff of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai mourn the recent passing of their dear colleague, Barry Stimmel, MD. His influence over and impact on generations of physicians, through mentoring, curriculum development and research cannot be overstated. We extend our condolences to his wife, Barbara, his family, friends and colleagues who surely miss his counsel and camaraderie.

ERSKINE--Robert S. Jr.,passed away in Essex, Connecticut on December 20, 2014. Born in Bronxville, New York to Robert and Marguerite Erskine, Bob attended Deerfield Academy and Harvard University before earning his JD from Columbia Law School in 1952. He served in the Merchant Marine, and also in the US Army until 1954. He practiced law his entire career at Carter, Ledyard and Milburn in New York City, becoming a partner in 1964. He met his wife Barbara through their shared love of music, and they settled in New York City after their wedding in 1959. They were both active members of the Blue Hill Troupe and Canterbury Choral Society in New York. Bob loved sailing, and cruised many miles with his family. He was a lifelong member of the American Yacht Club, sailed many Bermuda, Transatlantic, and Fastnet races, and was a member of the New York Yacht Club and the Cruising Club of America. A longtime summer resident of Nantucket, he was also member of the Nantucket Yacht Club and a founding Commodore of the Shimmo Yacht Squadron. He is survived by his wife Barbara, daughters Eliza Drummond and Anne Black, and son Thomas. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Russell Drummond, Sam and Catherine Black, Andrew, Cole and Madelyn Erskine. He is predeceased by his sister Martha Williams. No service is planned. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation: nantucketconservation.org.

MACHOL--Betty J. Treasure of treasures it would of been your 93rd and 54 year's of togetherness for me to remember our long journey, from loneliness to love, and back to loneliness. Each birthday I remember your never failing love and the manner in which it endured, making of each morning an eternal light of my forever love. Erwin 1/3
GLICKSMAN--Albert, Aly -Dearest husband, Happy Anniversary on the 24th, Merry Christmas on the 25th, and Happy Birthday on the 26th. Love Fran 1/3

TUNIS--Leonard, M.D. The Medical Staff records with sorrow the passing of Dr. Leonard Tunis. He was a urologist at Maimonides for over 30 years until his retirement. He will be missed by all his colleagues and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. George Neiderman, M.D., President Edward Chapnick, M.D., President-Elect Harry Adler, M.D., Secretary Abraham Taub, M.D., Treasurer 1/3

TODD--Ruth H.,82, of Yardley, PA formerly of Baldwin, NY, on December 16, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth W. Todd, mother of Katherina H. Gowers and Keith W. Todd, grandmother of Sarah Ruth Gowers and Emily Katharine Todd. A memorial service will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Lung Association (www.lung.org). 1/3

SCHECHTER--Aaron, born on March 19, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY passed away peacefully in New York on December 22nd. Aaron had a wonderful life with no regrets; to quote Frank Sinatra, "I did it my way". An entertainment CPA, "hand holder" and most importantly a genuinely nice man for his career of sixty-five plus years. His wife, Elaine, served as his right hand through it all. They had an unshakeable bond that later generations hope to emulate. He leaves his wife, Elaine Abrams and three wonderful daughters --Annie Kasper (Tom), Sarah Gill (Tony) and Betsy Waters (Andrew) along with the great joys of his life --Rebecca, Caroline and Priscilla Kasper, Maxwell and Sammy Waters and Oliver Gill. He often quipped; "We should have had the grandchildren first". Also survived by his sailing buddies Ellen and Marty Abrams, brother Mike Shepherd, Alex Rooks and Jules Alexander and their families. In 2000, after enjoying Compo Beach in Westport, CT for thirty-seven years, Aaron and Elaine returned to Manhattan where he enjoyed his backyard, Central Park, as a visitor and volunteer. Donations in his honor may be made to the Aaron Schechter Baruch College Scholarship Fund, c/o Baruch College Fund, One Bernard Baruch Way, Box A-1063, NY NY 10010. A memorial celebration will be held on Friday January 30, 2015 at 6pm at the Baruch Performing Arts Center Nagelberg Theater. Entrance on south side East 25th Street between Third and Lex. Bowtie Optional. 1/3
RUDE--Herb. The community of West End Synagogue, a Reconstructionist Congregation, mourn the loss of this warmest and most caring of men. Our sympathies to his Gerrie and their family. 1/3

MORGENLANDER--Howard, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center was saddened to learn of the death of Dr. Howard Morgenlander. He was a urologist who practiced at Maimonides until 2007. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. George Neiderman, M.D., President Edward Chapnick, M.D., President-Elect Harry Adler, M.D., Secretary Abraham Taub, M.D., Treasurer 1/3

MARION--Lillian (nee Wittlin) died peacefully on December 22nd, 2014 at the age of 101. She was the top salesperson at Sherle Wagner for many years. Lillian was predeceased by her husband Bernard Marion. surviving are her beloved sons, Russell Marion, MD (Barbara), and Edward Marion, MD (Alice), three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Burial will be private. 1

KLENETSKY--Gloria, nee Steinhauer, age 89, died peacefully on December 22, 2014 after a short illness. She is survived by her loving husband of 68 years Irving; children Allan (Francine), Emily (Joseph Pariente), grandchildren Eryn (Bill Levis), Russell (Jennifer), Jody, Jonathan, Gabriel; great- granchildren Zachary, Sophia, Maya and Lauren; sisters-in-law Rhoda Carlin, Helen Burros and Shirley Klenetsky and many loving nieces and nephews. Funeral today 10am, Neiberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Donation to The American Cancer Society or Hatzoloh. 1/3

KAYE--Eugenie, on December 22, 2014. Born Eugenie Subak on April 14, 1919. Holocaust survivor. Her parents Ernst and Irma, along with sister Hennie, were prisoners at the Terezin Concentration Camp where they lost their lives. She escaped to the United States and settled in New York City in 1939. Married to Sol Kaye in 1969. Devoted mother to Gary and wife Sandy; loving grandma to Lauren and husband Todd; adored GGma to Ryan and Amanda, and beloved by all who knew her. She was the face of "Amazing Things are Happening Here" ad campaign. Painting and poetry were her passion. She was courageous, inspiring and will be missed by all. 1/3

GLASGALL--Susan "Susy" Claudia, 65, of Rye Brook, NY, passed away on Monday, December 22, 2014, after a long and courageous battle with leukemia. Beloved wife of Neil; loving mother to Jason Schlessel (Amy) and Stephanie Glickman (Jordan); devoted daughter to Lilly and the late Robert Sternheim; caring sister to Judy Perline; and a friend to all. A cornerstone In her community and top realtor in Westchester County, Susy was known for her warm and bubbly personality who started every conversation with "Hi Sweetie". With a love for shopping and fashion, she quickly became the "Lipstick Warrior" while undergoing her treatment. The service will take place at 10:00am on Wednesday, December 24, at Kneses Tifereth Israel (KTI), 575 King Street, Port Chester, NY. Donations may be made to leukemia Fighters, "Leukemia Fighters/New York--Presbyterian Hospital", c/o Dr. Gail J. Roboz, 520 East 70th Street, Box 403, New York, NY 10021. 1/3

GELFAND--Milton B. July 15, 1922 -December 23, 2014. Husband to Leticia, father to Janice and Robert, father-in- law to Paul and Susan, beloved grandfather to Jacob, Benjamin, Samantha and Melanie. Successful businessman, bon vivante, wit. Graveside service, Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont NY, Wednesday, December 24, 1 pm. 1/3

ZURAWIN--Liza, born in Warsaw, Poland, passed away peacefully on December 23, 2014 surrounded by her family. She was a holocaust survivor who escaped to Cuba with her beloved husband Adam and then the United States where they settled and began life anew. Devoted mother to Iris Marden and Michael Zurawin and adored grandmother of Sasha and Gaby Marden, Nicole and Olivia Zurawin. Liza spoke seven languages, loved to travel, and to discuss politics with anyone and everyone. She is already missed. Service Friday, December 26, 2014, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

SHERMAN--Lillian Marion (Hill), 86, of Brooklyn, NY/ Trenton, died at a Bangor hospital, December 17, 2014, surrounded by her loving family after a four year struggle with a heart condition and cancer. She was born April 07, 1928, in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of William E. and Violet Louise (Weekes) Hill. Lillian graduated from Hunter College, class of 1949. She received her M.A. from Hunter College in 1952. Lillian was married to Allen Sherman in 1954. They celebrated 60 years of marriage in July. Lillian received her elementary school teaching certificate in June 1949. She taught grades 3-6 in the New York City Public School system. She had a magnificent sense of devotion to the education of her children. She specialized in reading improvement and enrichment areas. Language arts and social studies were fields of special interest. Her favorite novel to share with her 5th grade classes was The Yearling. Lillian retired from teaching in 1994. Lillian enjoyed reading, writing poetry, solving crossword puzzles, traveling and dining out with Allen in New York City. She is survived by her beloved husband, Allen Sherman; daughters, Jeanne L. Sherman and partner Joseph A. Jantzen of Trenton, ME, Jennifer L. Sherman and husband John P. Dineen of Bayside, NY; one granddaughter, Bridget T. Dineen of Bayside, NY; one brother, Roy E. Hill and wife Alma of Brooklyn, NY; two sisters, Mary Jane Fils-Aime and husband Alix of Lakeville, PA, Mildred A. Espino and husband Juan H. of Hawley, PA; and many nieces, nephews and great nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her two brothers, William H. Hill and Richard Hill. A service of remembrance will be held 1:00- 4:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm, December 29, 2014 at McLaughlin & Sons, 9620 3rd Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in Lillian's memory be made to the SPCA of Hancock County, 141 Bar Harbor Road, Trenton 04605. Services by Jordan-Fernald, 113 Franklin St. Ellsworth Condolences may be expressed at www.jordanfernald.com 1/3

RAPAPORT RANTZ--Fenia, died peacefully December 23. Beloved wife, sister, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, friend. Born in Grodno, Belarus, Fenia survived the Ghetto and three years in Auschwitz; courageously escaping from the death march. Fenia was driven to survive to tell the story she thought no one would ever believe and remained a warm, generous and loving person throughout her life. So very missed already. Donations may be made to Temple Ner Tamid www.nertamid.org or to the Blue Card which provides Holocaust survivors aid www.thebluecard.org. 1/3

WALLERSTEIN--Robert S.,M.D., of Belvedere, CA, died December 21, 2014, of heart failure, surrounded by children and grandchildren. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1921, he moved to New York City at age two. His Bachelors and MD were from Columbia University. An internationally renowned psychoanalyst, Wallerstein trained at the Menninger Foundation, Topeka, KS; and there became Director of Research and the longitudinal Psychotherapy Research Project. He was Chief of Psychiatry at Mount Zion Hospital; Chair of the Department of Psychiatry at University of California San Francisco; Supervising Analyst at the SF Psychoanalytic Institute; and served as President of the American and International Psychoanalytic Associations. He received the prestigious Sigourney Award for outstanding contributions to psychoanalysis in 1991. His 20 books and over 350 scholarly articles made a vast contribution to the scientific study of psychoanalysis. He was a leader by consensus, a pioneer in psychoanalytic research, and an advocate for training analytic practitioners from lay backgrounds, founding the innovative Doctor of Mental Health program at UC Berkeley-UCSF. He strived for a pluralistic general theory that would integrate the many strands of psychoanalysis. Bob was a generous, kind, and humble man, who could tell and re-tell stories about his personal and professional life with a remarkable lucidity, whether it was from 50 years ago or up to the day of his death. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 65 years, Judith Wallerstein, and his son Michael. He is survived by his daughters, Nina and Amy; his daughter-in-law Liz; his sons- in-law, Glenn and David, and five grandchildren. Donations can be sent to the Wallerstein Memorial Library, UCLFAA Inc. (University College London), c/o Chapel and York, 1000 N. West Street, Suite 1200, Wilmington, DE 19801; or New Israel Fund, PO Box 96712, Washington, DC, 20077-7438. 1/3

ROSENFELD--Herbert M.,92, of White Plains, NY, passed away peacefully in his sleep on December 24, 2014. Until the last weeks of his life he was an active food broker with Rosenfeld & Gigante (formerly Leo Feder & Son) and a top salesman for the Stanislaus Cannery with which he was affiliated for more than 60 years. He was a cigar-chomping, scotch- drinking, sports-and-newspaper addict, and his wonderful stories will be missed by many. Herb, a graduate of NYU, was a paratrooper in WW II. He was predeceased by his wife Doris and son Peter, and is survived by his daughter Susan Schulman, her children Jenny (and John) Carey and Andrew (and Maggie) Schulman, and his niece Nina Sutton. Herb was also predeceased by his second wife Ruth and is survived by her sons Alan Reisch (and Judy Dein) and Marc (and Rosemary) Reisch. He was Poppy to Jake, Henry, Lily, Ben, Drew, Zach, Jessica, Matthew and Remi. His business partner Joe Gigante, a dear friend, and everyone at Rosenfeld and Gigante, were family to Herbert M. He was very grateful for the loving care of Joyce and Anzonetta. Funeral will be at Temple Israel, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd., White Plains on Sunday December 28 at noon. Charitable donations, in lieu of flowers, would be welcome. 1/3

KAPLAN--Harold, First Lieutenant in World War II, graduate of Syracuse University, and former resident of New Rochelle, East Hampton, and Greenwich, CT, passed away on December 24th, 2014 in his New York City home at the age of 93. He was the president of Hicks & Otis Prints Inc., of Norwalk, CT., and of his late father's company Joseph A. Kaplan & Sons, which pioneered decorative plastic shower curtains. He is survived by his wife Penny, daughters Rani and June, son-in-law Jiro, and grandson Jono. 1/3

APPLEMAN--Arthur Aaron, passed away in his sleep on December 20, 2014. He was 67 years old. Arthur was a graduate of the University of Buffalo and the New England College of Law, and practiced law in New York for nearly 40 years. A lifelong New Yorker he loved the city and lived his life here to the fullest. He was preceded in death by his parents Milton and Helen to whom he was a devoted and caring son; and is survived by his cousins, Warren Appleman, Ellyn Elkins, Sunny Zacharias, and Barbara Raif. Arthur's upbeat nature, joyful spirit and sense of humor will be missed by his many close friends and colleagues. Services will be held at 11am on December 26 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York City. 1/3

STEINMAN--Caryl, 96 passed December 26, Vaudeville performer, opened Palladium at 19. Lead torch singer with Rudy Valle band. Acted opposite Henny Youngman. Owned Dancing Waters performing alongside Liberace, 1984 Olympics, Miss America and more. Predeceased by her husband Harold and daughter Ellen. She is survived by three grandchildren, Jesse, Heidi and Heather Paster, and their spouses, eight great-grandchildren and Drew. Services will be Sunday, 1pm at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: ASPCA and MSKCC. 1/3

STEINFELD--Solomon C.,beloved patriarch, passed away on December 24, 2014, surrounded by his loving family. He lived fully for almost 104 years. Sol was born on March 26, 1911, in New York City. Educated at City College and Columbia University, Sol dedicated his working life to education. He was a distinguished teacher and business department chair, who authored numerous business, bookkeeping and accounting textbooks for high school and college students. He was chairman of the business education department at Franklin K. Lane High School for most of his professional career, retiring as department chair at Flushing High School. He was known and loved for his caring, enthusiasm and interest in all people. In 1983, he retired to Tucson with his late wife Mollie where he continued to write his textbooks "Practical Record Keeping" and "Clerical Record Keeping." For the past twenty years, he has shared his life with Frances Cohen, his loving companion and best friend. For those that knew him even at 103 years, he died too young. He is survived by daughter Judith (Gerald) Fleischner and son Joel (Alice) Steinfeld. He is also survived by grandchildren Cindy Fleischner, Jeff (Jamie) Fleischner, Amy (Ben) Small and Jacob (Mercedes) Steinfeld. He was blessed with seven great grandchildren: Mollie, Josh, Jack, Ellie, Ari, Hudson and Quincy. In addition, he is survived by the Sosnow family from Scottsdale and Albany, NY. Our families would like to thank all of his family and friends who enriched his life. Sol touched many people with his positive attitude and will be remembered for his "every day is a bonus day" greeting each day. We will miss you Papa. 1/3

NOLAN--Lily. Lily Nolan (Petrovits) born May 12, 1924, died December 21, 2014 in Atlanta, Georgia. Surrounded by her children, Lily peacefully passed away to join her late husband, John. Born to immigrant parents who built the American dream, Lily lived life to the fullest. Whether cheerleading for Freeport High School or building fighter planes during World War II, Lily was forever optimistic. She raised five children in Wantagh, New York, nearby her beloved sister, Mitzi, and her family. Lily made her home a center for her children and their friends and delighted in watching them grow. She was a special person who believed in the positive and reinforced in her children that almost anything was achievable. After Wantagh, Lily and John lived in Cincinnati, Ohio; North Kingstown, Rhode Island and Seven Lakes, North Carolina. Lily is survived by her children, John, David, James, Suzanne, and Betsy; their spouses, Joyce, Janet, Jackie and John; nine grandchildren; seven great grandchildren; her sister, Mitzi and her six children. There will be a memorial service at The Cemetery of the Holy Rood in late January. 1/3

MENCHINI--Gino A.,on December 20, 2014. Lifelong dedicated proprietor of U. Santini Moving & Storage, Inc. Proud Korean War Veteran. Beloved husband of Frances of 60 years. Loving father of Gino P. (Carol), Thomas (Francesca) and Daniel (Lark-Marie). Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Christina, David, Noelle, Thomas Jr., Amelia, Danny and Sophia. Beloved pet, Lola. Funeral on Tuesday 8:15am from the Marine Park Funeral Home 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. www.marine parkfh.com Funeral Mass 9:30am St. Thomas More R.C. Church Breezy Point. Interment to follow at Green- Wood Cemetery. Visiting on Sunday 2-5:00pm and 7- 9:00pm and Monday 2-5:00pm and 7 to 9:00pm. 1/3

MALLACH--Julia, age 75, died Dec 20, 2014. Librarian, educator, published memoirist and short story author, much loved and loving wife to Dennis, mother to David and Douglas, grandmother to Timothy and Kathryn. So many were drawn to her by her tranquility, wit, intellect, modesty, and compassion. For all those who loved her the sun will shine less brightly now that she has left us. 1/3

LEEDS--Gerard, was born in Hamburg, Germany on August 3, 1922. After helping his rabbi clean up their temple when it was desecrated on Kristallnacht in 1938, he and his family were some of the last Jews to escape Nazi Germany when he emigrated to San Francisco. There, he joined the US Army where he worked on the first radar systems and patrolled Stinson Beach, CA with the cavalry. He later moved to New York City where he made his home. On New Years Day 1950, at a ski area, he met and fell in love with his wife, Lilo Schott, after she beat him playing a German board game called Muhle. He and Lilo enjoyed a terrific marriage of sixty-three years, authoring the book Wonderful Marriage. With an emphasis on business principles and integrity, together they built several electronics companies including Lumatron and Data Device Corp. and the hi- tech publishing company CMP Media, which fostered a workplace culture that was cited nationally for its benefits for employees, particularly working mothers. Gerry and Lilo were named one of Newsdays 100 Who Shaped A Century. Entrepreneur, publisher and education advocate extraordinaire, Gerry and his family co-founded several successful organizations including the Institute for Student Achievement, the Alliance for Excellent Education and the Schott Foundation for Public Education. The organizations that he helped found have helped millions of students across the country achieve higher education. An eternal optimist with indomitable spirit, Gerry worked hard to make the world better. He adored his wife, children, grandchildren, brother and sister, nephews and nieces, mom and dad, cousins, in-laws, friends, dogs, horses and bunnies, skiing and hiking. Gerry leaves behind a loving family, and a better community. He is survived by his wife, Lilo, children, Michael and Andrea, Richard and Anne, Dan and Sunita, Greg and Maria, and Jennifer and Jeff, along with fourteen wonderful grandchildren. Gerry Leeds passed away on November 27, 2014 at the age of ninety- two. He is missed dearly. 1/3

GELTMAN--Emily. Emily celebrated her 102nd birthday with her family on December 23 and passed away peacefully at her beautiful home two days later on December 25th. She was admired by all for her intellectual curiosity, her passion for the arts, her impeccable style, her generosity and her great love for her family and friends. Predeceased by her adoring husband, Sidney, and her lifelong friend, Roy Pinney, Emily is survived by her sons Gerald (Susan) and Richard (Deborah), grandchildren David (Chuck), Paul (Rena), Susannah (Yuriy), Lisa (Kevin) and Zoe and great-grandchildren Dylan, Ryan, Vanessa, Isabella, Julian, Ana and Daniel. She is already missed. Service Sunday, December 28, 2014 11:00am at Gutterman and Musicant 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ 07601. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Herbert A.,MD. May 4, 1937-October 7, 2014, of Upland, CA, died from ALS. Dr. Friedman was a Urologist who practiced in Brooklyn, NY, Poconos, PA, and for 21 years at Kaiser Permanente, Fontana, CA. He was a talented musician, recreational pilot, and flight instructor. Dr. Friedman was Past President of Temple Sholom, Ontario, CA. He leaves his beloved wife of 52 years, Grace, and children Joseph, Michael and Iris who miss him every day. May his memory be a blessing to those who mourn him. 1/3

QUELLER--David, on December 24, 2014, age 93. Beloved husband of 67 years to Libbie; children Robin, Harriet, Howard, Sherry and nine grandchildren. Funeral December 28, 10:30am, Bernheim-Apter, Livingston, NJ.
METZGER--Elaine L. Larchmont, NY. October 28, 1948 -- December 25, 2014 A huge loss of a wonderful person who will be fondly remembered and missed by all who knew her. Rest In Peace.

BARILE--Mary K. "Candy", age 68, concluded her Holy Journey at her home in Manhattan, unexpectedly yet peacefully on December 23, 2014. She was born in Newark, NJ and grew up in East Orange. At the time of her death she was a valued employee of Kiton in Manhattan. She was a consecrated member of the Focolare Movement for 45 years. Parents and one brother are deceased. She is survived by one brother, Ruggiero Barile of New Jersey and a sister Jenniann Barile of North Carolina. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Sunday, December 28, 2014 at 2pm at Our Lady of the Light Chapel of Mariapolis Luminosa, 200 Cardinal Road, Hyde Park, NY. Visitation from 10:00am to 1:30pm in the chapel preceding the Mass. Interment will follow the Mass at the cemetery of Mariapolis Luminosa. A light lunch will be offered at noon. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Focolare Movement, 257 Peace Avenue, Hyde Park, NY 12538. For more information, contact the Bronx Focolare center focfny@optonline.net or in Hyde Park: luminosa@focolare.us.

WALLERSTEIN--Robert S.,M.D., of Belvedere, CA, died December 21, 2014, of heart failure, surrounded by children and grandchildren. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1921, he moved to New York City at age two. His Bachelors and MD were from Columbia University. An internationally renowned psychoanalyst, Wallerstein trained at the Menninger Foundation, Topeka, KS; and there became Director of Research and the longitudinal Psychotherapy Research Project. He was Chief of Psychiatry at Mount Zion Hospital; Chair of the Department of Psychiatry at University of California San Francisco; Supervising Analyst at the SF Psychoanalytic Institute; and served as President of the American and International Psychoanalytic Associations. He received the prestigious Sigourney Award for outstanding contributions to psychoanalysis in 1991. His 20 books and over 350 scholarly articles made a vast contribution to the scientific study of psychoanalysis. He was a leader by consensus, a pioneer in psychoanalytic research, and an advocate for training analytic practitioners from lay backgrounds, founding the innovative Doctor of Mental Health program at UC Berkeley-UCSF. He strived for a pluralistic general theory that would integrate the many strands of psychoanalysis. Bob was a generous, kind, and humble man, who could tell and re-tell stories about his personal and professional life with a remarkable lucidity, whether it was from 50 years ago or up to the day of his death. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 65 years, Judith Wallerstein, and his son Michael. He is survived by his daughters, Nina and Amy; his daughter-in-law Liz; his sons- in-law, Glenn and David, and five grandchildren. Donations can be sent to the Wallerstein Memorial Library, UCLFAA Inc. (University College London), c/o Chapel and York, 1000 N. West Street, Suite 1200, Wilmington, DE 19801; or New Israel Fund, PO Box 96712, Washington, DC, 20077-7438. 1/3

STEINMAN--Caryl, 96 passed December 26, Vaudeville performer, opened Palladium at 19. Lead torch singer with Rudy Valle band. Acted opposite Henny Youngman. Owned Dancing Waters performing alongside Liberace, 1984 Olympics, Miss America and more. Predeceased by her husband Harold and daughter Ellen. She is survived by three grandchildren, Jesse, Heidi and Heather Paster, and their spouses, eight great-grandchildren and Drew. Services will be Sunday, 1pm at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: ASPCA and MSKCC. 1/3

STEINFELD--Solomon C.,beloved patriarch, passed away on December 24, 2014, surrounded by his loving family. He lived fully for almost 104 years. Sol was born on March 26, 1911, in New York City. Educated at City College and Columbia University, Sol dedicated his working life to education. He was a distinguished teacher and business department chair, who authored numerous business, bookkeeping and accounting textbooks for high school and college students. He was chairman of the business education department at Franklin K. Lane High School for most of his professional career, retiring as department chair at Flushing High School. He was known and loved for his caring, enthusiasm and interest in all people. In 1983, he retired to Tucson with his late wife Mollie where he continued to write his textbooks "Practical Record Keeping" and "Clerical Record Keeping." For the past twenty years, he has shared his life with Frances Cohen, his loving companion and best friend. For those that knew him even at 103 years, he died too young. He is survived by daughter Judith (Gerald) Fleischner and son Joel (Alice) Steinfeld. He is also survived by grandchildren Cindy Fleischner, Jeff (Jamie) Fleischner, Amy (Ben) Small and Jacob (Mercedes) Steinfeld. He was blessed with seven great grandchildren: Mollie, Josh, Jack, Ellie, Ari, Hudson and Quincy. In addition, he is survived by the Sosnow family from Scottsdale and Albany, NY. Our families would like to thank all of his family and friends who enriched his life. Sol touched many people with his positive attitude and will be remembered for his "every day is a bonus day" greeting each day. We will miss you Papa. 1/3
SILVERMAN--Philip. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Jill and Wendy (Jeff) Cohen. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Perri and Caroline. Loving brother of Myra. 1/3

SCHIFFER--Craig, 58, an investment banker who held numerous global leadership roles in over 35 years in the industry, died in an avalanche on December 23, 2014 while skiing with his children in Val Thorens, France. A resident of Summit, NJ, Craig is survived by his parents, Charles Schiffer and Carol Polinsky; his wife, Amy; his five children, Zach, Jessica, Zoe, Annie and Gabe; and his siblings Michael Schiffer and Leslie Schiffer McGinn. Born in Cleveland, OH on August 25, 1956, he grew up in Denver and went on to graduate from UC Santa Cruz with a BA in history. On June 1, 1996, he married Amy, the love of his life, mother of his three youngest children and an amazing stepmother to Zach and Jessica. An expert in credit and a strong strategic thinker, Craig worked at Lehman Brothers, from 1978 to 1996, holding various executive positions. In 1997 he moved to the debt division of Japan-based Nomura Holdings Inc. In 2003, he moved to Dresdner Kleinwort, as the New York-based chief executive of the Americas until 2006. In 2009 he opened Sevara Partners, an adviser to investors and companies, and in 2013 began working as a managing director at Cowen Group. Craig, a larger than life personality, was known for his loyalty, humor and boundless energy. An avid skier, biker, hiker and overall lover of the outdoors, he constantly sought adventure. His love of the outdoors was rivaled only by his love of food and friends. Nothing pleased him more than a meal with those he loved. His spirit and determination were infectious, an inspiration to everyone he came across, especially his children, whom he deeply loved. Craig simply had a zest for lifefor living it to the fullest and then some, and for helping others make the most of it, too. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, and all who knew him. It is his children's hope to carry on the legacy of this great man. 1/3

SCHECHTER--Aaron, born on March 19, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY passed away peacefully in New York on December 22nd. Aaron had a wonderful life with no regrets; to quote Frank Sinatra, "I did it my way". An entertainment CPA, "hand holder" and most importantly a genuinely nice man for his career of sixty-five plus years. His wife, Elaine, served as his right hand through it all. They had an unshakeable bond that later generations hope to emulate. He leaves his wife, Elaine Abrams and three wonderful daughters --Annie Kasper (Tom), Sarah Gill (Tony) and Betsy Waters (Andrew) along with the great joys of his life --Rebecca, Caroline and Priscilla Kasper, Maxwell and Sammy Waters and Oliver Gill. He often quipped; "We should have had the grandchildren first". Also survived by his sailing buddies Ellen and Marty Abrams, brother Mike Shepherd, Alex Rooks and Jules Alexander and their families. In 2000, after enjoying Compo Beach in Westport, CT for thirty-seven years, Aaron and Elaine returned to Manhattan where he enjoyed his backyard, Central Park, as a visitor and volunteer. Donations in his honor may be made to the Aaron Schechter Baruch College Scholarship Fund, c/o Baruch College Fund, One Bernard Baruch Way, Box A-1063, NY NY 10010. A memorial celebration will be held on Friday January 30, 2015 at 6pm at the Baruch Performing Arts Center Nagelberg Theater. Entrance on south side East 25th Street between Third and Lex. Bowtie Optional. 1/3

ROSENFELD--Herbert M.,92, of White Plains, NY, passed away peacefully in his sleep on December 24, 2014. Until the last weeks of his life he was an active food broker with Rosenfeld & Gigante (formerly Leo Feder & Son) and a top salesman for the Stanislaus Cannery with which he was affiliated for more than 60 years. He was a cigar-chomping, scotch- drinking, sports-and-newspaper addict, and his wonderful stories will be missed by many. Herb, a graduate of NYU, was a paratrooper in WW II. He was predeceased by his wife Doris and son Peter, and is survived by his daughter Susan Schulman, her children Jenny (and John) Carey and Andrew (and Maggie) Schulman, and his niece Nina Sutton. Herb was also predeceased by his second wife Ruth and is survived by her sons Alan Reisch (and Judy Dein) and Marc (and Rosemary) Reisch. He was Poppy to Jake, Henry, Lily, Ben, Drew, Zach, Jessica, Matthew and Remi. His business partner Joe Gigante, a dear friend, and everyone at Rosenfeld and Gigante, were family to Herbert M. He was very grateful for the loving care of Joyce and Anzonetta. Funeral will be at Temple Israel, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd., White Plains on Sunday December 28 at noon. Charitable donations, in lieu of flowers, would be welcome. 1/3

NOLAN--Lily. Lily Nolan (Petrovits) born May 12, 1924, died December 21, 2014 in Atlanta, Georgia. Surrounded by her children, Lily peacefully passed away to join her late husband, John. Born to immigrant parents who built the American dream, Lily lived life to the fullest. Whether cheerleading for Freeport High School or building fighter planes during World War II, Lily was forever optimistic. She raised five children in Wantagh, New York, nearby her beloved sister, Mitzi, and her family. Lily made her home a center for her children and their friends and delighted in watching them grow. She was a special person who believed in the positive and reinforced in her children that almost anything was achievable. After Wantagh, Lily and John lived in Cincinnati, Ohio; North Kingstown, Rhode Island and Seven Lakes, North Carolina. Lily is survived by her children, John, David, James, Suzanne, and Betsy; their spouses, Joyce, Janet, Jackie and John; nine grandchildren; seven great grandchildren; her sister, Mitzi and her six children. There will be a memorial service at The Cemetery of the Holy Rood in late January. 1/3

NEWTON--Robert L.,age 87 of Pompton Plains, NJ died peacefully on Christmas Day, 2014. Bob resided in Wayne, NJ for forty years before moving to Pompton Plains, NJ in 1996. A graduate of the University of Syracuse, he earned his Masters degree in Chemistry from Cornell University. He began his career on Wall Street with Clark Dodge & Co. After ten years with Clark Dodge, Bob joined F. Eberstadt & Co. retiring as Senior Vice President. His career was marked by much success, yet Bob would tell you that his greatest achievements were the friendships he developed all along the way. He was a humble man, selfless to a fault, and very generous. Bob is survived by his wife Alma, his children; Peg Patten and her husband Chris, Russ Newton and his wife Kimberly, and Audrey Newton, Almas children; Forrest DeVisser and his wife Jamie, and Garret DeVisser and his wife Maritta, five grandchildren; Jacob, Sami and Robert Newton and Alyssa and Olivia DeVisser, sister-in- law; Dahlia Newton and her children; Jessica Orvis and Roy Newton. Friends may visit with the family at the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne, NJ on Tuesday, December 30, 2014 from 11am to 1pm. A funeral service will follow at 1pm on Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bobs memory would be greatly appreciated to the NY-NJ Trail Conference or to Spence-Chapin Adoption Services. For a photo and more information visit www.vandermay.com. 1/3

MARINO--Robert A.,passed away on the December 21st winter solstice, which is a celebration of being "born again"--not of flesh, but of the spirit. He courageously fought brain cancer for 18 months, remaining eloquent, dignified, gracious and flirtatious, until the very end. Despite a difficult childhood and the untimely death of his mother, Bob led a life of leadership and service to others. He graduated from Copiague High School in 1971. He was editor-in-chief of the student newspaper, The Maverick, garnering numerous awards. He spearheaded the fight against school newspaper censorship, leading him to take on state politicians in Albany which included a colorful exchange with Governor Rockefeller! He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from Syracuse University in 1975. After moving to NYC, he enjoyed brief political successes before catching the real estate bug. He went on to study Real Estate Finance at Columbia University Graduate School of Business, earning his degree in 1982. Soon afterwards, he established his practice and became one of the top real estate appraisers in the state of New York. His keen sense for the booming market led him to purchase a condo at auction on the upper west side, at Columbus Common. Serving as Board President for ten years, he was instrumental in knitting together a cohesive and friendly community, creating opportunities for strangers to become friends. He was well known for his beautiful terrace garden, and he loved hosting weekly dinners with his friends, which came to be known as "family dinners". He opened his home, heart and wallet to friends and animals in need, providing shelter, food and comfort. He gave generously without a desire for acknowledgement or recognition. Bob was a passionate animal advocate adopting numerous cats and dogs throughout his life. He always had a treat in his pocket for every dog he met on his daily walks through the neighborhood and Central Park. His beloved Akita, Bella, was the motivation behind the fight to keep off leash privileges for dogs in NYC parks when the city sued to ban it forever in 2006. As president of NYCDOG, Bob brought thousands of people together and led a victorious campaign that resulted in the 9pm to 9am off leash privileges. Every dog owner in NYC owes a huge debt of gratitude to Bob Marino for this remarkable achievement. His close friends describe Bob as: handsome, charming, intelligent, unwaveringly loyal and fair, great listener with a huge heart, unfiltered sense of humor, lover of all blondes, playfully naughty, staunch Democrat, and matchmaker of people and animals. All of his friends' children regarded him as a beloved uncle. He never had an unkind word to say about anyone, unless they were Republican! He is survived by his loving sister Mary, who was his fierce advocate and caretaker for the last part of his life, his father and stepmother, five additional siblings, and extended family. In addition, Bob leaves behind hundreds of friends across the globe, whose lives he has impacted and changed for the better. A celebration of life was held for Bob this past May at his favorite restaurant in NYC, with over 200 people and animals in attendance. Ever generous, Bob donated his body to Rutgers University for research. Bob's final wish is for everyone to share their lives by adopting rescue pets who need love. For those who prefer to donate as a tribute to Bob, he encouraged and helped sponsor a new animal rescue in 2012 -Home Sweet Home of Long Island, 273 Walt Whitman Road #

LOPEZ--Loretta E.,died peacefully on December 23, 2014, at the age of 99. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of St. Joseph College, Brooklyn, Class of 1936. An avid lover of opera with season tickets to the Met, and a world traveller, she was an executive legal secretary in a trusts/estates practice for more than 40 years. Beloved daughter of the late Felix M. and Loretta Quinlan. Dear sister of the late Felix M. Jr., Anita McCarthy, Eugene R., Ramon, Joan, and Gerard F. She is survived by 18 nieces and nephews, 38 grandnieces and nephews, and 16 great-grand nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, December 31, 11am at Holy Cross Cemetery, 3620 Tilden Ave., Brooklyn. All services entrusted to Clavin Funeral Home. 1/3

KELLER--Barbara (Feuer), 83, of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach, NY, died peacefully on December 22, 2014. She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Donal E. Keller, DDS. She leaves her children Andrew Keller, MD (Gillian), Jane Gordon (Lawrence), and Marjorie Powers (Alan), five grandchildren, a niece and a nephew. 1/3

LEEDS--Gerard, was born in Hamburg, Germany on August 3, 1922. After helping his rabbi clean up their temple when it was desecrated on Kristallnacht in 1938, he and his family were some of the last Jews to escape Nazi Germany when he emigrated to San Francisco. There, he joined the US Army where he worked on the first radar systems and patrolled Stinson Beach, CA with the cavalry. He later moved to New York City where he made his home. On New Years Day 1950, at a ski area, he met and fell in love with his wife, Lilo Schott, after she beat him playing a German board game called Muhle. He and Lilo enjoyed a terrific marriage of sixty-three years, authoring the book Wonderful Marriage. With an emphasis on business principles and integrity, together they built several electronics companies including Lumatron and Data Device Corp. and the hi- tech publishing company CMP Media, which fostered a workplace culture that was cited nationally for its benefits for employees, particularly working mothers. Gerry and Lilo were named one of Newsdays 100 Who Shaped A Century. Entrepreneur, publisher and education advocate extraordinaire, Gerry and his family co-founded several successful organizations including the Institute for Student Achievement, the Alliance for Excellent Education and the Schott Foundation for Public Education. The organizations that he helped found have helped millions of students across the country achieve higher education. An eternal optimist with indomitable spirit, Gerry worked hard to make the world better. He adored his wife, children, grandchildren, brother and sister, nephews and nieces, mom and dad, cousins, in-laws, friends, dogs, horses and bunnies, skiing and hiking. Gerry leaves behind a loving family, and a better community. He is survived by his wife, Lilo, children, Michael and Andrea, Richard and Anne, Dan and Sunita, Greg and Maria, and Jennifer and Jeff, along with fourteen wonderful grandchildren. Gerry Leeds passed away on November 27, 2014 at the age of ninety- two. He is missed dearly. 1/3

KAPLAN--Harold, First Lieutenant in World War II, graduate of Syracuse University, and former resident of New Rochelle, East Hampton, and Greenwich, CT, passed away on December 24th, 2014 in his New York City home at the age of 93. He was the president of Hicks & Otis Prints Inc., of Norwalk, CT., and of his late father's company Joseph A. Kaplan & Sons, which pioneered decorative plastic shower curtains. He is survived by his wife Penny, daughters Rani and June, son-in-law Jiro, and grandson Jono. 1/3

KAPLAN--Harold M. March 4, 1921 to December 25, 2014. We wish to send our condolences, prayers, and best wishes to Mr. Harold Kaplan's wife Penny, their daughters Rani and June, and to their families. As the president of Hicks & Otis Prints, he lead by example which created a positive atmosphere for us all. The stewardship and counsel he provided has made his company successful to this day. He will be remembered by all of us. The employees of Hicks & Otis Prints, Inc. 1/3
KANER--Leni Herbert, passed away peacefully on December 26th after a courageous battle against cancer. We will miss you. Luv, Paula 1/3

GRIMMELMANN--Frances Kerr. Born June 12, 1918 in Laddonia, MO and died December 19, 2014 at home in New York City. Dear mother of Erik (Louise Gikow) and Ellen (Moshe Adler), who survive her. Predeceased by her husband of 65 years, Ihler; by her daughter Lisa, and by her siblings Hugh and Nancy. Much loved grandmother of Rachel, James (Aislinn Black), and Lily and great- grandmother of Beatrice. Long-time resident of White Plains, NY and later of Greenwich, CT. Graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism (1940). Former Conde Nast editor, medical librarian, and researcher. Had great times sailing on "Tranquillity" with Ihler. Loved and admired by all who knew her. The family wishes to thank her caregivers, Emy, Alice, Lulu, and Ouli. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Amnesty International, the Vera Institute of Justice, or The New Press. IGNYC49@gmail.com 1/3

GINSBERG--Doris, 98, died peacefully December 25, 2014. Born in New York City on October 27, 1916 to Blanche and Emanual Hertz. Mother of Elizabeth Ginsberg and Victoria Degnen, sister of Hamilton Hertz. Service private. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Herbert A.,MD. May 4, 1937-October 7, 2014, of Upland, CA, died from ALS. Dr. Friedman was a Urologist who practiced in Brooklyn, NY, Poconos, PA, and for 21 years at Kaiser Permanente, Fontana, CA. He was a talented musician, recreational pilot, and flight instructor. Dr. Friedman was Past President of Temple Sholom, Ontario, CA. He leaves his beloved wife of 52 years, Grace, and children Joseph, Michael and Iris who miss him every day. May his memory be a blessing to those who mourn him. 1/3

FREY--Virginia Howell Johnson, formerly of New York, NY, died on December 22, 2014 in Nashville, TN. Virginia was a Manager at CBS Television, Business Affairs. She retired in 1995 after 27 years of service. She is survived by her daughter, Cathleen (Casey) Del Casino; grandchildren, Caitlin and Ryan. An online guest book is available at: AustinFuneralService.com. 615-377-0775. 1/3

FISHER--Phyllis. On Thursday, December 18, 2014 Phyllis died of a long, valiantly and uncomplainingly resisted illness. All who knew her remember how she levitated whatever room she entered, filling it with warmth, humor and the irresistible feeling that life is good. Phyllis is survived by her spouse of 50 too short years, Doris Schepps; her great-niece Nika Dellureficio, whom she adored beyond words; her loving and loved niece Elizabeth Dellureficio; her two cousins Pearl and Ronald Berman, and Ronald's wife Bernice, all of whom she greatly loved and by whom she was beloved. Phyllis knew how to live life, what was of consequence and what was not. To those of us who shared her life the world without her is less bright. 1/3

EDDISON--William Barton Jr.,died on December 13, 2014 at Broadmead Retirement Community in Cockeysville, MD. A memorial service will be held at Broadmead on January 16, 2015, at 11:00am; a private burial will take place in Lyme, Connecticut, in the spring. William "Bill" Eddison was born on May 15, 1924. He grew up in Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY, and Northeast Harbor, ME. Bill graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and from Harvard College. During the War Bill served with the 15th Army Air Corps as an aerial gunner flying out of Italy. Shot down in 1944 he became a P.O.W. until he was liberated in 1945. He then returned to Havard. Bill later received Masters degrees from Columbia University and The University of Pennsylvania. He worked with the Bucks County Planning Commission, then the City of Lancaster and later for the City Planning Commission of Philadelphia. In 1967 he married Maria Elizabeth (Marice) Wehmeijer from the Netherlands. They settled in Baltimore, MD and then in Lyme, CT. Later they retired to Broadmead where Bill was an active member of the community. Bill is survived by his two sisters, Mary Eddison Welch of Bedford, MA, Anne Eddison Brainerd of Cambridge, MA and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his older brother, John C. Eddison and his younger brother, Lee Corbin Eddison. 1/3

DeFRANCO--Buddy. Dear lifelong friend, mentor and extraordinary musician. A Jazz Master, and father of modern jazz clarinet. The epitome of astounding mastery for seven decades, he was a kind, generous man and an exemplary role model for many of us. Buddy was a loved and loving friend. He will be forever in our hearts. Johanna and I extend our sincerest condolences to his amazing wife Joyce, son Chad and Family. Ronald B. Odrich 1/3

CURTIS--Charles Buckley, whose family originally settled Stratford, CT in 1734, passed away on December 21, 2014 in Peterborough, NH. Born October 14, 1929, he was the first child of Isobel Ramsay Buckley and John Talbot Curtis. "Chas" grew up in Southport, CT and graduated from Deerfield in 1947 and Yale in 1951. He rose to Executive Officer and Navigator in the United States Navy, following a long line of military and naval service stretching back to Silas Talbot, Captain of the U.S.S. Constitution. Early in his career he joined Pepperidge Farm and became General Plant Manager in Norwalk, CT. Chas then joined White, Weld & Co. to pursue a long-held interest in stock picking and portfolio management. He ultimately retired at 72 as Senior Vice President of UBS, having retained many of his original clients. Making turns into his eighties, Chas had a lifelong interest in skiing, first courting his wife of fifty-seven years, Ellen Martin Whitaker, at Mad River Glen. They later introduced their three boys to the "Alta Bounce." When not skiing, playing the drums, or listening to Louis Armstrong, he was a passionate and studious golfer at The Country Club of Fairfield, where he became President as his father had been. Chas also dedicated himself to Fairfield Country Day School as a long serving Trustee. Never happier than when out in the garden weeding, clipping, planting or supervising, he cherished his land at Mountain Meadow Farm in Weston, VT. Starting in 1964 with 20 acres and finishing with 192 acres, his careful and exacting stewardship of the trails, meadows, stonewalls, barn, milk house, sugar shack, and house may be his proudest legacy. He is survived by his wife, his sisters, Clare Rimmer of Kennebunkport, ME and Exeter, NH, Mollie Fair of Charleston, SC, and sons, John Talbot Curtis II of London England, Timothy Whitaker Curtis of Fairfield, CT, and Charles Buckley Curtis Jr. of Waitsfield, VT, along with seven skiing grandchildren. 1/3

COUGHLIN--Ruth B.,71, of Little Falls, NJ, passed away on December 25, 2014. Ruth was a Book Editor for the Detroit News for many years and also worked as an Editor for various New York City publishers. Devoted wife of the late William Coughlin. Dear sister of Michael J. Pollard of Los Angeles, CA. Cremation was private under the direction of the Shook Funeral Home, Clifton, NJ. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, www.cancer.org, in Ruth's memory. ShookFH.com 1/3

COLLERY--Helen Cassilly, 87, on December 17, 2014, in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Helen was raised in Baltimore and graduated from Vassar College. She married Arnold Collery in 1957. They lived at Amherst College, where Helen was a librarian, and in Manhattan, where Arnold served as Dean of Columbia College. She is survived by her brother Thomas Cassilly, her children Peter and Elizabeth Collery, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on January 9, 2015. Contact her children for details. 1/3

COELHO-ADAM--Yvette C.,passed away on December 18, 2014, at age 71. Born in Bombay, India and a New Yorker for nearly 50 years, Yvette was a Pediatric Occupational Therapist, who devoted her career to helping some of the City's most disadvantaged children. A proud American and an active member of the Republican Party, Yvette ran for office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on three occasions. Stunning, stylish, fierce and full of life, she was a devoted mother and role model to her daughter, Yvette Daphne Coelho- Adam, by whom she is survived. She is also survived by three siblings, living overseas. A Funeral Mass was celebrated on December 22, 2014 and a memorial celebration of her life will take place in early February. Memorial donations may be made to "Children of Bellevue." 1/3
BUSH--Jacqueline Wellington, 93, of Falmouth, MA, died December 22, 2014. She is survived by daughter Caryn Baird, and granddaughters Juliette and Jacquee Bush. 1/3

BROWN--Stephen B.,on December 27, adored "Captain" to his beloved grandchildren Zach, Jake, Ryan, Ike, and Sophie, the center of his life; his daughters Ali (Alan) Kotin and Jen (Neal) Simon; and devoted wife of 51 years, Linda Sirota. Brother of Harvey Brown. Born in Brooklyn, Steve graduated from Columbia University, where he played basketball, and New York University Law School. For many years, he was General Counsel at Champion International, and after his retirement served as Town Attorney for Southampton, NY. He held World Record for Grandparent Attendance at Baseball, Basketball, Lacrosse, Tennis and Golf Events Along the Eastern Seaboard, where his grandchildren participated during the last decade. Steve was a lifelong avid New Yorker, whose sense of humor was a source of joy to all lucky enough to know him. Funeral details forthcoming. 1/3

BRODBER-McLAREN-- Maizie, 80 of Jamaica W.I. Beloved mother, grandmother, Registered Nurse and Community Leader, passed away peacefully on December 15, 2014. BROCKMAN--Alan. 1931-2014. The Fire Island Pines Property Owners' Association will sadly miss our former President of 26 years. He will live on in his many accomplishments for the Pines. There will be a celebration of Alan's life on May 9, 2015 at 2pm at Whyte Hall, Fire Island Pines. FIPPOA Board of Directors 1/3

BING--Cynthia Eaton. Passed away peacefully at Mt. Sinai Hospital on December 12 after a long illness. Cynthia was born on April 6, 1942 in Belfast, ME. She attended Abbott Academy (Philips Andover Academy) and Connecticut College for Women (Connecticut College). After moving to New York City, she worked for Holland America Line as head of group sales. In 1972, she married Alexander Bing III, partner at L.F. Rothschild & Co. Cynthia was a dedicated mother to three young children when she began her career as a philanthropist in fields of education and environmental protection. She served on many boards including: Phillips Academy, Connecticut College, Trevor Day School, The Parents League of New York, Prep for Prep, Early Steps, Search and Care, New York State Association of Independent Schools, New York League of Conservation Voters, and Environmental Advocates. In many cases, Cynthia served as board president or acted as a committee head. Cynthia spent her summers with her family in Montana where enjoyed the mountains and cross-country horseback riding. Cynthia's parents, Lorimer and Ruth Eaton, and one child, Abigail R. Bing predeceased her. She is survived by her husband, Alexander Bing III; brother, Eben R. Eaton; daughter, Cynthia K. Bing; son, Alexander M. Bing; step-daughter, Virginia G. Bing; granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial; and son- in-law, Michael S. Padial. A Memorial Service is to be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave., at 3pm, January 6 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Church of The Heavenly Rest and/or Search and Care. 1/3

FRIEDBERG--Florence, 90, died suddenly after a period of declining health, on December 26, 2014 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY. She is survived by her loving husband of 72 years, Barry Friedberg, her devoted children Diane and Marc Houslanger and Richard Friedberg and Courtenay Dodge; her grandchildren Michelle Houslanger, Joseph Houslanger, Sarah and Max Krohn, Hannah and David Orowitz; a great-grandchild Genevieve Krohn, and her sister Beatrice Segal. Florence was born in New York City on May 4, 1924 to Betty and Samuel Schick and graduated from Theodore Roosevelt High School in 1942. She was a devoted mother and wife and also enjoyed painting and volunteering at various charities. Along with her husband, she was engaged in a variety of philanthropic projects both in Nassau County, NY and Boca Raton, FL. She knew love was her highest priority. She and her husband were also very active in Temple B'nai Israel in Elmont, NY. The funeral service, under the direction of Gutterman's, will be held on Monday, December 29th at Temple B'nai Israel, 471 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY with services conducted by Rabbi Samuel Kehati. Burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Barry and Florence Friedberg JCC in Oceanside, NY, Temple B'nai Israel of Elmont, or a charity of the donor's choice. May her memory be a blessing.

ROSEN --Harry. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Harry Rosen, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. FRIEDBERG--Florence, 90, died suddenly after a period of declining health, on December 26, 2014 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY. She is survived by her loving husband of 72 years, Barry Friedberg, her devoted children Diane and Marc Houslanger and Richard Friedberg and Courtenay Dodge; her grandchildren Michelle Houslanger, Joseph Houslanger, Sarah and Max Krohn, Hannah and David Orowitz; a great-grandchild Genevieve Krohn, and her sister Beatrice Segal. Florence was born in New York City on May 4, 1924 to Betty and Samuel Schick and graduated from Theodore Roosevelt High School in 1942. She was a devoted mother and wife and also enjoyed painting and volunteering at various charities. Along with her husband, she was engaged in a variety of philanthropic projects both in Nassau County, NY and Boca Raton, FL. She knew love was her highest priority. She and her husband were also very active in Temple B'nai Israel in Elmont, NY. The funeral service, under the direction of Gutterman's, will be held on Monday, December 29th at Temple B'nai Israel, 471 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY with services conducted by Rabbi Samuel Kehati. Burial will follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Barry and Florence Friedberg JCC in Oceanside, NY, Temple B'nai Israel of Elmont, or a charity of the donor's choice. May her memory be a blessing.

Pollard of Los Angeles, CA. Cremation was private under the direction of the Shook Funeral Home, Clifton, NJ. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, www.cancer.org, in Ruth's memory. ShookFH.com 1/3

COLEMAN--FREDERICK H. A long time New York textile industry executive and New Rochelle resident passed December 27th, at the age of 90. Mr. Coleman was for over 40 years a senior executive with APSCO Fabrics and its predecessor AP Silk, prior to that he was associated with Kohn- Hall-Marx. Coleman was 1939 graduate of Townsend Harris High School, a 1943 graduate of City College of New York, and later attended Columbia University Graduate School. He served in the United States Army in Europe during World War II in the Field Artillery Observation Corps. At age 15, he was awarded a trip to Japan by the Imperial Government , where he established a lifelong love of Japanese culture, making annual trips over the course of his business career. A trustee of Temple Israel New Rochelle, he is survived by his wife Claire and sons Franklin (Antoinette) of McLean, VA and Elliot (Patrice) of Bedford and five grandchildren Samuel, Daniel, Benjamin, Abigail, and Aiden. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel, Tuesday 10 AM. 1/3

GRAY--Barbara B. Barbara B. Gray, who resided at the Princeton Windrows retirement home in Princeton, NJ died on December 21, 2014 of heart failure. Mrs. Gray came from a family of German-Irish decent who arrived in America in the early 1700's, many participating in the American Revolution. Prominent among them was Charles Carroll of Maryland, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. Mrs. Gray was born in Salt Lake City on October 26, 1918 to Denise Karrick Bintz and Charles Carroll Bintz. She grew up in Salt Lake City where she attended Roland Hall and East High School and later graduating from Stanford University. Among her proudest moments were a startling 93 on a physics exam at Roland Hall, numerous equestrian firsts in the Salt Lake City Horse Show, most notably for Ladies Jumping, and her BA from Stanford where she was a member of the Pi Phi sorority. A devoted wife of 72 years, Mrs. Gray married Sherman Gray in October 1942. The son of Prentiss Nathaniel Gray and Laura Sherman, his family also includes a signer of the Declaration of Independence, Roger Sherman of Connecticut. Sherm received his BA from Harvard where he led the crew team to win the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley, England in 1939. After graduation, he joined the US Navy and served as a naval aviator flying a PBY aircraft in defense of the Aleutians Islands while Bobbie remained in Salt Lake. After the war the pair moved to New York where he joined Henry Schroder Banking Corporation. They began their several moves to and from Europe while Sherman worked for Schroder's Bank and later Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith. When Sherm was assigned abroad, Mrs. Gray moved the entire family, first to Switzerland, then France, then on to London before returning finally to the U.S. where she became a founding member of the Junior League of Long Island. The frequent moves involved the conversion of some 15 residences into gracious homes for her family and provided her with many spectacular recipes which she cooked with aplomb. Mrs. Gray is predeceased by her first daughter, Pamela Carroll Gray, of Newport Beach, CA, the late wife of Lowell Martindale. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, Sherman; her second daughter, Elizabeth Gray Lilleston and husband Richard D. Lilleston of Navesink, NJ; and her son, Prentiss Sherman Gray and wife Leslie G. Steinberg of Morristown, NJ; six grandchildren and their spouses: Jessica Carroll Chu, Pamela Sherman Lilleston and James Noe; Amanda January Lilleston and Justin Dimmel; Matthew Putnam Gray, Zachary Sherman Gray, and Nathaniel Prentiss Gray. And, last but not least, the newest joy in her life, a great-grandson, Kai Sherman Noe. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Stanford University. 1/3

BROWN--Stephen B.,on December 27, adored "Captain" to his beloved grandchildren Zach, Jake, Ryan, Ike, and Sophie, the center of his life; his daughters Ali (Alan) Kotin and Jen (Neal) Simon; and devoted wife of 51 years, Linda Sirota. Brother of Harvey Brown. Born in Brooklyn, Steve graduated from Columbia University, where he played basketball, and New York University Law School. For many years, he was General Counsel at Champion International, and after his retirement served as Town Attorney for Southampton, NY. He held World Record for Grandparent Attendance at Baseball, Basketball, Lacrosse, Tennis and Golf Events Along the Eastern Seaboard, where his grandchildren participated during the last decade. Steve was a lifelong avid New Yorker, whose sense of humor was a source of joy to all lucky enough to know him. Funeral at 11:45 today, 12/29, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC. 1/3

MARINO--Anthony, passed away peacefully on December 22, 2014 at the age of 94 surrounded by his family at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Marino was born in New York City on June 18, 1920. He and Linda, his beloved wife of 63 years, raised their three children, Dee, Charles, and Candy on the Upper East Side of Manhattan before retiring to Palm Beach, Florida. He delighted in spending time with his seven grandchildren. Mr. Marino served in the Army of the United States Engineer Combat Battalion from 1943 to 1946. He was a general contractor in the New York City area from 1946 to 1995. He was also a founding member of The Columbus Citizens Foundation. Mr. Marino is survived by his wife, Linda; a brother, Vincent; daughters, Dee Marino, Candice (Brian) Steller, and son, Charles (Helen) Marino; and grandchildren, Lauren, Amanda, Caroline, Matthew, Elizabeth, Julia, and Jack. Wake, 7pm to 9pm, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, on January 2, 2015. Funeral Mass, 9:45am at Church of Saint Ignatius Loyola, on January 3, 2015. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Finding a Cure for Epilepsy and Seizures ("FACES") at www.nyufaces.org (Click "Make A Gift" on the top right of the page and indicate you are making a memorial donation in memory of Anthony Marino. Use the following address in the online form so the family will receive acknowledgments: InHonorOfAnthonyMarino@ gmail.com). 1/3

He is survived by his loving wife of almost 66 years, Barbara, his daughter Robin Williams, son Ken Taub, daughter-in-law Diane Taub, and grandchildren Brian, Rachel, and Daniel Williams. KASS--Gerald M. JBI International, Inc. (established in 1931 as The Jewish Braille Institute) deeply mourns the passing of its former Executive V.P. and Honorary Board Member, Gerald M. Kass. Mr. Kass served as Executive Vice President from 1979--2000. Both the Board and the staff, many of whom worked beside him for years, will miss his devotion to the organization, which has never flagged, even through a long illness. He was instrumental in broadening JBI's mission to embrace the visually impaired Jews of Russia and Eastern Europe and in advocating for the mainstreaming of blind children in education at home and abroad. He also oversaw the creation of the JBI Low Vision Clinic at what was then The Ichilov Hospital in Tel Aviv. We will miss Jerry so very much. At this moment, our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his husband Frank, his children, Michael and Jonathan, and his grandchildren. May his memory serve as a blessing. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Barbara B. Friedman, Honorary Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO 1/3

STONE--Elhanan C. "Elky", 85, died December 27 of heart failure near his Longboat Key, FL home. He was known in the advertising and entertainment fields as a skilled lawyer, spending 25 years at Ted Bates Worldwide, where he served as executive vice president and general counsel. He led committees of the American Association of Advertising Agencies (4As), negotiating several national contracts with the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA). After Ted Bates was acquired, he was of counsel to Hall Dickler Kent Friedman & Wood and Reed Smith LLP, examining diverse topics such as electronic/online rights contracts for advertising performers. He enjoyed skiing with his sons, fishing, sports, a good cigar and traveling the world. An ardent Red Sox fan and proud Boston native, he reveled in the teams World Series championships. He was a dedicated alumnus of Roxbury Latin School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Education was another lifelong interest. He was elected president of the Board of Education in Stamford, CT in the 1970s. He served two years in the U.S. Army Judge Advocate General's office in Germany after graduating law school in 1955 and, later, in the U.S. Department of Justice antitrust division. Survivors include his beloved wife and debate partner, Mimi Stone; son Mark Stone and his wife, Margery, and granddaughters Margaret and Miranda; son Peter "Hopper" Stone and his wife, Shulamis Hirsch; and stepson David Wallace, and his wife, Lauren Goldberg. Other survivors include his brother, Harris Stone, sister, Syril Solomon, and their families. Funeral services are 1pm on Tuesday, December 30 in Newton, MA. 1/3
