EDWARDS--Dr. James B. The Board of Directors and staff of the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the passing of longtime director, Dr. James B. Edwards. Governor Edwards was a devoted director serving the foundation for 35 years. He was a man of protean talents, unsparing of self, wise in counsel, and the possessor -above all -of the gift of friendship. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Anne and their entire family. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Chairman; Josiah Bunting III, President The Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation 1/3

LANDA--Esther. National Council of Jewish Women, Inc. mourns the passing of its past President ('75-'79) Esther Landa, nee Rosenblatt, on December 28 in Palm Springs at the age of 102. An indefatigable advocate for civil rights, women's rights, and public education, Esther also cofounded Utah's Head Start program. She is survived by her daughter Terry Vismantas, also a former national NCJW Board member. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced in Salt Lake City, UT. 1/3

KENT--Robert W.,Esq., 79, of Chester NJ, formerly of Middletown, OH, attorney at Armco Steel Corp. Survivors include his wife, the former Valerie Lyle (DeVeuve); his children Robert W. Kent Jr., William M. Kent, Richard M. Kent, and Deborah Jeffries, his step-children; Keith A. Lyle, Dr. Brian Lyle, and Heather Webster, his grandchildren Alex, Joseph, Daniel and Maria, Sarah, Matthew, Lauren and Ian Kent, Katie Jeffries; his step-grandchildren Evan and Dana Webster, Carson, Delia, Gavin and Chase Lyle. He was predeceased by his first wife Sally Anne Macnair. Services handled by Bailey Funeral Home, Peapack, NJ. www.baileyfuneral.com Memorial Service Saturday, January 3, 2015 11am at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, 182 Main Street, Gladstone, NJ. 1/3

TELL--Jeanne, of Princeton Junction, NJ (formerly of Teaneck, NJ) on December 29, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Norman Tell, devoted mother of Constance Tell (Jeffrey Nathanson), Peter and Richard Tell, cherished grandmother of David, Shoshana and Anya, dear mother-in-law of Meah Tell. Services Friday 10am at Congregation Beth Chaim, 329 Village Rd, Princeton Junction. Burial at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA. For information: Orlands Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609.883.1400 1/3

FRANK--Claude. December 24, 1925 -December 27, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Lilian Kallir, adored father of Pamela. The most inspiring friend, mentor, musician and human being. May his joyous spirit live on in all who had the privilege of knowing him. 1/3

CARPENTER--Suzanne "Barbara" Hayward, of Delray Beach, FL, formally Greenwich, CT passed on December 28, 2014. Born in New Orleans, LA, Barbara was a long time member of the Rye Twigg and Greenwich Hospital auxiliary. Survived by her children Hilary Carpenter Lynch, of Village of Golf, FL; Patricia Lathem Carey of Darien, CT; Edward Brewster Prindle, of Seattle, WA; Timothy Knowlton Carpenter of Darien, CT and Francis Newton Carpenter, III of South Barrington, IL and many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral will be held on January 4, 2015, 2pm at St. Paul's Church, Delray Beach, FL. Funeral/interment January 7, 2015, 2pm at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home (www.lorneandsons.com), Delray Beach, FL in charge of services. 1/3

KASS--Gerald M.,passed away on December 27 adored by his two sons, Michael (Dara) and Jonathan (Jillian), and his husband and life partner of 24 years, Frank Elbling. Proud grandfather of Charlotte, Sawyer, Hannah, Charlie and Sammy. Prior husband of Jodi Kass-Tracten. Family is grateful to Ria Smith for her care. Services to be held at Central Synagogue this Tuesday at 11am. For many years, Gerald was Executive Vice President of JBI International and, in retirement, he was an active contributor to the New School IRP Program. Gifts to these organizations in his memory would be appreciated.

GALLANT--Claire B. Social worker and social activist, Democrat and Unitarian. Peacefully at home December 25. Widow of Edward Gallant of Stony Creek, CT. Friend and mentor to many. Survived by son Brad, his wife Joanna Waley-Cohen, grandchildren Kit and Isabel; daughter Anne and grandson Ricky Song. A memorial service will be announced.

BERMAN--Peggy. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Peggy Berman. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to her sons Chris and Andy, daughters-in-law both named Katherine, grandchildren Meredith, Doug, Sara, and Riley, and the entire family. Fredric Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary 1/3

CARR--Peter F.,Jr., beloved son, devoted and loyal father, loving brother and treasured friend, died on December 26, 2014 of a suspected heart attack. He was 69. Peter was born October 20, 1945 to Peter F. Carr, Sr. and Helen B. Carr (nee Trainer) in Pawtucket, RI. He attended St. Pius X Prep Seminary, Seminary of the Immaculate Conception and Fordham University. Peter retired from his position as an institutional sales trader at Stephens Inc. in Little Rock, AR, where he spent the majority of his professional career. Peter, known to many friends as "Pete," was an avid and voracious reader. He loved horses and was lifelong devotee of horse racing, an interest he shared with many close friends. Peter is survived by his son Kevin, mother Helen of Southampton, NY, sister Karen and her wife Yvette Christofilis of New York, sister Sharon of Southampton, NY and many dear friends and relatives. Peter was predeceased by his father Peter, Sr. in 1985. Peter, like his father, was cherished by all who knew him. There will be a Funeral Mass at The Catholic Church of St. John The Baptist in Hot Springs, AR, on December 31, 2014 at 10am. A graveside memorial service in Coventry, RI. will be announced at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to American Diabetes Association,www.diabetes.org; American Heart Association, www.heart.org; or Group For The East End, www.groupfortheeastend.org For Peter, a small act of kindness would be the gift most appreciated. 1/3

KEATING--Dr. James Peter, died December 25, 2014 in Cary, NC. He was an influential physician at St. Louis Children's Hospital and professor at Washington University School of Medicine. A brilliant doctor as well as a demanding and thoughtful teacher, Dr. Keating had a profound influence on hundreds of medical students, patients, and their families. Born January 19, 1938 in Braddock, PA, he is survived by his loving wife Susan, daughter Amy Keating Foote (Chris), son Thomas Keating, sister Mary Sommerfeld (Wayne), brother Larry Keating (Peggy), brother Jerry Keating (Mary), and many beloved nieces and nephews. Memorial service arrangements are incomplete at this time. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be directed to: Memorial to James P. Keating, Children's Hospital of St. Louis, PO Box 955423 St. Louis, MO 63195-5423. 314-286-0988. 1/3

BERRIE--Dawn Athena, passed away at her mother's home in New Jersey after a long illness. Born November 29, 1955, Sea Cliff, NY. After college she spent most of her time in New York City working for music companies Acclaim Entertainment, Take Two Interactive and Uproar as Director of Investor Relations. Her biggest joy was communicating with the many people that crossed her path. She was a beautiful and wonderfully spirited person who enjoyed helping others. She was preceded in death by her father, Donald Berrie. 1/3

FRANK--Claude, a truly rare man, one of a kind spirit and the gentlest of souls. Much beloved by all who knew you and forever admired by the legions with whom you shared your unique artistry and deep humanity. It will always be the greatest honor and privilege to have been part of your family these last 15 years. We will walk together again, Sweet Prince of Light, to laugh and to play. Until then, Resquiat in Pace. A.S. 1/3

CORRIGAN--Eileen "Goldie" (McGoldrick) Born 4/43/d, passed 12/12/14. Survived by husband, Joe, daughters, Caithlin Corrigan Fitzsimons and Mairead Beaumont, grandchildren Ella and Liam, and sister Kathy. Goldie lived in NYC and Oceanside, CA. A mass will be held at Our Lady of Sorrows Church White Plains, NY 1/9/15 11:30 am. A celebration of life to follow
GREENE--Andrew B.,M.D. Nov. 19, 1980 --Dec. 31, 2008. Six years gone. "Grief teaches the steadiest minds to waver." --Dad 1/3

GITTELSON--Fern Rotkowitz, age 69 of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of New York on December 19th. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Roger Gittelson, treasured daughter of the late Pete and Sadie Rotkowitz, sister of Norman and Stewart, proud, adored, and loving grandmother to Daniel, Carolyn and Michael, loving step-mother to Jane and Ken, and Meredith. Loving aunt, cousin; loyal, devoted, and treasured friend to many. A lifelong accomplished teacher for over 40 years at Lakeside and Chatterton Schools in Merrick, LI. Her passion, creativity, and active involvement in numerous organizations impacted many. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Contributions can be made to JAFCO in "Memory of Fern Gittelson" www.jafco.org. Services were held Tuesday, December 22.

PHILLIPS--Betty. Passed away peacefully with gratitude for a life well lived on January 11, 2015. She had a 71 year love affair and marriage to Morris Frank Phillips. Betty was a talented teacher, successful businesswoman and advocate for peace and social justice. She was a beloved mother, grandmother, mother-in-law, aunt and friend to many. Contributions can be made to The Women's Therapy Centre Institute, or The Long Island Alliance for Peaceful Alternatives.

APPLETON--Jean. The Board of Directors of the American Society of Jewelry Historians mourns the loss of its Founding Chairman Emeritus and first President Jean Appleton. Jean was always a dynamic force, promoting education and providing valuable insight and inspiration up to her last days. She will be sorely missed. 1/3

EINSIDLER--Mimi Mandelbaum. Passed away on January 24, 2015 in Boca Raton, FL. She was predeceased by her loving husband of 65 years, Fred. She was a loving mother and mother-in-law to son Jon (Karen) Einsidler and daughter Amy (Keith) Lewis and adored her grandchildren Bobby, Laura, Billy, Nina, Teddy and Scott. She was also a loving sister and sister- in-law to David (Rosemary) Mandelbaum. She was born in New York City on October 23, 1929 and grew up on the Upper Westside of New York. She attended the Fashion Institute of Technology. She left college to marry Fred and moved with him to Ann Arbor where he received his master's degree. She moved back to New York and was pregnant with Jon when Fred deployed in the Army to Korea during that war. Mimi was an avid reader of both The New York Times daily and books of all kinds. She possessed a keen mind and was a marvelous conversationalist across a broad range of topics from international and national events to pop culture, movies, novels, and television. Her contemporary attitude made her a sought out person for many of Jon and Amy's friends. She had a zest for life and a strong imagination. As a den mother, her most memorable cub scout trip was taking the troop to Belmont race track for a tour of the grounds and the stables. Mimi was a lady who always knew the "right" thing to do, could look elegant when dressed for the occasion but felt most comfortable in jeans and sneakers which she could wear effortlessly. When her grandchildren asked what Grandma Mimi looked like when she was younger, we would just point out the woman holding the torch at the beginning of a Columbia Pictures movie and say that was their grandmother when she was young. After Amy was born, the family moved to Long Island. In retrospect, this was an obvious move since the beach suited her perfectly. Years later, there were not many other women who could wear a bikini well into their 40s and look great like she did. She was at home at the beach chatting with friends or sitting alone and reading a book. The best days were ones she referred to as 7 o'clock beach days, when we were the last ones to leave. She also had this thing for lilacs. For Mimi, family was everything. She looked forward to holidays when the entire family would get together. As one could imagine, her "high holy day" was Mother's Day. As our family evolved, Mother's Day saw a different convergence as we moved the celebration to Rochester when Amy started her family and Mother's Day coincided with the Lilac Festival. Mimi was fond of saying that the success of a mother is shown in her children. She beamed with pride at what her children had become and the people her grandchildren were becoming. Mom will be sorely missed by her family and friends who all loved her as much as she loved them. The funeral will be held graveside for family at Westchester Hills Cemetery on February 1 at 10am. The family will sit shiva on February 1 from noon to 4pm at Jon Einsidler's house, 93 Downey Drive, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Heart Association. 1/3

GRUZEN--Jordan L.,FAIA. The Principals of IBI Group - Gruzen Samton are saddened to announce the death of Jordan Gruzen, FAIA on January 27th, 2015. Continuing the rich legacy of socially relevant and creative architectural design that began with his fathers firm Kelly & Gruzen in the 1930's, Jordan dedicated his professional career to the advancement of the art of architecture as a catalyst for better housing, public transit and infrastructure, educational institutions, facilities for the elderly and the quality of life for the citizens of New York City and elsewhere. His love of this City and his dedication to innovative architecture resonates in the quality and creativity of his built work that is his gift to New York and his legacy for all to experience. Jordan was a relentless advocate of design excellence, in constant pursuit of new opportunities, directions and solutions that would advance this profession. An active member of the architectural community, his unceasing energy and drive put him in the forefront of promoting this profession to a wide spectrum of clients, City and State organizations, students and other professionals. His influence on our firm and the city remains profound as we mourn his loss. 1/3

KREEK--Sherry R.,of Bronxville, NY, on January 28, 2015. Beloved wife of Robert M. Kreek. Loving mother of Carolyn (Mike) Cassetta and Katherine. Dear sister of Brooks Wright. Daughter of the late William and Gloria Rennert. Aunt of Geoff and Scott Robson and Christian Wright. Sherry was an intelligent, strong and spirited woman --a character not to be ignored. From beginning to end, she lived life on her terms. She was loved by her peers and respected by her daughters' friends. "Baby, this is as good as it gets." Her leadership at the SDSH Salon, which she managed, left a lasting impression on clients and coworkers alike. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, are between the hours of 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Tuesday, February 3, 2015 at 10:45am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: The Perlmutter Cancer Center Breast Cancer Research Program NYU Langone Medical Center c/o James Speyer, MD,106 East 34th St. New York, NY 10016. 1/3
BLOOMSTEIN--Morris J. 2/2/2011 -Forever loved. Ellen, Nina, Josh, Aliza and your grandchildren 1/3
VERBY--Stanley M. 11/12/17 -2/2/14 In memory of my beloved husband. We shared 72 years of a wonderful marriage, missing you every day. Love, Marjorie & Family 1/3

BREUER--Gert. With great sadness we mourn Gert's peaceful passing on January 30, 2015 at home with his beloved wife Liesel by his side. He leaves his sons, Stefan and Thomas, and six grandchildren, who will miss him greatly. Gert's long adventure took him from his birth in Hamburg, Germany in 1928 to the four corners of the globe, but he was no where happier than in Fair Harbor, NY (Fire Island) and Jose Ignacio del Faro, Uruguay where he spent the past 25 years enjoying two summers each year with his family and friends. 1/3

FENTON--Marilyn K.,passed away on January 22, 2015, at the age of 88, surrounded by her family. A graduate of Wellesley College, Lynn was a pioneer in women's health issues and spent much of her life dedicated to Planned Parenthood. She was a woman of grace and elegance, deeply engaged in the world around her until the time of her death. Lynn made you feel like the most important person in the room. She was enlightened and progressive, fiercely independent and resilient. But what most defined her was her extraordinary commitment to the love of her life and her family. Married for 60 years, Lynn and the late Dr. Arnold Fenton left a beautiful legacy of children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She was adored by her nine grandchildren for whom she was a model of strength, intelligence, beauty and resolve. With much love, her family raises a glass of vodka with a slice of orange, and an extra glass of ice. Donations may be made in her memory to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, New York. 1/3

FRIEDLANDER--Katherine B.,age 98 on January 27 of old age. Devoted and loving of the wife Kurt A. Friedlander of New York City and Westport, CT. Devoted and loving mother of Susan. A gracious hostess to many. Kay lead a active and social life and traveled around the world with her husband of 55 years. She was always interested in other people and gave to many charities and organizations, 100 Neediest Cases, Cancer Care, Silent Unity, PBS. Services private. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Jeanne S. (July 25,1927 -January 18, 2015). Jeanne (Tutti) passed away on January 18th after a long and wonderful life. The daughter of Milton and Clara Plough Shurman, she and her brother Courtney were raised in Memphis, TN. She attended the University of Wisconsin where she met Harold Friedman, whom she married in 1948. Jeanne moved to New York where she raised her children Gwen and Douglas. She moved to Manhattan in 1977. She attended theatre, films and loved City life. She was fortunate enough to travel through out the world. Over the years she forged many lifelong friendships which next to family were her most prized possessions. She moved to Los Angeles when Gwen and Don McGuire and Jill and Doug Friedman gave her three grandchildren, Brendan McGuire, Melissa Friedman and Michelle Friedman. She supported many charities including Vista Del Mar, Concern, The Triumph Foundation, St. Jude Hospital and others anonymously. She treasured all the people in her life and while she may have left us without expressing in words all the love she felt inside, those close to her could never doubt how strong those feelings were. Her legacy is of a life well lived. We are all better for having known and loved her and we will miss her. 1/3

McQUILLAN--John Q.,89, died Thursday, January 29, 2015 following a brief illness. He leaves his siblings, Margaret Mary McQuillan and Thomas A. McQuillan (Margaret A.); his nieces and nephews, Carl J. Pernicone, Peter J. Pernicone, Thomas H. McQuillan, Elizabeth A. McQuillan, Joanne M. Blankenship; his cousin, William H. McQuillan and many close friends. He was predeceased by his sister, Isabella M. Pernicone. Born and raised in the Bronx, New York, the son of John A. and Margaret L. (Higgins) McQuillan, John was a longtime resident of Crestwood, NY and Newtown, CT. Following his graduation from Regis High School in 1943, John enlisted in the United States Army, and served in the 280th Engineer Combat Battalion during WWII. He served in combat in the Ardennes, Rhineland and Central Europe Campaigns, most notably in the Battle of the Bulge before his Honorable Discharge in 1946. After serving with the U.S. Army, he attended Columbia University, graduating in 1950 with a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering. In 1959, he received his Juris Doctorate from Fordham Law School. Mr. McQuillan was a Partner at Kenyon & Kenyon practicing as a patent, trademark and copyright attorney for many years. Before practicing law he held engineering positions at Curtiss-Wright Corporation and Sperry Rand. He took much pride in his practice of intellectual property law and valued greatly the friends he made during his time in business. Throughout his life, John enjoyed travel, working on his vintage automobiles and spending time with family and friends at the family home in Newtown. Visitation will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home (Bronxville, NY) on Sunday, February 1st from 1-5pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held in the Church of the Annunciation, Crestwood, NY at 11am Monday. 1/3

MEYER--Henrietta Henrietta "Rita" Nichols Meyer, of Essex, MA died peacefully at home with family by her side on Wednesday, December 17, 2014. Rita was born on March 6, 1927 in New York City grew up there and in Cold Spring Harbor, New York. She graduated from Chapin School in 1944 and continued her studies at Smith and Radcliffe Colleges. Rita was an experienced sailor, birder, and loved the outdoors. She was married to Benjamin A. Barnes in 1945; divorced in 1962. In 1963 she married August R. Meyer, with whom she had many sailing and boating adventures including circumnavigating the eastern United States; he predeceased her in 2000. Rita was an ardent supporter of classical music and a generous philanthropist. She supported the Boston Symphony Orchestra for over 60 years. She became involved with Manomet Center for Conservation Sciences in 1981, and was named a Trustee Emeritus in 2005. Rita was actively involved in a number of other organizations, including Massachusetts Audubon Society, Massachusetts Horticultural Society, Museum of Fine Arts, The Pierce-Nichols House at Peabody Essex Museum, and The Trustees of Reservations. Rita was predeceased in 1991 by her youngest daughter, Hope Barnes. She is survived by her children Benjamin A. Barnes, Northampton, MA; Henrietta N. "Robin" Barnes, Jamaica Plain, MA; Phoebe Barnes, Southwest Harbor, ME; Mary B. Barnes, Sedgwick, ME; and Faith Barnes, Brunswick, ME; her step- children August R. Meyer, Jr., Beverly, MA; Natalie M. Bent; Nina M. Fletcher; and Peter B. Meyer, all of Essex MA; seventeen grandchildren; fourteen great-grandchildren and one great-great grandchild. A Memorial Service will be held at First Parish in Cambridge (1446 Massachusetts Ave. at Church St.) on Friday, February 6, 2015 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to ProjectSTEP, Inc., Symphony Hall, 301 Massachusetts Avenue, Boston, MA 02115 or online at: www.projectstep.org. 1

PETRIE--Carroll. Wife of the late Milton Petrie, mother of Andrea and the late Anthony, grandmother to Theodora, Carolina and Antonia, aunt to Camille and Carroll, died peacefully at home in New York on January 22. Visitation at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, February 3rd, from 4pm to 6pm. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer on February 4th, 10am. In lieu of flowers, a prayer in her memory for someone in need would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

RABEN--Joseph, Ph.D.,90, passed away peacefully on January 18, 2015. He was Professor Emeritus of Queens College, City University of New York and a member of the English Department from 1954 to 1984. Professor Raben's journal "Computers and the Humanities," founded 1966, catapulted the nascent field of digital humanities into academic awareness. At the time of his death, Professor Raben was completing a book, "Shelley and Milton in the Digital Age." He is survived by his wife Estelle "Frankie" Raben and a multitude of adoring children, step- children and grandchildren. 1/3

TREDANARI--Chiarina nee Mascieri, passed away at home, January 21, 2015 in the arms of her family. Cherie, 96 years, born April 28, 1918 of Italian immigrant parents, in South Philadelphia, schooled at Moore College of Art on full scholarship, established a successful art studio on Walnut St. in the '40s. In 1948, she married the love of her life, Leonardo Tredanari, television director/producer, who predeceased her in 2003. Cher moved to New York City with Len, and kids in 1956 to W. 103rd st. A founding member of the 103rd st. Block association, founder of art collaborative "Ten Uptown" and founder of the Sculptors Alliance. She is survived by her daughter, Adriana; son, Gregory (Carol Anne), grandchildren, Marco (Amy), Nicola, Rebecca; great-grandchildren, Giulia, Leonardo; brother Lee (Anita), many nieces and nephews and wayward kids who found love at her home. Dear mother, passionate artist, true friend, loyal neighbor and consummate chef! A force to be reckoned with - now she shines in the firmament. Donations to her memory to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice and Palliative Care: vnsny.org or 212-609-1525. 1/3

VAN DUSEN--Georgia. Georgia Palade Van Dusen, passed away on January 19, 2015, at her Manhattan home. Mrs. Van Dusen was born in Bucharest, Romania, in 1943, to Irina and Dr. George Palade. Her family moved to New York City in 1946. She had a career in children's book publishing before becoming a pioneer of Upper West Side property rejuvenation with her husband, Derek Van Dusen. She was a dynamic mother to her daughters, Heather and Hilary. In 1963 she joined the Blue Hill Troupe, a charitable theatrical group, and served on its board and ran its costume workshop for decades. She was also an active member of the summer community in Sorrento, Maine. Mrs. Van Dusen loved hosting parties, and often opened her home to "orphan" family members, friends, and pets. A lover of music, animals, and world travel, she will be remembered for her grace, strength, generosity, and love of laughter. Mrs. Van Dusen is survived by her husband and daughters; her brother, Philip; as well as countless family and friends. Memorial plans will be announced. Donations in her name may be sent to the North Shore Animal League, the Metropolitan Opera, the Riverside Park Conservancy, and the Schoodic Institute. 1/3

ANTHOINE--Robert renowned tax and arts law expert and enthusiastic supporter of the arts, died on January 23, 2015 after a brief illness. His beloved wife, Margarita Maria Anthoine, and daughter, Alison Anthoine, were by his side. Born in Portland, Maine on June 5, 1921, he was the only child of Edward and Sara (Pinkham) Anthoine. After graduating from Duke University in 1942, he served for four years as a Lieutenant in the US Navy. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1949 and returned there to teach in 1952. In 1963, he joined Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts as the head of its tax department. He continued to teach as an adjunct at Columbia for another three decades, and as a visiting professor at law schools around the world through his seventies. His interest in literature and the visual and theatre arts was unbounded. He became close friends with many of the artists whose work he collected, and was instrumental in creating and sustaining many arts-related foundations. He served as the Chairman of the Aperture Foundation for more than 20 years. His support of the Royal Shakespeare Company by, among other things, creating the American Friends of the RSC, led to his appointment as an Honorary Governor for Life of the RSC. He was proud to be the founding Chairman of the Lucid Art Foundation, together with painter Gordon Onslow Ford and Fariba Bogzaran, to support artists who explore the concept of arts and consciousness. He is also survived by three other children--Robert Neal, Nelson and Nina Anthoine; six grandchildren; a stepdaughter, Mary Danielle Hamilton-Russo; and two step-grandchildren. Interment will be private. A memorial celebrating his life will be held in March in NYC on a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Aperture, 547 W. 27th St., NYC 10001. 1

LEFFLER--John. John Leffler, 57, of Newtown, PA, lost his life in a tragic accident while on vacation with his family in Puerto Rico on January, 3, 2015. John was the youngest son of Ray and Frances Leffler of Brooklyn, New York. John was born in Brooklyn and raised in Spotswood, New Jersey. He attended Ursinus College where he played basketball, and eventually transferred to Rutgers University. He then earned his MBA at Farleigh Dickinson University. John met the love of his life Emi when they were both 19. They would later marry and raise three beautiful children, Michele, Kelly, and Brian. Upon graduation, John went to work for Combustion Engineering, and in 1987 joined Touche Ross, which was the start of a long and very prosperous consulting career. Most recently, John was the Managing Partner of IBM Global Business Services SAP practice and was well known and respected as a prominent leader in the consulting industry. John was a long time partner at IBM, PwC, and Price Waterhouse where he built and grew the SAP business to one of the largest and most successful, award winning consulting practices globally. During his tenure at IBM, John led some of their largest and most complex SAP business transformation programs and pioneered many revolutionary business design and implementation strategies. His innovative spirit and tremendous success led him to be widely respected and sought after as a thought leader, regularly speaking at SAP events and advising his clients and SAP alike on strategy, innovation and market trends. Over the course of his decades long career, John developed a devoted following of mentees, friends, and colleagues. Eminently personable, he was a born leader who inspired trust and confidence in all those around him and his relentless dedication to IBM and its clients' success allowed him to become a friend and trusted advisor to scores of IBMers and clients alike. Outside of work John enjoyed playing basketball and was an avid sports enthusiast. He was an animal and nature lover, and wine connoisseur. He also supported many non- profit organizations and charities including sitting on the board of NPower PA, among other boards and charitable interests. But his pride and joy was his family, his beloved wife Emi, twin daughters Michele and Kelly, and son Brian. Despite his extremely demanding work schedule, John always made his family his number one priority. He was a devoted husband and father, and was an instrumental force in the lives of his children. Whether it be coaching their basketball teams, participating in their various school events, or simply just being a dad, he was a role model and inspiration to his children. John's legacy is not only his family and the successful business that he built but also his unwavering loyalty to others. There was no better friend than John. He was loved, admired and respected by many who were blessed to have known him and be part of his extended family. John's mark on all who had the good fortune of knowing him will be felt for many years. John was laid to rest on Monday January 12, 2015 at Holy Cross Cemetery in East Brunswick, New Jersey, surrounded by family and friends. John's family has established the John J. Leffler Memorial Fund for Veterans in John's honor. Donations can be sent using the following link: https:// donatenow.networkforgood. org/buckscountyfoundation 1/3

ROSENSTEIN--Claire, age 90, January 23. Claire worked with composer Aaron Copland. Researched and wrote for Tex and Jinx Show, Steve Allen's original Tonight Show, NBC's Project XX, and other documentary programs. Most recently an archivist for NYC. She will be missed by nieces and nephews. 1/3

SLOTNICK--Herbert Norman, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Syracuse, New York, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, January 13, 2015. Mr. Slotnick was born on October 20, 1925, graduated from Haverford College, and was a veteran of World War II. In the early 1960's Mr. Slotnick bought the franchise rights for the Carrols restaurant brand, a fast food hamburger chain. He founded and was CEO of Carrols Corporation, which at its peak maintained 167 Carrols restaurants. Mr. Slotnick transitioned Carrols to a franchisee of Burger King, and for a time Carrols was listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Under his helm, Carrols employed 6,000 people, had over 4,000 stockholders, and engaged in a number of businesses, including motion picture production, movie theatres, and fast food restaurants. Carrols was also involved in real estate and nation-wide food and material distribution. Carrols had a construction subsidiary which built over 200 buildings consisting mostly of restaurants and multi-auditorium motion picture theatres. Today Carrols trades on the NASDAQ as the world's largest Burger King franchisee with over 650 units. Mr. Slotnick was predeceased by his wife, Joan Slotnick. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, David Slotnick and Carol Slotnick, his granddaughter, Emilia Slotnick, and his longtime companion, Carole Levinson Gerstein of Miami Beach. Services were conducted January 16, 2015 at the Birnbaum Funeral Chapel in Syracuse. Donations may be sent to Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, 407 East 70 Street, New York, NY 10021. 1/3
SIEGEL--Jeffrey. February 1, 1955. Happy 60th Birthday, Dear Boy. Love, From Everybody 1/3

BROWN--Walter H. A Partner at Brown Brothers Harriman since 1968, Walter Brown passed away peacefully on January 26 at the age of 91. A resident of both Skillman, New Jersey and Vero Beach, Florida (formerly of Madison, NJ and Bay Head, NJ), Walter was the husband of the late Catherine (Bunny) Brown to whom he was married for more than 60 years. He is survived by his four children, Walter H. Brown, Jr., Catherine G. Erickson, Rebecca K. Holmes and Harold G. Brown, as well as 12 grandchildren, 6 great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Born in Germantown, Pennsylvania to Harold and Martha Brown, Walter moved with his parents and two brothers to Westfield, New Jersey when he was a young boy. He would attend Westfield High School until his junior year when he and his twin brother, Charlie, would enroll at The Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut. There, Walter played football and ran track, breaking a 26-year school record for the quarter mile. Walter went on to attend Yale University, where he played football for the Bulldogs and defeated his twin brother in Yale's 26-7 victory over the Princeton Tigers in 1943. Walter interrupted his college education to serve as a Lieutenant JG in the U.S. Navy Reserve during World War II. He returned to Yale and graduated as a member of the storied class of 1945W. Throughout his life, Walter remained actively involved with his alma mater, including service as vice chair of Yale University's alumni board. In 2002, he was awarded the Yale Medal, the highest award presented by the Association of Yale Alumni, for his decades of dedicated service. Walter spent his entire career in international banking. He joined the New York Trust Company in 1947 and was named vice president supervising the bank's European operations in 1957. He joined Brown Brothers Harriman in 1959 and was named a General Partner of the Firm in 1968. During his many years at BBH, Walter was instrumental in developing the bank's international banking business. For nearly four decades he represented Brown Brothers throughout the world in travels to Latin America, the Middle East, and Europe. In recognition of Walter's efforts in Sweden and throughout Scandinavia, King Carl XVI Gustav of Sweden, with the recommendation of the Swedish American Chamber of Commerce, bestowed on Walter The Royal Order of the North Star in 1987. Though retired from Brown Brothers for many years, he remained a limited partner until 2015 and carefully followed BBH's activities and was proud of its many successes. Walter was a passionate supporter of educational causes. In addition to his numerous contributions to Yale, he was a Trustee at The Hotchkiss School, Chairman of the Board of Sweet Briar College, his wife's alma mater, from 1987-1995. He was also an honorary member of the Sweet Briar class of '49 and the Princeton class of '46. Mr. Brown has held positions as Vice Chairman of the Swedish-American Chamber of Commerce, Trustee of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, Director of Westvaco Corporation, and was a member of the Colombian American Chamber of Commerce, New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Bankers Association for Foreign Trade. More recently he was a Director of the Norwegian American Chamber of Commerce and the Boyce Thompson Southwestern Arboretum. Walter Brown radiated charm and was brimming with anecdotes with the instincts of a born raconteur. His ready sense of humor and warmth were sure to captivate any audience. In recognition of Walter's dedication to education, in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions are encouraged to the educational cause of your choice. A celebration of his life is planned for the future. 1/3

ELKAN--Gretel (May). May 2, 1912 to January 19, 2015. Passed away peacefully at home at age 102. Born in Worms, Germany, she came to the United States in 1933 and lived in West Newton, Massachusetts for 53 years. Devoted and loving mother of Judy (Al) Atkins of Larchmont, New York. Proud and adoring grandmother of Mike and Dan. Beloved aunt, cousin, sister-in-law and friend to many around the world. Preceded in death in 1990 by her loving husband of 43 years, Jurgen Elkan. She inspired us all with her boundless energy, warmth, resilience and humor. A funeral service was held in Hawthorne, New York on January 22, 2015. Donations in her memory may be made to American Jewish World Service: www.ajws.org. 1/3
IRELAND--James Duane. Gone too soon. You will always hold a place in my heart. Rita Rack 1/3

KINIGSTEIN--Carol, 89, on January 12. Carol led an intellectually full and physically active life. She was a consummate liberal, a life-long learner following current events and playing bridge to the end. She loved tennis, elder hostels, travel and her family. Carol will be greatly missed by her daughters Anne, June, and Joy Kinigstein, her sons-in-law and her five grandchildren. 1/3

ROCKEFELLER--Harriot. Harriot "Sue" Rockefeller, died peacefully early Christmas morning surrounded by her children and grandchildren. A former resident of Riverside and Greenwich, Connecticut, for the last four years, she had been living in Newton, Massachusetts. Diagnosed with Parkinson's disease over a decade earlier, Mrs. Rockefeller recently suffered a stroke. Sue was born in New York City to Otto Harry and Harriot Coffin Gruner, and she grew up on the south shore of Long Island in Hewlett, New York, where she loved to boat, fish and swim in the Great South Bay and at the Rockaway Hunt and Lawrence Beach Clubs. Sue graduated from the Westover School in Middlebury, Connecticut, and a week after his college graduation married her brother's Andover and Yale roommate, Hank Ross. Hank had been Navy ROTC at college, and Sue followed him on assignment during the Korean War to Coronado, California where their first child Ripley was born and later to Newport, Rhode Island, where Wendy Ross joined the family. Sue and Hank moved to Dallas, Texas for a short time, where Larry Ross arrived, and then to the Philadelphia and New York City suburbs, finally settling in Greenwich, Connecticut where her third daughter Kate was born, and where Sue resided for the next fifty years. Sue Ross was an incredibly warm and loving mother who epitomized all the very best things about a dedicated, doting mom, wife and homemaker in the suburban 1960's. Married to an advertising and pharmaceuticals executive, Sue was as much a part of Hank Ross' business and social success as he. When Hank succumbed to the excesses of the 1970's, Sue stood strong for herself and for her family. In 1979, she married Andy Rockefeller, and Sue began a new life chapter, moving from Riverside to Greenwich; Todds Point to Prouts Neck and from skating at Binney Park to skiing in Zermatt; different venues but with Sue unchanged in her values and fierce commitment to her family and her faith. Sues time with Andy brought each new found peace and contentment. Throughout her life, Sue dedicated herself to helping others, and for years was a Nurse's Aide at Greenwich Hospital, overseeing many blood drives at Christ Church. A long-standing member of Stanwich Congregational Church, Sue served as a Stephen Minister, counseling and helping those in need. Sue Rockefeller moved to Newton in 2010 next door to her youngest daughter Kate, and immersed herself into a wonderful, loving environment, embedded into the lives of her daughter, son-in-law Charlie and her Johnson grandsons. Sue is survived by her beloved brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. O.H. Gruner III of Pittsburgh, PA; Ripley Ross of West Hartford, CT; Wendy Carothers of Arlington, VA; Kate Johnson of Newton, MA and Larry Ross of Manchester Village, VT, as well as fifteen grandchildren and one great grandchild, with another on the way, due in May. She was pre-deceased by her courageous grandson, Samuel Robertson Johnson, whom she now holds in her loving arms forever. 1/3

MILLER--Seymour W.,J.D., December 18, 1914--January 25, 2015. Seymour or "Sy," as we was known to many of his colleagues and friends throughout his long life --will be remembered as a beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather; a successful attorney; a loyal friend; a generous and staunch supporter of the State of Israel; and a forceful and passionate human being. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Claire, as well as by family and friends who were privileged to have known his character, intelligence and humor. He served honorably as an infantryman in the U.S. Army during World War II, rising to the rank of Captain (and later to the rank of Major in the U.S. Army Reserves), having participated in the D-Day landings on the beaches of Normandy as well as the liberation of the Buchenwald concentration camp near Weimar, Germany. His distinguished legal career included serving as General Counsel of the Seafarers International Union before founding as co-Managing Partner the firm of Miller & Seeger, a law practice focusing on corporate commercial transactions and labor relations. During his career, he received numerous awards for professional achievement and charitable service. He was special and will be sorely missed. Donations in honor of Mr. Seymour W. Miller, Esq. may be made to: The United States Holocaust Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, DC 20024. 1/3

PETRIE--Mrs. Carroll, a major supporter of cultural, educational, and medical institutions, passed away peacefully in her Manhattan home on Thursday, January 22, at the age of 90. The personification of elegance, Carroll was also a force of nature who made a significant impact on the lives of many in New York City and across the country. Carroll was born in Greenville, South Carolina, to Helen Brown and William Carroll McDaniel. After attending Converse College she moved to New York City, where she worked as a model. She lived in Paris with her first husband, Alfonso Cabeza de Vaca y Leighton, Marques de Portago during the 1950s, until his death in 1957. She spent the rest of her days in New York, apart from a few years living abroad in Hong Kong and Europe. In 1978, Carroll married New York businessman and philanthropist Milton Petrie, and joined him in his tireless support of many of the city's important institutions. Among the ones closest to their heart were New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Museum of Modern Art, and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opened the Carroll and Milton Petrie European Sculpture Court in 1990. Carroll continued supporting these and other organizations after Milton's death in 1994. She had a lifelong love of animals, and through the ASPCA, established the Carroll Petrie Foundation Dog Rescue Project. She also devoted much of her energies to Converse College, whose nationally acclaimed music school is now known as The Carroll McDaniel Petrie School of Music. Another of her passions was the Parrish Art Museum, where she established the Carroll Petrie Foundation Wing. Mrs. Petrie also served on the boards of several medical and cultural institutions including New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, the Parrish Art Museum, The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art. Carroll was a member of the Board of the Central Park Conservancy and was The United Nations Associations National U.N. Day Chairperson for three years in the mid-1990s. The Museum of Modern Art recognized her as an Honorary Trustee in 1995, and named the fifth floor cafe in honor of her and Milton. Carroll received honors from many organizations including The Salvation Army, The American Red Cross, The American Cancer Society, Henry Street Settlement, and the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. She was honored in Israel in 1998 with the Israel 50th Anniversary Tribute Award. She held an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from New York Institute of Technology and an Honorary Doctorate of Arts from Long Island University. In 1987, the King of Spain bestowed Mrs. Petrie with the highest honor awarded to foreigners, the Medal of Honor of the Order of Isabel La Catolica. Mrs. Carroll Petrie is survived by her granddaughters Theodora Portago, Marquesa de Portago and Carolina Portago; and her nieces Camille Manning and Carroll Wilson. She was predeceased by her son Anthony Portago, Marques de Portago. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to ASPCA, Attn: Gift Processing Center, In Memory of Mrs. Carroll Petrie, 424 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128 or Converse College, Attn: Petrie School of Music, In Memory of Mrs. Carroll Petrie, 580 East Main Street, Spartanburg, SC 29302. Visitation will be held on Tuesday, February 3, 2015 from 4-6pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at Madison Avenue and 81st Street, and a funeral will be held for family and close friends on Wednesday, February 4, 2015 at 10am at The Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer at Lexington Avenue and 66th Street. 1/3
ROHR--Donald G.,94. Fought in WWII. History professor at Williams and Brown. Retired in Providence, RI. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Leon. 1921-2015, 93, passed away peacefully on January 29th, 2015, surrounded by his family. He is survived by his wife, Rita (nee Schwartz), whom he married in her home town of Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales over 65 years ago, and his daughters Susan (Michael Braun) of Manhattan and Jane (Daniel Hess) of Chappaqua, NY and his four grandchildren Jonathan and William Braun and Jesse and Emily Hess. Leon was born in Manhattan and raised in Brooklyn, NY by his seamstress mother as his father died when Leon was very young. He attended the prestigious Townsend Harris High School, Brooklyn College, Yale Law School and the London School of Economics. He met his wife during WWII when he was stationed in South Wales. Leon joined the law firm now known as Fried Frank Harris Shriver and Jacobson in 1949, became a partner in 1956, and served as Co-Chairman of the Firm for eight years. From 1953 to 1956, he was an Assistant US Attorney, Southern District of NY under J. Edward Lombard. From 1958-1959, Leon was an Assistant Deputy Attorney General of the United States and was involved in the effort to desegregate the schools in Little Rock. His commitment to public service while at the firm was exemplified by his role as the President of the Legal Aid Society of New York, Member of the Board of Directors Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Trustee and member of the Executive Committee of the Practicing Law Institute, Trustee of the William Nelson Cromwell Fund, Regent and President of the American College of Trial Lawyers and President for 11 years of the Supreme Court Historical Society. He is probably most well-known for his appointment as Special Prosecutor leading the investigation of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. Leon was the Recipient of the American Jewish Committee's Learned Hand Human Relations Award, the Federal Bar Council's Emory Buckner Medal for outstanding Public Service, UJA's Judge Joseph Proskauer Award "For Dedication to the Legal Profession and to his Community" and the Brandeis Distinguished Community Service Award, among numerous honors. He was appointed by the Chief Justice of the United States to membership in the Anglo-American Exchange and was the Special Master of the Appellate Division. He will be missed as a wonderful husband, father, grandfather and mentor to many young attorneys. Our special thanks to Beth, Cecelia, Glory, Nikka and Marie for all their extraordinary kindness and care. The funeral will be held at Riverside- Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 10021 on Friday, January 30th at 10 am. Shiva will be observed Saturday from 6:30pm-8pm, Sunday from 2pm-5pm and Monday through Wednesday from 5pm-8pm at his home. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. Donations may be made in his memory to the Supreme Court Historical Society or the Legal Aid Society of New York. 1/3

WOOTERS--J. Dukes, Jr. J. Dukes Wooters, Jr.,died peacefully after a short illness on January 21, 2015. He was 97. A long-time resident of New Canaan, CT, he was born in Cleveland, OH and raised in Easton, MD and Larchmont, NY. He was a graduate of The Taft School, Lehigh University and Harvard Business School. He served in the U.S. Army Quartermaster Corps during World War II and was involved with post-war reconstruction efforts. His long and active business career included positions as Director of Marketing at Reader's Digest, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Cotton Inc. and Managing Director at Galen Associates. While at Cotton Inc. he was the first to brand a commodity through aggressive television advertising and industry marketing and was responsible for the development of the now iconic Seal of Cotton. In tribute to his many contributions to the cotton industry, he was recently inducted into the American Textile Hall of Fame and the Cotton Research and Promotion Hall of Fame. When he died, he was President of Eye Surgery Fund, Inc. and was a member of the Advisory Board for the Department of Ophthalmology at Columbia University. He was a gracious man, a visionary marketer and a terrific storyteller. He is survived by his loving wife, Catherine Langdon Wooters, and five daughters by his late wife of 41 years, Mary Elizabeth "Betty" Kirby. They include Katherine (Rick) Sheppard of Bedford, NY; Joan Wooters- Reisin of New York, NY; Diane E. Wooters of Stamford, CT; Pamela (Wing) Chin of New Canaan, CT; and Jennifer (Jeremy) Goodman of New Canaan, CT. Also surviving him are seven grandchildren and five step-children. His second wife, Brigitte Schwarzenbach, and his brother, Charles Wooters, predeceased him. Donations in his memory may be made to: Eye Surgery Fund, Inc., P.O. Box 730, Bedford, NY 10506. 1/3

MORRISON--Richard H. Was born In Boston in 1948 and died of natural causes in Upstate New York on January 16, 2015. Richard was an accomplished artist working in photography, painting, filmmaking, installation and performance. His work was included in exhibitions at 303 Gallery in 1988 and at The Vrej Baghoomian Gallery in 1991. He performed as Einstein in the original version of the Robert Wilson/Phillip Glass opera "Einstein on the Beach" in Europe at The D'Avignon Theatre Festival and in America at The Metropolitan Opera in 1976. "Bust," a film he made with the artist David Wojnarowicz was included in the Berlin Film Festival in 1993. He worked as a social worker in the foster care system in West Palm Beach, FL in the 1980s and as a counselor at the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center in the Bronx, NY. He lived in Ithaca, New York City and Truro, MA. He is survived by his siblings Jim, Marianne and Patricia Morrison, and his niece and nephew, Heather and Nicholas Hughes. Loving partner, brother, uncle and friend, he will be greatly missed by those who loved him. Ashes of he and his long time partner, Larry Mitchell, will be spread in Cape Cod this summer. 1/3

GRUZEN--Jordan L. Architect Jordan L. Gruzen died peacefully on Tuesday at age 80 surrounded by his family. Gruzen, whose career spanned six decades, played a significant role in enriching the urban landscape of 20th century metropolitan New York where his firm, Gruzen Samton, was based. Gruzen, a Fellow of the AIA, and the firm received five national AIA design awards and numerous city and state AIA awards. Jordan was born in Jersey City on April 5, 1934. His father Barnett Sumner Gruzen founded the architectural firm Kelly & Gruzen in 1936, which Jordan carried on with partners and later became Gruzen Samton. Jordan's mother, Ethel (Brof) Gruzen, was a professional opera singer with the Metropolitan Opera House. Jordan received his B.Arch at MIT and M.Arch at the University of Pennsylvania and was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship to Italy. Jordan was a resident of Battery Park City and Amagansett, Long Island, where he lived in the apartment buildings and houses that he designed. He was active in his communities, including sailing with the Manhattan Yacht Club on New York Harbor, playing tennis at Devon Yacht Club, and helping to found The Interfaith Community and Lower Manhattan's Knickerbocker Chamber Orchestra. He participated heavily in New York New Visions during the reshaping of Lower Manhattan after 9/11. Jordan is survived by his wife Lee, son Alex and wife Karen, daughters Rachel and Georgia, brother Max, Alex's mother Joan, and grandchildren Elsa, Ava, Sonja and Bear. Friends and family will remember Jordan as a man of warmth, grace and optimism, who embraced life fully. Donations in his memory can be made to the Knickerbocker Chamber Orchestra. 1/3

SCHUPF--Cecilia Elkon, known as Lily almost all her life, died peacefully in her apartment, aged 102, on January 29, 2015. Lily was born on September 14, 1912 in Antwerp Belgium, the fifth child of Bernard and Sarah Elkon. After a normal well-to-do upbringing for that time and place, Lily entered into an unusual life when she met Willem Schupf in the spring of 1934. They married on October 9th of that year and embarked on a voyage to Singapore that very evening. Singapore was the center of an international diamond enterprise that Willem had built from 1918 on. Lily returned to Antwerp to give birth to sons Axel and Paul. In 1938 Willem had the rest of the Schupf family move to New York City, whereas his family returned to Singapore, leaving for the U.S. in 1941. Daughter Tina was born in 1944. His family lived in New Rochelle until 1968 and then in the city. Once her children were grown, Lily accompanied Willem on his constant travels to London, Antwerp, the Far East, Israel, South Africa and other excursions. They saw the world together. Family was a constant in Lily's life including grandchildren Schupf (Liz Lonsdale, Johanna, and Katherine Kim) and Nordlander (Chloe). The number grew to include Axel's wife Sara and step-children Debbie, Amy, Michael and Douglas. Great-grandchildren come next, Willem, Kira and Dede Lonsdale and Tasha, Elena and Jared Kim. Lily was a devoted parent and grandparent all her life. Willem died in 1992 at age 93. Lily remained in their apartment and became even more family oriented. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:15am on Sunday, 1 February. Shiva will be held from 5:00pm to 8:00am at 980 Fifth Avenue, Apartment 4A on Sunday and Monday (1 and 2 February). Donations may be made to The Jewish Museum. 1/3

A rare treasure, she will live in our hearts always. 1/3

SNOW--Sarah O'Bryan. After a three-year battle with breast cancer, Sarah, a woman of boundless youthful, energy, fierce intelligence and enormous love for family, died peacefully in her home, January 24, 2015. To celebrate her life, a service will be held in June at Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ. Born in Boston and raised in suburban Massachusetts, she graduated from Smith College in 1963. Following graduation, she held various portfolio and research jobs with Wall Street firms, was active in the Young Women's Financial Association and was successful in real estate as a residential sales broker for Whitbread, Nolan in New York City. In 1973, she and her beloved husband Don moved to Short Hills to raise their family. There she was active in school art appreciation and library programs. Sarah also was a member of the Junior League and the Cora Hartshorn Arboretum Board; an active church member, Sarah anchored its participation in The Interfaith Food Pantry. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, three sons (Andrew, Wellesley Hills, MA; Christopher, Brooklyn Heights, NY; and Nicholas, Venice, CA) and four grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to Smith College (The Smith Fund, P.O. Box 34002, Boston, MA 02241) or The Interfaith Food Pantry of the Oranges (P.O. Box 341 Short Hills NJ 07078). 1/3

WICKHAM--Michael W.,Palm Coast, Florida, passed away peacefully on January 20, 2015 at his home. He was born September 9, 1946 in Elmira, New York to Ernestine (Rodabaugh) and the late Harold G. Wickham. Growing up he was an Eagle Scout and attended the University of Delaware where he played football for the Fighting Blue Hens. Professionally, Mr. Wickham was a leader in the transportation and logistics industry during his 35 year career beginning with Roadway Express. He retired as Chairman of the Board of Roadway Corporation in December 2003, where he was Chief Executive Officer from 1997 to 1999 and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer from 1999 until his retirement in 2003. He founded and was Chairman of both the Board of Motor Freight Carriers and the American Transportation Research Institute. He also served on the Board of Akron Childrens Hospital and Foundation. Upon retiring from Roadway, he served as a director on the boards of C.H. Robinson Worldwide, Republic Services, Inc. and as Chairman for Douglas Dynamics, Inc. Mr. Wickham loved horseracing so he founded Pauleeanna Thoroughbreds, Inc., a small breeding farm in Micanopy, Florida. He enjoyed fishing, traveling with friends, and playing golf. Most of all he loved his family. He is survived by his wife of forty-four years Barbara, his mother Ernestine, and brother Robert Wickham (Ronda). He leaves behind three children, Devon W. Strickland (Stuart), Michael P. Wickham, and Lindsay A. Wickham. He is survived by one grandson Bryce W. Strickland. Services are entrusted to Lohman Funeral home of Palm Coast, Florida. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation or the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation. Condolences may be shared with the family at www.lohmanfuneralhomes.com. 1/3

Madi was the wife of the late Stanley and mother of Robert (Eileen), Ted (Carolyn) and Ilene (Giuseppe) and grandmother of Rebecca, Caitlyn, Anna Luisa, Maggie and Theo. HU--Hung-shu, international artist and professor emeritus, designer and painter, personal architect and philosopher, passed away January 22 in Iowa City, IA. Born in Shanghai, China in 1935, he became Head of Design of The School of Art and Art History at the University of Iowa in 1968, where he taught until he retired in 2003. Engaged as an artist every day of his life, Hu Hung-shu painted striking black and white oil abstract landscapes, garnering international attention and exhibits for his personal technique. His sculptural works span the globe, including "D Forever" (Iowa City, IA), "New Leaves" (Ogden, UT), "Diminished Seven in Space" (Port Orchard, WA), "Solar Kaleidoscope" (Cedar Falls, IA), "Falling Light" (Fort Lauderdale, FL), and "Tomorrow" (Taipei, Taiwan). His awards include Progressive Architecture's First International Conceptual Furniture Competition and the Tokyo International Lighting Competition. His book, "Basic Design: The Cultivation of Wisdom, Reason, and Sensibility, was published" in 2008. His passion for art and design invigorated the classroom. His words resonated with his students, many of whom are active artists and scholars. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Judy; son, Ching-chu (Jim); daughters, Ching-an and Ching-yuan; two grandchildren; five siblings and many nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his father, scholar Hu Sung- ping, and mother, Hseuh Gei- jen. A memorial is planned for April 26 in Iowa City. His artwork may be viewed at: www.huhungshu.com. 1/3

KERZNER--Joseph. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Joseph Kerzner, and extends sincere sympathy to his companion Lisa Koeper, children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President; Warren J. Spector, Secretary 1/3

KERZNER--Joseph The Yeshiva University family and the Board of Overseers of the Sy Syms School of Business, as well as the affiliated Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University, are profoundly bereaved by the passing of our partner and dynamic leader who, as a YU Benefactor and as Vice Chair of the Sy Syms School of Business Board of Overseers, established the Joseph Kerzner Chair in Accounting and was a major contributor to the new MBA Program at the Sy Syms School. A devoted son, he established the Samuel Kerzner Memorial Scholarship and the Sarah Rivka Kerzner Memorial Scholarship in our undergraduate schools for men and women, respectively. He was Yeshiva University's partner in helping YU establish dinners and convocations in Toronto where, on December 18, 1986, he received an honorary doctorate in recognition of his selfless devotion to our institution and generous scholarship support under the auspices of the Bora Laskin Scholarship Fund established by Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University for deserving and needy Canadian students. He was honored again with the Pioneer Award at our most recent convocation. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved children: Jeff Kerzner and Cheryl and Ron Pancer, dear brother and brother-in-law of Gertie and the late Walter Gangel, z'l, Anne Zaretsky, Lou and Helen Kerzner, Max and Dolly Kerzner, Albert and Anita Kerzner, Miriam and the late Morris Kerzner, z'l, doting grandfather and an especially cherished uncle of Michael Kerzner, who was extremely devoted to him, along with many other family members. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1

SCHIFF--Marietta Angelilli. My beautiful, sweet, loving sister died peacefully at her home, surrounded by family. Generous even to the end, she donated her body to NYU to help understand the rare form of cancer that she had. My darling sister, you were my loving supporter, constant protector and cherished friend. In darkness, you were my light; in weakness, my strength. Our bond cannot be broken. I love you always. Peter 1/3

AGOVINO--Al. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, staff, membership and people supported and their families mourn the passing of AHRC New York City's former Board Member, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. The father of a daughter with an intellectual and developmental disability (I/DD), Al and his late wife Vera worked tirelessly to improve the lives of people with I/DD and their families - work that continued even after the tragic loss of their beloved daughter. Al was a person of great integrity and common sense who helped many others get through the difficult trials in their lives. His commitment to advocacy for people with I/DD was exemplary. Al served on the AHRC New York City Board of Directors for twenty-six years. He resigned in 2002 because of ill health, but remained an active member of the organization. Al served as AHRC New York City's President, chaired many committees over the years and was on the NYSARC Board of Governors. He was appointed to the New York State Board of Visitors of Metro NY in 1978 by the Governor and served in that role for two decades including serving as President in 1995 and 1996. Al served in an advisory capacity on many state councils and commissions including the New York State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled, and the NYS Autism Advisory Council. He was well known and well respected throughout the I/DD community in New York State. We offer our sincere condolences to his children and grandchildren. Al will be remembered by his "AHRC New York City family" and will be greatly missed. Laura J. Kennedy, President Gary Lind, Executive Director 1/3

FLETCHER--Virginia F. November 2, 1922-January 26, 2015. Virginia Fletcher, age 92, died peacefully on January 26, 2015, at her home in Garden Grove, CA. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, William E. Fletcher, as well as her two children, Pamela F. Richardson, and Garry J. Fletcher. She is also survived by her son-in-law, John P. Richardson, and granddaughter Katharine P. Richardson, of New York City. Virginia's older sister, Julia Smethurst, age 93, of Cabot, Arkansas, also survives her. Virginia spent many happy years golfing at her beloved Navy Golf Course in Cypress, CA. She even had two holes-in-one in 2007, at age 85! A memorial tree is being planted at the golf course in her honor.

RODMAN--Arline Betty. Arline Betty Rodman, born August 14, 1932 to Miriam and Jo Kruger, sadly passed away in Los Angeles, in her home January 13, 2015. Arline joins her devoted husband, soulmate of 53 years, Norman Rodman. It was love at first sight when they met in Grossingers, followed by elopement and a wedding at The Waldorf Astoria New York City. They lived happily married between the U.S., Rio, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Europe, and London. They supported Martin Luther King Jr. and were recognized for their contribution to the 1970s Israeli peace negotiations in England. Arline Rodman's smile lit up the day. Sweet and generous thru to her last breath. Widowed in 2008, Arline returned to the U.S. for her final five years cared for by her loving daughters Debra Fay Rodman and Roberta Rodman. She is remembered by daughters Linda, Barbara, Debra, and Roberta, grandchildren Jason, Amanda, and Danielle, brother Edward Kruger. May she rest in peace and pure love forever. 1/3

Her heart and her home were places of refuge and happiness for us, as they were for so many. She was a friend unlike any other, and it is painful to think of our lives without her. She has left us with many wonderful memories, and we will treasure them in her absence. 1/3

MARA--Ann. Fordham University and its Board of Trustees mourns the loss of Ann Mara, matriarch of the New York Giants football dynasty, "first lady of football," and longtime friend and supporter of Fordham. "We have lost a great woman today, a woman of many talents, and a great soul," said Joseph M. McShane, S.J., president of Fordham. "She was indeed the first lady of Fordham football, but she was so much more than that: a keen businesswoman; a devout Catholic; a loving mother; a generous philanthropist; and a warm colleague. I know the Fordham community joins me today in mourning her loss, and in keeping the Mara family in our thoughts and prayers." Mrs. Mara is the widow of longtime Giants owner Wellington Mara, a 1937 graduate of Fordham College at Rose Hill. She was awarded an honorary degree from Fordham in 2008, and in 2012 received Fordham's Walsh Award, given each year to an individual who best exemplifies the support, loyalty, and passion for Fordham football. Mrs. Mara's connection to Fordham football dates back to the 1930s, when her future husband, Wellington, a classmate of Vince Lombardi, would bring her to University sporting events. The Mara family has multiple ties to the University: John Mara, the Giants' president and CEO, is a 1979 graduate of Fordham Law School and several of Ann's Mara's grandchildren attended the University. Wellington and John Mara are also recipients of honorary degrees from Fordham, and Wellington Mara received one of the University's first Founder's Awards. "During our courtship, [Wellington] dragged me to every football game and every basketball game," Mrs. Mara said when she accepted the Walsh Award. "That was his idea of a romantic night." In conferring an honorary doctorate of humane letters upon her in 2008, Fordham said of Mrs. Mara, "She is the matriarch; literally as a mother, grandmother, and great- grandmother, and figuratively, for the extended New York Giants family, a family that includes scores of players and hundreds of Giants alumni. Indeed, through it all: the defeats, the personal losses and the memorable triumphs, Ann Mumm Mara has been there." 1/3

STOLZBERG--Marilyn. passed away on January 10, 2015, surrounded by family. She was born in Brooklyn, NY on September 25, 1948 to Bertha (Rothfeld) Goldberg and Theodore Goldberg. Following graduation from Brooklyn College, Marilyn worked as a buyer for the Ohrbachs chain of department stores. Marilyn and her loving husband of 43 years, Mark, raised their three children (Susan Swinkin, David, and Daniel) in Stony Brook, NY with love and whimsy. Over the years, Marilyn created many fun-filled, unforgettable experiences for their children including annual pumpkin picking trips, Halloween and April Fool's Day dinners. She created a large backyard garden that was like a slow-motion explosion of color during warmer months. After focusing on raising their children for many years, Marilyn returned to school to become a registered nurse. She worked as an RN at the SUNY Stony Brook Hospital for three years, followed by 10 years at the University's Student Health Center. Marilyn was extraordinarily kind and giving; people who considered her a true and trusted friend are too numerous to count. She would safely escort insects outside of her home rather than see them harmed. The joie de vivre she exuded was contagious. She loved to dance, adding to the merriment of many celebrations by doing so. Words cannot express the deep sense of loss experienced by Marilyn's family and friends. Marilyn is survived by her husband, their three children, granddaughter Alison Swinkin, son- in-law Robert Swinkin, daughter-in-law Anne Siegler, sisters Carol Buxbaum and Barbara Shostak, and mother-in- law Ruth Stolzberg. 1/3

MEHL--Dr. Bernard, an esteemed educator and leader in the fields of pharmacoeconomics and hospital pharmacy, died Friday after a long struggle with Alzheimer's disease. Dr. Mehl, known to all as Bernie, was 81. He was born in the Bronx, NY and resided in Spencertown, NY. Dr. Mehl was a cum laude graduate of Fordham University College of Pharmacy, and trained in Medical Administration at the School of Aviation Medicine in the United States Air Force. He earned his MBA from Fairleigh Dickinson University and his DpS from Pace University. He was a fellow at the Leon Davis Institute of Health Economics at the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania. For most of his professional life, Dr. Mehl was associated with the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He held a faculty appointment at the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, as well as Long Island University School of Pharmacy and St. Johns University. He was instrumental in starting the first PharmD program in New York State and was awarded the John W. Webb visiting professor award from Northeastern University. On the state level he was an active and long time member of the New York State Council of Hospital Pharmacists, serving as President and Vice President for Government Affairs. Dr. Mehl was recognized nationally for his innovation in the practice of hospital pharmacy. He was instrumental in computerizing pharmacy systems, expanding the use of robotics and improving safety measures. In 2001, Dr. Mehl was awarded the Harvey AK Whitney Award, the highest honor in the field. Dr. Mehl's love of pharmacy extended beyond his professional life. He and his wife Florence, traveled extensively around the world, collecting apothecary jars, eventually amassing a museum quality collection. Besides his wife of 60 years, Dr. Mehl is survived by his son Spence, daughter Stephanie, their spouses Lily and Gary, grandchildren Carson, Elijah, and Jesse and brother Martin. His gentle presence will be deeply missed by his family and friends. Donations may be made in his memory to: Mount Sinai Center for Cognitive Health Attn: Martin Goldstein MD, Medical Director, Department of Neurology, 5 East 98 Street, New York, NY 10029. Memorial services will be held at 11:30am on Saturday, February 7th at the Interfaith Chapel at Cedar Crest Cedar Crest Village Drive, Pompton Plains, NJ 07444. 1/3

AGOVINO--Al. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, staff, membership and people supported and their families mourn the passing of AHRC New York City's former Board Member, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. The father of a daughter with an intellectual and developmental disability (I/DD), Al and his late wife Vera worked tirelessly to improve the lives of people with I/DD and their families - work that continued even after the tragic loss of their beloved daughter. Al was a person of great integrity and common sense who helped many others get through the difficult trials in their lives. His commitment to advocacy for people with I/DD was exemplary. Al served on the AHRC New York City Board of Directors for twenty-six years. He resigned in 2002 because of ill health, but remained an active member of the organization. Al served as AHRC New York City's President, chaired many committees over the years and was on the NYSARC Board of Governors. He was appointed to the New York State Board of Visitors of Metro NY in 1978 by the Governor and served in that role for two decades including serving as President in 1995 and 1996. Al served in an advisory capacity on many state councils and commissions including the New York State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled, and the NYS Autism Advisory Council. He was well known and well respected throughout the I/DD community in New York State. We offer our sincere condolences to his children and grandchildren. Al will be remembered by his "AHRC New York City family" and will be greatly missed. Laura J. Kennedy, President Gary Lind, Executive Director 1/3

HUSTED--Elbert Ervin III "Rusty" of Mantoloking, NJ, died on Sunday, February 1, 2015, at his home at Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, NJ. He was 94. He graduated from Newark Academy and Princeton University 42. A chemical engineer, he worked for Union Carbide, Inmont (now part of BASF), and Harrington Research Company. He served on the Mantoloking town council for 18 years and was actively involved with Rutgers University's Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences. He was a member of the Beaverkill Trout Club, the Manasquan River Golf Club, the Mantoloking Yacht Club and the Bay Head Yacht Club. He was predeceased by his wife, Thalia Barbara Smith Husted. Interment will be private. There will be a memorial service over the summer. 1/3

MARA--Ann. Our heartfelt sympathies to John and the entire Mara family. Ann Mara was the wonderful matriarch of the Giants organization. Like her beloved husband Wellington, with whom Bob Tisch began our families' enduring partnership, Ann was passionate about her faith, her family and her football team. Her love and presence for the team were a constant. We will all miss her honesty, strength, graciousness and wit, and are deeply saddened by her loss. Joan, Steve, Laurie, Jonathan and Lizzie Tisch and families 1/3

NEFT--Naomi Naomi Neft, 74, of New York, NY died peacefully at noon on February 2, 2015. Diagnosed with breast cancer in 1986, Naomi won her 28-year battle with the disease in resounding fashion by surviving to witness the most treasured milestones of her life, most notably her 50th wedding anniversary in 2014 and the birth of her 3 cherished grandchildren, including her long-awaited granddaughter born just last month. While her health was at times defined by disease, her life was defined by her deep and constant love of her family and friends, and their joyful love and admiration of her. She relished in her multi-faceted role as connector of loved ones, fearless friend, provider of comfort, support, and optimism, doting mother and grandmother, and pusher of food. Born in Brooklyn, NY on April 12, 1940, Naomi was a life-long New Yorker who often joked that Bloomingdale's was her summer home. She was graduated from Connecticut College in 1961 and worked as an encyclopedia editor before choosing to raise her family. Even so, her work was never done and she went on to co-author 2 books: Where Women Stand, with Ann Levine (Random House, 1997) and Recipes for Our Daughters, with Cynthia Rothstein (Ballantine Books, 2004). Naomi is survived by her husband of 50 years, David, her children, Michael and Debbie (Michael Norkin), her grandchildren, Theo, Luke, and Josie, her brother Stephen Silver (Margot), and her nieces, Amy Bigler (Ron) and Kate Silver. Funeral services for Naomi will held on Thursday, February 5 at 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Carl Schurz Park Conservancy (http://www.carlschurzparknyc.org).

ADELMAN--Lawrence. Formerly of Great Neck, New York, passed away on February 2, 2015 in Boca Raton, Florida at the age of 75 after a battle against brain cancer. Larry is survived by his wife Julie (nee Kerman) of 49 years and by his son, David Adelman (Ilana), daughter, Lauren Saltman (Scott), and daughter Heather Gladstein (Seth), and by grandchildren Sarah, Max, Sophia, Evan, Rachel, Levi and Judah. He is predeceased by his parents Max and Clare Adelman and by his sister Joyce. Larry was born January 7, 1940, in New York City. He graduated from Miami University (Ohio) and served for six years in the U.S. Navy Reserves. Larry received immense satisfaction from his career, which began in 1963 as an analyst trainee at Merrill Lynch. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA), one of the leading equity research analysts of his generation, and served as Director of Research and a member of the Board of Directors of Dean Witter Reynolds. When Larry retired from Morgan Stanley in 2002, Institutional Investor had named him a leading analyst on 28 occasions, and he was an inaugural member of the Wall Street Journal's analyst "Hall of Fame." He also served on Temple Beth-El of Great Neck's Board of Trustees. Larry's family gave him the greatest joy, and he was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather. Larry enjoyed spending time with dear friends, exercising, politics, watching sports, traveling, listening to music, reading, military history, and tinkering with cars, and in retirement, he found great pleasure in living on the Atlantic Ocean. His family has requested in lieu of flowers that donations be made in his memory to: Weill Cornell Brain and Spine Center, 525 East 68th Street, Starr 651, Box 99, New York, NY 10065. Or use the link weillcornellbrainandspine. org/donate-now. The funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, February 5, 2015 at 9:30am. 1/3
