PETRIE--Carroll. The Board of Directors and the entire staff of The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) deeply mourn the passing of Mrs. Carroll Petrie, a longtime supporter of the organization and committed hero for animals. A winner of the 2014 ASPCA Lifetime Achievement Award, Mrs. Petrie helped create life-saving programs including The Carroll Petrie Foundation Dog Rescue Project, a valuable initiative that has funded much-needed treatments and relocation services for over 16,000 shelter dogs at county and municipal animal sheltering organizations. Mrs. Petrie's profound love for animals --both her own and those in crisis she's never met --was matched by her selfless dedication to helping them. We'll miss her generous spirit, but her remarkable gifts will continue saving animal lives well into the future. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Petrie's family and friends. 1/3

RICE--Joseph, III. Born on January 26, 1928, of Manhattan, died peacefully on January 23 at his home surrounded by his loved ones. We mourn the loss of a man reflecting dignity and great compassion. A brilliant problem solver, mathematician and friend to all creatures, great and small. A pioneer of the broadcasting industry, working for WNYC public radio for over 30 years. His family established the Jewish community in Trenton, NJ in 1857 as well as Temple Har Sinai. Joseph will be greatly missed by all those lives he touched. 1/3

NEIDORF--Drew, most loving husband and father, passed away February 3, 2015 at the age of 61 with his wife and children at his side. A longtime resident of Larchmont, Drew had a successful 30 year career in finance, serving as president of CIT Credit Finance, Nations Credit, and Greystone Business Credit. Cherished by family and friends for his generosity, kindness, and humor, he is survived by his devoted wife Lynn and adoring children Josh and Carly. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 6, 2015 at 10am at Larchmont Temple. Donations in Drew's memory may be made to Breast Cancer Research. 1/3

SONNER--Hilda. With sadness we announce the death of Hilda Sonner, April 12, 1927. Hilda passed peacefully February 2, 2015. A resident of Lido Beach NY, Beachurst Queens, NY, Warren, VT and San Juan, Puerto Rico. Hilda was a loving and devoted wife to her late husband Lou Sonner and her first husband Manny Winick. Hilda is survived by her three children, Richard, Reid, Ivy, daughter- in-laws Allyson, and Nanette, Sandra Winick and son-in-law Kenneth P. Dressler. She predeceased by her son Chet. Is survived by her sister Mildred Kelberman, step brother Harvey Mittelman, six grandchildren, five nieces, and loving step-family the Sonners' and Mannheims'. Hilda left us with many fond memories, Hilda will be sincerely missed. Services will be held Friday, February 6 at 9:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY. 1/3

DAVIS--Patrick J.,on February 1, 2015 of Laurel Hollow, NY. Born in Co. Sligo, Ireland. Retired Vice President of Friendly Frost, Westbury, NY. Beloved husband of Sheila and the late Mona. Loving father of Katrina (Steven) and Nora (John). Cherished grandfather of Ryan, Lucy, Gabe and Charlie. Dear brother of Bea, Kathleen, Margaret, Peter and the late Jim, Frank and Henry. Reposing at Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, NY. Visitation Friday 4- 8pm. Funeral Mass 9am Saturday at St. Dominic RC Church, 93 Anstice St., Oyster Bay, NY. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. 1/3

HACH--Michael J, of East Quogue formerly of Hicksville on February 2, 2015. He became a member of IUOE Local 30 in 1961 as a Refrigeration Engineer. In 1968 he was hired as a union organizer and was later promoted to Business Representative. In 1986 he was appointed to the position of Business Manager, leading Local 30 through the most prosperous time during his career. He held the position of Business Manager until his retirement in 2000. He served on a number of committees including the Committee for Apprenticeship Standards for the International in Washington D.C. and he was Vice President of the Westchester-Putnam Counties AFL-CIO Central Labor Body. He was a man of unimpeachable character, integrity and honest. He believed that in order to gain at the negotiations table you need to represent the most talented and experienced Engineers. Training was paramount and Mike developed one of the best Apprentice Training Centers in New York for Stationary Engineers. Dear brother of Richard Hach. Loving father of Tara Daniels, Loren Parker, Chris Canon, Gregory Hach and Michael Hach. Beloved grandfather of Cooper Daniels, Leah Parker, Katherine Parker, Evan Parker, Jack Canon, Dylan Hach, Julianna Hach, Savannah Hach, Michael Hach and Brooklynn Hach. Friends may call on Thursday 2-4pm and 7-9pm and Friday 4-8pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes, Hicksville Chapel, 47 Jerusalem Avenue (Corner of West Marie Street). Mass Saturday 9:45am at St. Ignatius R.C. Church. Cremation Private. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Bruce, 52, died on February 2nd in New York after a long battle with cancer. A television sports producer, most recently at Bruce Silverman Productions, and a former Riverdale Soccer Club president, Bruce will be greatly missed by his wife Lydia, daughter Julia, son Evan and all who knew his kindness, joy and bravery. 1/3

HERBERT--Lieutenant Colonel Anthony B.,April 17, 1930 -June 7, 2014. Anthony Herbert was born in Herminie, PA and died in Canon City, CO. He enlisted in the Army in May of 1947. He served in Korea and was rapidly promoted to Master Sergeant. He was one of the most decorated soldiers in the Korean War. Herbert graduated from the University of Pittsburgh in 1956. He became an instructor at the Mountain Ranger Training Camp in Dahlonega, GA. He first deployed to Vietnam in 1968 with the 173rd Airborne Brigade. Included among numerous awards and decorations, Herbert received four Silver Stars, three Bronze Star Medals with a V, six Battle Stars, and four Purple Hearts. He was wounded 14 times -10 times by bullets, three times by bayonet, and once by white phosphorus. Services for Anthony Herbert will be at Arlington Memorial National Cemetery on Monday, February 9th at 11am. Charles Morgan III; Lieutenant Colonel (Ret.), James M. Tucker 1/3

MARA--Ann, on February 1, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Wellington T. Mara. Cherished grandmother of forty- three grandchildren and sixteen great grandchildren. Beloved sister of Donald Mumm and aunt to eleven nieces and nephews. Loving niece of the late Lillian Dubord. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10am, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, family requests that donations be made to Boys Hope Girls Hope of New York, or Catholic Charities of New York. 1/3

HARRINGTON--Jeremiah "Jerry," of Rye, NY died on Thursday, January 29 at the age of 67 following a car accident in Florida when a driver ran through a stop sign. He leaves behind his loving wife Helen, his two children Leigh and Colin, his adoring granddaughter Olivia, and his six siblings. The wake will be at Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY on Friday, February 6 from 3p-8pm. 1/3

BUKSBAUM--Lawrence J.,age 57 of Demarest, N.J. died on Saturday, January 31, 2015. Beloved husband of Karen Maloof. Loving father of sons Brandon and Scott. Adored brother of Madelyn Buksbaum. A memorial service for Larry will take place this Saturday morning, February 7 at 11 o'clock at Central Unitarian Church, 156 Forest Avenue, Paramus, N.J. LIEDTKE--Walter: The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Walter Liedtke. Walter was a curator of European paintings at The Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1980. He was a beloved friend, a widely admired colleague, and a greatly respected curator and scholar. We mourn his death and send our condolences to his wife Nancy. The Staff and Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art 1

LIEDTKE--Walter. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the tragic loss of Walter Liedtke, eminent curator and scholar of Dutch and Flemish paintings, who was part of the Met family for 35 years. The many major exhibitions he organized at the Met were revered by scholars and embraced by millions of visitors, including Rembrandt/Not Rembrandt, Vermeer and the Delft School, The Age of Rembrandt, Vermeer's Masterpiece "The Milkmaid," and the recent El Greco in New York. Besides catalogues accompanying those and other exhibitions, he masterfully catalogued the Museum's Dutch and Flemish paintings collection and was at work cataloguing the Met's Spanish paintings. He was a much loved and admired colleague, a passionate scholar and brilliant lecturer, a true gentleman, and a witty, generous friend. All of us join his longstanding colleagues in the Department of European Paintings in grieving with his beloved wife, Nancy, and their entire family. Walter will be sorely missed. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President 1/3

LUSTERMAN--Leon, 92, passed away February 2. He had enjoyed 64 wonderful years of marriage to Dove, and is survived by his daughter Nina (her husband Michael), son Daniel (his wife Shelley), grandchildren Jordan (wife Jessica), Tara (husband Jamie), and Anna, and great-grandchildren Aaron and Talia. NICHOLSON--George. Sterling Lord Literistic, Inc. and our many writers mourn the untimely passing of our comrade and agent George Nicholson. After an influential career in publishing books for young readers, George joined the agency in 1995 and for the next 20 years proved himself to be an inspired co-worker and a fierce advocate for the work he represented. He brought to our community the same tireless energy and innovative spirit that had made his reputation as the first, hugely successful publisher of inexpensive paperback books for young readers. His store of knowledge about his chosen profession, his unerring eye for good writing, his great good humor and innate compassion are irreplaceable and will be deeply missed. 1/3

BILDNER--Allen I.,of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida and West Orange, New Jersey, passed away on February 5, 2015. Born August 16, 1926, in Maspeth, New York, Allen was married for 64 years to Joan Lebson Bildner, who predeceased him. Allen was the former Chair and CEO of Kings Super Markets, a family-owned company for 52 years until its 1988 sale to Marks and Spencer. He was also a past chair of the Food Marketing Institute (FMI), the supermarket industry's national and global trade association, and a founder and past chair of the New Jersey Food Council. Allen was a respected leader in the Jewish and secular communities, serving on numerous nonprofit as well as for-profit boards including the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, the Maltz Jupiter (Fla.) Theatre, Yankee Sports and Entertainment Network (YES), New Jersey Bell and Seton Hall University. Allen received numerous community and industry honors, as well as awards from Dartmouth College, from which he graduated and from where he received an MBA. His honors include the Dartmouth Alumni Award, the Martin Luther King, Jr. Social Justice Lifetime Achievement Award of Dartmouth College, the Charles Evans Hughes Humanitarian Award of the National Conference of Community and Justice (NCCJ) and honorary doctorates, along with Joan Bildner, from Bloomfield College and Rowan University. In 2002, Allen was named by Supermarket News as one of the 50 visionary food industry leaders of the last 50 years. Along with Joan Bildner, Allen was a co-founder of the Bildner Center for the Study of Jewish Life at Rutgers. Allen is survived by his loving children, sons Rob and Jim, daughters-in-law Elisa and Nancy, and grandchildren Elana, Lizzie, Ari, Eli and Rafi. He is also survived by his sister, Phyllis Schechter, and is predeceased by a grandson, Peter. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and the communities in New Jersey and Florida where he lived, worked, and served. Funeral services will be held at 1:30pm on Sunday, February 8th at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Rd, South Orange, NJ 07079. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations may be made in his memory to the Joan and Allen Bildner Center for the Study of Jewish Life, Rutgers University, 12 College Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ 08901, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, DC 20024 and the Maltz Theater, 1001 E. Indiantown Rd., Jupiter, FL 33477. 1/3

BOCKMAN--Jeanne Lafont Passed quietly at her home in New York City, the late evening of January 29, 2015. Jeanne was 102 3, lived an active and engaged life until immediately before her peaceful death. She was beloved by her great-grandchildren: Adalay, Tate, Raphael, Nora, Calvin and Linus; her grandchildren: Peter Wachtel (recently deceased), Alexander Bockman and Danielle Shalov with their devoted spouses Phoebe and Gregory; and her deceased daughter, Laura Wachtel and her devoted son Richard Bockman, M.D., PhD. Jeanne Marie Mathilde Lafont was born in Noyon France to Rachel Marinere and Pierre Bernard Lafont on April 20, 1912. As a young child, with her sister (Andree Lafont Quatremain) and mother, she had to flee to Chateauroux to evade the German forces advancing in the early days of World War I. Her father served in the French army and died soon after the war. With their family home destroyed, the mother and daughters moved to Paris. She subsequently worked on the editorial staff of Plon Publishing. In the early 1930s, she met her American-born husband, William H Bockman, a medical student at the University of Paris. Their travels to Berlin and throughout Italy in 1937 raised their concerns about consolidating fascism in Europe and led to their return to New York City where they subsequently raised their family and lived a full and active life. William died at the age of 89. Jeanne lived a long and good life surrounded by her devoted family who gained their moral strength from her core values. She will be missed but never forgotten by the many especially Alexander and Danielle, their mother Dr. Darcy B Kelley, Solange and Evelyne Quatremain, Richard and Gale (Hayman). We extend our deepest appreciation to the excellent medical staffs at the Hospital for Special Surgery, New York Presbyterian Hospital and to Shaline Murther for her loving care of our beloved Jeanne. Much appreciation to Clover Lyttle and Marie Richard for their kind and comforting assistance. Lasting appreciation to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House and the Carter Burden Center, outstanding charitable institutions that deserve more support for their conscious caring. Her life will be celebrated at a memorial to be held at St. John the Martyr at 11am on February 21, 2015. 250 East 72nd Street, New York, NY. 1/3

LIEDTKE--Dr. Walter. It was with shock and immense grief that members of the Board of the American Foundation for The Courtauld Institute of Art (AFCIA) learned of the tragic loss of its Vice President, Dr. Walter Liedtke. Dr. Liedtke, an eminent art-historian, author and distinguished curator completed his doctoral studies at The Courtauld Institute of Art in London and always remained, especially through his service on the AFCIA Board, a stalwart supporter of the Institute's varied educational programs. It was thanks to Dr. Liedtke's immense prestige and wise counsel that AFCIA fulfilled its mission--a task that will now be far more arduous without him. On behalf of the AFCIA Board, its President and Executive Director wish, in this sad moment, to express with great sincerity their deepest condolences to his widow, Mrs. Nancy Liedtke. 1/3

VAN BUREN--Barbara. Born in Brooklyn, August 28, 1929, died in her Manhattan home on January 31, 2015. Educated in Catholic schools, she further received a BS degree from Queens College, and a MS in Social Work from Columbia University. A Social Worker for many years, she championed the rights of children, incarcerated women, and ex-offenders. Many social programs throughout New York City benefit today from Barbara's relentless efforts and skillful fundraising. She retired in 2011 at the age of 82 from West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH) after twenty-one years as the Director of Development. Barbara had a progressive spirit and was particularly talented at organization, preparation and inclusiveness, tempered by spontaneity and a zeal for having fun. Barbara's talents shone in her position as Director of Community Liaison in the Office of the New York City Council President (1977-1979). They also led to her successes in acquiring funding and grants for many service agencies: Project Green Hope (1980-1986) and the Fortune Society (1980-1986) as Development Director and Grants Administrator, both supportive services for ex-prisoners, male and female; the AIDS Services Delivery Consortium as Director (1987); and West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH), as Directory of Development (1980-2011). Up until her last illness, Barbara for many years co-chaired the Community Board Number Seven, Committee for Health and Human Services. Barbara was deeply religious, and viewed her faith as including social and community responsibility. Her staunch beliefs, and extraordinary talents in organizing social movements propelled her into leadership roles in progressive activities such as Call to Action. As a progressive she had a keen interest in feminist initiatives. Barbara loved New York City and all it offers. Barbara frequently traveled with friends. She was fun to be with and to go out with. She will be greatly missed. Barbara is survived by her brother Jerome, her sister-in-law Mary; niece Michele Van Buren Kiefer; nephews David Van Buren and Christopher Van Holmes; grand-nieces Jean Van Buren, Skye Terebey, Carlin Van Holmes, Madison Van Holmes and Aurora Kiefer; and grand-nephew Edward Kiefer. Calling hours at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Sunday February. 8, 3- 5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at St. Gregory Church, 144 W. 90 St., at 10am on Monday, February 9. Donations, in memory of Barbara, may be sent to Call to Action, 421 Eighth Ave., PO Box 8291, New York, NY 10116. 1/3

FLINT--Austin, playwright, Adjunct Professor in the Arts at Columbia University. Died at home in New York on January 31, 2015. Son of the late Edwin Dean Flint and Helen McVicker Flint. Born July 24, 1931 in New York. Great- great-grandson of Austin Flint, the American physician who discovered the heart murmur named for him. Graduated from Millbrook School, Harvard College, BA, and Columbia University, M.A. in English. He married Aili Flint (Waris) in 1958 in Helsinki where he was teaching. In 1960, he began a 47- year teaching career in writing at Columbia University; he taught playwriting and was Director of Undergraduate Studies in Creative Writing. Fellow of Jonathan Edwards College, Yale, where he taught College Seminars in playwriting. Plays: The Flaming Spider: Jonathan Edwards (Yale), Prison Light (New York) and Marching to Jubilee: William Lloyd Garrison's Campaign for the Abolition of Slavery (Yale), Compartments (New York), and others. Translations of works by Finnish writers and playwrights, with Aili. Member of The Century Association and The Dramatists' Guild. Trustee of Spring Lake Ranch,Vermont. A fan of Harvard football, and The Brooklyn Dodgers, he attended all seven games of the l955 World Series. Along with his beloved wife Aili, he is survived by Petri Austin Flint, Christina Flint Grossman, daughter-in-law Jennie Purnell, son-in-law Jeffrey Grossman, loving grandchildren Eric Austin, Belle, Alexander, Lindsay and Chelsea. Funeral to be held at Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, New York, NY 10025 on Tuesday, February 10, 2015 at 2:30 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Cape Cod National Seashore, 99 Marconi Site Road, Wellfleet, MA 02667 or a tribute donation to www.doctorswithoutborders. org. 1/3

On behalf of City College, we extend our sincerest condolences to the Petrie family. Lisa S. Coico, President 1/3

NADLER--David A.,PhD, a beloved father, son, brother and friend, and a renowned expert in the fields of corporate governance and effective leadership, passed away peacefully at his New York City home February 5 after a courageous two-year battle with cancer. He was 66. He retired in 2013 as vice chairman of Marsh & McLennan Companies, and was the founder and, for 25 years, the Chairman and CEO of Delta Consulting Group, one of the countrys elite boutique management consulting firms. The son of Leonard and Zeace Nadler of White Plains, he was born in New York, lived in Japan and Ethiopia where his father was on assignment for the U.S. Agency for International Development, and attended high school in the Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C. He received a BA in International Affairs from The George Washington University, an MBA from the Harvard Business School, and an MA and PhD in Psychology from the University of Michigan. In 1980, after two years on the faculty of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, David launched Delta Consulting Group, whose talented professionals pioneered the practice of organizational change. Over time, David became widely known as a thought leader and respected advisor to CEOs and corporate boards on governance, leadership, organization design and senior teams. He authored and/or edited 16 books and contributed scores of articles and chapters in professional publications. He continued working with clients and managing the firm after he sold Delta to Marsh & McLennan in 2000, eventually becoming vice chairman of the parent company in 2006. He served in that role until 2013, playing an instrumental role in the company's dramatic turnaround. Following his retirement from MMC, he and his brother, Mark his long-time associate at Delta and co-author of many of his publications co-founded Nadler Advisory Services, which continues to provide senior level consulting to boards, CEOs and senior teams. David was among the most prominent figures in the field of corporate governance. From 2009 through 2012 he was listed by the National Association of Corporate Directors as one of the 100 most influential people in the boardroom, and in 2013 was inducted into the NACD Directorship Corporate Governance Hall of Fame. David's passion for life extended far beyond his professional activities. He was devoted to his three daughters, Amy Horowitz and Cara Cook of Chappaqua, and Katie Nadler of New York City, and to his many friends. With homes in Westport, CT, and Naples, FL, he was an accomplished sailor, avid skier and enthusiastic golfer. David's many philanthropic activities included serving for 20 years on the board of Prep for Prep, a program for the education of gifted minority children, and on the board of directors of the New York City Ballet. He was a member of The George Washington University Board of Trustees, and Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Advisors, the Elliott School of International Affairs, at George Washington University. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his daughters; by his beloved sons-in-law, Andrew Horowitz and Brian Cook; by grandchildren Marley, Alex, Sophie, Emily and Henry; by his brothers, Mark and Scott; and by his former wife and close friend, Donna Gould. Funeral services will be held at 9:30am on Sunday, February 8, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St., New York City. Burial will follow in Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave.,Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in David's memory to: Joseph T. Ruggiero Cancer Research Fund at Cornell University, 1305 York Avenue, Room 716, New York, NY 10021, Prep for Prep Development Office, 328 West 71st Street, New York, NY 10023. www.prepforprep.org/ getinvolved 1/3

SHRUBSOLE--Eric, the dynamic 57th Street antiques dealer, died peacefully at his winter house in Florida, on Friday. Eric was born in 1912, the eldest son of Lillian and S. J. Shrubsole, the founder of the company Eric later ran. Eric joined his father's firm at the age of 14, learning the art of silversmithing and the finer points of the antique English silver that the firm bought and sold. In 1936 the father and son decided to open a branch of the business in New York City, and Eric spent the year driving across America from city to city laying the foundations for his shop, which would remain on 57th Street from then till now. Known equally for his technical knowledge, taste, salesmanship, and yes, wardrobe, Eric was a ubiquitous dealer, lecturer, and advisor at shows, museums, and private collections throughout the country. He could be seen roaming the halls of art and antique fairs in Europe and America well into his nineties, often with some fresh purchase in hand. A recent introduction to his annual catalog read: "Hurry in! The items in this catalog are like me: very attractive, in great condition for their age, and probably won't be around very long!" His kindness, generosity and humor will be missed by all who knew him. His first wife, Winnie, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, Karin Shrubsole, and his two stepsons, Christopher and Timothy Martin. Contributions in his memory can be made to St. Peter's Church, Lithgow, 692 Deep Hollow Road, Millbrook, NY 12545. 1/3

In lieu of flowers the family asks for donations to Variety, the children charity of New York which Herb was a huge contributor and on the board for many many years. Funeral services will be held at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery Emerson, NJ. 1

LIEDTKE--Walter. The Board of the American Friends of the Mauritshuis is saddened to announce the tragic passing of one of their own. Walter A. Liedtke was the Curator of European Paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 35 years. He was one of the six people who died in the train wreck on February 3, 2015, in Valhalla, NY. Walter was a highly esteemed authority on Dutch and Flemish art, who published prodigiously, organized major exhibitions and lectured widely. He was an authority on Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Delft architectural painting and wrote both the Flemish (1984) and Dutch (2007) catalogues of the Metropolitan. Proof of the wide range of his interests, he also was working on the catalogue of Spanish paintings at his death. Educated at Rutgers and Brown, he received his PhD from the Courtauld Institute of Art, University of London, in 1974. He taught at Ohio State University for four years before joining the Metropolitan's curatorial staff. Among the outstanding shows that he organized in New York were "Vermeer and the Delft School" (2001), "Rembrandt/Not Rembrandt" in the Metropolitan Museum (1995), and "Liechtenstein: The Princely Collections" (1985). His books include, "Architectural Painting in Delft: Gerard Houckgeest, Hendrick van Vliet, Emanuel de Witte" (1982), "The Royal Horse and Rider: Painting, Sculpture and Horsemanship 1500-1800" (1989), "Flemish Paintings in America" (1992), "A View of Delft: Vermeer and his Contemporaries" (2000), and "Vermeer. The Complete Paintings" (2008). He wrote more than one hundred articles and reviews and was the recipient of many awards, honors and grants. On a personal note, Walter was a witty man, who enjoyed the thrust and parry of debate and scholarly jousting. He held and voiced strong opinions and was always impeccably dressed. Walter scarcely seemed to age. He leaves his lovely wife, Nancy, who taught mathematics and shared his passion for raising horses on their farm in Bedford Hills. Walter will be sorely missed. We have lost a very good and learned friend. Peter C. Sutton 1/3

KOSOVSKY--Harry, M.D. Surrounded by loving family and friends, Harry Kosovsky, M.D., passed away on January 16, 2015 in Englewood, NJ, where he was a resident for 58 years. Dr. Kosovsky is survived by Trudy, his loving wife of 67 years and children Dr. Karen Kosovsky and Dr. Peter Kosovsky. Harry Kosovsky was predeceased by his parents Isidor and Pauline Kosovsky, and his sister Sylvia. Born December 3, 1918 in Paterson, NJ, Harry graduated from Columbia University class of 1940, with a degree in history and later graduated from New York Medical College. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology. He served in the United States Army during WWII, obtaining the rank of Captain, and was a former president of the Society of Medical Psychoanalysts. A kind, profoundly wise, sensitive, and ever humble man, Harry offered unwavering love and support to his family, friends, and patients. 1/3

HERBERT--Lieutenant Colonel Anthony B.,April 17, 1930 -June 7, 2014. Anthony Herbert was born in Herminie, PA and died in Canon City, CO. He enlisted in the Army in May of 1947. He served in Korea and was rapidly promoted to Master Sergeant. He was one of the most decorated soldiers in the Korean War. Herbert graduated from the University of Pittsburgh in 1956. He became an instructor at the Mountain Ranger Training Camp in Dahlonega, GA. He first deployed to Vietnam in 1968 with the 173rd Airborne Brigade. Included among numerous awards and decorations, Herbert received four Silver Stars, three Bronze Star Medals with a V, six Battle Stars, and four Purple Hearts. He was wounded 14 times -10 times by bullets, three times by bayonet, and once by white phosphorus. Services for Anthony Herbert will be at Arlington Memorial National Cemetery on Monday, February 9th at 11am. Charles Morgan III; Lieutenant Colonel (Ret.), James M. Tucker 1/3

ZAZANIS--George A.,M.D, pioneer of neurosurgery and former Chief of Neurosurgery at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, died of cancer on February 4th, 2015, in Vero Beach, Florida. He was 84 years old. Born in Youngstown, Ohio to parents who emigrated from Greece, Dr. Zazanis graduated from the University of Michigan. He earned both M.D. and M.S. degrees from Temple University School of Medicine, and while enlisted as a U.S. Army captain in Newfoundland, Canada, he was awarded a commendation medal in 1959. He completed his residency at Temple University, where he met Marina Pappas Zazanis, his adoring wife of 52 years. Following his residency, he joined the practice of his late partner Henry Liss, and in 1965, they performed the first stereotactic neurosurgical operation in the state of New Jersey. He served as Chief of Neurosurgery at Morristown Memorial Hospital until 1987, when he was appointed to chair the department at UMDNJ. Dr. Zazanis' neurosurgical procedures and clinical research were widely presented and published, and he sponsored numerous postgraduate candidates and postdoctoral fellows. Dr. Zazanis was honored with the title of Archon for his outstanding leadership and service to the Greek Orthodox Church and to the community at large. In addition to his devoted wife Marina, he is survived by his daughter, Elena and her husband, Paul Fish, and two sisters, Alpena Zazanis and Bess Nicholas. There will be a public viewing on Wednesday, February 11th, 5-7pm at William A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham, NJ. Private internment and services will be held on February 12th. A memorial service is scheduled for Sunday, March 22nd at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, 2525 South 25th Street, Fort Pierce, Florida. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be sent "In Memory of George A. Zazanis" to Orthodox Christian Mission Center, 220 Mason Manatee Way, St. Augustine, Florida, 32086, or to Temple University School of Medicine, Office of Institutional Advancement, 3500 North Broad Street, Suite 1101, Philadelphia, PA 19140. 1/3

CRAIG--Robert W.,visionary, scholar, and mountaineering legend, died on January 16, 2015 in Denver, Colorado at the age of 90. A fearless leader, Craig led or participated in climbing expeditions of the worlds highest peaks including K2 and Everest. He was a WWII Naval officer, an author, the first executive director of the Aspen Institute, and co-founder of the Aspen Center for Physics. In 1975 he founded The Keystone Center, a collaborative policy organization in Colorado and a year later, Keystone Science School. Bob's contributions to the world were significant and many and he will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held on April 18 at Keystone Resort in Keystone, CO. Contributions in Bob's memory may be directed to The Keystone Center (www.keystone.org) or the American Alpine Club (www.americanalpineclub.org) 1/3

MARA--Ann. Fordham University and its Board of Trustees mourns the loss of Ann Mara, matriarch of the New York Giants football dynasty, "first lady of football," and longtime friend and supporter of Fordham. "We have lost a great woman today, a woman of many talents, and a great soul," said Joseph M. McShane, S.J., president of Fordham. "She was indeed the first lady of Fordham football, but she was so much more than that: a keen businesswoman; a devout Catholic; a loving mother; a generous philanthropist; and a warm colleague. I know the Fordham community joins me today in mourning her loss, and in keeping the Mara family in our thoughts and prayers." Mrs. Mara is the widow of longtime Giants owner Wellington Mara, a 1937 graduate of Fordham College at Rose Hill. She was awarded an honorary degree from Fordham in 2008, and in 2012 received Fordham's Walsh Award, given each year to an individual who best exemplifies the support, loyalty, and passion for Fordham football. Mrs. Mara's connection to Fordham football dates back to the 1930s, when her future husband, Wellington, a classmate of Vince Lombardi, would bring her to University sporting events. The Mara family has multiple ties to the University: John Mara, the Giants' president and CEO, is a 1979 graduate of Fordham Law School and several of Ann's Mara's grandchildren attended the University. Wellington and John Mara are also recipients of honorary degrees from Fordham, and Wellington Mara received one of the University's first Founder's Awards. "During our courtship, [Wellington] dragged me to every football game and every basketball game," Mrs. Mara said when she accepted the Walsh Award. "That was his idea of a romantic night." In conferring an honorary doctorate of humane letters upon her in 2008, Fordham said of Mrs. Mara, "She is the matriarch; literally as a mother, grandmother, and great- grandmother, and figuratively, for the extended New York Giants family, a family that includes scores of players and hundreds of Giants alumni. Indeed, through it all: the defeats, the personal losses and the memorable triumphs, Ann Mumm Mara has been there." 1/3

SHRUBSOLE--Eric, the dynamic 57th Street antiques dealer, died peacefully at his winter house in Florida, on Friday. Eric was born in 1912, the eldest son of Lillian and S. J. Shrubsole, the founder of the company Eric later ran. Eric joined his father's firm at the age of 14, learning the art of silversmithing and the finer points of the antique English silver that the firm bought and sold. In 1936 the father and son decided to open a branch of the business in New York City, and Eric spent the year driving across America from city to city laying the foundations for his shop, which would remain on 57th Street from then till now. Known equally for his technical knowledge, taste, salesmanship, and yes, wardrobe, Eric was a ubiquitous dealer, lecturer, and advisor at shows, museums, and private collections throughout the country. He could be seen roaming the halls of art and antique fairs in Europe and America well into his nineties, often with some fresh purchase in hand. A recent introduction to his annual catalog read: "Hurry in! The items in this catalog are like me: very attractive, in great condition for their age, and probably won't be around very long!" His kindness, generosity and humor will be missed by all who knew him. His first wife, Winnie, died in 1984. He is survived by his second wife, Karin Shrubsole, and his two stepsons, Christopher and Timothy Martin. Contributions in his memory can be made to St. Peter's Church, Lithgow, 692 Deep Hollow Road, Millbrook, NY 12545. 1/3

SLATER--Bruce. A thoughtful, good man with great integrity. We will miss our cousin, partner and confidant. Our deepest sympathies to James and Anne. May he rest in peace. Gregg and Maurice Slater 1/3

TAGGART--Ralph Scott 93, of Charleston, South Carolina, entered into eternal rest Wednesday, February 4, 2015. Services by J. Henry Stuhr, Inc Downtown Chapel. Ralph was born April 30, 1921 in Chicago, Illinois, son of Van Cleve Taggart and Grace Bryant Taggart. He graduated from Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA, Class of '43, where he was a member of Beta Theta Pi fraternity. His enlistment in the U.S. Army Air Corps led to service in World War II as an aerial photo officer with a promotion to the rank of First Lt. Honorably discharged in 1946, Ralph was employed by a closely held timber and lumber manufacturing company until it was acquired by a major paper corporation in 1965, and operations suspended. Mr. Taggart was active in the management of this Mississippi lumber company and became Vice-President. He wrote articles on lumber and forestry equipment, was elected President of the Mississippi Forestry Association and served on the board of the Southern Pine Association, New Orleans, LA. Prior to a move to Blue Hill, ME, Mr. Taggart was a sales engineer for a New York Exchange listed chemical company. While residing in New Orleans, he was a member of the Southern Yacht Club, where he won many championships in his cruiser/racer sailboat. He was a member of the New Orleans Country Club, New Orleans Lawn Tennis Club, The Pickwick Club and several Mardi Gras and other Men's clubs. He played on the varsity tennis team in college and was ranked 3rd in the State of Louisiana when he played in the Senior tennis circuit. Flying was a love of his and he held a Commercial and Instrument rating while accumulating some 1800 hours of flying time in his Beechcraft aircraft. While in Maine he was a member of the Pot and Kettle Club, Bar Harbor, and the Blue Hill Country Club. He was an active patron of the Blue Hill Public Library. He lived his final days in South Carolina in his retirement home on James Island. Ralph is survived by his daughter, Molly Crosby Cole and son, Hollis Crosby Taggart; and his sister, Martha Keller. He was predeceased by his wife, Molly Crosby Taggart and son, Ralph Scott Taggart, Jr. 1/3

FLINT--Austin, playwright, Adjunct Professor in the Arts at Columbia University. Died at home in New York on January 31, 2015. Son of the late Edwin Dean Flint and Helen McVicker Flint. Born July 24, 1931 in New York. Great- great-grandson of Austin Flint, the American physician who discovered the heart murmur named for him. Graduated from Millbrook School, Harvard College, BA, and Columbia University, M.A. in English. He married Aili Flint (Waris) in 1958 in Helsinki where he was teaching. In 1960, he began a 47- year teaching career in writing at Columbia University; he taught playwriting and was Director of Undergraduate Studies in Creative Writing. Fellow of Jonathan Edwards College, Yale, where he taught College Seminars in playwriting. Plays: The Flaming Spider: Jonathan Edwards (Yale), Prison Light (New York) and Marching to Jubilee: William Lloyd Garrison's Campaign for the Abolition of Slavery (Yale), Compartments (New York), and others. Translations of works by Finnish writers and playwrights, with Aili. Member of The Century Association and The Dramatists' Guild. Trustee of Spring Lake Ranch,Vermont. A fan of Harvard football, and The Brooklyn Dodgers, he attended all seven games of the l955 World Series. Along with his beloved wife Aili, he is survived by Petri Austin Flint, Christina Flint Grossman, daughter-in-law Jennie Purnell, son-in-law Jeffrey Grossman, loving grandchildren Eric Austin, Belle, Alexander, Lindsay and Chelsea. Funeral to be held at Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, New York, NY 10025 on Tuesday, February 10, 2015 at 2:30 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Cape Cod National Seashore, 99 Marconi Site Road, Wellfleet, MA 02667 or a tribute donation to www.doctorswithoutborders. org. 1/3

GRANT--Merrill, Passed away at his home in Manhattan on February 3rd surrounded by his family. He was 82 years old. Born on July 9th, 1932 to Samuel and Rae Grant, Merrill and his older sister, Dorothy, were raised in Washington Heights. After graduating from high school at 16, Merrill first attended City College of New York where he received a Bachelor's Degree in 1953, and then Columbia University Business School, where he earned an MBA in 1954. Following a year of service in the United States Army, Merrill returned to New York where he continued building his professional life; establishing himself as an innovative, creative and highly regarded executive in the television industry. Although his professional successes were substantial, Merrill truly defined himself by his relationships with his friends and family. His extraordinary sense of humor, generous spirit, sharp mind and ability to express himself both in speech and writing drew others to him in a special way. He was both a cherished friend and wise mentor to many; he gave freely of his love, attention, and sage advice. He is survived by, and was a devoted husband of 53 years to, his wife, Barbara, a loving father to his children, Andrea and her husband, Michael, and Jonathan and his partner, Ashley, and an adoring grandfather to Drew and Kate. A memorial service will be held in Merrill's honor on Monday, February 9th at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. 1/3

KORNBLUTH--Lillian, 94, died peacefully in her sleep from pneumonia Sunday, January 25, 2015, in Santa Barbara, California with her family at her side. She was the youngest of four children born to Herman and Fannie Peck Hardis and is predeceased by her two brothers, Abraham and Leonard, and her sister, Ruth. A beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, she lived an extraordinary life. She was born in the Bronx, New York, where she graduated from high school and then attended Hunter College. When she married the love of her life, Milton Kornbluth, in 1940, she moved to Paterson, New Jersey, where she lived for fifty- nine years. One of her great passions was singing in the Temple Emanuel choir with Milton. Her enthusiasm for art was boundless. Lillian had been a housewife with three teenagers when she started a fine art gallery in her home. A few years later, she moved the gallery to a storefront in Fair Lawn, New Jersey, where she exhibited such important contemporary artists as Pablo Picasso, Milton Avery, Will Barnet, Wolf Kahn, Louis Kosowick, Dale Chihuly, Paul Resika, and Richard Segalman. She had a gift for discovering young artists to whom she gave the opportunity to develop and show their work. Those who enjoyed her gallery openings remember them as special occasions often followed by dinners in the Kornbluth's home, where relationships were formed that blossomed into lifelong friendships for artists and clients. In 1990, Lillian sold her gallery to her manager, Sally Walker, but stayed involved as a consultant to the gallery for the next nine years. Lillian moved with Milton to Marina Del Rey, California, in 1999. She was kind and generous to all who knew her. When her youngest son, Peter, was a teenager, the Kornbluth home was the social meeting place for Peter's friends. A house key was always kept under the front entrance door mat, and it was not uncommon for Lillian to come home from the gallery to find a group of Peter's friends relaxing in the family den, not always with Peter present. She always made them welcome. Lillian was predeceased by her husband, Milton, who died in 1999. Lillian is survived by her adored children, Richard and Ann Kornbluth of Syracuse, New York, Peter and Story Kornbluth of Santa Barbara, California, and Janet and Eddie Tucker of Joshua Tree, California. She will be missed by her precious grandchildren Rebecca Kornbluth of Temecula, California, Jeremy Kornbluth and Catherine Delorenzo of Rockville, Maryland, Day Kornbluth and Max Pittman of Brooklyn, New York, and Natalie Kornbluth of San Francisco, California; and her great- grandchildren, Arthur and Louisa Pittman of Brooklyn, New York, and Eli Kornbluth of Rockville, Maryland. 1/3

VAN BUREN--Barbara. Born in Brooklyn, August 28, 1929, died in her Manhattan home on January 31, 2015. Educated in Catholic schools, she further received a BS degree from Queens College, and a MS in Social Work from Columbia University. A Social Worker for many years, she championed the rights of children, incarcerated women, and ex-offenders. Many social programs throughout New York City benefit today from Barbara's relentless efforts and skillful fundraising. She retired in 2011 at the age of 82 from West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH) after twenty-one years as the Director of Development. Barbara had a progressive spirit and was particularly talented at organization, preparation and inclusiveness, tempered by spontaneity and a zeal for having fun. Barbara's talents shone in her position as Director of Community Liaison in the Office of the New York City Council President (1977-1979). They also led to her successes in acquiring funding and grants for many service agencies: Project Green Hope (1980-1986) and the Fortune Society (1980-1986) as Development Director and Grants Administrator, both supportive services for ex-prisoners, male and female; the AIDS Services Delivery Consortium as Director (1987); and West Side Federation for Senior Housing and Support Services (WSFSSH), as Directory of Development (1980-2011). Up until her last illness, Barbara for many years co-chaired the Community Board Number Seven, Committee for Health and Human Services. Barbara was deeply religious, and viewed her faith as including social and community responsibility. Her staunch beliefs, and extraordinary talents in organizing social movements propelled her into leadership roles in progressive activities such as Call to Action. As a progressive she had a keen interest in feminist initiatives. Barbara loved New York City and all it offers. Barbara frequently traveled with friends. She was fun to be with and to go out with. She will be greatly missed. Barbara is survived by her brother Jerome, her sister-in-law Mary; niece Michele Van Buren Kiefer; nephews David Van Buren and Christopher Van Holmes; grand-nieces Jean Van Buren, Skye Terebey, Carlin Van Holmes, Madison Van Holmes and Aurora Kiefer; and grand-nephew Edward Kiefer. Calling hours at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Sunday February. 8, 3- 5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at St. Gregory Church, 144 W. 90 St., at 10am on Monday, February 9. Donations, in memory of Barbara, may be sent to Call to Action, 421 Eighth Ave., PO Box 8291, New York, NY 10116. 1/3

LOVE ALWAYS EVERYWHERE Written and illustrated by Sarah Massini. 26 pp. Random House. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6) 
 
A crew of cherubic, messy-haired toddlers in fantastically stylish outfits bounces through this simple rhyming celebration of love in its many forms. On each page, the word “love” is paired with just one other (“me,” “you,” “smile,” “hug”) as we see Massini’s characters at the beach and at the playground, with a dog and a cat, and reading, painting and playing instruments. A teddy’s lost, then found, adding a dose of drama to a gorgeous and altogether satisfying little world.

CULLINAN GINIGER-- Bernice "Bee," 88, Professor Emeritus New York University, died February 5th surrounded by family. She is survived by her husband Kenneth Seeman Giniger, son James Webb Ellinger, daughter Janie Carley, daughter-in- law Marguerite Ellinger, five grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. Born in Hamilton, OH, October 12, 1926, she received her bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from The Ohio State University and was the Char- lotte Huck Professor of Children's Literature until moving to New York University in 1967. She taught at NYU for thirty years, retiring as Professor Emeritus of Reading and Children's Literature. Bee was the author or editor of more than forty books and Editor-in-Chief of Wordsong Books, Boyds Mills Press, 1990-2008. She received numerous awards and served as President of the International Reading Association (now International Literacy Association), 1979-1984. Bee was a much loved teacher and mentor who inspired many. A memorial service will be held at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street, Saturday morning March 7th, at 11am. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Bernice Cullinan Library Fund, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90 St., New York, NY 10128 or to the Bernice Cullinan Scholarship Fund Highlights Foundation. 814 Court Street, Honesdale, PA 18431. 1/3

NADLER--David A.,PhD, a beloved father, son, brother and friend, and a renowned expert in the fields of corporate governance and effective leadership, passed away peacefully at his New York City home February 5 after a courageous two-year battle with cancer. He was 66. He retired in 2013 as vice chairman of Marsh & McLennan Companies, and was the founder and, for 25 years, the Chairman and CEO of Delta Consulting Group, one of the countrys elite boutique management consulting firms. The son of Leonard and Zeace Nadler of White Plains, he was born in New York, lived in Japan and Ethiopia where his father was on assignment for the U.S. Agency for International Development, and attended high school in the Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C. He received a BA in International Affairs from The George Washington University, an MBA from the Harvard Business School, and an MA and PhD in Psychology from the University of Michigan. In 1980, after two years on the faculty of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, David launched Delta Consulting Group, whose talented professionals pioneered the practice of organizational change. Over time, David became widely known as a thought leader and respected advisor to CEOs and corporate boards on governance, leadership, organization design and senior teams. He authored and/or edited 16 books and contributed scores of articles and chapters in professional publications. He continued working with clients and managing the firm after he sold Delta to Marsh & McLennan in 2000, eventually becoming vice chairman of the parent company in 2006. He served in that role until 2013, playing an instrumental role in the company's dramatic turnaround. Following his retirement from MMC, he and his brother, Mark his long-time associate at Delta and co-author of many of his publications co-founded Nadler Advisory Services, which continues to provide senior level consulting to boards, CEOs and senior teams. David was among the most prominent figures in the field of corporate governance. From 2009 through 2012 he was listed by the National Association of Corporate Directors as one of the 100 most influential people in the boardroom, and in 2013 was inducted into the NACD Directorship Corporate Governance Hall of Fame. David's passion for life extended far beyond his professional activities. He was devoted to his three daughters, Amy Horowitz and Cara Cook of Chappaqua, and Katie Nadler of New York City, and to his many friends. With homes in Westport, CT, and Naples, FL, he was an accomplished sailor, avid skier and enthusiastic golfer. David's many philanthropic activities included serving for 20 years on the board of Prep for Prep, a program for the education of gifted minority children, and on the board of directors of the New York City Ballet. He was a member of The George Washington University Board of Trustees, and Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Advisors, the Elliott School of International Affairs, at George Washington University. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his daughters; by his beloved sons-in-law, Andrew Horowitz and Brian Cook; by grandchildren Marley, Alex, Sophie, Emily and Henry; by his brothers, Mark and Scott; and by his former wife and close friend, Donna Gould. Funeral services will be held at 9:30am on Sunday, February 8, at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St., New York City. Burial will follow in Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave.,Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in David's memory to: Joseph T. Ruggiero Cancer Research Fund at Cornell University, 1305 York Avenue, Room 716, New York, NY 10021, Prep for Prep Development Office, 328 West 71st Street, New York, NY 10023. www.prepforprep.org/ getinvolved 1/3

SOREL--Nancy Caldwell, died on February 5th at the age of 80. The cause of death was Lewy Body Dementia. Nancy was the author of "The Women Who Wrote The War", which chronicled the lives and work of women war reporters during World War II. She also wrote "Ever Since Eve: Personal Reflections of Childbirth", and collaborated with her husband, the artist Edward Sorel, on two books: "Word People and First Encounters." Her essays appeared in Esquire, Atlantic Monthly, and The New York Times Book Review, and she was a staff editor of Columbia Encyclopedia, Third Edition. Nancy Lee Caldwell was born in Kansas City, Missouri in 1934, the daughter of Dr. John and Ruth Conkling Caldwell. She graduated from Ohio Wesleyan in 1956 where she majored in English Literature. She continued to pursue her study of literature at the University of Edinburgh and later NYU. Nancy lived briefly in London where she was introduced to the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers). In 1961 she volunteered for the United Nations Association International Service in Linz, Austria, building homes for WWII refugees, still stateless sixteen years after the end of WWII. Nancy and Edward Sorel met in 1963 at Morningside Friends Meeting, which they later joined and where they were married in 1965. They became active in the anti-Vietnam war movement. In 1967, carrying their infant daughter Jenny, they participated in the (illegal) Easter Sunday pilgrimage across the Peace Bridge to Canada to deliver medical supplies destined for both North and South Vietnam. Nancy felt at home in the country. Having moved to Putnam County, she cherished the time spent in nature with her children and Newfoundland. A music lover, she was instrumental in starting the Putnam Concert Society. The family joined Bulls Head Quaker Meeting, and Nancy participated in a worship group at Green Haven Correctional Facility. She was active in New York Yearly Meeting, serving on numerous committees and acting as recording clerk for multiple terms. She contributed to writing and editing a book on the 300-year history of Quakers in New York State, and she briefly served on the board of the American Friends Service Committee. Nancy lived the last 33 years of her life primarily in New York City where she relished doing research at the Morgan and New York Public Libraries and writing at one end of their TriBeCa loft while Ed drew at the other. In addition to her husband, Edward, she is survived by her sisters, Suzanne Smith and Virginia Craig, both of Kansas; her beloved children and step-children, Jenny Sorel, Katherine Sorel, Madeline Sorel Kahn and Leo Sorel; and her six grandchildren, Saskia, Sabella, Walter, Adam, Dulio and Thelonious, whom she adored. Nancy emanated kindness, generosity and warmth. Even as the disease progressed, her grace and spirit prevailed. All who knew Nancy felt themselves fortunate. 1/3
Maria Contreras, 29, was arrested on Saturday evening in the Bronx and charged with six counts of second-degree rape. The student, a male, is 14 years old.

Loui Eriksson scored the go-ahead goal with 7 minutes 34 seconds left, and Tuukka Rask stopped 39 shots to lift the surging Boston Bruins to a victory over the visiting Islanders for their ninth victory in 12 games.

LUDEN--Mayer. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of our friend Mayer Luden. We will miss his feisty spirit and heart of gold, the holidays we've shared and the memories we cherish. His life was an inspiration to all of us. Our heartfelt condolences to Helga and the entire Luden, Greenwald and Greenbaum families. Tina and Steven Price Nina and Hal Fetner Polina and Yan Erlikh Beth and Howard Fiddle. 1/3

STAYMAN--Sidney, of Mamaroneck, NY passed away at 92 on Saturday, February 7. Beloved husband of 63 years to Bobby. Wonderful father and grandfather to four sons and daughters-in-law and six grandchildren. Dear brother of Selma Williams. Services will be held Tuesday, February 10 at Congregation Emanu-El, 2125 Westchester Avenue, Rye, NY at 10:00am. 1/3

FUCHS--Rose (Kallen), on February 5, 2015, at 98. A generous and loving woman. Dear wife of the late Josef. Devoted mother of Ira and wife Karen and the late John. Adoring grandmother of Juliana, Laura, Steven.

NADLER--David. New York City Ballet mourns the passing of David Nadler, a devoted and beloved member of the Company's Board of Directors. David's involvement over many years made an enormous impact on the Company and his enthusiastic commitment, wise counsel and friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our most sincere sympathy to his family. The board, staff and artists of New York City Ballet 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Rudin Family mourns the loss of John C. Whitehead. John was a loyal and dedicated leader in business, philanthropy, the military, and public service. His contributions to New York City, our state, our nation, and the world have been tremendous. Five generations of the Rudin family have benefitted from John's friendship, love, and affection. Our sincere and heartfelt condolences go out to John's beloved wife Cynthia and his entire family, especially John's grandson, our own David Earls. We wish John peace, light and love. 1/3

MAGID--Abraham, beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, and brother, passed away at age 86 peacefully at home surrounded by his devoted family on Saturday, February 7, 2015. Abe was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, and made his home in Albertson, NY, where he and his wife Sally raised their 4 sons. Abe was a longtime member of Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY, where he served as both president and a distinguished member of the Board of Trustees for many years. Abe was trained as a civil engineer at NYU and had a long and successful career in multiple real estate development projects. He was a loving man who cherished his family above all else. He and his wife Sally were married for 65 years, and were as in love today as the day they were married. They raised their family and traveled the world together, exploring their Jewish heritage and the world's cultures. Abe leaves behind his sons, Lawrence (Millie), Harold (Rhonda), Richard (Carol-Ann), and Marc (Amy). Also grandchildren Alfred, Melissa, David, Jordan, Emily, Julia, Lilly, Jessica, Risa, Zachary, and Samson, and great-grandchildren Ava, Audrey, Parker, Leo, Adi, and Nora. Also survived by his brother Joel (Bonnie). May his memory be a blessing. Shiva will be held at the Magid family home. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Trustees and Staff of Hudson Institute mourn the passing of John C. Whitehead, visionary civic and business leader, dedicated public servant, and longtime friend of Hudson Institute. 1/3
BRODSKY--Milton. We remember the wisdom, the fun, the love. Forever, Grace and Ruth 1/3

BRONNER--Felix, biologist, professor emeritus at the University of Connecticut Health Center and a painter of arresting abstract canvases, died in his sleep on February 7th, 2015 in Riverdale, the Bronx, lying next to Leah, his cherished wife of 67 years. He led a life of learning, bravery, love and honor and will be deeply missed. He was a pioneer in calcium metabolism and published scores of scholarly articles. Born in Vienna, raised in Berlin, he arrived as a teenage refugee in the United States where he went to high school and college, served in the US Army and got a PhD at MIT. He took up painting at age 50 and created pieces that hang in homes all over the world. A Zionist and a liberal, Felix was active in political and Jewish causes, always giving back to his communities, including Louisville, KY, where he was at the University of Louisville Medical School in the 1960s, and West Hartford, CT, where he spent four decades. He is survived by Leah, daughter Deborah, son Ethan, daughter-in-law Naomi and four grandsons, Eli, Gabriel, Joseph and Joshua. A funeral will be held on Monday, February 9th at noon at the Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. in the Bronx. 1/3

BURKE--Estelle (Newman), 99, passed away February 7 after a brief illness, in her home, with family by her side. She was born in New York City to Max and Anna Newman. Following her mother's death, her stepmother was Frieda Newman. She married the love of her life, Dr. Sidney B. Burke, on November 23, 1942, just before he went to serve overseas as a U.S. Army physician. Estelle loved learning, the theater, philanthropy, and above all her children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, extended family, and many friends. There will be a graveside service; inquire with the family. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Division of Cardiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Attn. Dr. Clyde Yancy, 676 N. St. Clair Ste. 600, Chicago, IL, 60611. 1/3

KOEPPEL--Robert, of Locust Valley, NY passed away on February 6 at age 83 due to complications after a stroke. Robert practiced real estate law in his own firm in Brooklyn, NY and continued to work right up until his illness. He was born in Brooklyn, NY and grew up in Belle Harbor, NY. He served in the Army in Europe during the Korean War. He graduated from NYU and Brooklyn Law School. He met his wife, Ellen, on a ski trip in 1959 and they were married in 1961. He served on the board of the American Youth Hostels. He was an avid golfer, swimmer, skiier, sailor, and gardener. He and his wife enjoyed traveling, visiting art museums, and attending classical music concerts. He is survived by his wife, Ellen, his daughters Ruth and Judith, and his sister, Marjorie Baldinger. The funeral was held on Sunday, February 8. 1/3

MELNIKER--Shirley, 91, a much loved wife, mother, attentive grandmother and proud great-grandmother passed away peacefully in her sleep February 6, 2015, surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband of 70 years, Benjamin Melniker, her son Harvey and her daughters-in-law Heather and Nadine Melniker. She will be deeply missed by her five grandchildren Avital (David Berman), Douglas (Rachael), Sophie (Matthew Shuman), Lara, Carly and her five great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her younger son Charles Melniker and by her sister Evelyne Friedman. Shirley was a loving, generous, self-effacing and beautiful person with great taste, style and impeccable character. She was devoted to making Jewish holidays and family celebrations fun yet traditional and memorable. Her cooking was legendary and all the recipes generously shared. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Rockefeller University community mourns the loss of our beloved friend John C. Whitehead, a cherished and highly esteemed member of our Board of Trustees. The world has lost one of the great public servants and business leaders of our time. As a boy, John was an Eagle Scout, and he never lost his passion for service. Throughout his life, John personified the attributes of the Greatest Generation, from his heroic D-day landing on Omaha Beach to assuming the chairmanship of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, charged with the massive challenge of rebuilding Ground Zero. We feel so blessed that John was a trustee of The Rockefeller University from 1989 until his death. He was a significant agent for change at Rockefeller, and his trusteeship had a transformative effect on the institution. As Chairman of the Board's Development Committee in the 1990s, he helped to elevate private support for the University to extraordinary new levels. When John sought support for an institution or a cause he loved, no one ever wanted to disappoint him. In 1998, John was the recipient of the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service, Rockefeller University's highest non- scientific honor, in recognition of his brilliant leadership, his integrity, and his legendary generosity. In 2009, the University established the John C. Whitehead Presidential Fellowships to further recognize John's myriad contributions to Rockefeller's scientific excellence and to honor him more broadly for his distinguished pro bono work for a wide range of other institutions. John Whitehead was a statesman in the worlds of business, international affairs, and philanthropy. Above all, he was determined to make a contribution to society. In this he succeeded, perhaps beyond his wildest dreams. John will be tremendously missed by the entire Rockefeller University community. We send our heartfelt condolences to John's adored wife, Cynthia; his children and stepchildren; and his entire family. "His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, 'This was a man'." David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti Marnie Imhoff, Senior VP for Development 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Rockefeller University community mourns the loss of our beloved friend John C. Whitehead, a cherished and highly esteemed member of our Board of Trustees. The world has lost one of the great public servants and business leaders of our time. As a boy, John was an Eagle Scout, and he never lost his passion for service. Throughout his life, John personified the attributes of the Greatest Generation, from his heroic D-day landing on Omaha Beach to assuming the chairmanship of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, charged with the massive challenge of rebuilding Ground Zero. We feel so blessed that John was a trustee of The Rockefeller University from 1989 until his death. He was a significant agent for change at Rockefeller, and his trusteeship had a transformative effect on the institution. As Chairman of the Board's Development Committee in the 1990s, he helped to elevate private support for the University to extraordinary new levels. When John sought support for an institution or a cause he loved, no one ever wanted to disappoint him. In 1998, John was the recipient of the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service, Rockefeller University's highest non- scientific honor, in recognition of his brilliant leadership, his integrity, and his legendary generosity. In 2009, the University established the John C. Whitehead Presidential Fellowships to further recognize John's myriad contributions to Rockefeller's scientific excellence and to honor him more broadly for his distinguished pro bono work for a wide range of other institutions. John Whitehead was a statesman in the worlds of business, international affairs, and philanthropy. Above all, he was determined to make a contribution to society. In this he succeeded, perhaps beyond his wildest dreams. John will be tremendously missed by the entire Rockefeller University community. We send our heartfelt condolences to John's adored wife, Cynthia; his children and stepchildren; and his entire family. "His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, 'This was a man'." David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti Marnie Imhoff, Senior VP for Development 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. Asia Society's Board of Trustees, Staff, and our entire global community mourn the passing of our Chairman Emeritus and Honorary Life Trustee John Whitehead. He was an inspirational leader and a model citizen--of New York City, of the United States, and of the world. We were privileged to have him as a friend, supporter and advocate for our efforts in the arts, policy and education for over three decades. As Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1989-1995, he helped us conceive and realize the expansion of our Park Avenue headquarters and New York museum in 2001. He was a key participant at our Williamsburg policy conferences in Thailand (1990), in Australia (1991), and in the Philippines (1995). It was an honor to celebrate his lifelong achievements and service at our annual gala dinner held just before his 90th birthday in 2012. His ongoing commitment to and involvement with our organization--most recently as an Honorary Counselor for the Asia Society Policy Institute--will continue to inspire and animate our work. We express our deepest condolences to Cindy and his entire family. Ronnie C. Chan, Co-Chair Henrietta H. Fore, Co-Chair Josette Sheeran, President and CEO Asia Society

REICH--Norman S. Should you go first and I remain, one thing I'd have you do: Walk slowly down that long, lone path, for soon I'll follow you. I'll want to know each step you take that I may walk the same, For some day down that lonely road you'll hear me call your name. Everlasting love, Nancy

ASH--Allan, of New York, NY passed away on February 8, 2015 after a noble fight against the ravages of age. Allan was born in the Bronx, NY on December 17, 1916 to Gussie and Nathan Ash. Allan graduated from the College of the City of New York with an undergraduate degree and a master's degree by the age of eighteen. He was a professor in the accounting department of the evening division of the College of the City of New York. He attained his CPA, joined an accounting firm and soon became a partner of the firm which is now known as Ash & Parsont LLP. He has been an integral part of that Firm for over 70 years. Allan was predeceased by his loving wife, Anita, and his daughter Jerilyn. He is survived by his son Joel and his wife Dawn, his grandson's Neil and his wife Cynthia, Gary and his wife Anna, and his granddaughter Kimberly and his great-grandchildren Austin, Andrew and Isabella. The funeral service will be held on Wednesday, February 11, 2015 at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, NY. 1/3

FRUSHTICK--Steven. Shalik, Morris & Company, LLP mourns the loss of Steven Frushtick, our friend and a senior partner in the Firm's New York City office. Steve's kindness, brilliance, compassion and leadership will be missed both personally and professionally. Our deepest sympathies to the Frushtick family. 1/3

GREENE--Karen Sperling. Beloved wife for 28 years of Steven Greene passed away peacefully with her husband and children by her side on Saturday, February 7th. Born in 1954 to Diana Notari in Bronxville, New York, Karen, formerly of Great Neck, NY, was a lover of literature, thunderstorms, rock and roll, high heels, and crossword puzzles. In her career, she was driven and magnetic, working in senior positions at major marketing firms including as VP at Rubenstein Associates. She went on to co-found Sperling Greene Associates, a successful PR firm with her husband, and most recently held a senior position with the American Cancer Society. Karen lit up every room she entered with her warmth, wit, and exuberance, and brought delight to Tenafly through her commitment to community events like the Tenafly 5K, Kiwanis, and worked towards housing for the developmentally disabled. She is survived and sorely missed by her husband, Steve, her children Ariel, 24 and Jared, 21, and her sister Diana Billeci of Florida. Funeral services, Tuesday February 10, at noon at Temple Sinai, Tenafly, NJ. For more information, call Temple Sinai at (201) 568-3035. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to ASPEN NJ. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of John Whitehead, our Chairman Emeritus and father of our colleague Overseer Anne Whitehead. Exemplary business executive, statesman, civic leader, philanthropist and World War II hero, John was a national treasure, relied upon by presidents, governors and mayors. He was highly revered in the nonprofit and humanitarian world, which he entered in 1956 when he joined our Board to aid refugees fleeing from Hungary as Soviet tanks rolled into Budapest. From then on, John was key leader of the IRC, championing the cause of refugees and serving as our Board President from 1979 to 1985, as Board Chairman from 1991 to 2000 and finally as Chairman Emeritus. He was an extraordinarily generous donor and persuasive fundraiser whose efforts benefited millions of uprooted people worldwide. He led or participated in some 30 IRC delegations and fact-finding missions in conflict zones around the world, the most recent a 2008 trip to Jordan and Syria to investigate the plight of Iraqi refugees. We are grateful to John for his enormous contributions to the IRC and the cause of refugees. We express our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Cynthia; his daughters, Anne and Sarah; his son, J. Gregory; and his entire family. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board; Glenda Burkhart Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3

MacNEIL--Donna P. Donna MacNeil (1935-2015) died peacefully in the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Haven at Bellevue Hospital on February 7, 2015 after a long struggle with lung disease and breast cancer. She was 79 and had lived a varied and colorful life--as a fashion designer's model, avid reader, traveler, photographer, sailor, ballet enthusiast--and adored friend of many for her delicious wit and sweet disposition. She was born in Newark, NJ to Lucille Stagg, a nurse, and Pasquale (Pat) Nappi M.D., a gynecologist. He gave up his practice to serve as an Army doctor during World War 2, the family traveling to a series of military base towns, such as Enterprise, Alabama. Donna often attended several different schools in a year. After the war she attended Prospect Hill Country Day school in Newark, then studied for two years at Skidmore in Saratoga Springs, NY, before transferring to New York University. Graduating in 1956, Donna was accepted in the NYU PhD program in psychology but chose to work to help her first husband, David Powell, study to become a psychiatrist. Donna worked as a model for Monte Sano & Pruzan couturiers. A brief marriage to Thomas McGinley, a Wall Street institutional investor ended when he died in a car accident in Ireland. Donna then joined the Dior-trained French fashion designer, Jacques Tiffeau, winner of Coty Awards in 1960 and 1964. A "perfect six" size, Donna was first his design model, then general assistant. Later, she married Joseph Richards, who worked on the business side of The New Yorker, traveling extensively with him in Europe and Asia. After their divorce in 1984, she married Robert MacNeil, then co- anchor of The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour on PBS. A keen sailor from childhood, Donna cruised with him up the New England coast and bare-boated in the Caribbean. She also spent several years working as manager of Superlearning, a company selling materials to stimulate the mental states that enhance learning. She survived breast cancer in 2007 but was diagnosed afresh in 2013. She was also hospitalized four times for pneumonia. Donna is survived and mourned by her husband, known to friends as "Robin"; her sister, Carol Wenzel of Millville NJ; her niece Meg O'Callaghan of Rye NY; and her nephew, Gregory Wenzel of Ithaca, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later time. 1/3

BLOOM--Pauline (Paula). Devoted mother of Jack, Fredi and Robert. Proud grandmother of Allan (Suzanne), David (Randi), Carrie (Gary) and Tracy (David). Dear mother-in-law to Ginger and Marilyn. Loving great grandmother to Claire, Mia, Eliza, Logan, Samantha, Dylan, Lanie, Harlan, Gabby and Jack. Her great spirit, enthusiasm and intellect will be well remembered by all those who were fortunate enough to know her. Services at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills at 10am on Wednesday, February 11.

We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. The Board and Staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America

BENNETT--Elizabeth Simpson, poet and educator. Bryn Mawr College '54. Born October 16, 1932 to Rep. Kenneth Farrand Simpson and Helen Louise Knickerbacker Porter Simpson in New York City. Mrs. Bennett had lived many years in Washington, DC where her late husband, Robert Bennett, Jr. was Vice President of the Federal National Mortgage Corporation and President of the National Corporation for Housing Partnerships. She died on November 1, 2014 in San Francisco. Preceded in death by her son, Robert Porter Bennett, and her two sisters. Survived (in New York) by a brother, Dr. William Kelly Simpson, her sons and daughters-in-law; Mr. & Mrs. Bruce A. Bennett, Mrs. Cynthia Bennett of Cody, WY, Mr. & Mrs. Andrew R. Bennett, and her grandchildren, Robert Kelly Knickerbacker and John Porter Simpson Bennett all of San Francisco. COHEN--DANIEL Daniel B. Cohen, died February 9, 2015 at the age of 85. Born and raised in Bensonhurst and Palestine, Daniel joined the Israeli Air Force in 1948 to fight in the war for independence and afterward became a navigator for El Al. He returned to the U.S. to study geology at the University of Kansas and eventually moved back to New York, where he had an accomplished 30-year career at Segal & Co. A constant source of joy and comfort to his late wife, Fern, his children and grandchildren, his widow, Margery and her children, and to so many friends and family, Danny was generous, thoughtful, patient and wise, a man of uncommon decency who brought out the best in us. He was deeply cherished and will be sorely missed. Services: Wednesday, February 11, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 11:30 a.m.

WHITEHEAD--John C. Achim Moeller, Moeller Fine Art, is deeply saddened by the passing of John C. Whitehead. John represented what we all aspire to, a life of accomplishment that never sacrifices allegiance to a strong ethical and moral rectitude. It was my privilege to contribute to the creation of his magnificent art collection. Over thirty years, I saw his love for and knowledge of art grow, his collector's passion flourish, his pride in contributing to Haverford College and the collections of our greatest museums, his pleasure in being surrounded in his home by works he cherished. He was an exceptional man and will be profoundly missed. I send my sincere condolences to John's wife, Cynthia, and the entire Whitehead family. 1/3

John Whitehead's remarkable career was an inspiration to the students and community of Macaulay Honors College at CUNY, where he was an honorary director and recipient of an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters.
