FRUSHTICK--Steve, 65, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, February 8th at his home in Mamaroneck, NY. He succumbed to a heart attack while exercising. His family, friends and clients are shocked and heartbroken at the loss of this exceptional man. An accomplished marathon runner and loyal Knicks fan, equipped with a laser-like financial mind, Steve most of all cherished his family, including the newest addition, his granddaughter, Alice. In addition to Alice, he is survived by his loving wife Susan, sons Evan and Russ, parents Bill and Rita and sisters, Carol and Jill. A senior partner at the accounting firm Wiener Frushtick & Straub P.C., which merged with Shalik, Morris & Company, LLP this past January, Steve played a pivotal role in advising countless families, executives and entrepreneurs, in New York and nationwide. For the thousands of clients Steve served 24/7, he was more than a brilliant CPA. Steve was a confidant in the truest sense of the word, a veritable fount of knowledge and wisdom at the intersection of business and life. He delivered his financial and tax advice quickly, with the utmost in confidence and clarity. He was never shy in voicing his opinion, yet deeply human and humble. His love of life and its ironies was legendary, as was Steve's sense of humor, full of memorable adages and anecdotes, often shared via early morning salvos from his EFudd123 account. He will be sorely missed by family, friends and clients. His memory, spirit and stellar counsel will endure. Steve was laid to rest at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY on February 10th. For friends wanting to pay their respects, the family will be observing shiva at their home until February 15th. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The entire staff of Christie's America is saddened by the death of our friend and Advisory Board member John C. Whitehead. His knowledge, counsel and humor will be much missed within our firm and the wider New York community. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Marc Porter, Chairman; Stephen Lash, Chairman Emeritus. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America mourns the loss of Board Co-Chairman, Distinguished Eagle Scout John C. Whitehead. His thoughtful and generous leadership of NYC Scouting and Exploring has left an indelible mark on hundreds of thousands of NYC young people and their families. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. The Board and Staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America

MERYMAN--Richard, 88, a LIFE magazine writer who pioneered the art of taped interviews, died in Manhattan on February 5. By excising his questions, he created vividly candid magazine monologues by Marilyn Monroe, Laurence Olivier, Elizabeth Taylor, Charlie Chaplin, Louis Armstrong, and his life-long friend, Andrew Wyeth. Many interviews became books such as Andrew Wyeth: A Secret Life (1996). Raised in Dublin, NH, he graduated from Andover and Williams College, was an All-American lacrosse player, and a WWII Navy ensign. His first wife, artist Hope Brooks, died in 1975. He married Elizabeth Burns, an art consultant, in 1980. Along with his wife, he is survived by four children Meredith, Helena, Ned, Christopher and their spouses, and six beloved grandchildren. Plus innumerable friends-too many to count, much less name. A tribute will be held Saturday February 14, 3:30pm at 91 Horatio Street. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Honorary Trustee, John C. Whitehead. John was a leading force in the re-establishment of LCT, and his wise and gentle vision, combined with extraordinary powers of persuasion, made our Theater come alive again. He loved the theater, he loved our Theater, and we will miss his enthusiastic presence at all our shows. He was a man of warmth and grace, always willing to help. An old fashioned man in the best sense; a man of integrity; a great man. We extend our condolences to his wife Cynthia and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

BECK--Lorraine, passed away peacefully at home on February 9, 2015. Cherished mother of Susan Beck Champlin, her husband Jim, Stuart Beck, his wife Tulik, adored grandmother of Michael, Julie, Emma, Chip, Johanna, Sam, adoring great- grandmother of Josh, Ben, Jack, Coco, Indie and Henry. Beloved sister of Billie Ross. An avid bridge player, reader, knitter and a wonderful friend to all. We will miss her terribly. Services 10:30 Wednesday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. 1/3

KAHN--Anita Anna. Passed away peacefully at her New York City home on February 8, 2015. She was 94 years old. Anita was born in Jersey City on February 23, 1920 the daughter of Morris and Pauline Goretsky, Russian immigrants. Anita's father was a dry goods salesman and her mother was a seamstress. She met her future husband Arthur Edward Kahn, who became a prominent New York dentist, on a blind date. His father had been a candy store owner and his mother a housewife. After serving on an Air Force base in Texas during WWII, Anita and Arthur moved to Manhattan where he began his dental practice. Anita had been an art student at Temple University and during the 1950s she resumed her studies at The New School for Social Research as a student of Moses Soyer, Richard Pousette-Dart, and Anthony Toney. This rekindled interest in the arts led in the following decades to Anita and Arthur becoming art collectors and patrons of the arts. Anita was known for her beauty, flair for dressing, acumen, and her sharp wit. She is remembered by her daughters Robbie and Karen, her grandsons Levin and Matthew, and her great grandchildren Aziz, Aya, and Peyton. May Anita's memory be for a blessing. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Board and staff of the Council for Economic Education remember warmly and with gratitude our former Board member and long-time mentor and supporter. Nan J. Morrison, CEO and Barry Haimes, Board Chair. 1/3
WHITEHEAD--John. The Trustees of Common Good express their gratitude for the leadership and support of John Whitehead. Philip K. Howard, Chair 1/3

HORN--Judith H. beloved mother, grandmother, partner and friend passed away Sunday, February 8th. She was an educator and children's advocate for 40 years. She leaves behind her daughters, her grandchildren, her partner and countless children whose lives she has touched. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Blythedale Children's Hospital. 1/3

SKLAR--Rita (Gruber) on February 10, 2015, born August 24th 1924. Daughter of Goldie and Maxwell Gruber. Most devoted wife of the late Leo J. Sklar, M.D. Cherished mother of Susan Lerner; Peter and Joyce Sklar; Patty and Steven Greenstein. Beloved Nana of Caroline and David Perel; Gabrielle and Michael Keown; Keith and Michelle Sklar; Michele and Eric Levin; Matthew Greenstein; Vanessa and Alex Hughes. Adorning Gran-nana of Livia, Ethan and Charlotte Perel; Zoey Sklar; Aden Levin; Lea Greenstein and Bailey Hughes. Sister of Cy Gruber. Donations can be made to the charity of your choice. Services will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel on Wednesday February 11th 2015 at 1pm. Boulevard- Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. 1/3

ASH--Allan, of New York, NY passed away on February 8, 2015 after a noble fight against the ravages of age. Allan was born in the Bronx, NY on December 17, 1916 to Gussie and Nathan Ash. Allan graduated from the College of the City of New York with an undergraduate degree and a master's degree by the age of eighteen. He was a professor in the accounting department of the evening division of the College of the City of New York. He attained his CPA, joined an accounting firm and soon became a partner of the firm which is now known as Ash & Parsont LLP. He has been an integral part of that Firm for over 70 years. Allan was predeceased by his loving wife, Anita, and his daughter Jerilyn. He is survived by his son Joel and his wife Dawn, his grandson's Neil and his wife Cynthia, Gary and his wife Anna, and his granddaughter Kimberly and his great-grandchildren Austin, Andrew and Isabella. The funeral service will be held on Wednesday, February 11, 2015 at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, NY. 1/3

LINOWES--Dorothy Wolf, on Tuesday, February 10, 2015 in Chevy Chase, MD. Resident of Scarsdale for 39 years. Wife of the late David F. Linowes. Mother of Joanne (Lee David) Alinsky, Richard (Elisa) and Jonathan (Lisa) Linowes and the late Susan (surviving, Jeffrey) Linowes- Allen. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 13 in Washington, DC, with shiva following. Donations may be made to the David and Dorothy Linowes Philanthropic Fund at the Jewish Communal Fund. Mail to 5630 Wisconsin Ave., #

PARISE--Andrew J.,90, of Cedarhurst, NY, on February 8, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of Andrew Jr. (Deborah), Louise Bencal, and David (Mary Lynn). Cherished grandfather of Kristen (Gordon), Robert (Emily), Jamie (Josh), Erica (Alex), Jessica (Devin), and great grandfather to Courtney, Brooke, Page, Mia and Maddie. Loving Companion of JoMarie. WWII 87th Infantry Battle of the Bulge Veteran. Awarded two Purple Hearts. Mayor of Cedarhurst for the past 20 years. Retired Town of Hempstead Executive Assistant to seven presiding Supervisors and Executive leader of Lawrence-Cedarhurst Republican Party since the early 1960s. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at the Perry Funeral Home Inc., 118 Union Ave., Lynbrook, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 10am at St. Joachims RC Church, Cedarhurst, NY. Interment to follow at Greenfield Cemetery, Hempstead, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in Andrews name can be made to: The Lawrence High School Scholarship Fund; Cedarhurst Memorial Park Fund; Wounded Warriors Fund. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The entire FSVC global family mourns the loss of John Whitehead, our Chairman, who passed away at age 92. He was an extraordinary human being, and we are most fortunate to have had his leadership at FSVC from the organization's very beginning. John Whitehead co- founded FSVC with former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance in 1990, and together they imbued the organization with its mission to help build sound financial systems in transition and emerging market countries. Their vision has led directly to more than 8,500 experts from the international financial, legal and regulatory communities taking part in more than 2,700 FSVC missions, reaching 35,000 counterparts in over 50 emerging market countries. The world has lost a great statesman and civic giant. We have lost our leader and a true friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Whitehead family, and will honor John Whitehead's legacy by continuing this important work. John L Walker, Vice Chairman, and J Andrew Spindler, President and CEO, on behalf of the Board of Directors of the Financial Services Volunteer Corps. 1/3

ALBERT--Sidney. Sidney Albert, of blessed memory, passed away on February 5 while walking near his home in Manhattan with his devoted wife of 50 years, Sara Albert. Beloved father of Jeff (Anjum) and grandfather of Musa. Served his country in the Pacific Theatre of World War II as a Pilot in the US Army Air Corps. He will be deeply missed. Donations may be made to the Aquaya Institute at: info@aquaya.org 1/3
KRAMER--Barbara. We remember Barbara Kramer who died 2/11/2013. Beloved by family, friends and pets alike, we'll never forget you. 1/3

SHAPELL--David. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, David Shapell. Mr. Shapell was a passionate supporter of Israel and the Jewish people. He was devoted to Holocaust remembrance and education. Though we have lost an inspiring advocate and valued International Board and President's Circle member, David will be long remembered through his exceptional contributions to the Weizmann Institute: the David and Fela Shapell Family Holocaust Memorial Plaza, the David and Fela Shapell Family Institute for Preclinical Studies at the Nancy and Stephen Grand Israel National Center for Personalized Medicine, and the David and Fela Shapell Family Center for Genetic Disorders Research. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Fela; his daughter Rochelle Shapell and son-in-law Lorne Buchman, son Benjamin and daughter-in-law Susan Shapell, and son Irvin and daughter-in-law Kathy Shapell; to his grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. May David's memory be for a blessing. Ellen Merlo, Chair, American Committee Dr. Jay A. Levy, President, American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive Vice President & CEO, American Committee Janis Rabin, Executive Director, Southern California Region Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President, Weizmann Institute of Science Abraham Ben-Naftali, Chair, International Board 1/3

SHAPELL--David. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of David Shapell, one of the original Visionaries of the Society and Vice Chair of the West Coast region. David was born in Wolbrom, Poland and lost most of his family during the Holocaust. After the war, David met Fela in Germany and they were married there. Together they moved to the United States and had three children, Rochelle, Benjamin and Irvin. David Shapell was dedicated to the mission of Holocaust remembrance and was a steadfast partner and patron of Yad Vashem. The Visitors Center at Yad Vashem was established thanks to the generosity of David and Fela Shapell, as well as a Study Center in the museum. They recently gave the inaugural donation to build a new Art, Artifacts and Archive Repository at Yad Vashem. We send our heartfelt condolences to Fela and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Honorary Trustee, John C. Whitehead. John was a leading force in the re-establishment of LCT, and his wise and gentle vision, combined with extraordinary powers of persuasion, made our Theater come alive again. He loved the theater, he loved our Theater, and we will miss his enthusiastic presence at all our shows. He was a man of warmth and grace, always willing to help. An old fashioned man in the best sense; a man of integrity; a great man. We extend our condolences to his wife Cynthia and his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

EISENBUD--David Elliot, MD died on February 6th, 2015. Born on October 22, 1954, he was a Vascular Surgeon and Certified Wound Specialist. David was a graduate of the Pingry School, he received a BA Cum Laude from Yale University, an MA in Organic Chemistry from the University of Chicago, his MD from the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine and a MBA from New York University Stern School of Business. David was a Vascular Surgeon at Beth Israel Hospital, Newark for many years and was the former Director of the Wound Care Center at Overlook Hospital, Summit, NJ. He was the former president and COO of Advanced Biohealing Incorporated and past President of the American Academy of Wound Management. He was currently the Managing Partner at the Millburn Surgical Associates and Chief Medical Officer at CoDa Therapeutics Incorporated. Love and missed by sons, Evan and Matthew, sister Leslie Eisenbud Quint, MD and his mother June.

FOLEY--Adrian M. "Bud," Jr.,one of New Jersey's leading lawyers for six decades, died at home in Essex Fells surrounded by his family on February 9, 2015, three weeks after his 93rd birthday. Born on a farm in Bartlett, North Dakota, he moved as a child to New Jersey where he attended his beloved St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, went on to graduate cum laude from Seton Hall University, and after the war received his law degree from Columbia University. A decorated veteran of World War II he was a B-24 navigator in the United States Army Air Corps who flew missions over the Mediterranean, Baltic and European theaters. He was awarded the Air Medal with three oak leaf clusters, the Presidential Unit Citation with two oak leaf clusters, and five battle stars. Bud married his college sweetheart Mary Malone in 1945 and until her death in 2005 they were inseparable. Friends fondly referred to the dynamic couple by one name: "BudandMary." Adrian Foley lived a life of remarkable accomplishment without sacrificing his firmly held religious beliefs or the ethical responsibilities of his legal profession. With his extraordinary power of persuasion, combined with his wise vision, his life defined the concept of thoughtful leadership. He was a man of warmth and grace who could never say no to any call for help without hesitation. Bud's brand of storytelling was always a source of delight, especially to his grandchildren. Self-deprecation was a favorite theme. About himself he would say: "Frequently in error; never in doubt!" Writing in a New York Times article Richard Reeves called Adrian Foley one of the 15 most powerful men in New Jersey, "one who generally turns up on one side or the other in all major legal disputes affecting New Jersey." A New Jersey Monthly article called him "probably the most powerful lawyer in New Jersey." He coyly referred to both of these pieces as works of fanciful fiction. Adrian represented everything that was good in public life. Active in all facets of the Bar he was the youngest President of the New Jersey Bar Association, and the youngest elected Surrogate in the State of New Jersey. He served for many years as the state delegate to the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association and was elected to the ABA's Board of Governors. He was the tenth chair of the Litigation Section of the ABA and chaired many ABA committees including the first to permit lawyer advertising. He served as a Director of the American Judicature Society and was a permanent delegate to the Third Circuit Judicial Conference. He was also a fellow of the American College of Trial Attorneys and a Fellow of the American College of Estate and Trust Counsel. He was honored by the New Jersey Commission on Excellence in Law with the Justice Daniel O'Hern Award in recognition of his commitment to professionalism and his outstanding career and achievement in service to the Bar. Governor Richard J. Hughes appointed Adrian to preside as President of the New Jersey Constitutional Convention in 1966. Governor William Cahill appointed him the first treasurer and chief financial officer of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Governor Brendan Byrne reappointed him to that position. Together with Sports Authority Chairman Sonny Werblin, he was instrumental in devising a bond issue that generated the funds for construction of Giants Stadium and the Meadowlands Race Track. This was no small feat, given the fierce political opposition from New York City and State officials that fought to keep the Giants from moving across the Hudson River. Adrian also served on the Board of Overseers of Seton Hall University's Immaculate Conception Seminary for over a decade. He was a Member of the Board of Visitors of Columbia University Law School and a Trustee of Seton Hall University. He was the first recipient of the All University Award granted by Seton Hall and the first recipient of the Saint Benedict's Prep Medal and also elected to St. Benedict's Athletic Hall of Fame. He received an honorary PhD degree from St. Peter's College. He was a Knight of Malta and received a Medal of Service from the Archdiocese of Newark for whom he served as legal counsel for many years. He was a lector, Eucharistic Minister and daily communicant at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church in Roseland. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of Prudential Insurance Company for many years where he chaired the Finance Committee. In addition to his professional and social service, Bud was the past president of the New Jersey State Golf Association and a Trustee of the Essex Fells Country Club where he was a member for 57 years. He was also a member of the Skeeters Club in New York City. Adrian Foley was a partner in the Connell Foley law firm for 56 years. His knowledge, counsel and humor will be sorely missed by his lifelong friends and colleagues at the Firm, his second family. He is survived by his devoted children Adrian M. Foley III (Lindy) of Duncan, S.C, Dianne Foley of Shaker Heights, OH, Corinne Errico (Robert) of Short Hills, and Christopher Foley (Jenny) of Apharetta, GA; by his 13 cherished grandchildren; and by his 10 loving great-grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited for visiting hours on Friday, February 13th at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church, 28 Livingston Avenue, Roseland, NJ from 3:00pm to 9:00pm. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday February 14th, 10:00am in the church with entombment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in East Hanover. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Saint Benedict's Preparatory School, 520 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd., Newark, NJ 07102. www.sbp.org.

MOORE--Douglas Keith, of Leonia, NJ; born 1953, in New York City, died February 11, 2015. Doug was the loving and beloved husband of Neva Schneier Moore, whom he met at 16 when they attended Franklin School in Manhattan. Doug was the devoted father of Jared Bryan Moore and his wife, Caitlin. Doug's greatest joy in life was his family for whom he fought a courageous and determined battle to survive after a heart attack in September of 2014. Doug was the son of Elaine Moore and Sanford Earl Moore (deceased). He was the brother of Cathy Lynn Moore (Stephen T. Gheen) (Durham, NC), Leanne Moore (Richard Gumer) (New York City) and Ross Moore (Beth Allen Moore) (Old Greenwich, CT). He was the brother-in-law of Mike and Jane Schneier, Roger and Faye Schneier and Stephanie and Ira Rubin. He leaves behind nine nieces and nephews. Doug was a managing director and the senior planner in the U.S. Trust Family Office Group. He was a nationally recognized expert in his field; has written over sixty professional articles; served as a co- chairperson of the Estate Planning and Taxation Committee on the advisory editorial board of Trusts & Estates magazine; and has lectured before various professional groups. Memorial services will be on February 13, 2015, at 1pm at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York. RILEY--Allan J. a prominent real estate investor who for a time owned One Time Square amongst othe properties in the United States and Britain, a patron of the arts and benefactor of the University of Notre Dame, died on Thursday, February 5th, at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old. The youngest of three brothers, Allan was born on July 18th 1935 in Indianapolis, Indiana. He attended Catholic High Schools in Cleveland and Chicago as well as Indianapolis and graduated with honors in 1957 from the University of Notre Dame where he majored in English and Speech. He studied Performing Arts at Stanford University and served two years in the Air Force. In 1964 he moved to New York City to join William A. White Real Estate Company. In the early seventies, he established his own real estate firm, now called Allan Riley Realty, Inc. Mr. Riley is survived by his wife of 30 years, Radwan Jabbour Riley, and by his brother William. He is predeceased by his father Leo, his mother Edna and his older brother Eugene. One of Mr. Riley's passions was 19th Century British and American paintings and drawings which he loaned to various museums. For the past eight years he served on the board of the Smithsonian American Art Museum. His other passions included fishing and travel. Mr. Riley's many contributions to Notre Dame include the University's Center for the Fine Arts. In 1982, he donated funds for the renovation of a former chemistry building which was renamed Riley Hall in honor of his parents, Leo and Edna. Allan and his wife fund annual student endowment awards in the fields of design, art history, studio art, and photography at the university. He sat on the board of the University's Snite Museum of Art. Some of his permanent gifts to the museum include a portrait painting by Joshua Reynolds and a landscape painting by Louis Remy Mignot. In 2002, Mr. and Mrs. Riley funded the purchase of 40 British drawings from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries that remain part of the Museum's Riley Collection. Mr. Riley was an avid fan of Notre Dame and maintained season box seats at the University's stadium. Mr. and Mrs. Riley support the International Theological Institute in Vienna. Allan was an active board member at the institute. He also served on the boards of various charities including Save the Children and Lincoln Hall Boys Haven in Somers, NY. He and his wife resided in both Manhattan and New Canaan, CT. 1/3

FRIEDENTHAL--Esther, MD, 95, died on January 22, 2015 in her home in Whitestone, NY. Born in Lodz, Poland, she traveled across wartime Germany from the Warsaw ghetto to Brussels, Belgium, to continue her medical studies, and later to Montpelier, in Vichy France, finally arriving in the United States in 1941, to join her father, Boruch Shefner, a prominent Yiddish journalist in Poland and columnist and co-editor of the Jewish Daily Forward in New York City. She graduated from Wayne State University Medical School in 1946, and served as intern and resident in pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital in New York City, where she met her future husband Dr. Meyer Friedenthal. She later switched to radiation oncology where, at Montefiore Hospital and the Einstein School of Medicine she made significant contributions in the field of cancer therapy using microwave technology. A tireless and dedicated physician, she was loved and admired by her colleagues and patients alike. She is pre-deceased by her father Boruch, and stepmother Helena Shefner, her beloved twin sister Meri Nowogrodzki, and nephew Richard Nowogrodzki. She is survived by two sons, Robert Sage, of Boston, MA, and George Friedenthal, of Santa Barbara, CA, and two granddaughters, Linnea and Ariane Nicole Sage. She will be lovingly remembered by all who knew her.

FLUG--Martin Raphael, beloved father, grandfather, son, brother and husband, and an entrepreneur and business leader in New York and Colorado since the early 1960s. Died at home in Aspen, Colo., on February 10, 2015. Son of the late Samuel S. Flug and the late Evelyn R. Flug of Brooklyn, NY. Born January 6, 1931, in Brooklyn. He graduated from Harvard College (1952), Yale Law School (1955), and Harvard Business School (1957). A winter visitor to Aspen since 1963, he has lived there since 1979. He was the husband of Sarah Kennedy Flug; the father of Jeremy J. Flug of Denver and Eliza Flug of Seattle; grandfather of Matthew, William, Benjamin and Henry Flug of Denver and Lauren Coburn of Seattle; father-in-law of Angela Murray Flug of Denver; and brother of James F. Flug of Washington DC, Barbara Flug Colin of Roslyn Estates, N.Y., the late Robert K. Flug of Portland, Ore., and Victoria Flug Sterling of Denver. At his death he was co-chairman of the Board of Gulftech International, Inc., of Aspen, a group of five companies that design, manufacture and lease food-processing equipment. A natural entrepreneur, he often told the story of his first serious business venture, when, on his way to enroll in Harvard, he got sidetracked and used his tuition money to buy the first Boston dealership for the then unheard-of Vespa Motor Scooter. The business was a great success, as he foresaw (and he still enrolled in Harvard that semester on a scholarship). The energy and vision and restless intelligence he showed in his business ventures also extended to his varied civic, charitable and educational activities, including Trustee of the Aspen Center for Physics, Life Trustee of the Aspen Music Festival and School, Benefactor of the Martin R. Flug Professorship of International Law, the Ernest Rubenstein Scholarship and the Samuel S. Flug Memorial Scholarship, all at Yale Law School, and of the Samuel S. and Evelyn R. Flug Scholarship Fund at Harvard College, Past Board Member and Officer of the Aspen Country Day School, Past Chairman of United Way of Rye, NY, Past President of Manursing Island Club, NY. In honor of his mother and his own dedication to childrens education, he founded and supported the Evelyn R. Flug Childrens Library in Aspen, and a private foundation to support experiments in education. But a simple--even if impressively lengthy--list of boards and titles does not capture his deep involvement and commitment to causes and activities he cared about. In Aspen, inspired by his early friendship with local newspaper publisher Bil Dunaway, Martin Flug reveled in mountain life with the same intensity he brought to all his endeavors. He bicycled all summer, including his iconic rides in Aspen's Fourth of July parades, dressed in an Uncle Sam suit. He skied with abandon every winter and was an early aficionado of uphill skiing, long before it enjoyed its current wave of popularity--skiing up Buttermilk and then descending with glee. His skiing adventures extended to heli-skiing in Canada, where (as he loved to tell the story) he once brought an end to a season-long snow drought by leading his skiing party in an American Indian rain chant. At home in Aspen, his hospitality extended to a lengthy list of artists and intellects, most especially the musicians of the Aspen Music Festival and physicists visiting the Aspen Center for Physics. 1/3

GOLDSCHMID--Harvey J. Columbia Law School Prof. Harvey J. Goldschmid, a renowned corporate governance expert who served as a commissioner and the top attorney at the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and played a key role in implementing one of the most sweeping federal securities laws in U.S. history, died on February 12. He was 74. A beloved professor and mentor to generations of Columbia law students, Goldschmid was a two-time recipient of the Willis L.M. Reese Prize for Excellence in Teaching. He described his classroom philosophy in a 2013 interview, explaining that the most important part of teaching was "to think about not only what the law is, which students need to know, but what it ought to be." Goldschmid was a dedicated public servant. He served as general counsel of the SEC from 1998 to 1999, as special senior adviser to then Chairman Arthur Levitt in 2000, and as an influential commissioner for the agency from 2002 to 2005. "Very rarely in life do you meet a scholar and government official who both makes great contributions to public policy and is a good man. In my lifetime, I have never met one who was the equal of Harvey J. Goldschmid," Joel Seligman wrote in Columbia Law Review. Goldschmid's term began just after the passage of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, a law that aimed to improve the quality of corporate financial reporting. He served during some of the most tumultuous times in the agency's history, as regulators and legislators called for stricter controls for public companies. He was a strong advocate for shareholders and defended the agencys efforts to curtail corporate fraud. "As a sometime historian of the Commission," Seligman wrote, "I am confident that he has become the most influential SEC Commissioner who did not become a Chair in the agency's history. Since this is an agency that has been blessed with extraordinary Commissioners, I mean this encomium as the highest possible praise." A New York native, Goldschmid was born into a working-class family in the Bronx in 1940. In moving testimony before the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs during his confirmation process in 2002, Goldschmid spoke about his family and their influence on him. "My parents believed in our financial markets, and, because of Social Security and their investments, retired to a relatively comfortable life in Florida," he said. "Our nation, as this Committee has indicated, is now witnessing the most dramatic business scandals that have occurred during my professional life. On a very personal level, I feel the pain of the retirees and the investors whose futures have been jeopardized." After his service at the agency, Goldschmid remained an influential voice in economic policy. After the financial collapse of 2008, he advocated strongly for the creation of a systemic risk agency. In 2012, he was named to the resulting Systemic Risk Council. Goldschmid, served as counsel to Weil, Gotshal &Manges until his death. He was a prolific writer in the fields of corporate, securities, and antitrust law. He also served as a consultant on antitrust policy to the FTC, a member of its Task Force on High Tech/Innovation Issues, a public governor and chair of the Regulatory Policy Committee of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, a trustee of the International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation, a director of the National Center on Philanthropy and the Law, a director of Transparency International-USA, and as a vice chair of the Center for Audit Quality. Goldschmid was a magna cum laude graduate of both Columbia College and Columbia Law School. After law school, he clerked for Judge Paul Hays of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit and then practiced law at Debevoise & Plimpton. He joined the Columbia Law Faculty in 1970. He is survived by his wife Mary and his three children, Charles, Paul, and Joseph, each of whom earned a J.D. degree at Columbia Law School. Funeral services will be held privately. A memorial service is planned at Columbia Law School. Donations in his memory are being directed to the Columbia Law School Annual Fund. Our hearts are heavy with the weight of this great loss.

RAIA--Liliana, 86, of Brooklyn, NY, residing with her daughter Camille and family in Ridgewood at the time of her passing on Tuesday, February 10th. Born in Milan, Italy where, after obtaining her Doctorate in French, she taught French in Milan. After she married her husband, she moved to Brooklyn, NY where she was dedicated to raising their family. Beloved wife of 59 years of Anthony M. Raia, MD. Loving mother of Joseph Raia and Camille Raia. Cherished grandmother of Julia, Peter and Anthony M. Rondos and Anthony J. Raia. A devoted Catholic, Liliana was a parishioner of St. Anselm RC Church in Bay Ridge, NY. Family and friends may visit Thursday, 4-8pm at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ. Funeral Mass Friday, 10:30am at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, 1 Passaic St., Ridgewood. Burial will follow at Maryrest Cemetery in Mahwah. Information and condolences available at www.feeneyfuneralhome.com.

GOLDMAN--Dorothy S. April 29, 1922--February 11, 2015. Devoted wife of 71 years to Erwin R. Goldman. Loving mother to daughter Amy Goldman and Karl Janowitz, sons Roger Goldman and Fern Portnoy, and Sam Goldman. Loving matriarch to Jodi Goldman, Cindi Goldman-Patin, Jenni Ackerman, Lee Leibowitz, Jake Goldman and Ben Goldman. Adoring and adored great- grandmother of Emily and Nate Ackerman, Hannah and Adam Leibowitz, and Max and Leo Siegmeister. Impressive grandmother-in-law to Richard Siegmeister, Carrol Patin, David Ackerman, and Melissa Leibowitz. Amazing sister-in-law to Ricki Marks and Louis Goldman. Exceptional aunt to Lydia and Emily Strong, Andy Marks, Liz Salston, Mindi Faigen, and Lisa Grayson. Friend, volunteer, supporter, and lover of her family, friends, and the arts. Crusader for social justice before it was fashionable. On the way to the hospital, she announced to one and all, that she had just had the best weekend of her life. The only thing that mattered to her was her family. When her vision narrowed due to macular degeneration, she never stopped trying to make her world bigger. Funeral services will be Friday morning at Central Funeral Home, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ. 201-945-032 for time. Shiva Sunday and Monday at the Goldman residence. Donations in her memory can be made to United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C. 1/3

GOLDSTONE--Susan, of Little Compton, RI, died on Wednesday, February 11th, 2015, in New York City at age 70. Susan was the beloved wife of Arthur, the cherished mother of Andrew and Thomas, the revered "second mother" to daughters-in-law Shanna and Jennifer, the much adored grandmother of Max, Oliver and Charles, and the darling sister of Cynthia. Susan was a graduate of the Kent Place School in Summit, NJ, and Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA. Arthur and Susan were married on June 9th, 1966, in New York City, where they also raised their children. Her family was her first devotion and the members of her family became her muses for her artistic passion: photography. Susan felt truly "at home" in her two favorite places - Little Compton, Rhode Island, and Santa Fe, New Mexico. In lieu of flowers, Susan requested that donations be made to the Susan T. Goldstone Fund at The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, 555 Long Wharf Drive, New Haven, CT 06511. Services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday, February 18th, 2015, at 11:30am. Interment will occur in Union Cemetery in Little Compton in the spring.

KLEIN--Edith. Mindy Shapiro and Jeffrey Simmons are saddened by the passing of Edith Klein. Her quiet strength, perseverance and cholent will be missed. We extend our sympathy to her family and loved ones.

EISEN--Dr. Audrey, who was dedicated to the persuit of knowledge, loved travel, fine wine and food, theater and interesting people, passed away from Alzheimer's Disease peacefully in Hospice care on February 9, 2015. Mother to Jill, Susan & Marc Weisberg, daughter of the late William and Marcia Eisenberg of Brooklyn, sister of Mitchell Eisenberg. Audrey was a professor in the Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences program at Hofstra University, and a Director of The Department's Graduate Program for many years. She will miss New York City and the city will miss her.

MANICE--Beatrice Goelet, of New York City, Newport, RI, and Sandricourt, France, died at home in New York City on February 10, 2015, surrounded by her family, after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's disease. She was born in Arcachon, France, on September 4, 1922, and grew up in France and the United States. Predeceased by her parents, Robert W. Goelet and Anne-Marie Guestier Goelet, by her husband Hayward F. Manice, and by her brother, Francis Goelet, she is survived by a large and loving family: John H. Manice (Anne), Anne de La Haye Jousselin (Edmond), Robert G. Manice (Heidi), Amelia M. Berkowitz (Mortimer) and Pamela H. Manice, as well as 14 grandchildren and 12 great grandchildren. She is also survived by her brothers, Robert G. Goelet and John Goelet, and their families. She was a loving daughter, devoted wife, beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. She was an ardent and quiet supporter of educational, medical and conservation-related institutions in the United States and France. A funeral service will be held at 1:30pm on Friday, February 13th, 2015 at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, 66th Street and Lexington Avenue, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to your favorite charity.

SHRADY--Henry Merwin III, 1936-2015. Age 78, died at home in Snedens Landing, New York, after a long struggle with cancer, his beloved wife Gale Barrett Shrady, by his side. Born in Paris to expatriate parents, he followed the artistic path of his father, Frederick C. Shrady, and his grandfather and namesake, Henry M. Shrady, both sculptors. A graduate of San Francisco Art Institute and Columbia University, he was a sculptor, painter; film production designer; and restorer of old buildings and houses. He was always an energetic optimistic with endless ideas of things to fix and build. He never saw an old wreck of a house, or boat or car that he didn't love. He played polo, skied and sailed. A proud New Yorker and East Village resident, Mr. Shrady was the first President of the First Street Block Association, Honorary Trustee of the New York City Marble Cemetery and, until recent illnesses, a member of the St. Nicholas Society and The Century Association. His family will remember him for his enthusiastic storytelling, improvisational piano playing, passionate political discussions, bow ties and many adventures on land and sea. Mr. Shrady will be greatly missed by friends and family including his wife, his children Pierre Shrady (Mary) of Koln, Germany, and Francesca Shrady (Paul) of Santa Fe; his stepchildren Katherine Kavanagh (Keith) and Colleen Kavanagh (Noel) of Manhattan, and Matthew Kavanagh (Hilary) of Johannesburg, South Africa; nine grandchildren; and his dachshund, Pepper. A memorial celebration will be held in early Spring.

ERDEL--Florence S.,age 98, daughter of the late Charles and Goldie Storich, sister of the late Albert Storich, dearly beloved mother of Jeffrey Erdel and his wife Barbara, cherished grandmother of Stephanie (and husband Mark) and Corey, proud and doting great-grandmother of Emma and Michael. Also survived by caring sister Gloria Triffleman and many loving nieces, nephews and cousins. Florence served for 27 years as Executive Secretary to the late Alex Rose, legendary founder of The Liberal Party and President of The Headwear Union. She will be missed and remembered by family and friends and all who knew her --a special individual, impossible to forget. She will live in our hearts forever. 1/3

O'CONNOR--Robert Hartley, 90, of Bronxville and Shelter Island, NY died on January 14, 2015 in Bronxville. He is survived by his wife of nearly 65 years, Julia Sturges O'Connor; children Sandra O'Connor, Russell O'Connor, and Linda Casertano; sons-in-law Edwin Hydeman and Drew Casertano; grandsons Alexander (Renee Bissell), Tyler (Annie), and William Casertano. Born in Kansas City, MO to A.H. O'Connor and Mildred M. O'Connor, he attended Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, NJ; entered Yale with the class of '45W; served in the Navy aboard destroyer escorts in WWII; and graduated from Yale in 1948. He had a 30-year career in sales and marketing with IBM. Funeral service Saturday, February 28, at 1:00pm at Christ Church, Bronxville. 1/3

LOMASNEY--Irina. Irina Chavchavadze Lomasney, 23 April 1920--10 February 2015, formerly Princess Irina Borisovna Chavchavadze, wife of Myron (Kim) Arms Lomasney and daughter of the late Duke Dimitri and Duchess Catherine Leuchtenberg de Beauharnais, passed away in Montreal in her 95th year. The funeral was held at St. Peter and St. Paul Russian Orthodox Church in Montreal QC on Friday, February 13th, 2015. Burial will take place on Monday, February 16th at 11:00am at the Russian Orthodox Convent Novo-Deveevo, 100 Smith Road, Nanuet NY. During World War II, Irina served as a Lt (N) Women's Royal Naval Service (WRENS) Special Branch. After the war, she married Kim, and settled in New York City and Long Island, NY. Irina was an avid skier and tennis player. Fluent in five languages, she was always elegant, amusing, charming, and had a good sense of humor. Irina was closely connected to the White Russian Diaspora in US, Canada and Europe. She was active with several charities including the Tolstoy Foundation, and was a co- founder of the Petroushka Ball in support of the Russian Children's Welfare Society. Irina is survived by her children Peter, Elena, Nicholas, four grand children, and three great-grandchildren. Many thanks to the kind and considerate staff at the Fulford Residence in Montreal where she was wonderfully cared for by the kind and considerate staff. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Fulford Residence, 1221 Guy Street, Montreal H3H 2K8 http://fulfordresidence.com/ contact.htm. Thanks also to the doctors and staff at the Jewish General Hospital in Montreal for their care and kindness during her last two weeks. 1/3

VANCE--Gordon R.,of Manhattan passed away at home Wednesday, February 11, 2015. Born June 14, 1926, in Plainfield, NJ, he was a lifelong lover of nature and birdwatcher. He also loved woodworking and carpentry projects; he pursued these passions at his home in Davis Park, Fire Island. After serving as a combat infantryman in WWII, Gordon received his degree in architecture from Pratt Institute. He began his career at the architecture firm of Harrison & Abramovitz in New York, before going to work for the United Nations, where he became head of facilities. His projects at the UN took him all over the world, including Africa, South America and Europe. He leaves behind Susan, beloved wife of 56 years, devoted daughter Kathleen and son-in-law John, adored grandchildren Julia and Dinah, and many friends and family.

FLUG--Martin Raphael, beloved father, grandfather, son, brother and husband, and an entrepreneur and business leader in New York and Colorado since the early 1960s. Died at home in Aspen, Colo., on February 10, 2015. Son of the late Samuel S. Flug and the late Evelyn R. Flug of Brooklyn, NY. Born January 6, 1931, in Brooklyn. He graduated from Harvard College (1952), Yale Law School (1955), and Harvard Business School (1957). A winter visitor to Aspen since 1963, he has lived there since 1979. He was the husband of Sarah Kennedy Flug; the father of Jeremy J. Flug of Denver and Eliza Flug of Seattle; grandfather of Matthew, William, Benjamin and Henry Flug of Denver and Lauren Coburn of Seattle; father-in-law of Angela Murray Flug of Denver; and brother of James F. Flug of Washington DC, Barbara Flug Colin of Roslyn Estates, N.Y., the late Robert K. Flug of Portland, Ore., and Victoria Flug Sterling of Denver. At his death he was co-chairman of the Board of Gulftech International, Inc., of Aspen, a group of five companies that design, manufacture and lease food-processing equipment. A natural entrepreneur, he often told the story of his first serious business venture, when, on his way to enroll in Harvard, he got sidetracked and used his tuition money to buy the first Boston dealership for the then unheard-of Vespa Motor Scooter. The business was a great success, as he foresaw (and he still enrolled in Harvard that semester on a scholarship). The energy and vision and restless intelligence he showed in his business ventures also extended to his varied civic, charitable and educational activities, including Trustee of the Aspen Center for Physics, Life Trustee of the Aspen Music Festival and School, Benefactor of the Martin R. Flug Professorship of International Law, the Ernest Rubenstein Scholarship and the Samuel S. Flug Memorial Scholarship, all at Yale Law School, and of the Samuel S. and Evelyn R. Flug Scholarship Fund at Harvard College, Past Board Member and Officer of the Aspen Country Day School, Past Chairman of United Way of Rye, NY, Past President of Manursing Island Club, NY. In honor of his mother and his own dedication to childrens education, he founded and supported the Evelyn R. Flug Childrens Library in Aspen, and a private foundation to support experiments in education. But a simple--even if impressively lengthy--list of boards and titles does not capture his deep involvement and commitment to causes and activities he cared about. In Aspen, inspired by his early friendship with local newspaper publisher Bil Dunaway, Martin Flug reveled in mountain life with the same intensity he brought to all his endeavors. He bicycled all summer, including his iconic rides in Aspen's Fourth of July parades, dressed in an Uncle Sam suit. He skied with abandon every winter and was an early aficionado of uphill skiing, long before it enjoyed its current wave of popularity--skiing up Buttermilk and then descending with glee. His skiing adventures extended to heli-skiing in Canada, where (as he loved to tell the story) he once brought an end to a season-long snow drought by leading his skiing party in an American Indian rain chant. At home in Aspen, his hospitality extended to a lengthy list of artists and intellects, most especially the musicians of the Aspen Music Festival and physicists visiting the Aspen Center for Physics. 1/3

MERYMAN--Richard, 88, a LIFE magazine writer who pioneered the art of taped interviews, died in Manhattan on February 5. By excising his questions, he created vividly candid magazine monologues by Marilyn Monroe, Laurence Olivier, Elizabeth Taylor, Charlie Chaplin, Louis Armstrong, and his life-long friend, Andrew Wyeth. Many interviews became books such as Andrew Wyeth: A Secret Life (1996). Raised in Dublin, NH, he graduated from Andover and Williams College, was an All-American lacrosse player, and a WWII Navy ensign. His first wife, artist Hope Brooks, died in 1975. He married Elizabeth Burns, an art consultant, in 1980. Along with his wife, he is survived by four children Meredith, Helena, Ned, Christopher and their spouses, and six beloved grandchildren. Plus innumerable friends-too many to count, much less name. A tribute will be held Saturday February 14, 3:30pm at 91 Horatio Street. 1/3

TASH--Martin, passed away February 8, 2015 of Boca Raton, Fl, formerly of Dix Hills, NY. Loving husband of Arlene to whom he was married almost 53 years. Beloved brother of Harriet (Arnold) Rosenberg and Betty Tash. Adored father of Faye Tash and Jill Wrubel. Cherished grandfather of Leah Purvis, Marissa Wrubel and Michael Wrubel. Martin Tash was retired from Plenum Publishing Company where he was President and Chairman of the Board. Services were held at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton. 1/3

BARSHOP--Ruth Mirer, 95 years old, died on February 11, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted and loving mother of Ronald and Leslie Barshop and Jill and Neil Molberger. Cherished grandmother of Allison, Ryan and Jenny, Megan and Benny, Matthew and Timna, Benjamin, and Jaimee. Dearest great-grandmother of Anneliesse, Liam and Maya. Funeral services Friday, 12 Noon at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. A celebration of her life will be announced at a later date.

GUNTHER--Corinne Dorf, of Basking Ridge, NJ. passed away on February 9th. She was a beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Born in Baltimore, MD in 1925, she was married to Edward Gunther for 65 years before his passing in 2012. Corinne taught first grade and coached girls' high school athletics at the Waldorf school in Garden City, NY. Her calling to serve resulted in many accomplishments. She was Executive Director of the Visiting Health Services of Morris County, NJ, Vice Chairman of the Human Services Advisory Council, Chairman of the New Jersey Home Care Committee for the White House Conference on Aging, Board member of First Call for Help, Past President of NORWESCAP, which oversees 54 action service programs, past President of the Morris County League of Women Voters and of Zonta International, a worldwide service for women executives. Adored, respected and inspired by all who knew her, she is survived by daughter Stephanie Shnay (husband Abram) grandchildren Scott Shnay (wife Haesther) Kate Termini (husband John) great grandson Harley Shnay and sister Marjorie Jaffe. Services are private and, should you wish, kindly make donations in Corinne's name to a charity of your choice. Services are by J. L. Apter Memorial Chapels of Somerville, (908)575-1800.

HALPERN--Marvin. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the passing of our longtime member Marvin Halpern. We extend condolences to his wife Sandra and to the entire Halpern family. Rabbi Matthew Futterman Richard Holland, President
FOLEY--Adrian M.,Jr. The members of The Skeeters mourn the loss of their colleague and friend, Bud Foley, and send their condolences to his family. 1/3

STEIGMAN--Margot Robinson on February 8, 2015. Beloved sister of the late Libby Robinson. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Joseph Steigman. Cherished friend and inspiration for so many others along her road to 100. Funeral Mass on Friday, February 13th at 10:00am at St. Charles Borromeo Church, 19 Sidney Place in Brooklyn Heights. In the near future, there will be an event celebrating Margot's many accomplishments in the fields of fine art and vaudeville. Funeral services were handled by McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, Brooklyn, N.Y. 1/3

LUCCA--John J.,DDS, of Ridgewood, NJ. The family and friends of Dr. John J. Lucca, as well as his colleagues at Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, mourn his passing at age 93. He died in his bed at home, very peacefully in his sleep on Wednesday, February 11th. Dr. Lucca received his DDS degree from Columbia in 1947 and was a member of the faculty since that time. He rose from the rank of research assistant in 1947 to Full Professor and Director of the Division of Prosthodontics, a position he held until his retirement in 1986. He was a member and past president of the Greater New York Academy of Dentistry and the American College of Dentists. Because of his dedication and devotion to the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine on so many levels, the John J. Lucca Prosthodontics Clinic was so named in 2000. Dr. Lucca served on many secular and religious committees. He was inducted into the American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta in 1974, a Roman Catholic organization to aid the sick, disabled, poor, homeless and illiterate. He was the beloved husband for over 55 years of Mary Ann Lucca, who predeceased him in 2002, and devoted father of Diane, Eileen, Denise, Nancy, William, and the late John, who predeceased him in 2004, and loving grandfather of 15 and great-grandfather of four. Family and friends may visit Monday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10:00am at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel RC Church, 1 Passaic Street, Ridgewood, followed by entombment at George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Dr. Lucca's memory to: The John J. Lucca, DDS Prosthodontics Clinic, payable to "Post-doctoral Prosthodontic Program" and mailed to: Post-doctoral Prosthodontic Program, Attn: Shelby WhiteDivision Director, Columbia College of Medicine, 630 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032. Information and condolences available at www.feeneyfuneralhome. com

WEINTRAUB--Susan (nee Stutman), 68, of Tenafly, NJ passed away on February 12. Beloved wife of Israel, devoted and loving mother to Benjamin (Arlene) and Seth (Marcy). Cherished sister to the late Deena Stutman. Service 12pm, Friday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.
SKYDELL--Adrian. We mourn the passing of our esteemed longtime friend and neighbor, Adrian Skydell. Our heartfelt condolences go to his family. The Board of Directors 975 Park Avenue Corp. 1/3

MORGENS--Amalia, died at home, February 11, age 100, widow of Joseph Morgens, devoted mother of Deborah Morgens Harnik (Stephen) and Robert Morgens (Amy). She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren Caline, Lara and Nicholas, and her great-grandchild Crosby Basroon. Funeral service on Sunday, February 15 at Central Synagogue Lexington Avenue at 55th Street at 12 noon.

HIRSCH--Diane. The congregation of Temple Shaaray Tefila, New York City, records with deep sorrow the death of Diane Hirsch, mother of our beloved rabbi, Deborah A. Hirsch. We extend heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Hirsch, her spouse Carole Rivel, her brother Dr. Sam Hirsch, his wife Dr. Marti Walsh and their family. May God comfort her loved ones and may her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Joshua Strom Michael Starr, President 1/3

GOLDSCHMID--Harvey J. Our friend Harvey J. Goldschmid, who passed away on February 12, was Senior Counsel at Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP for more than ten years. He was a wonderful colleague and friend, and he contributed to Weil in many significant ways during his tenure at the Firm. His knowledge and expertise were unparalleled, as evidenced by his prestigious positions in both academia and government. Harvey was a brilliant lawyer and educator, and he will be greatly missed by his friends and former colleagues at Weil. We will remember him with the utmost respect and affection, and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family. 1/3
DICKSTEIN--Michael, February 9 after a long illness. Always dapper, jaunty, with a joke and broad smile. Adele has waited long enough. You will be missed by the Jaffe, Lager and Weinstock Families.

FORREST--Neil, of Roslyn, NY, on February 12 of complications from multiple myeloma. Esteemed lawyer at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, specializing in litigation and bankruptcy law. Avid New York sports enthusiast. He is survived by his loving wife, Alisa, devoted children Andrew, Jennifer, and Matthew, his brother Ken, and other relatives and friends who admired and loved him. We will remember and miss Neil for the rest of our lives. Funeral services at noon on Sunday, February 15, Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights NY. Donations in his honor to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. 1/3

TASH--Martin, passed away February 8, 2015 of Boca Raton, Fl, formerly of Dix Hills, NY. Loving husband of Arlene to whom he was married almost 53 years. Beloved brother of Harriet (Arnold) Rosenberg and Betty Tash. Adored father of Faye Tash and Jill Wrubel. Cherished grandfather of Leah Purvis, Marissa Wrubel and Michael Wrubel. Martin Tash was retired from Plenum Publishing Company where he was President and Chairman of the Board. Services were held at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The U.S. Fund for UNICEF pays tribute to the life and legacy of John C. Whitehead, who passed away on Saturday at the age of 92. Mr. Whitehead was a compassionate friend and national board member for the organization, generously serving as a loyal supporter and advocate for children. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

LUCCA--John J.,DDS. It is our sad duty to report that John J. Lucca, DDS, Professor and Director Emeritus at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on Tuesday, February 10, 2015, at the age of 93. Dr. Lucca was an admired professor, a loyal supporter of and fundraiser for the College of Dental Medicine, and will be missed by all who had the distinct pleasure of knowing him. Dr. Lucca received his DDS from the School of Dental and Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine) in 1947 and began serving on the school's faculty the very same year. Beginning as a research assistant, Dr. Lucca's academic career culminated in a 23-year term as professor and director of the Division of Prosthodontics. In 1954 he became a Diplomate of the American Board of Prosthodontics and in 1968 became the president of the Greater New York Academy of Prosthodontics. He was a prolific publisher, an active volunteer for dental professional organizations and for the College of Dental Medicine, was a fellow of the International College of Dentists, and served as chair of the College's 1852 Society. In 2000, Dr. Lucca was honored with the naming of the John J. Lucca, DDS, Prosthodontics Clinic, thanks to gifts from his family, friends, and colleagues. The wake for Dr. Lucca will be held at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue in Ridgewood, NJ, on Monday, February 16, with viewing hours of 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The funeral will be Tuesday, February 17, at 10am at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 1 Passaic Street, in Ridgewood, NJ, with interment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park in Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Lucca's family has requested donations be made to the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine by contacting Geraldine Connors at (212) 342-5612 or gc2399@columbia.edu. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Lucca's family on behalf of the students, alumni, faculty, and staff of the College of Dental Medicine. Christian S. Stohler, DMD DrMedDent, Dean Richard M. Lichtenthal, DDS Chair, Section of Adult Dentistry George Shelby White, DDS Director, Division of Prosthodontics

COHN--Richard A.,passed away peacefully on February 12, 2015 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Roberta Kimmel Cohn. Brother-in-law of Richard Kimmel and the late Joel Kimmel. Brother of Evelyn Golbert and brother in law of the late Mel Golbert. Uncle of Ellen Golbert Magdassi, Stan Golbert and the late Steven Golbert. He was an art dealer of German Expressionism. May he rest in peace. Services Sunday 12:30pm at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

SCHMITT Margaret M.,45, died peacefully February 12 at her home in Manhattan after a courageous three-year battle with breast cancer. She is survived by her mother Marie Schmitt, her brother Christopher Schmitt and his wife Kim, her uncle Robert Sullivan, and her extended family Kathleen Sullivan and Helen Stacy, Bobby and Kandy Sullivan, James and Sara Sullivan and Kira, Danny and Sean Sullivan, and Ed and Lorraine Schmitz; she was also dearly loved by her late aunt Joan Sullivan, who she called her "rock," and her late Aunt Patricia Devereaux. Fiercely loving and wildly generous, she made an art form of friendship and was greatly loved in return by an extraordinary circle of friends. A graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology, she developed numerous product lines for several top clothing brands over a two-decade career that took her fearlessly around the world in search of the best textiles and finishes. Stylish and fashion- forward, fun-loving and creative, full of energy and can-do competence, she lit up the lives of all those who loved her and are so grateful for the gift of her life. There will be no services; a celebration of her life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Triple Negative Breast Cancer Foundation, www.TNBCFoundation.org or P.O. Box 204, Norwood, NJ 07648. 1/3
STRAUSS--Lauri. Your and Herb's love and laughter are with us. Lentch-Bentch. Mom, Julie, David, Gregory & Emily 1/3

MORGENS--Amalia, died at home, February 11, age 100, widow of Joseph Morgens, devoted mother of Deborah Morgens Harnik (Stephen) and Robert Morgens (Amy). She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren Caline, Lara and Nicholas, and her great-grandchild Crosby Basroon. Funeral service on Sunday, February 15 at Central Synagogue Lexington Avenue at 55th Street at 12 noon.
SEE--Robert W. We are saddened by the death of our long-time friend, Robert W. See. He will be missed by all of us. The Gordon Family 1/3

LINEBERRY--William Paul, of Amagansett, NY, died peacefully on February 6. Born August 6, 1934, in Akron, OH, William entered a doctoral program in Political Economy at Columbia University, then became a writer for Scholastic, The Foreign Policy Association, The Council on Foreign Relations, Newsday, Newsweek, the United Nations Development Program, and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Over the course of his career, he traveled throughout Africa, Southeast Asia, the Caribbean, South America and Europe, making friends everywhere along the way. His keen mind, incisive wit, gentle demeanor, boundless curiosity, kindness and generosity will be sorely missed. Above all, William was a devoted father to Michael, enchanted father-in-law to Cami, adoring grandfather to Ella, loving brother to Mary, proud uncle to Judy and Paula, delighted great-uncle to Amy and Ben, and wonderful friend to many. A beachside memorial service celebrating his life will be held in the spring.

FADEM--Zelda. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Zelda Fadem and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

UCCELLANI--Ennio L.,DDS. It is our sad duty to report that Ennio L. Uccellani, DDS, Professor Emeritus at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on Monday, February 9, 2015, at the age of 90. Dr. Uccellani received his DDS from the Columbia University School of Dental & Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine) in 1948. His academic tenure with the school began in 1950 and ended 40 years later when he was Assistant Dean for Clinical Affairs. Among a number of other offices held, Dr. Uccellani served as president of the Greater New York Academy of Prosthodontics and consultant to the Veterans Administration Hospital. In 1994, the College of Dental Medicine appointed him Professor Emeritus and Special Lecturer, thanking him for his "dedication, straight forward advice, and excellence as a teacher." Dr. Uccellani is survived by his three daughters, Claudia, Luise, and Valerie, two sons-in-law, and five grandchildren. The family will have a private service in Dr. Uccellani's honor. If you would like to share remembrances with them, please visit the condolence book at www.coffeyfuneralhome.com. Those who want to pay their respects through a contribution in Dr. Uccellani's memory may do so by contributing to the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine's Student Scholarship Fund. To make a donation, please contact Geraldine Connors at (212) 342-5612 or gc2399@columbia.edu. Donations may also be sent to WQXR classical radio, 160 Varick St., New York, NY 10013. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Uccellani's family on behalf of the students, alumni, faculty, and staff of the College of Dental Medicine. Christian S. Stohler, DMD DrMedDent, Dean Richard M. Lichtenthal, DDS Chair, Section of Adult Dentistry George Shelby White, DDS Director Division of Prosthodontics

AMBROSINO--Beverly, died January 27, 2015, 86 years old. Beverly lived a very full and productive life. She was a compassionate friend and always left us smiling. She will be sorely missed. 1/3

DANZIS--Jo-Ann. Jo-Ann Danzis, A Small Giant. Anyone who's had a connection to pancreatic cancer knows that it's particularly aggressive. Although she passed on January 28, 2015 Jo-Ann Danzis approached this disease with a tireless energy like she did with all other endeavors in life inspiring many others along the way. It was this determination that allowed her to survive for nearly three and a half years. Never put off by a challenge she accomplished much-research chemist at the Rockefeller Institute, college professor, high school teacher, business woman, athlete, artist, photographer, art collector, lover of music, gourmet cook...but more than anything she cherished her family and friends who could always rely on her wisdom, fortitude and selfless nature. Pre-deceased by her husband, Colin. Survived by her brother Kenneth, sister Ila, children Mitchell and Nicholas, grandchildren Magnolia and Kiri. Only 5'2" and living just about 74 years, she may have been short in stature, shorted in years but was very long in life. 1/3

DRANETZ--Abraham, of Scotch Plains, NJ, formerly of Osterville, MA, passed away February 12, 2015 at the age of 92. Beloved husband, devoted father, proud grandfather, loyal brother, and cherished friend, Abe was born in Brockton, MA, and raised in Hyannis, MA. He graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University in 1944, receiving a Bachelors degree in electrical engineering, and after serving two years in the United States Army, received a Masters degree in electrical engineering from MIT in 1948. After graduating, Abe joined Gulton Industries in New Jersey, where he quickly rose through the ranks from Research Engineer, to Chief Engineer, to Director of Engineering, and ultimately, Vice President of Gulton. In 1962, Abe left Gulton, founding his brainchild, Dranetz Technologies, Inc., for which he served as President and Chairman. Dranetz produced sonar testing equipment and power line disturbance analyzers, which set the international benchmark for precision testing equipment. Under Abe's leadership, the company won several E-Star awards from the U.S. Department of Commerce, was repeatedly included in INC Magazines list of fastest growing small companies, and on numerous occasions, was included in Forbes Magazines list of "Up and Comers." In 1999, he was honored as an "Engineering Hero" by the New Jersey Society of Professional Engineers. In addition to his career with Dranetz Technologies, Abe authored numerous articles, contributed to several books, was awarded a number of patents, and served on numerous boards and councils. He proudly served his alma mater, as a member of the Board of Overseers at Tufts Universitys College of Engineering, and was also a member of Tau Beta Pi, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, in addition to several other societies. As a child of the Depression, Abe was particularly sensitive to the needs of others, and gave generously, yet humbly, of himself to numerous causes and institutions. He was a steadfast supporter of significant initiatives at both Tufts and MIT, in addition to many other educational, medical and civic organizations. Yet Abe's proudest achievement, and greatest joy, was his family, to whom he was wholly devoted. He leaves behind the love of his life, Marianna, with whom he shared 57 wonderful years; son Ron Dranetz (Linda) of Chester, NJ; daughter Karen Wolf (Barry) of New York City; four grandchildren, Staci Wolf, Jenna Wolf, Jennifer Dranetz and Alexander Dranetz; and a brother, Marshall Dranetz, of Bryan, TX. He was predeceased by a sister, Sylvia Ross, of Bethesda, MD. Abe also leaves behind numerous friends who will miss him dearly. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, February 17 at 10am, Beth Israel Cemetery/Woodbridge Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. 1/3

WEIR--June. June Weir, passed on Thursday, February 12 following a long illness. June was recognized as one of Americas leading fashion authorities. Born in Youngstown, Ohio in 1928, she attended and graduated from Ohio Wesleyan University. After moving to New York, June began a long career In fashion journalism. She was Appointed Vice President and Associate Publisher of both WWD and W after serving as Fashion Editor of both newspapers. She was then appointed by Conde Nast Publications to become American Vogue's Fashion News Director. Her various other positions included Deputy Style Editor for the New York Times Sunday Magazine and Executive Fashion Editor of Harpers Bazaar. June lectured at some of the country's great museums and leading fashion stores. In 2000, she became a weekly columnist on "InShop.com". June travelled across America to see first hand some of the countrys great mail order companies. She reported her findings in Mirabellas Column, "She Shops By Night". Beginning in 2000 and for eight years June helped create New York University's Yearly Fashion Conference in addition to creating and teaching 25 new courses at NYU. June leaves her sister, Phyllis Wilkie along with her nephew, Jeffrey T. Wilkie and his family, wife Marilyn and children Andrew, Kyle and Blair. Memorial Services to celebrate June's life will be held at Immanuel Lutheran Church at 122 E. 88th Street, New York, NY on Saturday, February 28th at 11am. Any donations can be made to The United Lutheran Church at The Wartburg, Wartburg Place, Mt. Vernon, New York 10552. 1/3

CORNYETZ--Paul. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Paul Cornyetz on the morning of February 10, 2015, aged 91, at his home in New York City with his wife, Beth Holden-Cornyetz at his side. Paul was a practicing psychoanalyst, an associate member of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis from 1955 until his death and the President of the NPAP training institute from 1990-1992. Paul was motivated by a need to understand the nature of human beings. He listened to his patients and learned to follow them. Paul is survived by his wife, his son Daniel, his daughter Nina, and his ex-wife, Bernice Cornyetz. A man of humor, wisdom, and compassion, his passing is deeply mourned by his survivors. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. Asia Society's Board of Trustees, Staff, and our entire global community mourn the passing of our Chairman Emeritus and Honorary Life Trustee John Whitehead. He was an inspirational leader and a model citizen--of New York City, of the United States, and of the world. We were privileged to have him as a friend, supporter and advocate for our efforts in the arts, policy and education for over three decades. As Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1989-1995, he helped us conceive and realize the expansion of our Park Avenue headquarters and New York museum in 2001. He was a key participant at our Williamsburg policy conferences in Thailand (1990), in Australia (1991), and in the Philippines (1995). It was an honor to celebrate his lifelong achievements and service at our annual gala dinner held just before his 90th birthday in 2012. His ongoing commitment to and involvement with our organization--most recently as an Honorary Counselor for the Asia Society Policy Institute--will continue to inspire and animate our work. We express our deepest condolences to Cindy and his entire family. Ronnie C. Chan, Co-Chair Henrietta H. Fore, Co-Chair Josette Sheeran, President and CEO Asia Society

CHRISTY--David Stewart, an economist and advisor to the Afghan resistance during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan, died in his home in New York on February 7, 2015 at the age of 90. When the United States began to support the Afghan resistance in the 1980s, aid was dispensed on the condition that no serving U.S. intelligence officer enter Afghanistan. Retired from government service and uncompensated by the U.S. government, Mr. Christy was at liberty to travel to Afghanistan with mujahidin groups, advising them and analyzing their viability. Along with Dr. Qudrat Mojadidi, an Afghan-American doctor, he helped establish and fund an OBGYN clinic for Afghan refugees in Peshawar, Pakistan. The hospital was sponsored, in part, by the International Rescue Committee of New York. Mr. Christy accompanied Professor Sigbutullah Mojadidi to Kabul when he returned as the president of Afghanistan after the Soviet withdrawal in 1989. Mr. Christy was born on February 20, 1924, in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania, the son of Dr. Joseph Augustus Christy and Flora Stewart. He was still a naval cadet, in training to be a pilot, when his class was dissolved at the end of WWII. Because of his ranking in class, Christy was given the opportunity to continue flight training on a non-reserve status with a further commitment to spend six additional years in the Navy Air Corps. When he declined, he was shifted as a commissioned officer to the Office of Naval Intelligence and placed on reserve status. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in chemical engineering in 1946. Mr. Christy was a lifelong student of philosophy and religion. His first exposure to the Muslim world was in 1947, while attending the speech of the first sultan of Morocco. This modest initial contact was the seed of a lifetime of casual study of Islamic culture. As a partial result, over the last six decades, Christy immersed himself in the cultures of Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia. His work as an economist-entrepreneur took him to the Far East, as well as to countries such as Nigeria, Cameroun, Ghana, Egypt, and Sudan, where he established joint ventures with governments of newly independent nations. Christy was on the Advisory Committee of China Institute in America. He served on the vestry of St. James' Episcopal Church and was a church school teacher, a Stephen Minister, and a Lay Eucharist Minister there. At the age of 84, he completed the Shikoku 88-Temple Pilgrimage, honoring the 9th century Buddhist teacher Kukai, by circumambulating the Japanese island of Shikoku. He is survived by Anita Christy, his wife of forty years; three children by his first marriage--Lee Dahlberg, Joseph Stewart Christy, and Susan Christy--and two children by his second marriage--David Stewart Christy, Jr. and Sarah Alden Christy; two former stepchildren, Arthur O. Sulzberger, Jr. and Karen Alden Sulzberger; five grandchildren; and seven godchildren. His foster son Amon Nassimi, an interpreter for the US State Department in Afghanistan, was killed by a Taliban car bombing in 2013. The funeral will be at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the International Rescue Committee,122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168, 212- 551-3000, or +1-855-9RESCUE or St. James' Episcopal Church. 1/3

STRIANESE--Michael Francis, of New York, died February 9th following a brief illness. He was 91. Mr. Strianese was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 7, 1923. He served in the United States Marine Corps from June 1943 until his discharge as a Corporal in January 1946. A qualified marksman and crewman, Mr. Strianese served in the Asiatic-Pacific region for two years and participated in the Battle of Okinawa in April of 1945, the largest amphibious assault in the Pacific during World War II. Following his service in the Marine Corps, Mr. Strianese returned to New York and married Rosemary, his wife of 60 years. In addition to his wife, Mr. Strianese is survived by his children, Michael (wife Alyson), Christine Strianese Coulton (husband Andrew), and Anthony, as well as seven grandchildren. 1/3
