SCHMITT Margaret M.,45, died peacefully February 12 at her home in Manhattan after a courageous three-year battle with breast cancer. She is survived by her mother Marie Schmitt, her brother Christopher Schmitt and his wife Kim, her uncle Robert Sullivan, and her extended family Kathleen Sullivan and Helen Stacy, Bobby and Kandy Sullivan, James and Sara Sullivan and Kira, Danny and Sean Sullivan, and Ed and Lorraine Schmitz; she was also dearly loved by her late aunt Joan Sullivan, who she called her "rock," and her late Aunt Patricia Devereaux. Fiercely loving and wildly generous, she made an art form of friendship and was greatly loved in return by an extraordinary circle of friends. A graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology, she developed numerous product lines for several top clothing brands over a two-decade career that took her fearlessly around the world in search of the best textiles and finishes. Stylish and fashion- forward, fun-loving and creative, full of energy and can-do competence, she lit up the lives of all those who loved her and are so grateful for the gift of her life. There will be no services; a celebration of her life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Triple Negative Breast Cancer Foundation, www.TNBCFoundation.org or P.O. Box 204, Norwood, NJ 07648. 1/3

ABRAMOWITZ--Dr. Herbert, of Whitestone, Queens, a dentist for over 40 years, passed away in his home, Saturday January 31. He had suffered a stroke in 2013. A dentist during the day and a jeweler at night, he is credited with being the creator of "Hypo-Allergenic" jewelry. He held several patents, including the "dri stand", a dental mirror protector, and hypo-allergenic earrings, trademarked the "M.D." post, a slotted hollow earring post of surgical grade stainless steel orthodontic tubing. This development led to other patents including an ear-piercing kit and a compression earring for post- operative keloid surgery. A full line of jewelry was manufactured for this niche market and sold through a mail order business. Born in Bensonhurst on June 28, 1928, Dr. Abramowitz was the only child of Isadore and Pauline Abramowitz. He graduated with a bachelor's and dental degree from New York University. He was a Captain in the Korean War and supervised the dental clinic at Perrin Air Force Base, in Texas. He was truly a renaissance man, fascinated in how "things work and grow". An avid gardener, woodworker, photographer, camera and LP enthusiast, he bred angelfish, and earned degrees in welding and landscaping. He grew prize-winning dahlia flowers in his garden in the tight-knit Saltaire, Fire Island community, where he was known as the "Dahlia King". He was loved for his charming and engaging sense of humor. The adoring husband of Gloria Abramowitz for 58 years, and father of Jody Weisman and Andrew Abramowitz, father-in-law of Andrew Weisman, and grandfather of Hannah, Isabelle and Henry. The family is actively devoted to Kimberton Hills, a non-profit organic, agricultural community in Pennsylvania where his special needs son Andrew lives. 1/3

Her great grandson Asher was the light of her life. She will be missed but leaves behind wonderful memories of happy times with her family and friends. I would like to thank her loving caregivers Shelly, Carla and Djyn. 1/3

GLICK--Norman Robert, died February 11, 2015. He retired as a Physician's Assistant V.A. Bay Pines, actor, director, and producer. Last season he staged Two by Tavel Theater for the New City. Beloved Brother, uncle, and friend. Decorated Veteran of Viet Nam. A Military service, complete with 21 gun salute, held Friday, February 13, 2015 National Cemetery at Bay Pines, Florida. 1/3

HORN--Judith H. beloved mother, grandmother, partner and friend passed away Sunday, February 8th. She was an educator and children's advocate for 40 years. She leaves behind her daughters, her grandchildren, her partner and countless children whose lives she has touched. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Blythedale Children's Hospital. 1/3

RILEY--Allan J. a prominent real estate investor who for a time owned One Time Square amongst othe properties in the United States and Britain, a patron of the arts and benefactor of the University of Notre Dame, died on Thursday, February 5th, at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old. The youngest of three brothers, Allan was born on July 18th 1935 in Indianapolis, Indiana. He attended Catholic High Schools in Cleveland and Chicago as well as Indianapolis and graduated with honors in 1957 from the University of Notre Dame where he majored in English and Speech. He studied Performing Arts at Stanford University and served two years in the Air Force. In 1964 he moved to New York City to join William A. White Real Estate Company. In the early seventies, he established his own real estate firm, now called Allan Riley Realty, Inc. Mr. Riley is survived by his wife of 30 years, Radwan Jabbour Riley, and by his brother William. He is predeceased by his father Leo, his mother Edna and his older brother Eugene. One of Mr. Riley's passions was 19th Century British and American paintings and drawings which he loaned to various museums. For the past eight years he served on the board of the Smithsonian American Art Museum. His other passions included fishing and travel. Mr. Riley's many contributions to Notre Dame include the University's Center for the Fine Arts. In 1982, he donated funds for the renovation of a former chemistry building which was renamed Riley Hall in honor of his parents, Leo and Edna. Allan and his wife fund annual student endowment awards in the fields of design, art history, studio art, and photography at the university. He sat on the board of the University's Snite Museum of Art. Some of his permanent gifts to the museum include a portrait painting by Joshua Reynolds and a landscape painting by Louis Remy Mignot. In 2002, Mr. and Mrs. Riley funded the purchase of 40 British drawings from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries that remain part of the Museum's Riley Collection. Mr. Riley was an avid fan of Notre Dame and maintained season box seats at the University's stadium. Mr. and Mrs. Riley support the International Theological Institute in Vienna. Allan was an active board member at the institute. He also served on the boards of various charities including Save the Children and Lincoln Hall Boys Haven in Somers, NY. He and his wife resided in both Manhattan and New Canaan, CT. 1/3

SAWIKIN--Charles, passed away February 12. Beloved father of Judy Fein and Harvey Sawikin. Grandfather of Dr. Samuel Sharmat, Leo and William Sawikin. Great- grandfather to Sophia, Beena and Pia Sharmat. A Holocaust survivor and memoirist, he gave his time to the Workmen's Circle, Yiddish Book Center and other causes. Warm and sweet, he always had a twinkle. May he rest in peace. 1/3
MELTZER--Elton. Remembered with everlasting love & treasured memories by his adoring wife, children, grandchildren & great-grandchildren. 1/3

DEMBNER--Shirley, passed away suddenly on February 4. She cared deeply for her family and friends, but lived for her beloved daughter Lindsay who was the light of her life. They shared a love for all animals, but Lola was their favorite. Donations in her memory may be made to Pets Alive at http://petsalivewest.org/ index.php/help/donate/ or to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation 1/3
SEE--Robert W. We are saddened by the death of our long-time friend, Robert W. See. He will be missed by all of us. The Gordon Family 1/3

SKYDELL--Adrian Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) lament the passing of a distinguished alumnus, Rabbi Adrian Skydell, of blessed memory, ordained in 1943, who served as spiritual leader of several congregations and then went into business, developed a very large and successful thread manufacturing company and also invested in real estate. Upon retirement he devoted his time to the study of Talmud, which he loved, and became a truly outstanding Talmudic scholar. He also spent part of the day studying the early masters of Latin, Greek and English languages, literatures and philosophy, was proficient in these areas, and earned a masters degree from Columbia University. His beloved wife, Dr. Ruth Skydell, of blessed memory, was a member of YU's Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology Board of Overseers. Together, they were YU Guardians. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his children: Benjamin "Buddy" Skydell (and Seryl Ritter); Laurie (and Dr. Myron) Goldberg; Harry (and Rachel) Skydell, YU Guardians; to his sister, Anita Chanowitz, and to his brother, Irving (and Cecile) Skydell; to a host of nieces and nephews and to his many grandchildren. May the entire Skydell family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1

WHITEHEAD--John. John Whitehead's remarkable career was an inspiration to the students and community of Macaulay Honors College at CUNY, where he was an honorary director and recipient of an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. His life was indeed one of leadership in business, public service, and philanthropy. We extend our condolences to his family and to the wide circle of people that he touched with his wisdom and wit. William E. Macaulay Ann Kirschner Macaulay Honors College 1/3

LEVY--Lewis, E.,86 died at home on February 12 after a long illness. Son of the late Harry and Hannah Levy, graduate of Erasmus Hall and George Washington University. Korean War veteran, co- founder, Towne Office Supply. Good neighbor and kind and loyal friend to everyone he met regardless of their station in life. Well cared for by Herbert Bantegui, Ekow Mensah-Nunoo, Jean Dureus, Albert Acheampong, and the Senior Bridge Staff. Services Tuesday February 17, 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

RONGA--Frank. Beloved husband of Anna (nee Chiodi). Dearest father of Ellen and husband Larry and Richard and his husband Robert, grandfather of Laura and Andrew, brother of Antoinette Di Fonzo. Reposing at Ralph Giordano Funeral Home, 1727 Crosby Ave., Bronx, Sunday and Monday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass Tuesday 10:30am St. Benedict's Church. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery. 1/3

HAMILTON--Christian. Longtime New York City playwright and lyricist Christian Hamilton died February 17, 2014, aged 86, in Cornelius, NC. A fine curmudgeon, he stood for excellence, high ideals, kindness, and simple joys. Rachel Jeffreys Hamilton, his wife of 35 years, will love him forever. 1/3
METH--Max Bernard. 2/12/37 -2/17/13. I see your goodness in our children and grandchildren. You are truly missed. Love, Blanche. 1/3

FARBER--Rita, 86, of Lenox, MA passed away on February 11, 2015. She was predeceased by her parents Eva and Hyman Katz and her husband Arthur. She is survived by her loving partner Benjamin Kaplan, daughter Karen (and David) Freedman, son Richard (and Kathy) Farber, as well as four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Rita, a graduate of Hunter College, was a dedicated New York City science teacher for 31 years. Her passions included attending the theatre, reading Yiddish literature, playing bridge, traveling, and cooking. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the COPD foundation at www.copdfoundation.org, or to Shakespeare and Company in Lenox, MA at: www.shakespeare.org. 1/3

KLEIN--Edith. Mindy Shapiro and Jeffrey Simmons are saddened by the passing of Edith Klein. Her quiet strength, perseverance and cholent will be missed. We extend our sympathy to her family and loved ones.

PLUMER--Ralph "Rick", 74, on February 7. Former Controller of Trinity Church, Rick was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. He succumbed to cancer, after a battle which he fought with his hallmarks: dignity, determination and strength. He was a good, strong, steadfast, generous, smart, kind man. He made a difference in many lives, during his time at Trinity from 1967-'90, as Controller from '79-'90, and by simply being himself. Donations can be made to St. Jude's Children's Hospital.

KARTIGANER--Norman. February 1, 2015. Survived by former wife Patricia, daughters Kathy Kartiganer, Randy (Aydin) Esen, Sharon Kartiganer, grandchildren Sarah, Bobby, Aykan, Jenny, Cenk, and sister Geraldine (Leonard) Steinlauf. Predeceased by sister Rita (Julian) Feinberg. Graduate of University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, founder Kartiganer Enterprises, Worcester, MA, retired to Palm Beach, FL. Memorial service: Sunday, February 22, 1pm, The Boston Synagogue, 55 Martha Road, Boston, MA. 1/3

MARGOLIS--Dr. Robert A.,entered into eternal rest on February 12, 2015 at the age of 78. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Jennifer and Eric Fryer and Steven and Jenifer Margolis. Loving grandfather of Andrew and Madeline Fryer and Michael and Brian Margolis. Dearest brother of Barbara Sheerin. Funeral services Monday February 16, 2015 at 10am at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John. The Trustees and staff of The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation mourn the passing of John C. Whitehead. As chair of the Foundation's Board from 1990 to 1997, Mr. Whitehead contributed his deep knowledge and appreciation of the arts, humanities, and nonprofit governance to the Foundation's grantmaking. In addition to guiding the Foundation's long-term commitments to the performing and visual arts, scholarly research, and diversity in the academy, Mr. Whitehead brought his broad experience in international and public affairs to bear upon the Foundation's efforts to help strengthen institutions of higher education in Eastern Europe and South Africa. An advocate of building sustainable resources for future generations, Mr. Whitehead was also a strong and early supporter of the Foundation's efforts to create electronic archives of scholarly work in anticipation of the digital age. We extend to his family our deepest condolences. W. Taylor Reveley, III, Chair; Danielle S. Allen, Vice-Chair; Earl Lewis, President 1/3

SHRADY--Henry Merwin III, 1936-2015. Age 78, died at home in Snedens Landing, New York, after a long struggle with cancer, his beloved wife Gale Barrett Shrady, by his side. Born in Paris to expatriate parents, he followed the artistic path of his father, Frederick C. Shrady, and his grandfather and namesake, Henry M. Shrady, both sculptors. A graduate of San Francisco Art Institute and Columbia University, he was a sculptor, painter; film production designer; and restorer of old buildings and houses. He was always an energetic optimistic with endless ideas of things to fix and build. He never saw an old wreck of a house, or boat or car that he didn't love. He played polo, skied and sailed. A proud New Yorker and East Village resident, Mr. Shrady was the first President of the First Street Block Association, Honorary Trustee of the New York City Marble Cemetery and, until recent illnesses, a member of the St. Nicholas Society and The Century Association. His family will remember him for his enthusiastic storytelling, improvisational piano playing, passionate political discussions, bow ties and many adventures on land and sea. Mr. Shrady will be greatly missed by friends and family including his wife, his children Pierre Shrady (Mary) of Koln, Germany, and Francesca Shrady (Paul) of Santa Fe; his stepchildren Katherine Kavanagh (Keith) and Colleen Kavanagh (Noel) of Manhattan, and Matthew Kavanagh (Hilary) of Johannesburg, South Africa; nine grandchildren; and his dachshund, Pepper. A memorial celebration will be held in early Spring.

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America mourns the loss of Board Co-Chairman, Distinguished Eagle Scout John C. Whitehead. His thoughtful and generous leadership of NYC Scouting and Exploring has left an indelible mark on hundreds of thousands of NYC young people and their families. We extend our deepest sympathy his family. The Board and Staff of the Greater New York Councils Boy Scouts of America
ROPER--Betty Marshall. Jan. 20, 1921- Sept. 2, 2014. The teaching of kindness on her tongue. Our rock, comfort, and compass.

COHN--Richard A.,passed away peacefully on February 12, 2015 at the age of 91. Beloved husband of Roberta Kimmel Cohn. Brother-in-law of Richard Kimmel and the late Joel Kimmel. Brother of Evelyn Golbert and brother in law of the late Mel Golbert. Uncle of Ellen Golbert Magdassi, Stan Golbert and the late Steven Golbert. He was an art dealer of German Expressionism. May he rest in peace. Services Sunday 12:30pm at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

LINEBERRY--William Paul, of Amagansett, NY, died peacefully on February 6. Born August 6, 1934, in Akron, OH, William entered a doctoral program in Political Economy at Columbia University, then became a writer for Scholastic, The Foreign Policy Association, The Council on Foreign Relations, Newsday, Newsweek, the United Nations Development Program, and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Over the course of his career, he traveled throughout Africa, Southeast Asia, the Caribbean, South America and Europe, making friends everywhere along the way. His keen mind, incisive wit, gentle demeanor, boundless curiosity, kindness and generosity will be sorely missed. Above all, William was a devoted father to Michael, enchanted father-in-law to Cami, adoring grandfather to Ella, loving brother to Mary, proud uncle to Judy and Paula, delighted great-uncle to Amy and Ben, and wonderful friend to many. A beachside memorial service celebrating his life will be held in the spring.

WILLIAMS--L. Pearce, Professor Emeritus in the History of Science at Cornell University, died February 8, 2015, at Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, NY, at the age of 87. A tall and imposing figure, he reveled in the teaching of both the History of Science and the History of Western Civilization, and enjoyed giving his presentation, "The Notorius Note-Taking Lecture," to students entering university during his years as a chair professor at Cornell. Williams is survived by his devoted wife of 65 years, Sylvia Alessandrini Williams, as well as his four children: Dave Williams of Newark, OH, and his two children Linus and Vivian; Alison Williams Lewin of Wilmington, DE, and her three children, Eleanor with spouse James, Sylvia, and Gregory with spouse Madeline; Adam Williams and his companion Lynne Frey of Camden, ME; and Sarah Bonnefoi and spouse Marc of Basking Ridge, NJ, and their four children, Marie, Anne, Elena and Theo. Pearce enrolled at Cornell University in 1944 as a chemical engineer, but immediately left Cornell for a year's service in the United States Navy. Upon his return to the university, he found his lifelong passion for history of science through a required course taught by the late Henri Guerlac. Pearce graduated from Cornell with honors with a BA in 1949, and then pursued a Ph.D. at Cornell, which he completed in 1952. He taught at Yale and the University of Delaware, and was delighted to return to teach at his alma mater in 1960. His biography of Michael Faraday won the Pfizer Prize and he authored several other books and numerous articles in his field. He often expressed his opinions on various issues to the Ithaca Journal and the Cornell Daily Sun, gaining him a certain local notoriety, or fame, depending on one's point of view. Pearce's more physical activities included hunting with his beloved Weimeraners, gaining a black belt in karate, playing touch football games with his colleagues and students on Sundays, and wood chopping, a benefit of which was his hours spent by his fireside. A memorial service will be held later in the year; time and place will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Pearce's second home: The Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Carl A. Kroch Library, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853. Through his diverse and varied pursuits, Pearce touched many lives. As he would have said, "I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith," (2 Timothy 4:7 KJV).

BESKIND--D. Herbert. Beloved father of Ellen (Peter) Safir of Washington DC, Susan (Michael) Lelyveld, of Lexington, MA and Joanne Elkin of New York, died February 9, in Washington, DC, where he resided for the last 24 years. Herb, the son of Rose and Morris Beskind, was born July 18, 1915 in Brooklyn. He attended PS 193 and graduated from James Madison High School. He attended Dartmouth College, from which he received an A.B. in 1936, continuing on at the Tuck School. He received his M.S. in Business Administration from Columbia University in 1938. Most of his career was at DCA Food Industries, where he retired as Financial Vice President and Director of the company. He then served as Chairman, Executive Committee, Eastern Life Insurance Company (now US Life Insurance) and as Director of the Concord Fund. Herb was Chairman of Hillside Hospital in Glen Oaks, NY. He served on the Board of the Jewish Family Service of New York, and on the Board of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. He was a former member and governor of the Harmonie Club. His great interests were Asian and contemporary art, music, bridge, horticulture, opera, ballet, and fly fishing. He created a teaching collection of Chinese art and a Japanese garden for the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College. His daughters fondly remember him tending to the beautiful Japanese influenced gardens he created at their home in Scarsdale. Herb was married to Dorothy Levitt, and to Serena Martin- Trigona. Both marriages ended in divorce. In addition to his daughters, Herb is survived by grandsons Archie (Sarah) and Roland (Alicia) Smart, Jesse Safir (Alexandra), and Victor Lelyveld, granddaughter Kate Elkin, and three great-grandchildren. He was devoted to his daughters; he was proud of their accomplishments and independence and cherished his relationships with them. He was a great Dad. 1

ENGELMAN--Ethel. 93, of New York City and formerly of Cambridge, MA, died peacefully in her home February 13, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Howard Engelman for 57 years. Devoted mother to Augusta Engelman-Kaiser and Arnold Engelman. Beloved grandmother to Allegra, Marnie and Francesca Kaiser and Nora and Audrey Engelman. Dear sister to Philip and Leonard Roseman. Cherished mother-in-law to William Kaiser and Carol Rosegg. Loving sister-in-law. Wonderful aunt to many nieces, nephews and dear cousins. Compassionate friend to all, her lively spirit will be missed but never forgotten. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th St on February 17th at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Church Street Station, PO Box 780, New York, NY 10008. 1/3

GORHAM--David L.,retired Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of The New York Times Company, passed away in Florida on Saturday, February 7, 2015. Mr. Gorham, a C.P.A., joined The Times in 1974, was appointed Chief Financial Officer in 1980 and retired in 1997. Born in Salt Lake City, Utah, he received degrees from University of Utah and Haas School of Business at University of California Berkeley. He served in the U.S. Air Force as a pilot of refueling aircraft and attained the rank of Captain. While at The New York Times, Mr. Gorham was intimately involved with its recovery from the effects of the 1975 New York City financial crisis and, later, The New York Times diversification into regional media outlets and ultimately The Boston Globe. He served on the board of The International Herald Tribune and other Times related companies. Mr. Gorham was known for his love of family. He will be missed by his wife of sixty years, Carolyn; his five children, Joyce Gorham Peterson of Midland Park, NJ; J. Nathan Gorham of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.; Roger Gorham of Hillsborough, NJ; Sarah Gorham Harris of Upper Saddle River, NJ; and Stephen Gorham of Sammamish, Wash. He also leaves nine grandchildren, three nephews and three nieces. Mr. Gorham and his family were long-time residents of Upper Saddle River, NJ and later, New Smyrna Beach, FL. He was known for his good humor and could frequently be found playing tennis or walking his dog. The family will hold a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers and in keeping with his generosity in support of education, donations in his honor may be made to a college of your choice. 1/3

SIMONS--Robert A. "Bob", 81 of West Hartford, CT, husband of Barbara (Hoffman), died February 12, 2015 at his home surrounded by his family. Born June 13, 1933 in Hartford, Bob developed into a standout baseball player and went on to serve in the US Army during the Korean War. Bob graduated from the Barney School of Business in 1959 and met Barbara, his wife of 56 years. Throughout his career, Bob assumed many leadership roles in business, community, public service organizations and Jewish causes. He was the Founding Principal of Simons Real Estate Group as well as Figure Eight Properties and the company's properties spanned across several states. He also developed and owned many notable properties in Greater Hartford. In addition to his wife, Bob is survived by his children Harris and wife Linda, Bruce and wife Elisabeth, and Sharon and husband Jeff. He also leaves his sister Judy Klemba and husband John, sister-in- law Ferne Hoffman, and his brother Howard. Bob was also blessed with nine grandchildren including Jacquelyn, Austin, Charlie, Ted, Jenna, Sydnie, Aidan, Madeline and Jack. Funeral Services will be held Monday, February 16, 2015 at 1:00pm at Beth El Temple, 2626 Albany Avenue, West Hartford with burial in Beth El Cemetery, Avon. Memorial contributions may be made to Hillel at The University of Hartford or to the Northwest Boys and Girls Club, 1 Nahum Drive, Hartford, CT 06112. 1/3
DICKSTEIN--Michael, February 9 after a long illness. Always dapper, jaunty, with a joke and broad smile. Adele has waited long enough. You will be missed by the Jaffe, Lager and Weinstock Families.

FLAUM--Merrill. 1935-2015, 80, of New York, NY, beloved husband and best friend to wife Carole for 46 years, passed away surrounded by his loving family on Wednesday, February 11, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, NY to Jack and Bessie Flaum, Merrill lived most of his life in New York City. He was a warm and loving man who most enjoyed being outside in the sun, traveling, and spending time with those he laughed with and lived for. He spent his career in sales at various companies within the garment industry before retiring in recent years. Among his proud achievements were completing several marathons in New York City and Philadelphia. Besides his wife Carole, Merrill is survived by his two sons, Jonathan and his wife Stacy and Cary and his wife Amy; and his grandchildren, Brianna, Ellie, Morgan and Gabi. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in Merrill's name to the American Cancer Society.

HEWETT--Lance, on February 6, 2015. Director, Actor. Founder and Artistic Director of Isle of Shoals Productions, Inc., a Manhattan-based not-for-profit theatre company for 19 years. Survived by two sisters, Bobbie Law and Bonnie Hewett, and his long-time Isle of Shoals partner and collaborator, Bryan Williams.

KARN--Sibyl. Her family, with deepest sorrow, reports the death of Sibyl Karn, after a prolonged illness, on February 4, 2015, her 90th birthday. She was a resident of the Upper Eastside and is survived by her loving husband, Andrew, three beloved sons, Jonathan, Theodore and Kenneth and six grandchildren.

DISPENZIERI--Angelo. Angelo Dispenzieri died peacefully at home in Manhasset, NY surrounded by his family on February 8, 2015 at age 85 after a long struggle with post-polio syndrome. Beloved by his wife of 32 years, Eileen Stegman Dispenzieri, his daughters, Elizabeth Mutlu of Bay Terrace, NY and Angela Dispenzieri of Rochester, MN, and his grandsons, Michael Mutlu and James Mutlu. Also survived by his ex-wife Francine Dispenzieri and many nieces and nephews. Born to Sicilian immigrant parents, Cataldo and Sebastiana, on August 2, 1929, he was raised in Williamsburg, Brooklyn with his six siblings: Frank, Josephine Lepani, Anthony, Charles, Angela Pumilia and Salvatore; all of whom preceded him in death. He earned his BA from Baruch College (1953) and his PhD in Psychology from New York University (1961). He lived a full life; a Professor of Psychology at Baruch College where he also served as Dean of Evening and Extension Division; a psychotherapist in private practice; and a consultant/lecturer in industrial/organizational psychology. In his private life, he enjoyed his family, music, fine art, and things of beauty. He lived for love, knowledge and compassion for others, and often said that there is no problem in life that could not be solved. His brand of knowledge, optimism, and story telling was a source of solace, hope and transformation for many. We will miss his presence but he will be with us as he touched us with his love and wisdom. There will be no funeral services at the decedent's request; a private memorial will be held in the spring. Donations in his memory may be made to New York Public Radio, PO Box 1550, New York, NY 10116-1550. 1/3

ISAACS--Gertrude, on February 11, 2015 at age 79. Beloved wife, "Puppi," of the late Bernard Isaacs, cherished mother of Michele and Diane and their husbands, Tommy and Marc, adored "Mimi" of Carly and Daniel. First and foremost, a deeply devoted wife, mother and grandmother, she will be remembered by those who loved her for her fierce determination, quiet strength, and kind and generous spirit. She will live in our hearts forever. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St) on Tuesday, February 17, 2015 at 11:30am. Interment at Riverside Cemetery to follow. 1/3

KAHN--Anita Anna. Passed away peacefully at her New York City home on February 8, 2015. She was 94 years old. Anita was born in Jersey City on February 23, 1920 the daughter of Morris and Pauline Goretsky, Russian immigrants. Anita's father was a dry goods salesman and her mother was a seamstress. She met her future husband Arthur Edward Kahn, who became a prominent New York dentist, on a blind date. His father had been a candy store owner and his mother a housewife. After serving on an Air Force base in Texas during WWII, Anita and Arthur moved to Manhattan where he began his dental practice. Anita had been an art student at Temple University and during the 1950s she resumed her studies at The New School for Social Research as a student of Moses Soyer, Richard Pousette-Dart, and Anthony Toney. This rekindled interest in the arts led in the following decades to Anita and Arthur becoming art collectors and patrons of the arts. Anita was known for her beauty, flair for dressing, acumen, and her sharp wit. She is remembered by her daughters Robbie and Karen, her grandsons Levin and Matthew, and her great grandchildren Aziz, Aya, and Peyton. May Anita's memory be for a blessing. 1/3

ENGELMAN--Ethel. 93, of New York City and formerly of Cambridge, MA, died peacefully in her home February 13, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Howard Engelman for 57 years. Devoted mother to Augusta Engelman-Kaiser and Arnold Engelman. Beloved grandmother to Allegra, Marnie and Francesca Kaiser and Nora and Audrey Engelman. Dear sister to Philip and Leonard Roseman. Cherished mother-in-law to William Kaiser and Carol Rosegg. Loving sister-in-law. Wonderful aunt to many nieces, nephews and dear cousins. Compassionate friend to all, her lively spirit will be missed but never forgotten. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th St on February 17th at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, please donate to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Church Street Station, PO Box 780, New York, NY 10008. 1/3

MacNEIL--Donna. We mourn the passing of Donna MacNeil not only as friends but also as members of The Movable Feast Book Club. Since 1997 we have met to discuss 125 novels; our animated dinners were enriched by Donna's contagious warmth, devilish humor, and, as her health declined, courage. We will miss her at our tables. Throughout we were moved by the devotion and support of her husband, Robin, to whom we extend our deep sympathy and admiration. Arlene and Alan Alda, Judy and Leslie Gelb, Bette and Winston Lord, Hannah Pakula, Calvin Trillin 1/3

TEDESCO-GARONE--Anna. The Stecher and Horowitz Foundation grieves the loss of the beloved wife of our esteemed Board Member Vincent T. Garone and sister of Lucia Tedesco. Her indomitable spirit and love infused all the lives she touched. We treasured her. 1/3

TESCHNER--John H.,66, died at home on February 14, after a long illness. A kind and loyal friend to all he knew, he is survived by his wife Gabriela, daughter Tanya (Vinson) Osman, grandson Pierson, mother Marcia, sister Susan (Peter) Mellis, niece Alix (James) Brown, nephew Michael (Martha Lee) Mellis and great nieces/nephews Eve, Charlotte, William, Bradley, Max and Jack. He joins his beloved father Buddy, who predeceased him. Services Monday, February 16, 10:30am, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue. 1/3

GLASER--Morris (Moishe), of Brooklyn, NY died peacefully in his sleep Sunday, February 8, at the MJHS Menorah Center in Manhattan Beach. He was 85. Devoted high school literature teacher for forty plus years in the New York City education system and fondly remembered into retirement by many of his students; Korean War veteran; world traveler from Park Slope to Patagonia to Paris to Pistoia; feinschmecker connoisseur of the world's cuisines; deplorer of euphemisms and cliches; admirer of Proust and Nabokov, Beethoven and Bartok; Morris forged his own way through life and is dearly remembered by his friends for his loyalty, his individuality, and for courageously taking the road less traveled. His survivors include his sister Goldie Katz, niece Laura Katz, and nephews David and Charlie Katz, and six grandnieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service is planned for the spring, the date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Morris's name to BrightFocus Foundation for Alzheimers Research http://tinyurl.com/nw3q85l

DRANETZ--Abraham, of Scotch Plains, NJ, formerly of Osterville, MA, passed away February 12, 2015 at the age of 92. Beloved husband, devoted father, proud grandfather, loyal brother, and cherished friend, Abe was born in Brockton, MA, and raised in Hyannis, MA. He graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University in 1944, receiving a Bachelors degree in electrical engineering, and after serving two years in the United States Army, received a Masters degree in electrical engineering from MIT in 1948. After graduating, Abe joined Gulton Industries in New Jersey, where he quickly rose through the ranks from Research Engineer, to Chief Engineer, to Director of Engineering, and ultimately, Vice President of Gulton. In 1962, Abe left Gulton, founding his brainchild, Dranetz Technologies, Inc., for which he served as President and Chairman. Dranetz produced sonar testing equipment and power line disturbance analyzers, which set the international benchmark for precision testing equipment. Under Abe's leadership, the company won several E-Star awards from the U.S. Department of Commerce, was repeatedly included in INC Magazines list of fastest growing small companies, and on numerous occasions, was included in Forbes Magazines list of "Up and Comers." In 1999, he was honored as an "Engineering Hero" by the New Jersey Society of Professional Engineers. In addition to his career with Dranetz Technologies, Abe authored numerous articles, contributed to several books, was awarded a number of patents, and served on numerous boards and councils. He proudly served his alma mater, as a member of the Board of Overseers at Tufts Universitys College of Engineering, and was also a member of Tau Beta Pi, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, in addition to several other societies. As a child of the Depression, Abe was particularly sensitive to the needs of others, and gave generously, yet humbly, of himself to numerous causes and institutions. He was a steadfast supporter of significant initiatives at both Tufts and MIT, in addition to many other educational, medical and civic organizations. Yet Abe's proudest achievement, and greatest joy, was his family, to whom he was wholly devoted. He leaves behind the love of his life, Marianna, with whom he shared 57 wonderful years; son Ron Dranetz (Linda) of Chester, NJ; daughter Karen Wolf (Barry) of New York City; four grandchildren, Staci Wolf, Jenna Wolf, Jennifer Dranetz and Alexander Dranetz; and a brother, Marshall Dranetz, of Bryan, TX. He was predeceased by a sister, Sylvia Ross, of Bethesda, MD. Abe also leaves behind numerous friends who will miss him dearly. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, February 17 at 10am, Beth Israel Cemetery/Woodbridge Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. 1/3

SANDERS--Tony R.,accomplished poet, beloved father, brother and friend to many died on February 11, 2015. Born on May 2, 1957 in New York City, he was educated at Phillips Andover Academy, Yale, The Iowa's Writer's Workshop and University of Houston. Tony published four collections of poetry, including his latest collection of prose poems Subject Matters and a collaboration of verse with his dear friend and fellow poet Chard deNiord. Tony's poetry appeared in numerous publications including, Poetry, Paris Review, The Yale Review, The Gettysburg Review and The New York Times Book Review. Ten of his poems were nominated for Pushcart Prizes. He lived in New York City and Vermont. Tony was a member of The National Arts Club and Poets House. He is survived by two sons, Matthew and Jack Sanders, as well his sisters Jody Foote and Barbara Bradley, and brother Malcom Sanders. Donations can be made in his memory to Poets House, 10 River Terrace, New York, NY 10282 or poetshouse.org. 1/3

WEYHE--Arthur H. (1917-2015). An artist, engineer and World War II Veteran, and son of the late Erhard and Hannah Weyhe. He was born and raised in Manhattan, spent summers in Nova Scotia and later lived in Hurley, New York. Arthur died peacefully in his sleep on February 12, 2015. He is survived by his son Philip Weyhe and daughter-in-law Georgina; daughter Abby Weyhe Anderson and son-in-law Gary; grandchildren Philip Weyhe Jr., Brendan Weyhe and Rachael Weyhe; niece Deborah Kiley and her sons Dennis and Owen. Arthur was an active benefactor of the arts, nature preservation and civil liberties. He had an extraordinary presence and will be missed. A memorial to celebrate Arthur's life will be held at the Kleinert/James Center for the Arts, Woodstock, NY on Saturday, February 21 at 3:00pm. 1/3

TEDESCO-GARONE--Anna M. Daughter of the late Vittoria and Flaviano Tedesco. Cherished, loving, caring, sister of Lucia. Beloved, devoted, adoring wife of 57 years of Vincent T. Garone. The inseparable wind beneath our wings passed to her heavenly, unexpected rest on February 13, 2015. Her beauty, intelligence, grace and elegance radiated in all her accomplishments. Fluent in five languages, she served as liaison between the U.S., China, and Iran during the Carter Administration. She attended St. Jean Baptiste High School and Fordham University. She loved music, travel, an exceptional cook and was a vicarious reader. Family will receive friends Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc. 34 Hempstead Ave (Corner Peninsula Blvd) Lynbrook. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10:30am at St. Joseph R.C. Church; Hewlett. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. Memorial Donations may be made to the American Heart Association. For further information please visit: flinchandbruns.com. 1/3

GOLDSCHMID--Harvey J. He was the model law professor, combining real world experience and transactional sense with a strong understanding of economic theory. Students adored him; practitioners respected him; and government agencies depended on him. He was also an admirable human being, generous, open-minded, and compassionate. With particular awareness of his contributions to the shaping of corporate and securities law, we Columbia colleagues mourn his passing. Jack Coffee, Merritt Fox, Ron Gilson, Jeff Gordon, Zohar Goshen, Rob Jackson, Kate Judge, Curtis Milhaupt, Katharina Pistor 1/3

HARRIS--Herman, 88, of East Brunswick, NJ passed away peacefully on February 14, 2015. A lifelong resident of New Jersey, he was a CPA who loved to sing in a chorus and paint in watercolors. 1/3

WEINER--Melvyn MD. Cherished husband of Serafina. Beloved father of Bruce (Susan), Robert, William (Lois), and Nancy Tice (Hal). Caring stepfather of Nathaniel Bier (Esther), Monica Goldman, Cindy Sofer (David), and Jessica Habif (Hayim). Beloved grandfather of Elizabeth Shulman (Arie), Daniel, David and Sarah Weiner, Stephanie Chernoff (Brian), Rachel Weiner, Rose, Ashley and Erica Weiner, Ben and Hannah Tice, Elizabeth Bier, Harry and Alex Goldman, Sarah Abigail, Abraham and Shimon Sofer, David, Emily, Joshua and Zachary Habif. Great grandfather of Sammy and Maya Shulman. He was predeceased by his wife Sondra Goldwyn Weiner. May his memory be a blessing to all who loved him. We have all lost a truly good man; and so he will dwell in the house of the lord forever, Amen. 1/3

ISAACS--Gertrude, on February 11, 2015 at age 79. Beloved wife, "Puppi," of the late Bernard Isaacs, cherished mother of Michele and Diane and their husbands, Tommy and Marc, adored "Mimi" of Carly and Daniel. EVANS--John Robert. Died peacefully at home February 13, 2015 after a long struggle with Parkinson's disease. John enjoyed a full life marked by contributions on many fronts. He pioneered a new model of medical education as the founding Dean of McMaster University Medical School in 1965. He served as President of the University of Toronto from 1972-1978. He was the first Director of the World Banks Population, Health and Nutrition Division. He was the CEO of Allelix, Canadas first biotechnology company, the Chair of TorStar, the first Chair of the Canadian Foundation for Innovation, the Chair of the Rockefeller Foundation, and most recently the founding Chair of MaRS. Throughout his career and his life, his greatest satisfaction came from caring for others as a clinician and mentoring colleagues in their careers. Born October 1, 1929, John joined siblings Mary, Watson, Gertrude, Gwendolyn, Anne and Elizabeth as the youngest of seven children of Mary and William Watson Evans. John will be missed by his loving wife Gay, of 61 years, his children Derek, Mark, Michael, Gill, Tim and Willa, his daughters/sons-in-law, Janet, Sarah, Lise, Alayne and David and his 23 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Grace Church on the Hill in Toronto on Thursday, February 19, 2015 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Parkinson's Society Canada. 1/3
GOULD--Eleanor. We mourn the passing of "Mrs. Gould", an indelible presence in our lives. Our love goes out to Suzanne and Jeff and their families. The Finkel/Bernstein Family 1/3

RABKIN--Leo, passed on February 15, 2015, at 95. Leo Rabkin's abstract art preserved and presented life's most delicate, tender discoveries and interactions. His advanced sympathy with modernism's restraint, formality, and openness with materials focused his individual sensitivities into decades of hand-made collages, plastic sculptures, watercolors, and unique etchings. Light-- and shadow--were constant attendants. An independent in his work, he was fully engaged with the art and social issues of his times. He served as President of the American Abstract Artists often during its early history and more recently on the New York City Art Commission. Leo and his extraordinary wife Dorothea were eminent collectors of American Folk Art: serious benefactors to this culture and to the museum that represents it, New York's Museum of American Folk Art. Their home/studio itself, with its sky-lit great hall, is a museum worthy of being landmarked. Leo came to New York as a young man from Cincinnati, where years of immersion in music and theatre helped form a character of great, insightful humanity. Dorothea came to New York after WWII from Berlin. Here she created a new life of immense intelligence, generosity--and humor. We friends hope that we can live up to the example of accomplishment, open-mindedness, and endless kindness that Leo and Dorothea showed us all, year after year, exhibition after exhibition, visit after visit. 1/3

TEICH--Vivian. At 8:15am, February 14th, 2015, our dear mother, wife, sister, grandmother, and friend, Vivian Teich (nee Schindler), passed away at home, peacefully in her sleep, after a nearly five year battle with ovarian cancer. Vivi was truly one of a kind, lighting up her family, her classrooms and theater stages with her radiant beauty, personality, humor and warmth. Throughout her life and brave battle, she inspired many to live life to the fullest, share love, and reach for the stars. She is survived by her husband Morton, her five children, Karina, David, Marko, Aaron and Aly, 11 grandchildren, and her sister Nicole. While our world is dimmer without her in it, the sky is now a little brighter with Vivi sparkling among the stars. Following a private burial in Long Island the family will hold a Memorial Service today, February 17, 2015, at 2pm at Frank E Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st St). 1/3

JAEGER--Jerry Joseph, beloved husband of 58 years to Marcia Z. Jaeger, devoted father to Bruce W. Jaeger (Phyllis) of Manhattan and Dr. Lawrence D. Jaeger (Erika) of Larchmont, NY passed away on February 15th, 2015. In addition to his wife and children, he leaves behind his beloved grandchildren, Cole, Quentin, Chase and Ryan, and his sister Marilyn Stever, cherished nieces and nephews and many dear friends. Jerry served with honor as a hospital corpsman in the U.S. Navy on the USS Haven hospital ship off the battle zone in Inchon, Korea. He was awarded the Korean Service medal, the National Defense medal and the U.N. Service medal. Services will be held on Friday, February 20 at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Glenville Cemetery in Greenwich, CT. 1/3

GLASER--Morris (Moishe), of Brooklyn, NY died peacefully in his sleep Sunday, February 8, at the MJHS Menorah Center in Manhattan Beach. He was 85. Devoted high school literature teacher for forty plus years in the New York City education system and fondly remembered into retirement by many of his students; Korean War veteran; world traveler from Park Slope to Patagonia to Paris to Pistoia; feinschmecker connoisseur of the world's cuisines; deplorer of euphemisms and cliches; admirer of Proust and Nabokov, Beethoven and Bartok; Morris forged his own way through life and is dearly remembered by his friends for his loyalty, his individuality, and for courageously taking the road less traveled. His survivors include his sister Goldie Katz, niece Laura Katz, and nephews David and Charlie Katz, and six grandnieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service is planned for the spring, the date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Morris's name to BrightFocus Foundation for Alzheimers Research http://tinyurl.com/nw3q85l

WEINBERG--Charles L. The Board of Trustees of Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, along with its Administration and staff mourn the passing of our dear friend and trustee, Charlie Weinberg. Blythedale has been fortunate to have been associated with Charlie since 1966, during which time he served in many leadership positions. Charlie has held the position of Treasurer, Vice President and President of the Board of Trustees. Most recently, he served as Chairman of our Facilities Committee. Charlie was an extraordinary humanitarian who always helped those in need. His wisdom, thoughtfulness and guidance were invaluable and will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Judy and his entire family. Owen Gutfreund, Chair Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President & CEO

RACINE--Leo I.,age 96, died in Palm Beach on February 14. Beloved husband of June Walsh for 72 years. Loving father of Timothy of Palm Beach, William of Pittsburgh, PA, John of Los Angeles and Mary Dryfoos of Poughkeepsie, NY. Proud grandfather of Gillian and Alexis Racine, Robert and Pamela Dryfoos and the late Sean Racine. Great-grandfather of Jake Dryfoos. A Veteran of World War II, he served as pilot of B17 Flying Fortress with the 8th Air Force. A graduate of Deerfield Academy and College of The Holy Cross. Leo worked in the New York office of Joseph P. Kennedy, Inc. for 42 years, and participated in campaigns of JFK, RFK and EMK. After retiring to Palm Beach, he became Historian of the winter White House when it was purchased by John and Marianne Castle. Visitation at Quattlebaum Funeral Home on Wednesday from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass on Thursday at Noon at St. Edward's Church.

FOXEN--Eleanor Amy, on February 15, 2015 of Laurel Hollow, NY. Beloved wife of the late William Alfred Foxen. Cherished mother of Kathleen (Kim), Nancy, Elizabeth (Fred), Bebe (Rich), Peter (Brenda), Anne (Richard) and the late William, Jr. (Denise). Adored grandmother of Katherine, John (Carolyn), Katie, Isabel, Molly, James, Ashley, Emily, Peter, Matthew, Alex, Abbey, Nicholas, Juliet, Christian, Lindsay and Gracie. Dear sister of Elizabeth and the late Marcelle. Eleanor Veronica Amy was born on January 23, 1923 to her wonderful parents Henry and Marcelle. She grew up in Garden City, Long Island, where she was an outstanding student at Garden City High School. She graduated from Manhattanville College in 1944 at the top of her class. Eleanor went on to work at Benton & Bowles Advertising Agency, where she met the love of her life, Bill Foxen. After twenty five years as a stay-at-home mother, she took a position as Village Clerk for Laurel Hollow, where she worked until she retired at age 75. Eleanor was the epitome of grace and dignity, religious devotion, intellectual curiosity, and good humor. It is hard to count the number of people whose lives she touched and influenced. It is impossible to describe the depth of love that her family has for her. In her last days she wanted to make sure that we all knew that she had had a wonderful life; that we should be grateful for the wonderful lives that we have; how special we all are; and how much she loved each and everyone of us. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY. Visiting is Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Thursday morning at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church, Anstice St., Oyster Bay, NY. Private burial.

WEINBERG--Charles Lippe, on February 15, 2015, age 94. He is survived by his wife, Judy, children, David and Vivian Weinberg, Jean Weinberg and Mark Dinaburg, and Barbara and Walter Groden, and his loving grandchildren, Deborah Groden, Philip Weinberg, Suzanne and David Laswell, and Sarah Dinaburg. Charles was a founder of both Westchester Reform Temple and Westhab, whose mission is, "Building Communities. Changing Lives," and these are words by which he lived. Charles served on the Boards of White Plains Hospital, Builders Institute, Blythedale Children's Hospital, and Surprise Lake Camp. A world-traveler he loved skiing, the arts and animals of all sizes. His trademarks were his quiet kindness and wit and his ubiquitous yellow ties. Charles leaves behind a legacy of compassion, generosity and humility, and he will be endlessly missed. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in his name to the charity of your choice. A funeral service will be held Thursday, February 19, 2015, 11:30 am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

COHEN--Professor Getzel M. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Professor Getzel M. Cohen, of blessed memory, a world- renowned professor of classics. Professor Cohen was the beloved husband of Sheila Cohen, revered father of Shifrah Wassner, Ephraim Cohen and Sender Cohen. Sender Cohen is an alumnus of Yeshiva College and a member of the YU Board of Trustees who, together with his wife, Tali Rosenblatt, is a YU Benefactor. Professor Cohen is the beloved brother of Avi Cohen, a grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle to many. Professor Cohen had a chair at Princeton University, from which he earned his PhD, and was a professor at the University of Cincinnati, where he taught until this semester. He was a guest lecturer at the Sorbonne in Paris and at many universities throughout the world. He will be sorely missed by his family, friends and students. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. The Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America mourns the loss of Board Co-Chairman, Distinguished Eagle Scout John C. Whitehead. His thoughtful and generous leadership of NYC Scouting and Exploring has left an indelible mark on hundreds of thousands of NYC young people and their families. We extend our deepest sympathy his family. The Board and Staff of the Greater New York Councils Boy Scouts of America

TEDESCO-GARONE--Anna. The Stecher and Horowitz Foundation grieves the loss of the beloved wife of our esteemed Board Member Vincent T. Garone and sister of Lucia Tedesco. Her indomitable spirit and love infused all the lives she touched. We treasured her. 1/3

WEINER--Dr. Melvyn. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Dr. Melvyn Weiner, beloved husband of Serafina Bier Weiner. To her, his children, grandchildren and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3
STEIN--Neil. Dear Neil, Happy Birthday. We remember you today as we remember you every day and will never forget you. Love, Bruce, Elyse and Family 1/3

MILLER--Beatrice 90, of North Woodmere, NY. Died peacefully on February 15 surrounded by family. While we mourn her passing, we also celebrate her long and happy life. All who loved her affectionately called her "The Bub." She is survived by Samuel, her husband of 66 years; her brother Rabbi Matthew Clark; her children Jane Groothuis (Michael) and Eric Miller (Dan); her grandchildren Adam, Alex and Carrie; and her great-grandchildren Justin, Benjamin, Brandon, Eli, Zoe, Lucas and Caleb. 1/3

BARTLETT--Elizabeth E. "Betsy". April 1, 1937 February 14, 2015 of New York City and Weston, CT, died peacefully at her home, surrounded by family. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio to Col. Walter J. Easton and Elizabeth Scott Easton. She graduated from Hathaway Brown School and attended Skidmore College. Betsy made a career as a Lady Arrow model and an interior decorator. Betsy was passionately involved in the community, and took great pride in her work. She was a long-time senior director at both St. Barnabas Hospital and New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC). More than anything, she was a devoted friend and family person. She was pre-deceased by former husband Peter Barry Bartlett (1934-2012). She is survived by her partner of 25 years, A. Jones Yorke, her sister and brother- in-law Virginia and Ralph Joslin, her children Kimberley Kernan of Rowayton, CT, Christopher Bartlett of Baltimore, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT, and adopted son Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, Tennessee. She cherished her six grandchildren Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett, and Christopher and Carly Lieder. Arrangements for a memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church in New York City are pending. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to either NYSPCC or St. Barnabas Hospital. 1/3

BUTTRICK--Harold Edgar, architect, died peacefully in his sleep at home, aged 84, surrounded by his family. Buttrick, whose career spanned six decades, was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, a member of the Century Association and the Harvard Club, and an active participant in the life of the city. Born in 1931, Harry was the eldest of three children of Constance LaBoiteaux Drake and Charles Edgar Buttrick, and had five additional siblings. He grew up in Bryn Mawr, PA and Nantucket, MA. Prior to enrolling as an undergraduate at Harvard, he was awarded an English Speaking Union travelling scholarship in its inaugural class, and spent several months in England. In 1953 he started graduate work at Harvard's Graduate School of Design, and two years later, married his GSD classmate Ann Octavia White, a granddaughter of architect Stanford White. Buttrick established his first solo practice in New York City in 1961 and subsequently engaged in several partnerships, including Buttrick, White and Burtis. His built work includes the St. Thomas Choir School building, the Dana Center in Central Park at the Harlem Meer, a monastery in Nairobi, Kenya, many residences, offices, Tower Records stores, and projects for numerous private schools. He oversaw the rebuilding of the Pulitzer Fountain at Grand Army Plaza, and his most recent partnership, Murphy, Burnham and Buttrick, continues with the restoration of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Throughout his professional life, Harry influenced and encouraged many young designers. An avid reader, gardener, hiker and music lover, Harry resided in Manhattan and Lyme, CT. Buttrick is survived by his wife Ann, and their children John Buttrick, Jerome Buttrick, Mary Burnham, Sarah Buttrick and Catherine Leland, five brothers, and seven grandchildren. Harry was a much loved husband and father. He had many dear friends and will be remembered for his positive personality, clear intelligence, elegance and good cheer. A funeral mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York at 10:30am on Thursday, February 20th. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New Yorkers for Parks, 55 Broad Street, New York, NY 10004. 1/3

BUTTRICK--Harold Edgar, architect, died peacefully in his sleep at home, aged 84, surrounded by his family. Buttrick, whose career spanned six decades, was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects, a member of the Century Association and the Harvard Club, and an active participant in the life of the city. Born in 1931, Harry was the eldest of three children of Constance LaBoiteaux Drake and Charles Edgar Buttrick, and had five additional siblings. He grew up in Bryn Mawr, PA and Nantucket, MA. Prior to enrolling as an undergraduate at Harvard, he was awarded an English Speaking Union travelling scholarship in its inaugural class, and spent several months in England. In 1953 he started graduate work at Harvard's Graduate School of Design, and two years later, married his GSD classmate Ann Octavia White, a granddaughter of architect Stanford White. Buttrick established his first solo practice in New York City in 1961 and subsequently engaged in several partnerships, including Buttrick, White and Burtis. His built work includes the St. Thomas Choir School building, the Dana Center in Central Park at the Harlem Meer, a monastery in Nairobi, Kenya, many residences, offices, Tower Records stores, and projects for numerous private schools. He oversaw the rebuilding of the Pulitzer Fountain at Grand Army Plaza, and his most recent partnership, Murphy, Burnham and Buttrick, continues with the restoration of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Throughout his professional life, Harry influenced and encouraged many young designers. An avid reader, gardener, hiker and music lover, Harry resided in Manhattan and Lyme, CT. Buttrick is survived by his wife Ann, and their children John Buttrick, Jerome Buttrick, Mary Burnham, Sarah Buttrick and Catherine Leland, five brothers, and seven grandchildren. Harry was a much loved husband and father. He had many dear friends and will be remembered for his positive personality, clear intelligence, elegance and good cheer. A funeral mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York at 10:30am on Thursday, February 19th. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New Yorkers for Parks, 55 Broad Street, New York, NY 10004. 1/3

Widow of the late Herman Fadem, beloved mother of Donald Meyer and step- mother of Richard Fadem, cherished grandmother of Jessica and Andrea Meyer and Luke and Anna Fadem. She will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to Mount Sinai Hospital and Central Synagogue. Funeral Services were held on Tuesday at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. Burial followed. 1/3

KRAKAUER--Jordan. Athlete Ally mourns the loss of Jordan Bradley Krakauer and expresses our heartfelt condolences to his mother and board member Frances Boller, father Ronald Krakauer, and all of his family, friends, and loved ones. We will miss Jordan's profound commitment to sports, on and off the field; he is our MVP. 1/3

WESELY--Edwin J. Passed away peacefully at home, at age 85, on February 15, 2015, after several years of declining health. Born into a European Catholic immigrant family in New York City, attended Brooklyn Tech and Deep Springs College. Graduate of Cornell University and Columbia Law School. Distinguished legal career: Federal Prosecutor, litigation partner with Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts (now Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman) for 37 years. Special Master in Federal Court cases. Dedicated humanitarian: many years as Chairman/ President of CARE, leading international relief and development agency, co-founder of CARE International. Many honors including Foreign Press Association World Humanitarian Award 1988. Member of Council on Foreign Relations. Served on nonprofit boards, chaired legal committees in Federal Court system. Traveled extensively, lived his life with zest. Survived by his wife of nearly a quarter-century, Marcy Brownson, former wife Yolanda T. Wesely, daughters Marissa Wesely and Adrienne Shirley, granddaughter Emma Allen, and a large extended family. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Deep Springs College (www.deepsprings.edu) or CARE (www.care.org).

CAPPELLO--Saverio "Reno" 74, died February 8, 2015 in Miami following a stroke in January. Reno was born in Ethiopia, where he lived until he was eight, and then lived in Italy until he emigrated to New York with his brother Enzo and mother Anna, when he was 15. He embraced America and was a scholarship student at New York University, where he received a BA and an MBA. He joined the New York National Guard while attending NYU and served for over 37 years, achieving the rank of Major before retiring in 2000. He had several careers, including as an economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an investment consultant and an entrepreneur. For the past 20 years, he had his own tax practice and served many beloved clients. Reno enjoyed cooking for his family and friends and travelled extensively in his later years. He was the loving husband of Cherrie Nanninga, cherished father of Annalisa and Dino Cappello, and caring grandfather of Maya and Jonah Porter, and Julia and Henry Cappello. He is also survived by his daughter-in- law, Valerie Cappello, his sisters-in-law, Patricia Cappello and Cathi Nanninga, and his nieces and nephews, Catherine Crevoiserat, Brian Cappello, and Madeline and Taylor Applegate. He was pre-deceased by his beloved brother Enzo, who died in October 2014. He will be hugely missed by family, friends and clients alike. May his memory be a blessing to all who loved him. A memorial service in Manhattan is planned for April 16; details will be announced at a later time. CHIRELSTEIN--Marvin A.,died on February 16th of heart failure. Born on October 8, 1928, Marvin went on to become one of the most famous tax law professors of his time. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1950; and then from the University of Chicago Law School in 1953, where he was editor-in-chief of the Chicago Law Review. After practicing in Washington D.C., and New York City, Marvin joined the Yale Law School faculty in 1965 where he remained until 1981 as the William Nelson Cromwell Professor of Law. He was a visiting professor at Harvard in 1976-77, and at Columbia in 1981-82. After a brief period in private practice, Marvin joined the Columbia faculty in 1984. A legendary teacher, Marvin taught federal taxation, corporate finance, and contracts. His texts on federal income taxation and contracts are widely used. He is survived by his loving wife Ellen and their son Paul. Services will be private. 1/3

WARING--Saul. Saul Waring, a prominent advertising executive, who built one of the industry's premier creative firms, Waring & LaRosa, died peacefully on Thursday, February 12th at his home in Manhattan. He was 84. His wife, Willa, said the cause was pulmonary fibrosis. Mr. Waring, the son of immigrant parents, grew up in the Bronx, where he learned about life, hard work and survival. He attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated from Baruch College CUNY, where he later returned to mentor students in its marketing department. In 1968, Mr. Waring, along with his longtime business partner, Joe LaRosa, opened Waring & LaRosa, which led to an extensive and rewarding career in the advertising business. The two men became co-chief executives of the firm and life-long friends. Mr. Waring was a generous philanthropist and was actively involved with The Weizmann Institute of Science, SYDA Foundation, Shalom Hartman Institute, Publicolor and Midori & Friends. He is survived by his loving wife, Willa, of Manhattan; his daughter, Janet, of Sebastopol, California and Manhattan; his son, Rob, his daughter-in-law, Ragnhild, and his beloved granddaughter, Inga, all of Oslo, Norway. A celebration of Saul's life will take place on Friday, February 20, from 6-8pm at All Souls Church at 1157 Lexington Ave., between East 79th and 80th Streets, in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to any of the aforementioned charities. 1/3

She grew up in Garden City, Long Island, where she was an outstanding student at Garden City High School. She graduated from Manhattanville College in 1944 at the top of her class. Eleanor went on to work at Benton & Bowles Advertising Agency, where she met the love of her life, Bill Foxen. RABKIN--Leo. Abstract artist and folk art collector Leo Rabkin died peacefully at his Chelsea home on Sunday, February 15 at the age of 95. Rabkin created colorful painted sculptures inside new and antique boxes. Throughout his long career, he described his works as nugatory divigations, wanderings of the spirit having little or no tangible value. Working with commonplace things found on city streets, he was ahead of his time and of inspiration to younger artists. Born 1919 in Cincinnati, Ohio, Rabkin spent his early life studying the violin and as a boy usher for the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Early exposure to the rigors of classical music helped him to "think abstractly." He was a member of the American Abstract Artists group for more than fifty years, serving as President from 1964-78. The group honored him with a tribute exhibition in the summer of 2014. He also served for many years on the Fine Arts Federation of New York. Leo Rabkin came to New York City in 1945 after service in World War II. He earned a master's in education and guidance counseling at New York University leading to a fifteen-year position at the Livingston School for Girls on King Street. His own experience with psychoanalysis deepened his understanding of art and led to studies with William Baziotes, Hale Woodruff and Robert Inglehart. He married Dorothea Herz (see NYT obit. December 5, 2008) in 1958 and the couple created a landmark collection of American folk art. The Rabkins donated many works to the American Folk Art Museum including the iconic whirligig sculpture of Uncle Sam riding a bicycle. The High Museum of Art in Atlanta also received historic folk art from the Rabkin Collection. In 2000, the couple created the Dorothea and Leo Rabkin Foundation to do charitable work in the arts community. He is survived by his nephew and nieces, Barry Blasberg, Gail Britt and Jill Blasberg Rosenstein, the children of his late sister, Emily Rabkin Blasberg. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

CHIRELSTEIN--Marvin A. Columbia Law School Professor Emeritus Marvin A. Chirelstein, a leading scholar of federal taxation, corporate law, and contracts whose textbooks are still used by students across the country, died on February 16. He was 86. Chirelstein first joined Columbia Law School in 1954 to work on the Federal Income Tax Project under Dean William C. Warren. He then joined the government as an attorney in the U.S. Department of the Treasury and later taught at Rutgers School of Law and Yale Law School. Chirelstein returned to Columbia Law School as a visiting professor in 1981 and became a full-time faculty member in 1984. Two years later, he was named the first Isidor and Seville Sulzbacher Professor of Law, an appointment announced by then-Columbia University President Michael I. Sovern. In addition to being a highly sought after academic expert on taxation, contracts, and corporate law, Chirelstein was a beloved professor who once taught a seminar on the legal side of one of his favorite sports: boxing. A music lover who played the violin, he was known for his dry sense of humor and quiet wit and was adored by students. Two of his textbooks, Concepts and Case Analysis in the Law of Contracts and Federal Income Taxation: A Law Students Guide to the Leading Cases and Concepts, have guided generations of future lawyers through the complexities of the law. A third, Cases and Materials on Corporate Finance, opened the way to interdisciplinary analysis of corporate law. Teaching was Chirelsteins passion, in addition to tax. Upon his appointment to the faculty in 1984, Chirelstein told the Columbia Law School News that he considered himself an educator at heart. As a professor at Yale Law School from 1965 to 1981, Chirelstein taught three future Columbia Law faculty colleagues: John C. Coffee Jr., Merritt B. Fox, and Ronald J. Gilson. He also taught future U.S. President Bill Clinton, who commented: "I had the privilege of having Professor Chirelstein for both Tax Law and Corporate Finance at Yale--he was memorably patient with me in the former, and seemed pleased when I redeemed myself in the latter. He had a great sense of humor, forgiving me for reading One Hundred Years of Solitude in class and laughing at my answer when asked how I could be such a bad tax student and do so well in corporate finance: I said it was a lot like politics--someone's trying to gain at someone else's expense, and there have to be rules to avoid fraud and violence. It was the beginning of a long, if long distance, friendship. Professor Chirelstein, as I neared graduation, told me about a teaching vacancy at the University of Arkansas Law School in Fayetteville, and recommended me for a job that enriched and changed my life. I'll always be grateful for his gifted teaching, endless curiosity, and generous spirit." For Prof. Fox, Chirelstein first kindled his interest in corporate finance. "Students looked forward to going to Chirelsteins class every day, Fox said. He was remarkably incisive and sophisticated in his treatment of the issues, while at the same time being incredibly funny. It is a source of real pleasure that my son, Peter Fox 09, was able to have the same experience, taking tax with Chirelstein here at Columbia Law School. A trusted adviser, Chirelstein was often asked to provide commentary on taxation policies or reform efforts. In a 1994 Letter to the Editor published in The New York Times, Chirelstein supported President Clintons progressive taxation. . . . the distribution of national income has grown increasingly unequal over the last dozen years, at least in part as a consequence of the tax legislation that President Reagan put over on a gullible public, Chirelstein wrote in the Times. We are constantly told that American voters are disaffected, that they suffer from a political malaise, that they no longer trust their political leaders, and so on. Surely one reason is a growing sense that economic progress has been for the few. Progressive taxation won't solve the problem. But it helps, both actually and as a symbol of our national ideals. On Tax Day in 1998, Chirelstein appeared on PBS NewsHour with Jim Lehrer to again defend the U.S. tax system despite its complexities, which he attributed to Congress trying to administer too many programs through the tax code. We collect a trillion, three hundred billion dollars a year through the administration of our tax laws, and thats done largely by voluntary compliance, he said. I think anyone would regard that as an immense achievement. Professor John Coffee, who first met Chirelstein as a student at Yale Law School said Chirelstein was a Man for All Seasons. His students immediately learned that he had a martini-dry wit, a razor-sharp mind, but a uniquely self-effacing teaching method under which he convinced students that he needed their help to solve a seemingly simple problem on the blackboard, Coffee recalled. During the 1970s, his influential work with Victor Brudney illuminated the field of corporate law, but also showed that he was committed to fairness and preferred background norms of equality and equal treatment. Chirelstein graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1950. He earned his J.D. from the University of Chicago Law School in 1953 and served as editor-in-chief of the University of Chicago Law Review. He is survived by his wife, Ellen, and his son, Paul. Our hearts are filled with sorrow at the passing of this great man. 1/3

O'SULLIVAN--Joseph on 24/15/d. Joe, 82, was born in Queens, served in the Korean War and finished Columbia University and Columbia Business School. He joined the (Morgan) Guaranty Trust in 1959, retiring in 1989 from JP Morgan Securities, where he led the Municipal Bond Group. Respected for his integrity and dearly loved for his kindness and reflection, he is greatly missed by his loving wife of 50 years Lou Ann, his brother Jeremiah, and his many devoted nieces and nephews. The family extends their gratitude to Joe's devoted healthcare assistant and friend, Sam Menash. A mass will be held on Saturday, February 21st at 9:30 am in the chapel at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

GORE--Lesley. Dear Lesley: You left your party early! Now we have the option to cry but we just won't. We'd rather remember. Oh, Lesley, we remember the first party when we went to your Sweet Sixteen and then all the many events and maybe some we don't remember. We remember youth. We remember good health. We remember how we all took it for granted and the heady life we all led and the early success of being sought out, sought after and then in a blink, the evaporation as new styles and fickle audiences dictated tastes and careers but your talent remained as it was before. Some capitulated, others were bummed out, but you remained strong. You were filled with wry wit and we laughed and you kept courageously trying new types of writing, using your husky voice as part of your resilience to keep plugging tunes, masters and concepts. You blessedly had the support of Lois, a rock of a partner and Michael as a brotherly part of the team. We were both blessed to have Mr. Marty, our friend in common, but there will be no more yacht trips and no more Mr. Marty to play with at the villa from hell in St. Bart's or the fancy hotels in Capri. There is no more Jean-Claude keeping our table for us at Chez Josephine to celebrate our festival for Valentines Day and no more red ostrich plumes getting in our food from the molting boa you were forced to wear around your neck while we told naughty stories. But darling, we still see you and we see you with all of those people every night when we see the twinkling of the stars in the sky. We know you are with them. We know everyone is singing, dancing, sailing, laughing and telling funny outrageous stories. You have convinced the angels to be your back-up group and to sing harmony. Now no one owns you, Lesley, but we do own our memories of you. Goodbye, our Sweetie Pie from Tenafly. Goodbye. Myrna and Freddie Gershon 1/3

BARTLETT--Elizabeth The Board of Directors and staff of The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (The NYSPCC) mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Elizabeth (Betsy) Bartlett. A dedicated member of the Board of Directors for over 36 years, Betsy maintained a passionate commitment to the safety and well-being of New York City's children throughout her tenure. She was unanimously elected to the Board in 1979, served as Vice-President from 1991 until 2013, and chaired the Development Committee from 1979 until 2012. Betsy's wisdom, compassion and generosity of spirit were an inspiration to us all. We extend our deepest condolences to Jones, her children and the entire Bartlett family.

GRIMM--Kathleen "Kate", 68, of NYC died peacefully in her home on February 17. She was the beloved and admired eldest of nine siblings. Kathleen received her B.A. from Manhattanville College and held a J.D. From New York Law School and an LL.M (Tax) from NYU School of Law. Kathleen's career was one of significant service and contribution to New York. She was First Deputy Commissioner of the NYC Department of Finance and NYS Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York. Since 2002, Kathleen was Deputy Chancellor in charge of Operations at the NYC Department of Education. Kathleen is survived by her sisters: Barbara of Brunswick, NY, Paula of NYC; six brothers: Karl of Troy, NY and Port Charlotte, FL, Gary (Theresa) of Latham, NY, John (Ann Marie) Of Richmond, VA, Peter of Troy, NY, Mark (Karen) of Guilderland, NY, and David of Babcock Lake, NY as well as 10 nieces and nephews and three grand nieces and nephews. Calling hours at Frank E. Campbell Friday from 4:00-8:00pm. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 11:00am at The Church of St. Catherine of Siena on E. 68th St. in NYC. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery, Troy, NY. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Kathleen Grimm Government Service Scholarship Fund at New York Law School. https://alumni.nyls.edu/grimm-scholarship.
