GRIMM--Kathleen. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of our beloved Trustee and alumna Kathleen Grimm '80. Ms. Grimm had a long record of dedication to public service, most recently as Deputy Chancellor of Operations at the New York City Department of Education. She was a long-time member of the New York Law School Board of Trustees and also served on NYLS's Alumni Association Board of Directors for over two decades, including as Past President. Ms. Grimm graduated from NYLS cum laude in 1980 and then earned an LL.M. (Tax) from New York University School of Law. She worked as an IRS estate tax attorney and in private practice before embarking on her long career in public service. Her service to her beloved City is evidence she was one of the City's most dedicated civil servants ever. She served five Mayors, one Comptroller, seven Commissioners, and four Chancellors. She was First Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department of Finance, New York State Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York, and had been Deputy Chancellor at the NYC Department of Education for more than 12 years. At New York Law School's 122nd Commencement Exercises in May 2014, the Law School awarded her the President's Medal in recognition of her inspiring leadership, her distinguished and dedicated service to the Law School, and her outstanding accomplishments and influence in the fields of law and education. On February 11, 2015, the NYLS Board of Trustees established the Kathleen Grimm '80 Government Service Scholarship Fund and the Kathleen Grimm '80 Medal for Distinguished Public Service in her honor. Ms. Grimm's family asks those wishing to remember her to do so by donating to the Fund at: https://alumni.nyls.edu/ grimm-scholarship or by sending a check to: NYLS Office of the Dean, 185 West Broadway, New York, NY 10013. Arthur N. Abbey, Chair, New York Law School Board of Trustees; Anthony W. Crowell Dean and President, New York Law School 1/3

SUYDAM--Peggy Card, passed away peacefully on February 13, 2015 at Riverwoods in Exeter, NH. A longtime resident of Bellport, NY and South Bristol, ME, Peggy was a beloved mother, an accomplished thespian, and a small business owner. She was 93. Peggy was a graduate of Sayville High School and Lasell Junior College. She was the daughter of Clarence Preston Card and Margaret Johnston Card of Sayville. She married Lispenard "Liz" Suydam (predeceased) in 1942. They met racing sailboats on the Great South Bay. Peggy's love of off Broadway theatre was contagious among her friends. In the early 1960s, she and two neighbors founded the Bellport Playcrafters, the longest continuing amateur theatre group in the State of New York. She was involved in every phase of production, singing, and acting. Her most memorable role was that of Eliza in "My Fair Lady." Other shows included "South Pacific," "Oklahoma," "Carousel," "The Seven Year Itch," "Kiss Me Kate," "West Side Story," "The Women," "Bell Book" and "Candle," and her last role as Fiona in "Brigadoon." Peggy started a local gift and gourmet shop in Sayville named the Country Mouse. She sold the business and her beach house in Davis Park in the early 1970s when she and Lispenard moved to South Bristol, ME. In South Bristol, she was active in the early years of the Antiques Fair, which continues to benefit Miles Memorial Hospital today. In 2001, the couple moved to Riverwoods. Peggy soon volunteered in both the library and store. A description of Peggy would not be complete without mentioning her love for animals, particularly pets. She generously supported both the Humane Society and the ASPCA. Though many would say it was none of her business, she was outspoken when she saw instances of human cruelty to animals, as she believed that pets were unable to defend themselves. This love was instilled in both her children and grandchildren. Peggy had many accomplishments. Her greatest, however, was as a first-class lady and mother of three, occasionally unruly, boys. She is survived by all three: Nardi Suydam and his partner Elizabeth Parker, Bryce Suydam and his wife, Maryann Gilligan Suydam, all of Marblehead, MA and Peter Suydam and his partner Sally Vittum of New Harbor, ME. Peggy is also survived by four grandchildren, Nick, Bryce, and Jonathan Suydam, and Maggie Butorac, as well as one great-grandchild, Jack Butorac. A memorial service will be held at Saint Anne's Episcopal Church in Sayville at a time and date in June to be announced. 1/3

VITERBI--Erna Finci. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Erna Finci Viterbi of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., a devoted Technion supporter. Together with her husband, Qualcomm co-founder and Technion Distinguished Visiting Professor Dr. Andrew Viterbi, she was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. Andrew is a member of the Technion International Board of Governors and the ATS National Board of Regents. Among the couple's many gifts to the Technion are the Andrew J. and Erna F. Viterbi Center for Advanced Studies in Computer Technology, the Andrew J. and Erna F. Viterbi Chair in Information Systems/Computer Science, the Andrew and Erna Finci Viterbi Fellowship Program, and the Viterbi Family Foundation Faculty Recruitment and Fellowship Program. We extend our heartfelt condolences to husband Andrew, children Audrey and Daniel Smargon, Alan and Caryn Viterbi, and Valerie Viterbi, widow of the late Alexander Viterbi, and the entire Viterbi family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

SIFFERT--Robert, MD. A great teacher and orthopaedic surgical clinician who developed innovative procedures in the area of pediatric orthopaedics. He was my privilege to share 35 years of clinical practice and close association with him. We extend our condolences to his children and their families. Roger & Judy Levy

SIFFERT--Robert S.,orthopedic surgeon, passed away peacefully at home on February 18. He was 96 years old. Dr. Siffert was the youngest and longest-serving Chair of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City, serving for 26 years. In 1960, he was appointed Director of the Department. When the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine was created, he served as its first Professor and Chairman of Orthopedics. He was the first recipient of the Robert K. Lippmann Chair in Orthopedics. In 1986, he was named the Bernard J. Lasker/Robert S. Siffert Distinguished Service Professor. Dr. Siffert also was the Senior Orthopedic Consultant for the Department of Health of NYC. He published over 150 articles with major emphasis on research and clinical pediatric orthopedics. His book "How Your Child's Body Grows" was an accessible guide for parents. He was a fellow of many national and international orthopedic societies. He received numerous awards, including the Arthritis Foundation Lifetime Achievement Award, the Mt. Sinai Hospital Jacobi Medallion and the Richman Award for Humanism and Ethics. He also served as the Vice President of the National Easter Seals. Dr. Siffert worked with Care-Medico on month-long medical service missions teaching and delivering medical care in developing countries, including Tunisia, Kenya, Indonesia, Afghanistan, Peru and Haiti. Dr. Siffert insisted that he never retired but "graduated" to continue his research in osteoporosis and his work as a graphic artist. Dr. Siffert was an avid artist. His woodcuts were shown in New York and on Martha's Vineyard. Dozens of his woodcuts now hang on permanent display at the United States Courthouse in Manhattan and in the United States Supreme Court. Dr. Siffert served as Captain and Flight Surgeon in the U.S. Army Air Force in World War II, flying the "hump" between China, Burma and India. He received four Battle Stars. Dr. Siffert was predeceased by his wife, Miriam, of 67 years. He is survived by his daughter Joan, his son John (Goldie), his grandchildren Molly Ann Ouanes (Alexx), David and Matthew, as well as his partner Ruth Friendly. He will be missed profoundly by his family and all he touched. Donations may be made to the Department of Orthopedics, Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

A mass will be held on Saturday, February 21st at 9:30 am in the chapel at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

GRIMM--Kathleen "Kate", 68, of NYC died peacefully in her home on February 17. She was the beloved and admired eldest of nine siblings. Kathleen received her B.A. from Manhattanville College and held a J.D. From New York Law School and an LL.M (Tax) from NYU School of Law. Kathleen's career was one of significant service and contribution to New York. She was First Deputy Commissioner of the NYC Department of Finance and NYS Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York. Since 2002, Kathleen was Deputy Chancellor in charge of Operations at the NYC Department of Education. Kathleen is survived by her sisters: Barbara of Brunswick, NY, Paula of NYC; six brothers: Karl of Troy, NY and Port Charlotte, FL, Gary (Theresa) of Latham, NY, John (Ann Marie) Of Richmond, VA, Peter of Troy, NY, Mark (Karen) of Guilderland, NY, and David of Babcock Lake, NY as well as 10 nieces and nephews and three grand nieces and nephews. Calling hours at Frank E. Campbell Friday from 4:00-8:00pm. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Saturday at 11:00am at The Church of St. Catherine of Siena on E. 68th St. in NYC. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery, Troy, NY. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Kathleen Grimm Government Service Scholarship Fund at New York Law School. https://alumni.nyls.edu/grimm-scholarship.

MORRIN--John, aka Solomon Shapiro, passed away on February 18, 2015 at the age of 95. SIFFERT--Robert S.,orthopedic surgeon, passed away peacefully at home on February 18. He was 96 years old. Dr. Siffert was the youngest and longest-serving Chair of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City, serving for 26 years. In 1960, he was appointed Director of the Department. When the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine was created, he served as its first Professor and Chairman of Orthopedics. He was the first recipient of the Robert K. Lippmann Chair in Orthopedics. In 1986, he was named the Bernard J. Lasker/Robert S. Siffert Distinguished Service Professor. Dr. Siffert also was the Senior Orthopedic Consultant for the Department of Health of NYC. He published over 150 articles with major emphasis on research and clinical pediatric orthopedics. His book "How Your Child's Body Grows" was an accessible guide for parents. He was a fellow of many national and international orthopedic societies. He received numerous awards, including the Arthritis Foundation Lifetime Achievement Award, the Mt. Sinai Hospital Jacobi Medallion and the Richman Award for Humanism and Ethics. He also served as the Vice President of the National Easter Seals. Dr. Siffert worked with Care-Medico on month-long medical service missions teaching and delivering medical care in developing countries, including Tunisia, Kenya, Indonesia, Afghanistan, Peru and Haiti. Dr. Siffert insisted that he never retired but "graduated" to continue his research in osteoporosis and his work as a graphic artist. Dr. Siffert was an avid artist. His woodcuts were shown in New York and on Martha's Vineyard. Dozens of his woodcuts now hang on permanent display at the United States Courthouse in Manhattan and in the United States Supreme Court. Dr. Siffert served as Captain and Flight Surgeon in the U.S. Army Air Force in World War II, flying the "hump" between China, Burma and India. He received four Battle Stars. Dr. Siffert was predeceased by his wife, Miriam, of 67 years. He is survived by his daughter Joan, his son John (Goldie), his grandchildren Molly Ann Ouanes (Alexx), David and Matthew, as well as his partner Ruth Friendly. He will be missed profoundly by his family and all he touched. Donations may be made to the Department of Orthopedics, Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

SIFFERT--Robert S.,MD. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and longtime colleague, Robert S. Siffert, MD, a distinguished physician and former Chair of Orthopaedics at The Mount Sinai Hospital and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. An internationally acclaimed orthopaedic surgeon, he also served as Orthopaedic Surgeon-in- Chief, among other titles, and under his stewardship, the Department of Orthopaedics introduced some of today's most commonly used practices, including hip arthroplasty. His career at Mount Sinai spanned five decades: he started as a resident in orthopaedics in 1946, later joined the voluntary staff, and held leadership positions until his retirement in 2000, after which he maintained the rank of Distinguished Service Professor. Dr. Siffert also served as Senior Consultant to the New York City Department of Health from 1952-- 60, and, driven by a long-time interest in pediatric orthopaedics, in 1970 he founded the Pediatric Orthopaedic Club of New York. A popular visiting professor and lecturer across the country and the world, he authored nearly 200 articles and chapters, as well as four books in his field. He performed many medical service missions abroad, including service as a flight surgeon in World War II. He was also recognized as a skilled artist who crafted intricate woodcut pieces, many of which are on permanent exhibition at the Federal Courthouse in lower Manhattan. We extend our deepest condolences to his family, colleagues, and friends. It is with profound gratitude and fondness that we will remember Dr. Siffert's many years of service, not only to Mount Sinai, but to the global medical community. Peter W. May Chairman Boards of Trustees Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD President and Chief Executive Officer Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai President for Academic Affairs Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

COSTANTINO--Giuseppe Prolific Psychologist, writer, researcher, clinician and professor. Pioneer of multicultural assessment, Dr. Costantino is the author of the only projective/narrative multicultural test, TEMAS (Tell-Me-A-Story). Passed away Wednesday February 18, 2015.

KRIEGER--Douglas H. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing of its distinguished member and Past President 1981-1982. Funeral service is tomorrow 11:00am John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, New York, NY. Joseph Carola III President 1/3
BURKE--Christine B. February 21, 2006 Truly remembered because you truly cared. As Ever, Eric Coleman

KATZ--Larry "Cha Cha" Born April 5, 1931 in the Bronx. He weathered a troubled childhood to become a leading executive in the Women's Garment and Fashion Industry. Equally at home on a golf course, in a sales room or at the track, Larry and his wife Rita cut a graceful figure on many dance floors. Though he disdained formal education, Larry had a keen and logical mind and provided his younger brothers Gerald and Stuart with sage advice and an inspirational example. His kindness and generosity, to family and friends, was legendary. His giving ran the gamut of donations to Native American organizations to furnishing the State of Israel with a high tech ambulance. He will be deeply missed by his brothers, their wives Barbara and Jane, his nieces Vicki (Jack), Lesley, Jennifer (Scott), Emily (Steven), Amanda and Sally and his devoted friend and caregiver Neil. Larry was an independent spirit who in his words "Did the best he could with the hand he was dealt." Chapel services to honor his memory will be held on Sunday, February 22, 2015, 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, with interment to follow at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY where he will be laid to rest next to his beloved Rita and close to his adored mother Sally.
ROSENKRANTZ--Diane. February 21, 2011. We'll be loving you, always. Edmund and Elizabeth

WEINBERG--Charles L. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend and Board Member Charles L. Weinberg. For more than 40 years, his support and leadership helped to transform the Hospital to the facility it is today. His endearing, quiet nature and warm spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Judy and their entire family. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board of Directors; Jon B. Schandler, CEO Susan Fox, President

FODOR--Marcia Kreitzer, 89, died February 8 in New York City from pneumonia. Marcia was born in the Bronx. She spoke English and Yiddish and lived an active life enjoying the cultural offerings here and the company of her many friends. Her professional life included positions at a talent agency, the Educational Alliance camps and HIP. She is survived by her son, Eric, her daughter-in-law Valerie and grandchildren Benjamin and Isabel. She was predeceased by her sister Sylvia and her husbands Lester Kreitzer and Tibor Fodor. Her memory will be cherished and she will be sorely missed by family and friends. A memorial service is planned for February 22 at 2pm at Strykers Bay Apartments, 66 West 94th Street. 1/3

ZAPHIROPOULOS--Miltiades L.,M.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute & Society are deeply saddened at the loss of our eminence grise, in his 101st year. Beloved for his modesty, grace and quiet elegance, his loyal devotion and wise counsel sustained and influenced generations at our Institute. An esteemed colleague, as teacher, friend, and Training and Supervising Analyst, his humanity, spirit, and energy infused his many roles. Consummate clinician and imaginative teacher, the legacy of his vitality, erudition, incisive wit, playful mind, and compelling but gentle honesty inspires us. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Nicholas Samstag, Ph.D., President, White Society Christopher N. Young, President, Board of Trustees 1/3

BARTLETT--Elizabeth The Board of Directors and staff of The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (The NYSPCC) mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Elizabeth (Betsy) Bartlett. A dedicated member of the Board of Directors for over 36 years, Betsy maintained a passionate commitment to the safety and well-being of New York City's children throughout her tenure. She was unanimously elected to the Board in 1979, served as Vice-President from 1991 until 2013, and chaired the Development Committee from 1979 until 2012. Betsy's wisdom, compassion and generosity of spirit were an inspiration to us all. We extend our deepest condolences to Jones, her children and the entire Bartlett family.

POMERANCE--Eric, beloved artist, photographer, and social activist, died February 16th, nearly 102. Brooklyn born to Esther Perlstein and Harry Pomerance March 2, 1913, he later resided in Greenwich Village and Great Neck. At 16 he earned passage to Argentina as a ship's baker. Thoughtful and observant, he worked as architectural assistant, building supervisor and, in a Dutch production studio, became expert at stop-motion photography. At a WWII bombsight factory, he successfully pressed for safer working conditions. He ran supplies during the Spanish Civil War against fascism. In the 1950's he helped defeat conversion of Washington Square Park into a bus turnaround. He co-founded Great Neck's chapter of nuclear peace group SANE. Eric's watercolors of urban landscapes and city buildings, were exhibited in a 2012 solo show at QCC CUNY. Eric was predeceased by his wife Hortense Baer and son Joseph, and by brothers Ralph and Bill. He is survived by niece, Pam Steiner (Henry) and nephews, Steven (Allyn) and Rafe (Lenore), and by his beloved second wife Diane (Graszik), whom he met in 2004 and married in 2011. (graszik@aol.com) 1/3

WASSERMAN--George Bernard, a loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, passed away on February 19, 2015, the day before his 84th birthday. Born in Cologne, Germany in 1931, he came to the United States with his parents in 1938. After attending Brooklyn Technical High School and New York University, Mr. Wasserman served in the United States Army during the Korean War. He later received his MBA from Columbia University. After a distinguished 30 year career at IBM, he became a partner at Temple Barker Sloane and Mercer Consulting. He was active in the Jewish community, serving as President of Scarsdale Synagogue in Scarsdale, New York and later as President of Am Hayam, the Cape Cod havurah group. He was a resident of Orleans, Massachusetts and Tucson, Arizona. Mr. Wasserman is survived by his wife of 57 years, Renate Wasserman, children Sherri (and John) Goodman, Lauren (and Thom McLeod), and David (and Carolyn) Wasserman, and 10 grandchildren: Natalie, Robert and Matthew Goodman, Madeline, Amanda, and Olivia McLeod, and Daniel, Joshua, Adam and Hannah Wasserman. The funeral service will be held at 1:30 pm on Monday February 23 at Scarsdale Synagogue, Scarsdale New York. Contributions can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. 1/3

CORVINO--Paolo "Paul". A renaissance man, who found success as a boxer, a designer and builder of luxury homes, a sports agent, and as a gifted artist. An old world soul who took life as it came, never cared about the date, or wore a watch. A kind and loving man. You have left an empty seat at our table that will never be filled. Love Forever, Karen, Dick and Sara. 1/3

NAKAMURA--James I.,Professor Emeritus of Economics, Columbia University, died in Silver Spring, MD, February 13, 2015. Born 1919, Toppenish, WA; grew up on a farm, Arroyo Grande, CA, 1923-1942; Gila River, AZ, internment camp, 1942-44. Married Tetsuko Fujii in NYC, 1944. US Army officer in Manila and Tokyo, 1946-1950. Education: BS and Phi Beta Kappa, Columbia General Studies; PhD, economics, Columbia University. His book based on his thesis radically revised thinking about the dynamics of Japanese growth in the Tokugawa and Meiji periods. Professor, Columbia University, 1964 -1989 and co-founder of the Japan Economic Seminar. We will remember James for his positive nature, stimulating conversation and love of family. Survived by wife of 70 years, sons Richard and Leonard, four grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and sister Yoshie. 1/3

SCHRECK--Herman: Your unconditional love bounded and strengthened our relationship. Your belief that to be different was far more than just alright. Your spirit of community, the importance of helping others, of Judaism and family and friends are values that will be with me forever. You were not just my father, you were my best friend and I believe that the best parts of me are what I got from you. Love, Joel 1

ZAPHIROPOULOS--Miltiades L.,M.D., 101, on February 18, 2015. Milt was a great inspiration to many both personally and professionally. Wise and witty, ethical and elegant, caring and curious, his was indeed a life well-lived. His passing is a great loss to his children Lela and Leigh, colleagues, patients, caregivers, friends and extended family. Donations may be made to The William Alanson White Institute, NYC. 1/3
FELDMAN--Tiffani Bea. Missing your smiles and laughter. Love you as much as ever. Mom, Dad, Kerrin and Grandmother 1/3

ROSENHEIM--Mitchell S. September 26, 1931 -February 15, 2015. New York, San Antonio, Palm Beach County. Horace Mann, Colgate University Yale University Law School. The most wonderful love affair: 17 years filled with travel, books, music, canoeing, sailing, cruising, golf, volunteering, family, friends, adventures. Mitch, sail off with my love and that of many. Jane Birnbaum 1/3

BIENER--Lawrence "Larry," 85, of Merritt Island, FL and New York on February 18, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Muriel (Mickey) Biener; father of David (JoAnne), Charles (Susan), Steven (Frances), and Judy (Jeffrey); grandfather of Jeffrey, Jason, Jennifer, Jillian, Elizabeth, Alex, and Hannah; great-grandfather of Clarissa and Jefferson; brother of the late Sigmund; inspirational teacher of thousands. Funeral at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ on Sunday, February 22 at 11:30am.

RABKIN--Leo. Abstract artist and folk art collector Leo Rabkin died peacefully at his Chelsea home on Sunday, February 15 at the age of 95. Rabkin created colorful painted sculptures inside new and antique boxes. Throughout his long career, he described his works as nugatory divigations, wanderings of the spirit having little or no tangible value. Working with commonplace things found on city streets, he was ahead of his time and of inspiration to younger artists. Born 1919 in Cincinnati, Ohio, Rabkin spent his early life studying the violin and as a boy usher for the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Early exposure to the rigors of classical music helped him to "think abstractly." He was a member of the American Abstract Artists group for more than fifty years, serving as President from 1964-78. The group honored him with a tribute exhibition in the summer of 2014. He also served for many years on the Fine Arts Federation of New York. Leo Rabkin came to New York City in 1945 after service in World War II. He earned a master's in education and guidance counseling at New York University leading to a fifteen-year position at the Livingston School for Girls on King Street. His own experience with psychoanalysis deepened his understanding of art and led to studies with William Baziotes, Hale Woodruff and Robert Inglehart. He married Dorothea Herz (see NYT obit. December 5, 2008) in 1958 and the couple created a landmark collection of American folk art. The Rabkins donated many works to the American Folk Art Museum including the iconic whirligig sculpture of Uncle Sam riding a bicycle. The High Museum of Art in Atlanta also received historic folk art from the Rabkin Collection. In 2000, the couple created the Dorothea and Leo Rabkin Foundation to do charitable work in the arts community. He is survived by his nephew and nieces, Barry Blasberg, Gail Britt and Jill Blasberg Rosenstein, the children of his late sister, Emily Rabkin Blasberg. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

COHN--Roberta Kimmel, passed away peacefully on February 20, 2015 at the age of 78. Beloved wife of the late Richard Cohn. Sister of Richard Kimmel, sister in law of Ronna, the late Joel Kimmel, sister in law of Sue. She is also survived by nieces and nephews Andrew Kimmel (Lori), Beth Tokayer (Gershon), Dr. Alan Kimmel (Betsy), Stephanie Lobel (Jeff) and many grand nieces and nephews. Roberta was an Art Dealer. May she rest in peace. Services Monday 12:30pm at "The Riverside," 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

GLASER--Martha, daughter of Pearl and Samuel Farkas, beloved sister of Bella Rosenberg, died December 3, 2014. Martha's early interest in equal rights activism evolved into a successful career as a pioneering manager and producer of jazz artists, notably Garner Erroll. She is survived by her niece Susan Rosenberg. 1/3

GRIMM--Kathleen. The entire Publicolor family mourns the passing of a great civil servant, our treasured friend, Kathleen Grimm. Our deep condolences to her family and friends. Ruth L Shuman, Founder & President 1/3

WARING--Saul. We are saddened by the passing of our dear friend, Saul Waring, a great champion of music education and a passionate advocate of Midori & Friends programs and our City's students. We extend our condolences to his wife, Willa, his children and the entire Waring Family. Midori, Founder, Alan Fischer, Chair Emeritus, Peter Glaser, Chair, Midori & Friends. 1/3

GLASER--Morris (Moishe), of Brooklyn, NY died peacefully in his sleep Sunday, February 8, at the MJHS Menorah Center in Manhattan Beach. He was 85. Devoted high school literature teacher for forty plus years in the New York City education system and fondly remembered into retirement by many of his students; Korean War veteran; world traveler from Park Slope to Patagonia to Paris to Pistoia; feinschmecker connoisseur of the world's cuisines; deplorer of euphemisms and cliches; admirer of Proust and Nabokov, Beethoven and Bartok; Morris forged his own way through life and is dearly remembered by his friends for his loyalty, his individuality, and for courageously taking the road less traveled. His survivors include his sister Goldie Katz, niece Laura Katz, and nephews David and Charlie Katz, and six grandnieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed by all. A memorial service is planned for the spring, the date will be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Morris's name to BrightFocus Foundation for Alzheimers Research http://tinyurl.com/nw3q85l

ROTHSCHILD--Joan. Died February 1, 2015 on her 87th birthday. Born in New York City, daughter of Anna (Cohen) and Alfred Rothschild and survived by sister Ruth Mayleas and niece Alexandra Heth, both of NYC. Attended public schools and graduated from Cornell with BA in English in 1948. An activist resident of Greenwich Village in the 1950s and 1960s, Joan participated in the presidential campaigns of Adlai Stevenson, helped establish the Village Independent Democrats, joined the coalition of architects to remove 5th Avenue buses from Washington Square Park and was an active member of the League of Women Voters. Subsequently earned MA in government and PhD in politics from NYU. In 1969, Dr. Rothschild relocated to Cambridge to join Harvard's Program on Technology and Science, and in 1972 joined the faculty of Lowell Technological Institute where she chaired the Women's Studies program and taught political science and technology. As feminist research into technology issues proliferated, she organized panels at annual meetings of the New England Women's Studies Association and the Berkshire Conference on the History of Women. The original work of these feminist scholars appeared in Joan's edited collections, "Women, Technology and Innovation" (1982) and "Machina Ex Dea: Feminist Perspectives on Technology" (1983), which latter collection was used widely as a text and remained in print for 14 years. Upon retirement from UMass Lowell, Dr. Rothschild returned to NYC and was appointed research associate at the Center for Human Environments at the CUNY Graduate Center to a organize a conference "Re-Visioning Design and Technology: Feminist Perspectives" at CUNY in 1995, bringing together practicing as well as academic architects, urban planners and designers, industrial designers, design historians and graphic designers. Her last completed project, the publication of "The Dream of the Perfect Child" in 2005, was the culmination of 15 years of research, funded in part by the National Science Foundation, which traced the development of the Enlightenment ideology of human perfectibility and its wedding to science through the 19th Century Positivists and then the Eugenicists as they upended the dream into an inegalitarian program for racial purity and progress. The book proposes not a ban on such research but asks us to listen and think carefully about where we might be heading. Active in community affairs, Dr. Rothschild was a member of the Women's City Club of New York, the Society for the History of Technology and the National Women's Studies Association. She often celebrated NYC as the perfect place to retire to: public transportation is at your doorstep, theaters, museums, art galleries, concert halls abound, and you are never the oldest person in the audience! A gathering in celebration of her life will be held in the near future.

GORHAM--George Whittington, MD, died on January 29th in New York City. Born in 1927 into an Albany family of physicians, he was an internist in NYC for more than 40 years. A graduate of Exeter Academy, he served in the US Army ('45-'46) before completing his BA at Yale in 1950. He received his MD from Johns Hopkins in 1954, where he also did his internship and residency. He later completed a fellowship in renal disease at Boston University School of Medicine ('57-'60). He cared deeply for his patients and for the practice and teaching of medicine. Devoted to family and friends, he was always ready to help or advise. A life-long music lover, he enjoyed playing the recorder and singing--particularly country and western. Loved and missed by daughter Sarah G. Hunter, granddaughter Abigail G. Hunter, son-in-law David Hunter, son John W. Gorham, daughter-in-law Julie Glover, and his Cushman cousins. Memorial to be held in the spring. Please email johnwgorham@yahoo.com for details. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C, The Board of Directors and Staff of the Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship mourn the loss of John C. Whitehead, a man of tremendous integrity and grace whose commitment to our country, New York City and Goldman Sachs resulted in a life of unique leadership and countless accomplishments. Mr. Whitehead was a trusted advisor to the NFTE Board of Directors and staff for many years and his leadership and wisdom will be missed by us all. We offer our deep condolences to his wife, Cynthia; his daughters, Anne and Sarah; his son, J. Gregory; and his entire family. 1/3
DRABKIN--Steven Wayne. 10/19/61 -2/23/81. We treasure his memory. How little time we had to share. 1/3

BEARD--Timothy Field. Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A.M. mourns with profound sadness the death on February 13, 2015 of our esteemed brother Timothy Field Beard. Born December 19, 1930, he was raised at Kane Lodge on April 3, 1984 and served the craft faithfully for more than 30 years. Mr. Beard's funeral service will be held on March 14, 2015 at Christ Episcopal Church, Roxbury, CT at 11am. Alan G. Moore, Secretary W.: Socrates G. Karally, Master 1/3

RABKIN--Leo. The American Folk Art Museum notes with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend, esteemed abstract artist, and collector Leo Rabkin. Leo, with his wife, Dorothea, who predeceased him, shared an interest in the human form that was evinced in the exceptional whirligigs, weather vanes, and sculptures that served as the basis of many exhibitions at the museum over the course of three decades. This remarkable couple's commitment to the museum resulted in the donation of one of their and the museums most cherished works: Uncle Sam Riding a Bicycle Whirligig. Leo once remarked: "Folk art appeals to me because it embraces all the impulses and freedoms of Americans." The Rabkins' largesse will make possible the continuing appreciation of the works of art they so deeply loved. We will miss them both. Laura Parsons, Chairman Edward V. Blanchard, President Dr. Anne-Imelda Radice, Executive Director 1/3

RUSKIN--Dr. Edwin 92 of New Rochelle, NY and Boca Raton, FL on Feb 9, 2015 joining wife of 65 yrs Clarice 'Ricky' Kleinberg departed 3 wks prior. Son of Dr. A. Randall Ruskin and Dorothy Prussak. Duke Univ M.D. '45. Prof of Derm NYU & Chief of Derm New Rochelle Hosp over 30 yrs. Playwright of "My Son, the Doctor", aired ABC-TV Nov 1954. Preceded by daughter Karen; survived by children Donna and Neal.

WESELY--Edwin J. Passed away peacefully at home, at age 85, on February 15, 2015, after several years of declining health. Born into a European Catholic immigrant family in New York City, attended Brooklyn Tech and Deep Springs College. Graduate of Cornell University and Columbia Law School. Distinguished legal career: Federal Prosecutor, litigation partner with Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts (now Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman) for 37 years. Special Master in Federal Court cases. Dedicated humanitarian: many years as Chairman/ President of CARE, leading international relief and development agency, co-founder of CARE International. Many honors including Foreign Press Association World Humanitarian Award 1988. Member of Council on Foreign Relations. Served on nonprofit boards, chaired legal committees in Federal Court system. Traveled extensively, lived his life with zest. Survived by his wife of nearly a quarter-century, Marcy Brownson, former wife Yolanda T. Wesely, daughters Marissa Wesely and Adrienne Shirley, granddaughter Emma Allen, and a large extended family. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Deep Springs College (www.deepsprings.edu) or CARE (www.care.org).
SIEGAL--Annette. 1/21/1924- 2/22/2011 Four years since you left us. Your family misses you every day. Love always, Gary, Erin, Mattie & Liz

Decker; and Ms. Shannon's daughter, Lisa Knight. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, March 7, at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT.

KATZ--Larry "Cha Cha" Born April 5, 1931 in the Bronx. He weathered a troubled childhood to become a leading executive in the Women's Garment and Fashion Industry. Equally at home on a golf course, in a sales room or at the track, Larry and his wife Rita cut a graceful figure on many dance floors. Though he disdained formal education, Larry had a keen and logical mind and provided his younger brothers Gerald and Stuart with sage advice and an inspirational example. His kindness and generosity, to family and friends, was legendary. His giving ran the gamut of donations to Native American organizations to furnishing the State of Israel with a high tech ambulance. He will be deeply missed by his brothers, their wives Barbara and Jane, his nieces Vicki (Jack), Lesley, Jennifer (Scott), Emily (Steven), Amanda and Sally and his devoted friend and caregiver Neil. Larry was an independent spirit who in his words "Did the best he could with the hand he was dealt." Chapel services to honor his memory will be held on Sunday, February 22, 2015, 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, with interment to follow at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY where he will be laid to rest next to his beloved Rita and close to his adored mother Sally.

BORGENICHT--Lillian Nacht, 97, passed away peacefully at home February 21, 2015. She was the beloved wife of the late Travis Borgenicht with whom she spent 50 years. They shared successful careers in the children's clothing industry as well as a lively social life centered at the Friars Club. Upon retirement, Lillian's creative skills were expressed in her beautiful sculptures and paintings. She mesmerized us with her colorful stories of New York City life in the early 20th century. She will be remembered for her wonderful sense of humor, exquisite style and fierce political opinions. Lillian is survived by her loving daughter Linda Rosen Schoenfeld, son-in-law Lester Schoenfeld, granddaughters Jennifer Gwen Schoenfeld and Dana Marisa Schoenfeld and sisters Rosalie Steier and Sylvia Luckom. We all will miss her dearly. 1/3

RABKIN--Leo, passed on February 15, 2015, at 95. Leo Rabkin's abstract art preserved and presented life's most delicate, tender discoveries and interactions. His advanced sympathy with modernism's restraint, formality, and openness with materials focused his individual sensitivities into decades of hand-made collages, plastic sculptures, watercolors, and unique etchings. Light-- and shadow--were constant attendants. An independent in his work, he was fully engaged with the art and social issues of his times. He served as President of the American Abstract Artists often during its early history and more recently on the New York City Art Commission. Leo and his extraordinary wife Dorothea were eminent collectors of American Folk Art: serious benefactors to this culture and to the museum that represents it, New York's Museum of American Folk Art. Their home/studio itself, with its sky-lit great hall, is a museum worthy of being landmarked. Leo came to New York as a young man from Cincinnati, where years of immersion in music and theatre helped form a character of great, insightful humanity. Dorothea came to New York after WWII from Berlin. Here she created a new life of immense intelligence, generosity--and humor. We friends hope that we can live up to the example of accomplishment, open-mindedness, and endless kindness that Leo and Dorothea showed us all, year after year, exhibition after exhibition, visit after visit. 1/3

FINK--Dr. Robert, a pillar of the Memphis psychiatric community, passed away on February 17, 2015 after a one-year battle with pancreatic cancer. Son of the late Dr. Benjamin and Rebecca Fink, Dr. Robert Fink was a graduate of Freeport High School, St. Lawrence University, and the University of Tennessee Medical School and psychiatric residency. Dr. Fink honed his respected leadership skills as president of his college fraternity and then the St. Lawrence inter-fraternity council. Colleagues, aware of his therapeutic and managerial skills, appointed him psychiatric director at each of the major Memphis hospitals, Tri-County Mental Health Center, and New Day Partial Hospitalization Program. He also served as consultant to the Army Alcoholism Program. Not only his 40 year psychiatric experience, but also his extraordinary personality showered his patients with rapt listening, empathetic kindness, and quiet sense of humor, which elevated the psychiatric ill to a sense of well-being. Dr. Fink lent his enormous skills equally to the most down-trodden, as well as the movers and shakers of Memphis society. His joys were rooting for Memphis basketball, fishing from his home on Narragansett Bay, photography, loving his family and patients with help of his loyal assistant of 40 years, Charlotte. Dr. Fink leaves behind his sister, Dr. Janet Kowal (Dr. Robert), brothers Dr. Gerry Fink (Dr. Rosalie), and Dr. Alan Fink (Phyllis), who feel cheated that his passing robs them of spending more time together. Dr. Fink also leaves behind his wife of 48 years, Gerry, four broken-hearted daughters Peninah Salid (Rabbi Jay), Deena Tagger (Nissim), Anna Kaminetsky (Shimon), and Sara Wachtel (Jonathan), as well as 28 grandchildren whom he made feel important every day. Donations in Dr. Fink's memory should be made to Hadassah Hospital (pancreatic research Professor Gideon Zamir).

FRICHNER--Tonya Gonnella, Esq. Gowanahs, Snipe Clan name, a citizen of the Onondaga Nation, Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy, Haudenosaunee. Ms. Gonnell Frichner, 67 of Union City, New Jersey began her journey to her Creator on February 15, 2015 and is survived by her loving husband of 42 years, University Professor Fashion Institute of Technology Herb Frichner and their son Jason M. Frichner (Eva). A global indigenous leader and President and Founder of the American Indian Law Alliance (AILA) since 1989. AILA is a Non-Governmental Organization in consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC). To express sympathy please visit: www.ballweg-lunsford.com 1/3

GREINER--Renata. The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons wishes to express its sadness on the passing of Renata Greiner, a donor, friend and great dog lover. Our condolences and our deepest gratitude go to her family for thinking of ARF's animals during their time of sorrow. 1/3

GRIMM--Kathleen. Kathleen was a warm and caring educator and friend. She was always there for children in need and for those who support their education. The Urban Assembly and Take The Field will miss her. 1/3

MICHEL--Morton, died on January 19, 2015, at the age of 98. Only son of the late Aaron and Goldye Michel. Morton was a World War II Navy veteran and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side. There are no immediate survivors. Graveside services were private. Contributions may be made in Morton's memory to United Jewish Appeal. 1/3

SCRETCHINGS--Francis, 67, passed away on February 12th. The Board of Trustees and staff of CancerCare are saddened at the loss of Francis "Frank" Scretchings, devoted and beloved staff member. Frank was the organization's Facilities Manager, and, at 39 years of service, its longest serving employee. Our condolences to Frank's family and all those whose lives he touched. 1/3

BUCHLEITNER--James Francis. September 10, 1949 - February 17, 2015. Retired design professional. Devoted son of Gertrude Snyder Buchleitner, beloved brother of Gene & Sally Buchleitner and cousin of Nancy Snyder. Treasured friend of the Shakkour/Lane/Thorne families, Vincent Thomy, Stephen Foster, Julius Vignorelli & David Hoey, Lorry & Peter Dudley, Andrew Oyen & Edmond Badalian, and so many other wonderful and creative people who are no longer with us.

MEENAN--Monica Durand of Kennebunk, ME, and formerly of New York City, died at home February 4, 2015. Monica was born in White Plains, NY and was a graduate of Manhattanville College. She went on to become an editor at Town & Country Magazine. Monica greatly enjoyed the arts and travel. She served as a docent at the Portland Museum of Art, and was actively involved in the Kennebunkport community. Monica was predeceased by her husband Dennis A. Meenan and sister Bernice D. Walsh. She is survived by her sisters Angela D. Dealy (James) of Cincinnati, OH and Marianne Durand-Duffy of White Plains; four nieces and three nephews. Funeral services have been held. Donations in Monica's memory may be made to the Portland Museum of Art, Seven Congress Square, Portland, ME 04101.

CHARMATZ--Lester, age 86. Beloved husband of Joyce Kagan Charmatz, nee Simon and the late Patricia Charmatz, nee Sadie. Cherished father of Andrew Charmatz (Sara Witt) and James Charmatz. Loving step-father of Irv (Ali) Kagan and Jeffrey (Amy) Kagan. Devoted grandfather of Phoebe, Peri, Sammy, Joey, Benjamin, Sophie and Noah. Dear brother of the late Arthur (survived by Barbara) Charmatz. Funeral services Monday 12:30pm at Beth Israel Cemetery-Woodbridge, NJ. Info: (630-648-9824) or www.mitzvahfunerals.com 1/3

GINES--Bernadine Coles. The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants (NYSSCPA) mourns the passing of Bernadine Coles Gines, an NYSSCPA member and the first black woman in New York State to earn a CPA license. Mrs. Gines received a BSBA from Virgina State College in 1946 and an MBA from New York University in 1947. Experiencing racism and sexism in her two- year search for work at a public accounting firm, Mrs. Gines was finally hired by a small New York City firm in 1949. She received her CPA license in 1954 and spent most of her career working for the Office of the New York City Comptroller. A trailblazer, a role model, and a truly dedicated certified public accountant, the NYSSCPA is honored and proud to have counted Mrs. Gines among its members and extends its deepest sympathies to the Gines family. 1/3

WALLACK--Dan, 93, advertising copywriter, beloved husband, father, grandfather and uncle, passed away on February 20. Lifetime Manhattanite adored his late wife Rhoda and daughters Holly and Bonnie, Dan remained active and young, intensely loyal to his family and friends, a leader at the Westside JCC, sensitive and honest helping others. 1/3

WEINBERG--Charles L. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend and Board Member Charles L. Weinberg. For more than 40 years, his support and leadership helped to transform the Hospital to the facility it is today. His endearing, quiet nature and warm spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Judy and their entire family. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board of Directors; Jon B. Schandler, CEO Susan Fox, President

LEVY--Paul, 88, Cooks Falls, NY, died February 18, 2015. Born on May 21, 1926 in the Bronx, NY, the son of the late Louis E. and Gussie Michaelson Levy and brother of the late Rita Tischler; beloved husband of Betsy Levy (46 years); loving father of Susan (Paul) Wright, Ellen (John) Caputo, Jane (Archie) Walker, Nicholas (Marni) Levy; grandfather of seven; great-grandfather of four. A native New Yorker, WWII Veteran, Former Conservation Chair of Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, Artist/ Advertising Executive. 1/3

CHODOSH--Melba Age 88 - 2/15/d. Born 2/26/26 to Herman and Rose Goldberg. Resident of Oquossoc ME and NYC. Beloved wife of late Paul L. Chodosh, mother of Pam, Jon, Josh, Jim and Hiram. Survived also by 11 grandchildren, one great-grandchild and many loving friends. Donations to Rangeley Health and Wellness Ctr.

BARTLETT--Elizabeth E. "Betsy". April 1, 1937 February 14, 2015 of New York City and Weston, CT, died peacefully at her home, surrounded by family. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio to Col. Walter J. Easton and Elizabeth Scott Easton. She graduated from Hathaway Brown School and attended Skidmore College. Betsy made a career as a Lady Arrow model and an interior decorator. Betsy was passionately involved in the community, and took great pride in her work. She was a long-time senior director at both St. Barnabas Hospital and New York Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC). More than anything, she was a devoted friend and family person. She was pre-deceased by former husband Peter Barry Bartlett (1934-2012). She is survived by her partner of 25 years, A. Jones Yorke, her sister and brother- in-law Virginia and Ralph Joslin, her children Kimberley Kernan of Rowayton, CT, Christopher Bartlett of Baltimore, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT, and adopted son Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, Tennessee. She cherished her six grandchildren Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett, and Christopher and Carly Lieder. A memorial service will be held on Monday March 2nd (4pm) at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to either NYSPCC or St. Barnabas Hospital. 1/3

ADAMS--Robert V. Xerox executive, entrepreneur, board member of the L.A. Opera, philanthropist, nature photographer, beloved husband, father, and grandfather, died in Santa Monica, California on February 10th after a long and courageous battle with heart disease and cancer. He was 83 years old. Born in Hammond, Indiana December 27, 1931, he attended Purdue University on a track scholarship and was the first of his family to attend college. He graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1954 and in later years he was honored as a Distinguished Engineering Alumnus, won the Outstanding Mechanical Engineer Award, and received an honorary doctorate in engineering. He took great pride in giving back to the university by endowing a chair in Mechanical Engineering. While working as an engineering manager at Inland Steel, he earned his MBA at the University of Chicago and would remain on their advisory board as a lifetime member. The largest lecture hall in the downtown campus of the Business School is named in his honor. He joined Xerox in 1969 when it bought Scientific Data Systems, the company for which he was then working. As president of Xerox's Printing Systems Division he led the development, manufacturing, sales, and marketing of laser printing products and became executive vice president of Xerox in 1985. After retiring he returned to become CEO of Xerox's new venture capital operation, Xerox Technology Ventures. He started nine new companies; two of which went public. In an interview Bob once said, When you're in a new venture, there are no rules. There is no path. You cannot look at where you've been to figure out where you want to go. You cannot look at someone else who's doing it already. You have to invent as you go along. In 1998 he joined the board of the L.A. Opera, creating a long range plan that to this day has a significant impact on the company. With his wife he underwrote the Robert Wilson production of Madama Butterfly and in 2009 he was elected a lifetime trustee of the opera. In recent years he pursued his lifetime passion for photography. His nature photographs drew critical praise, appeared at the San Diego Natural History Museum and were featured at galleries in Twin Bridges, Montana and Venice, California. He loved nature, music, fly fishing, travel, his ranch in Montana, books, fine wines, films, hiking, and was devoted to his family and many friends. Always the last to speak, he had the most to say with the fewest of words. He is survived by his wife Barbara Abercrombie; the children of his first marriage, Leslie Adams of Twin Bridges, Montana; Julie Olson of Oahu, Hawaii; and Bo Adams (Kristine) of Torrance, California; his stepchildren, Brooke Abercrombie and Gillan Abercrombie Frame; his brothers Richard Adams and Paul Adams, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Music Guild of All Saints in Beverly Hills or The Educational Fund of the Los Angeles Opera or a charity of your choice.

HARRIS--Joseph. A colleague and friend for over 35 years. Chairman Emeritus of the Johnny Mercer Foundation. Dedicated to his profession he was the hallmark of excellence; a true gentleman who standards were of the highest. Davida & Alvin Deutsch

SIFFERT--Robert S.,orthopedic surgeon, passed away peacefully at home on February 18. He was 96 years old. Dr. Siffert was the youngest and longest-serving Chair of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City, serving for 26 years. In 1960, he was appointed Director of the Department. When the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine was created, he served as its first Professor and Chairman of Orthopedics. He was the first recipient of the Robert K. Lippmann Chair in Orthopedics. In 1986, he was named the Bernard J. Lasker/Robert S. Siffert Distinguished Service Professor. Dr. Siffert also was the Senior Orthopedic Consultant for the Department of Health of NYC. He published over 150 articles with major emphasis on research and clinical pediatric orthopedics. His book "How Your Child's Body Grows" was an accessible guide for parents. He was a fellow of many national and international orthopedic societies. He received numerous awards, including the Arthritis Foundation Lifetime Achievement Award, the Mt. Sinai Hospital Jacobi Medallion and the Richman Award for Humanism and Ethics. He also served as the Vice President of the National Easter Seals. Dr. Siffert worked with Care-Medico on month-long medical service missions teaching and delivering medical care in developing countries, including Tunisia, Kenya, Indonesia, Afghanistan, Peru and Haiti. Dr. Siffert insisted that he never retired but "graduated" to continue his research in osteoporosis and his work as a graphic artist. Dr. Siffert was an avid artist. His woodcuts were shown in New York and on Martha's Vineyard. Dozens of his woodcuts now hang on permanent display at the United States Courthouse in Manhattan and in the United States Supreme Court. Dr. Siffert served as Captain and Flight Surgeon in the U.S. Army Air Force in World War II, flying the "hump" between China, Burma and India. He received four Battle Stars. Dr. Siffert was predeceased by his wife, Miriam, of 67 years. He is survived by his daughter Joan, his son John (Goldie), his grandchildren Molly Ann Ouanes (Alexx), David and Matthew, as well as his partner Ruth Friendly. He will be missed profoundly by his family and all he touched. Donations may be made to the Department of Orthopedics, Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

HUME--David D. Headmaster Emeritus of Saint David's School, dies at 87. The Headmaster, Trustees, Faculty, Staff, Boys, Alumni, and Parents of Saint David's School, New York City, mourn the passing of a dear friend, Headmaster from 1953 to 1990, Headmaster Emeritus and Honorary Trustee thereafter. Mr. Hume is perhaps the most revered and influential figure in the history of our school. He came to Saint David's when he was just twenty-five years old and the school just one. For the next thirty-seven years, this brilliant, principled man, with a wonderfully whimsical sense of humor and powerful intellect, set the direction and tone of the school. He helped create the school's most honored traditions that sustain it to this day. In so many ways, Saint David's is today the school that David Hume helped it to become. During his headship, 1,200 young men graduated. David was a graduate of Canterbury School, Yale University, and Columbia University. During his tenure at Saint David's, Mr. Hume served as President of the New York State Association of Independent Schools, the Country Day School Headmasters Association, Interschool Orchestras of New York, the Elementary School Heads Association, St. Thomas More Chapel (Yale University), and the Guild of Independent Schools of New York City; Vice-President of the Independent Schools Multi-Media Center; Director of the National Association of Independent Schools; Trustee of the Professional Children's School of New York City, Marymount School of New York, and Nightingale-Bamford School, New York City. He was a member of the Elizabethan Club, Yale University. He was an avid reader, writer, painter, sailor, boat builder and patron of the arts. Mr. Hume's tremendous dedication to the School for more than six decades is appreciated and celebrated. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Catherine, his sons, Christopher, '68, Adam, '70, Benjamin, '71, and Noah, '75, his daughters, Charity, '72, Amity, '74, and his sister, Rozanne Edmondson, and her sons, Timothy, '73 and Nicholas, '75 and their families at this time. Details regarding a memorial mass will be forthcoming. 1/3

SCHRECK--Herman: Beloved husband of the late Shirley; cherished and devoted father to Joel and Gregg, Ellen and Mona, Ira and Barbara, Marc and Nina, Allanand Ronni; the best pop-pop to Rachel and Joey, loving grandfather to Jamie and Sheri, Jessica and Peter, Michael and Bree, Jodi and Tom, Jesse and Daniel; loving great-grandfather to J.J., Casey, Tyler, Cooper, Alex, Jeremiah, Reed, Ethan, Donavan and Cheyanne, faithful longtime companion to Eva Smith. He was a beloved brother to the late Nat, Sol, Nettie, Mendel, Bertha and Fanny. Survived by sister Regina. Beloved brother-in-law, uncle and friend to many. Words can never express how deeply he was loved and how much he will be missed. 1

SCHWARTZ--Richard M. head of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson's environmental practice and a pioneer in environmental law, died February 21, 2015 at Mt. Sinai St. Luke's Hospital from complications of cancer. He was sixty-four. Mr. Schwartz, a graduate of Yale College, University of Chicago Law School and a Mellon fellow at Clare College, Cambridge, began his legal career at Skadden Arps. He then served in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, where he held supervisory positions including head of the environmental unit. He received awards from the Environmental Protection Agency for the negotiation of a major Superfund settlement and from the Department of Justice for superior performance in civil environmental enforcement. In addition to environmental cases during his tenure at the U.S. Attorney's Office, Mr. Schwartz successfully defended the General Services Administration in an action brought by Richard Serra, who alleged the government's decision to move his sculpture "Tilted Arc" from the Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan constituted a breach of contract and violated the free expression and due process rights of the artist. Mr. Schwartz joined Fried Frank in 1992 where he was highly regarded for his representation in the environmental field as well in real estate and private equity. He represented Tishman Speyer in its acquisition of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village. It was the largest real estate transaction in the United States at the time. His environmental transactional practice included negotiation of the first prospective purchased agreement in California with Region 9 of the Environmental Protection Agency. Also known as lover of food and wine, Mr. Schwartz was on the the board of GrowNYC and did pro bono legal work for the non-profit sponsor of "green markets" throughout New York City. Mr. Schwartz is survived by his wife Wendy, his sons Isaac, a portfolio manager at Robotti & Company, and Noah, an advisor on the National Security Council staff in Washington, D.C., and his brother Dr. Leslie Schwartz of Juno Beach, Florida. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in New York on February 24 at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer donations to GrowNYC, 51 Chambers Street, room 228, NY, NY 10007 or to the American Friends of the Mendelsohn Foundation, c/o Susan Bender, Treasurer, 60 W. 57th Street, NY, NY l0019. 1/3

HUME--David. The InterSchool Orchestras of New York deeply mourns the passing of our best friend, founding president and constant support, the brilliant educator David Hume. In 1970, when budget cuts and other priorities were eliminating music from the education of New York City school children, David was one of the few important leaders to take action on the crisis that was taking place in arts education. David's pioneering contributions with ISO have had a lasting effect on three generations of children by uncovering talent, developing careers, creating devotion to fine music, and renewing musical activity in the schools. None of this would have been possible were it not for his vision. Thank you David for the joy and success you have brought into so many lives. Board of InterSchool Orchestras of New York 1/3

ROBERTS--Judith Messinger, August 22, 1936 - February 23, 2015. Cherished daughter of the late Edna (Balser) and Benjamin Messinger. Beloved wife of Fredric. Henry. Much loved sister-in-law, aunt, niece and cousin. She was an inspiration to us all. Mom, We love you and miss you too much already. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, February 25 at 11:30am at Riverside Nassau- Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment following at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York. 1/3

WEILL--Donald M. 2/24/30-1/28/13 "His memory keeps shining brightly..." On this special day and always, our love, Elaine, Wendi, Steve, Jeff, Kenny and his entire devoted family. 1/3

HUME--David D. Marymount School of New York mourns the loss of our dear friend and former Trustee, David D. Hume. David served as Headmaster of Saint David's School for 37 years and on the Marymount Board of Trustees from 1969 to 1989. His wisdom and sage counsel guided Marymount from its early days as an independent school through its first capital campaign. David will also be remembered for mentoring many other heads of schools. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife and our dear friend, Cathy, his daughters and our alumnae, Charity and Amity, and his entire family. Marymount School of New York Kelly C. Coffey, Chair Concepcion R. Alvar, Headmistress

SCHWARTZ--Richard. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Richard Schwartz. We will miss his warmth, caring and devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Wendy, their children Isaac and Noah, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

SEGERSTROM--Henry T. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall celebrate the life of our dear friend and colleague Henry T. Segerstrom, who passed away on Friday. Henry became a Carnegie Hall trustee in 2009, and immediately distinguished himself as the driving force in establishing a bi-coastal artistic partnership between Carnegie Hall and the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in California, representing the first time Carnegie Hall partnered with a performing arts center outside New York. In 2010, we were honored to award him the Carnegie Hall Medal of Excellence for his lifetime business achievements and his personal support of the arts. Henry was passionate about artists creating great art, and he had a great passion for their work and the creative process. Over the course of four decades, Henry singlehandedly developed the cultural landscape of Orange County, CA, in addition to devoting his time and resources to numerous national and international institutions. We will always remember Henry as a great humanitarian, a man with a huge heart who understood the importance of giving back to the community, and leading by example. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Elizabeth, who brought such great joy to his life, and to his children Andrea Grant, Toren, and Anton, his sister Ruth Ann Moriarty, and all of his family and friends. Sanford I. Weill, President; Ronald O. Perelman, Chairman; Clive Gillinson, Executive & Artistic Director 1/3

LITT--I. Ira. I. Ira Litt, born September 11, 1930 passed peacefully February 22, 2015. Son of the late Florence and the late Arthur Litt and brother of the late Sydelle and the late Frank Rosen. Beloved husband of Joan, Devoted father of Marty, Debbie and the late Stacey Litt, Craig and Suzanne. Adored Grandfather of Alex, Jordan, Jared, Jenna, Jason, Andrew and Gillian. Loving Uncle to Harold, Joanne, Christopher and Kase. Ira was a Mason and pioneer of the private label men's underwear industry. And a leader in his community. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, February 24, 2015, 2:30pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. 1

SUGHRUE--Mary E.,Mary E. Sughrue, 78, of New York City, died peacefully on February 20. Mary was from a family of five children raised in Milton, MA. She is survived by her loving brothers, Rev. Paul Sughrue, of Acton, Mass. and Peter Sughrue of Bridgehampton, NY, and by her adoring sister, Ginny Crowley of Kennebunk, ME. She was predeceased by her brother, Steven. "Aunt Mimi", as she was known to many, is also survived by eight nieces and nephews, and sixteen grandneice and grandnephews. Mary was loved by all for her constant support, her great generosity, and her eternal optimism. She relished her role of being a loving aunt and a dear friend to all. Mary graduated from Simmons College in 1957. She spent ten years employed at Harvard Business School, before venturing to New York City. There she worked at the Frick Museum and for the Rockefeller family, before becoming involved in public policy under the umbrella of New York State. Mary spent over 25 years working as a Special Assistant in the office of New York State Medicaid Fraud Control Unit. In her retirement, Mary was a devotee of the Metropolitan Opera and a member of the Harvard Club of New York. Mary's Funeral Mass will be celebrated by her brother at St. Elizabeth Church in Milton, Mass, on Wednesday, February 25 at 11am. Calling hours will be Tuesday, February 24, 4pm to 7pm at Dolan Funeral Home, 1140 Washington Street, Dorchester Lower Mills. In lieu of flowers, donations on Mary's behalf may be made to St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue, New York City, NY, 10069 or to the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67 St. NYC, NY 10065. 1/3

ASHIN--Harry B. Remembering our father on his 100th birthday with love, respect and gratitude. Linda and Jayne 1/3

BOOTH--Edgar H. (1926-2015) A long-term resident of Glen Rock, NJ, died on February 21, 2015, at home, after a long illness, with his family at his side. He was 88. Born on June 8, 1926, in Brooklyn, NY. During WWII, he enlisted in the army. After the war, he graduated from Stanford University, majoring in journalism. In 1953, he graduated from Harvard Law School, joining his father, Benjamin H. Booth, at Booth, Lipton & Lipton, in NYC, where he spent more than 30 years. He practiced for another 30 years at other firms in NYC, specializing in bankruptcy and insolvency cases. In Glen Rock, he served on the Glen Rock Board of Education from 1971-1977, and was Board President from 1973-1974. In December 1955 at the wedding of a close friend from high school, Edgar met his future wife Joan Blumberg, and they were married the following October. Edgar often said that marrying Joan was the best thing that ever happened to him. Edgar is survived by his wife Joan; his sister Deborah Katz of Rowe, MA; his son Charles Booth and his wife Carole Petersen, of Kailua, HI; his daughter Janet Zide and her husband Stephen, of Old Greenwich, CT; and five grandchildren, Daniel, Jordan, Caroline, Justin, and Lauren. Services will be held at Schoems Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rte. 4, Paramus, NJ 07652, 11:00 am, Wednesday, February 25, 2015. Donations may be made to Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Suite 301, Paramus, NJ 07652. 1/3

PARKER--Lenore Louise, 81, born in Rome, NY, long- time resident of New York City, passed away February 7th, 2015, in Naples, FL. Friends and family describe Lenore as one of the most essential people in their lives, noting her intelligence, wisdom, warmth, honesty and clarity of thought. As a young woman in 1960, she moved to Spain with her first husband, artist James Parker and infant son, where she lived and worked in Madrid, Malaga and Fuengirola. Returning to the United States, she became Public Relations Director for the American Medical Center in Denver. Back in NYC, Lenore served as Assistant Director and then Executive Director of the American Council for Emigres in the Professions and the Executive Director of the YWCA for the City of New York. Lenore ended her career as a Consultant to the YWCA Retirement Fund. Widowed early, she re- married writer, poet and art collector, Robert Fagan, who died in 2009. An art lover, she was a voracious reader, could quote poetry at the drop of a hat, loved opera, travel, crossword puzzles, friends and family. Lenore leaves her son and daughter-in-law Donald and Amy Parker and grandchildren James and Rachel Parker of Brookline, MA; sister Nan Menzies; brothers Tony and Jack LaGatta; niece Katherine Ansonia and nephew Steven Menzies, among many other family and friends. Memorial and burial are private. Donations in her memory can be made to: Amnesty International www.amnestyusa.org. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Richard. The Board of American Friends of the Mendelssohn Foundation note with great sadness the loss of our Board member Richard Schwartz. A special friend to us all, we remember with fondness the visit to Leipzig we shared with Wendy and Richard. We send our profound expression of sympathy to Wendy, their children and family. Kurt Masur, International Chairman Tomoko Masur, President 1/3

MULLEN--Jeanne K.,of Manhattan on February 22, 2015. She was born in NYC on April 25, 1925. She graduated from St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn, NY -Class of '47. Jeanne retired from a management position in the Engineering Department of AT&T after a 35 year career. She was honored as a Lady Commander of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem in 1997. Most of all she cherished family and will be remembered for her compassion and generosity. She is survived by her sisters Edith Boisi (the late James), Claire Brophy (the late Frank), 12 nieces and nephews, 32 grand nieces and nephews and nine great- grandnieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her sister Eileen Mullen. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Rd, Syosset, NY. Visitation on Thursday, February 26, 2015 from 6- 9pm. Funeral Mass Friday, February 27, 2015 at 10:30am St Mary's RC Church, 110 Bryant Ave., Roslyn, NY. Burial at Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to Rosalie Hall, 4150 Bronx Blvd., Bronx, NY 10466. 1/3

DEUTSCH--Jeanine (Franco) on February 24, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Harvey, adored mother of Allan and Colette, dear mother-in-law of Susan and Robert. Devoted grandmother of Nicole, Michelle, Lindsay, Jeffrey and blessed great-grandmother of Olivia. Service Thursday, February 26, 2015, 11:45am, "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

MORISEY--Dr. Patricia G. It is with deep sadness that the Leake & Watts Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Dr. Patricia Garland Morisey, Board Member 1970 2005. Pat was a true champion for at-risk, disadvantaged children and families. Her dedication to the agency and its work will be fondly remembered and forever appreciated. 1/3

SCHWEBEL-SIMON--Phyllis, a special woman and Matriarch of our family, died Monday at the age of 87. Loving, loved and formidable. Phyllis lived life to the fullest. We were all fortunate to have been loved by her for so long. Cherished wife of Morris Schwebel until his death in 1995. Beloved wife of Myron Simon. Phyllis enjoyed a successful career in market research at Crossley Surveys, Inc, and Time Magazine and capped off her career teaching at FIT. She was a leader in her industry and was president of Advertising Women of New York and executive member of the American Advertising Federation. Survived by daughters Janis Brooks and Leslie Goldrich, sons-in-law Larry Brooks and Steven Goldrich, grandchildren Jordan and Joanna Murawski Brooks, Eric Goldrich and Spencer Goldrich and great-grandchildren Scott Brooks and Reese Brooks. The funeral will take place at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, N.Y., on Thursday, February 26th at 12pm. Donations may be made to the Susan G. Komen Foundation. 1/3
SPECTOR--Robert. Bob, dear, we miss you so much and will love you forever. Eleanor Your Family 1/3

MATLES--Ann Miriam, of Rye Brook, NY, died February 24. Beloved wife of the late Martin Matles. SCHWEBEL-SIMON--Phyllis. We mourn the passing of our good friend Phyllis Schwebel- Simon and extend our sincere condolences to her family. Phyllis and Jerry Edelman 1/3

MARSHALL--James J.,a retired industrial engineer of both Manhattan and Point O' Woods, NY, died on February 22, 2015 in Winchester, MA. He was 84 years old. Born in Tulsa, OK on September 9, 1930, he attended Yale University, where he played both Offensive and Defensive End on the Varsity Football team. A member of the United States Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps, he graduated in 1952, and once commissioned, served as the Chief Engineer on the USS Heermann, a World War II-era destroyer then deployed in the Korean War. Loving and beloved husband of Sheila (Hermes), father of Alice, Katharine, Claire, Jamie, and J.J., he was an extraordinary man who will be greatly missed. An informal memorial luncheon will be held in his honor at the Yale Club at 12pm, Thursday, March 5th, 2015. 1/3

WOLLMUTH--Edward Hale. November 28, 1938 -February 19, 2015. Edward was the beloved husband of Judith Metzger Wollmuth, whom he married in 1960. He was raised in Kenmore, NY by his parents, Edward Hale and Elizabeth Wollmuth. Ed was the loving father of David H. Wollmuth and Karen Wollmuth Short, and a loving grandfather to six grandchildren, John, Charles, Grace, Carly and Julie Wollmuth, and Carter Short. A longtime resident of Buffalo, he served as a tank commander in the United States Army Reserve. Ed began his business career in 1956 as an apprentice draftsman with the Worthington Corporation. He left there in 1976 to join Goulds Pumps, where he served in executive engineering positions of increasing authority until his retirement in 2000. In addition to his family, Ed loved aviation, railroads, and the Buffalo Bills. Memorial donations may be made to the Laurie H. Wollmuth Charitable Trust, c/o Rory Deutsch, Wollmuth Maher & Deutsch LLP, 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10110. 1/3

DECKER--Malcolm, of Greenwich, CT. Devoted companion of Rosamond Shannon. He is survived by brother John R. Decker; daughter Melissa Stamps; son Andrew Decker and daughter-in-law Amy Engeler; grandchildren Georgia and James; step-children Andrea Sheya and Benjamin Dossett; nieces Lynda Gallagher, JoAnne Greenwood, and Laurie Pitcher; nephew John B. Decker; and Ms. Shannon's daughter, Lisa Knight. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, March 7, at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT.

BOOTH--Edgar H. (1926-2015) A long-term resident of Glen Rock, NJ, died on February 21, 2015, at home, after a long illness, with his family at his side. He was 88. Born on June 8, 1926, in Brooklyn, NY. During WWII, he enlisted in the army. After the war, he graduated from Stanford University, majoring in journalism. In 1953, he graduated from Harvard Law School, joining his father, Benjamin H. Booth, at Booth, Lipton & Lipton, in NYC, where he spent more than 30 years. He practiced for another 30 years at other firms in NYC, specializing in bankruptcy and insolvency cases. In Glen Rock, he served on the Glen Rock Board of Education from 1971-1977, and was Board President from 1973-1974. In December 1955 at the wedding of a close friend from high school, Edgar met his future wife Joan Blumberg, and they were married the following October. Edgar often said that marrying Joan was the best thing that ever happened to him. Edgar is survived by his wife Joan; his sister Deborah Katz of Rowe, MA; his son Charles Booth and his wife Carole Petersen, of Kailua, HI; his daughter Janet Zide and her husband Stephen, of Old Greenwich, CT; and five grandchildren, Daniel, Jordan, Caroline, Justin, and Lauren. Services will be held at Schoems Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rte. 4, Paramus, NJ 07652, 11:00 am, Wednesday, February 25, 2015. Donations may be made to Valley Hospice, 15 Essex Road, Suite 301, Paramus, NJ 07652. 1/3

ROSENBAUM--Sylvan, on February 23, 2015. Cherished husband of Janet (Fleischer) Rosenbaum. Beloved and loving father of David; Susan and John Skelly; and Bonnie. Adored and adoring grandfather of Brian and Danielle. Brother of Howard Rosenbaum. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, February 26, 2015 at 1:30pm at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY. Interment to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery. 1/3
FASSLER--Leon. Missing you today, every day, always. Estelle 1/3

FLUG--Martin. We at the Aspen Center for Physics deeply regret the passing of Marty Flug. A bemused observer of the ways of physicists, Marty was a long-time member and trustee of the Center, a key adviser on financial matters and an exceptionally generous supporter for whom the Flug Forum, our main meeting space, is named. His active involvement, personal warmth and energy will be very much missed by all of us. Life at the Center won't be the same without him. 1/3
