FREEDMAN--Monroe H. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Monroe H. Freedman, a professor of law and the former dean at the Maurice A. Deane School of Law at Hofstra University, on February 26, 2015. Freedman, a professor of law for 42 years, was an internationally-renown scholar and pioneer in the field of legal ethics who instilled in thousands of students the responsibility of lawyers to zealously represent their clients, as well as to stand for social justice. He received the American Bar Association's highest award for professionalism, in recognition of "a lifetime of original and influential scholarship in the field of lawyers' ethics," and a Martin Luther King Award for decades of work to advance human dignity and social justice. For 30 years he lectured annually on lawyers' ethics at Harvard Law School, and from 2007-2012 he was a visiting professor at Georgetown University Law Center. His current book is Understanding Lawyers' Ethics has been required reading at law schools including Harvard, the University of California, Berkeley, and Georgetown, is assigned or recommended at other law schools, has been used in training programs for the bar in Canada and is being translated into Chinese. During the 1960s, Freedman served as chair of the National Capital Area Civil Liberties Union, was counsel to several civil rights organizations and was a consultant to the U.S. Civil Rights Commission. Beginning in 1963, he was also the first volunteer general counsel of a gay rights organization, and consulted pro bono in death penalty and Guantnamo cases. In 1980, Freedman became the first executive director of the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council. In tribute to the memory of Professor Freedman, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half-staff. Alan Bernon, Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz, President Hofstra University 1/3

POST--George B. Jr.,the real estate appraiser, musician and past Chairman of the Beaufort Housing Authority Board, Beaufort's Board of Architectural Review and Zoning Board of Appeals, died peacefully February 27 surrounded by his family. He was born in Cincinnati, OH the son of George and Linda Post, grew up in Darien, CT, and was educated at St. Marks School and at Harvard College. He moved with his wife Sally to Beaufort in 1989. In 2004 Post was appointed by the Beaufort City Council to The Housing Authority Board, where from 2005 to his retirement in 2013 Post served as chairman. He served as chairman of the city's Historic Review Board, then known as The Board of Architectural Review, from 1998 to 2002. From 1991-1994 Post served on the city's Zoning Board of Appeals, from 1993-4, as its chairman. For the past 22 years Post has been a general certified residential and commercial real estate appraiser for Bundy Appraisal and Management. An avid sailor, he was a Commodore of the Beaufort Yacht and Sailing Club. A gifted performer, he was a regular in Beaufort Performing Arts performances. Prior to his arrival in Beaufort, Post played keyboards and was the lead singer for the rock band, The Nude Ants, that performed regularly at CDBG's, The Peppermint Lounge and at other clubs on New York's trend-setting Lower East Side and at Studio 54 and Traxx uptown. The Nude Ants won numerous awards for their music videos, including for "Lady Light" that was written and performed by Post. He is survived by his wife Sally, and their sons Ben and James. His vibrant energy, enthusiasm for life and laugh will be long-remembered. The family asks that memorial gifts be made to The First Presbyterian Church Music Fund in Beaufort, or The Islesboro Island Trust, 376 West Bay Road in Islebboro, ME. Please share your stories about George by visiting copelandfuneralservice.com Copeland Funeral Service is assisting the family with services. 1/3

BILLER--Hugh F.,MD. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are very saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague, Hugh F. Biller, MD, former Professor and Chairman of the Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery at The Mount Sinai Hospital and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. An internationally recognized educator and head and neck surgeon, Dr. Biller was a pioneer in conservative laryngeal surgical procedures. When he was named Chair in 1972, at age 37, he became Mount Sinai's youngest Chair appointee. Under his stewardship, the Department expanded rounds to include a number of key staff from different specialties, providing an early model of truly comprehensive care. Dr. Biller authored more than 350 scientific articles and co-authored the book "Surgery of the Larynx" with Byron Bailey. He won numerous awards, served as President of Mount Sinai's Medical Board, and was a frequent and popular lecturer. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, colleagues, and friends. He was a devoted physician and educator, and it is with gratitude that we remember his many years of service to Mount Sinai and his patients. Peter W. May Chairman Boards of Trustees Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD President and Chief Executive Officer Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai President for Academic Affairs Mount Sinai Health System Eric M. Genden, MD Dr. Isadore Friesner Chair Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

RYBAK--Ben, age 94, died on March 1st at his home in Fort Lee, NJ. Born in Poland to Leon and Sara Rybak on December 17th, 1920, he emigrated to Argentina at the age of nine. He attended medical school and completed his medical residency in Buenos Aires, where he practiced for 14 years as a gastroenterologist. He brought his new family to the United States in 1961 and settled first in the Bronx and later in Englewood, New Jersey, retraining and practicing as a pathologist at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens for 28 years. His areas of interest and research included the early detection of gastric cancer and the gastrointestinal manifestations of HIV. Ben was known to all as an intelligent and loving man, a truly gentle spirit whose passions were his family, his Jewish faith and his teaching. He is survived by Fanny, his loving wife of 57 years, his two children, Judith and Leon, and his grandchildren Daniel and Sofia. Funeral services will be at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, NJ at 1pm on March 3rd. 1/3

FARMER--Thomas L.,died February 5, 2015 at his home in northwest Washington D.C. surrounded by his wife and three children. He was 91 years old. The cause was progressive supranuclear palsy. Born in Berlin in 1923, to an American father and a German-Jewish mother, Thomas Farmer graduated from Great Neck High School in 1940 and from Harvard College (A.B. 1943) where he was a member of the Editorial Board of the Harvard Crimson. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943 to 1946. At war's end, as a member of the Military Intelligence Division of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, Washington, he debriefed Wehrmacht officers on German Army Order of Battle. He thereupon read law at Brasenose College, Oxford (LL.B.1948) and graduated from Harvard Law School (LL.M. 1950). His marriage to Elizabeth Becker in 1951 ended in divorce in 1970. Thomas Farmer combined private law practice with public service. From 1951 to 1954 he was a Covert Operations Officer for the CIA. From 1954 to 1964, he was an associate of the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett. He worked in John Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1959 and in 1960 and as the General Counsel for the State Department's U.S. Agency for International Development from 1964 to 1968. He served as Chairman of the Intelligence Oversight Board during the Carter administration. From 1970 to 1994 he was partner in the law firm Prather Seeger Doolittle and Farmer. Thomas Farmer was deeply involved in developing relations between the United States and Germany. He helped found the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies (1983) and the American Academy in Berlin (1994). He received the Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany in 1997. He is survived by his wife of twelve years, Wanda Walton, his children: Daniel Farmer, Sarah Farmer and Elspeth Farmer, and five grandchildren. 1/3

FISHMAN--Dr. Joshua Aaron The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of the revered Dr. Joshua Aaron Fishman, its former Vice President for Academic Affairs and former Dean of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology who was a world renowned scholar in the field of linguistics, psychology and specialties in the sociology of linguistics and other academic fields. He and his wife of 63 years, Gella Schweid Fishman, shared a love of family and the study and teaching of Yiddish at YU and elsewhere. Heartfelt condolences are extended to their children: Menakhem-Monele (and Leslie) Fishman, Dovid Eliyohu (and Elissa) Fishman, Avrom (and Eilat) Fishman, nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. He will be sorely missed by his admiring colleagues and friends. May all who were privileged to know him be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

BENMOSCHE--Robert. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing of Robert Benmosche, a valued Board Member, 1997-2006. His generosity and vision inspired his personal support and that of MetLife, which he served as Chairman, President, and CEO, of the Philharmonic's education programs, radio broadcasts, and many special events. ROSS--Carol Gladstein McAlester, beloved daughter of Margaret F. and Irvin A. Gladstein, McAlester, Oklahoma. Forever treasured wife of James E. Ross, New York, New York. Born May 12, 1938 and passed away on February 27, 2015 at 5:12am. A great star of Oklahoma and of Humanity. Her light cannot be dimmed. Carol was a graduate of The University of Oklahoma with graduate studies at U.C.L.A. and The University of Denver. At OU's Centennial celebration she was selected, with Tom Paxton, as the two Theater Arts students' greatest artists in the University's history. She appeared many times on Broadway and was Sister Sophia in the National tour of The Sound Of Music. She taught Master Classes at OU. Carol is survived by her husband James E. Ross; sister, Bette Jan Brook; her step- children, Janna E. and Kathryn A. Ross, as well as numerous nieces, nephews, cousins and friends around the world. A graveside service will be held on Friday, March 6, 2015 at 2:00pm at Fairlawn Cemetery in Oklahoma City, OK. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Emanuel in New York City at a date yet to be determined. Gifts in Carol's name should be made to the National Kidney Foundation. Carol loved and was loved by everyone who knew her. Her passing leaves a great void in our lives. 1/3

MALHOTRA--Rajiv DeVera, 36, of Clinton, CT passed away March 1, 2015. Born on November 24, 1978 in Jackson Heights, NY. He was the son of Sham Lal Malhotra and Annie DeVera Malhotra. He had resided in Clinton after graduating from Boces in Long Island. Rajiv was employed at the Coast Guard Academy for the past five years. He was a member of the Vista Vocational and Life Skills Center for 15 years. Besides his parents, Rajiv leaves behind his sister Reena Malhotra Arora and her husband Madhur and his nephews Landon Rajan Arora and Kyle Emilio Arora. We will miss our beloved Rajiv, our boo boo, our darling boy. He had a passion for travel, food, swimming and tennis. He was taken from this world way too soon, but his big smile and kind soul will forever be in our hearts. Family and friends may visit Swan Funeral Home, 80 E. Main St., Clinton on Thursday, March 5, 2015 from 10-11am. A funeral service will be held at the funeral home at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his name to Vista Vocational & Life Skills Center 1356 Old Clinton Rd., Westbrook, CT 06498. For online tributes and condolences, please visit www.swanfh.com. 1/3

RECHLER--Morton, passed away on February 28, 2015. He was born on July 29, 1921 to Michael and Yetta Rechler. He is survived by his wife, the former Beverley Lewis, and his children Bennett (Bonnie), Hannah Rabinowitz (David), Yvetta Newman (Andrew) and predeceased by his son Daniel. He is also survived by his grandchildren Debra Rechler, Halley (Erin) and their son Graham, Zachary (Lindsay), Jennie Jamieson (Dan), their children Elijah and Naomi, and Michelle Carney (Leon) and their son Gabriel. He was a gifted sculptor, a successful businessman, a philanthropist, but most of all he was a loving, devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed. There will be a private family service. 1/3

Adamko; mother to Michael Adamko; Joanne Adamko Tatham and Chuck Tatham and "Grandmargie" to Trevor and Nicholas. Longtime resident of Colonia, New Jersey and snowbird in Palm Desert, CA. TRAUTFIELD--Lillian, of Woodbury, NY formerly of Plainview, on March 3, 2015, just shy of her 89th birthday. Daughter of Sadie and Harry Lichter of Middle Village. Predeceased by her older brother, Norman. Beloved wife and best friend of Irwin for almost 65 years. Cherished mother of Marcia (Todd), Debra (Tom) and Marilyn (Howard). Adored grandmother of Holly (Josh), Adam, Neil, Marc, Jessica and Bari. Fondly remembered sister-in-law of Estelle and Betty, and treasured aunt. She was smart, funny and above all, devoted to her family. Services are Friday, March 6th at 11am, Gutterman's , Woodbury, NY. 1/3

KORNREICH--William D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with deep sorrow the passing of William D. Kornreich, beloved brother of our dear friends and Benefactors Kathy and Sam Weinberg. The Kornreich family have been valued supporters of Einstein medical research and education for three generations. William and Kathy's late father, Matthew, was an Overseer and a past Chairman of our Men's Division; their late mother, Susanne, was a leader in our Women's Division. Kathy is a past president of the Women's Division, Sam serves as an Overseer, their son Andrew serves on our Professional & Leadership Division board and their daughter Lisa is a past vice president of the Women's Division NY Chapter. To Kathy, Sam, Lisa, Andrew (Jenna), William's beloved wife Eileen and the entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Richard M. Joel, President Yeshiva University Allen M. Spiegel, MD, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1/3

FIREMAN--Robert. November 13, 1936 -March 2, 2015. Pre-teen Bob was a mail-order business "boy" selling fish supplies through ads in comic books. Too careless to pass engineering at NYU, he graduated CCNY with a BS in physics and MS from Stevens Institute of Technology. Acing a company's aptitude test, Bob was recruited into a burgeoning new field that wasn't yet widely labeled: computer systems analyst. His colleagues described his mind as "brilliant". The crafts zeitgeist of the 60s called him. Not being adept at any himself, he opened a crafts store. In time, this serial entrepreneur became a futon furniture designer and manufacturer, patenting three futon frame mechanisms. An intrepid sourcer, he developed factories in the US and South America. The last 12 years he fell in love with unusual hardwoods he found in Indonesia, where he was committed to sustainable harvesting. Products were sold in the Greenpoint Brooklyn FTS warehouse. Known for his love of family and wry wit, Bob leaves behind his wife of 49 years, his daughter, son in law, two grandchildren, brother, his wife's siblings and spouses and beloved nieces, nephews and cousins and friends from all over the world. Funeral Friday March 6, 11:00am Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. 1/3
MINARD--Julia Armstrong, March 5, 1985 -Nov. 13, 2005. "The past is never dead. It's not even past." 1/3

HENKOFF--Isaac "Ike", 84, formerly of Montclair, New Jersey, died on Tuesday March 3, 2015 at home in Little Falls, New Jersey. He graduated from Bayonne High School, Rutgers University and Harvard Law School. He served in the US Army from 1954 to 1956. A former trial attorney, he was a partner at the law firm of Chapman, Henkoff, Kessler, Peduto & Saffer until his retirement in 2001. He was an avid fan of the Yankees and the Jets, and enjoyed the New York symphony, ballet and opera. He was predeceased by his son Philip Henkoff and his long-time companion Judith "Judy" Baum. He is survived by his daughter Lisa, of New York City, her husband Manu Rana and their daughter Maya; his brother Hank of Dedham, Massachusetts and Hank's sons Ron and David and their families; Judy's daughter Erica, her husband Tim and their son Dashiell; and Judy's daughter Jenny, her husband Henry and their son Caleb. Services will be held at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, New Jersey on Sunday, March 8 at 11:00am. Burial will follow at King Solomon Memorial Park, 550 Dwasline Road, Clifton, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, to the Simon Wiesenthal Center, or to Wounded Warrior Project, causes Ike supported for many years. 1/3

He is also survived by his grandchildren Debra Rechler, Halley (Erin) and their son Graham, Zachary (Lindsay), Jennie Jamieson (Dan), their children Elijah and Naomi, and Michelle Carney (Leon) and their son Gabriel. He was a gifted sculptor, a successful businessman, a philanthropist, but most of all he was a loving, devoted husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed. There will be a private family service. 1/3

SILVER--David. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long- time member David Silver. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3

SILVER--David. Passed peacefully on March 3, 2015 surrounded by his loving family and many friends. David was born on March 26, 1939. He grew up in Worcester, MA and attended Babson College. David was the founder and CEO of Regency Home Fashions. He was the driving force in the success of this privately held company from its creation in 1968 until his retirement in 1997. He also partnered with Jerry Dellafemina in the Red Horse Market in the early 90's. David was blessed with an extraordinarily generous spirit of giving and spent five years of tireless effort raising four million dollars to build the East Hampton RECcenter. David believed deeply in giving to the East Hampton community that brought him and his family so many years of joy. David, along with his wife Patricia, supported the college education of 11 East Hampton students through the PDS scholarship fund. They also donated several playgrounds in honor of their parents. Additionally, they were generous benefactors of the Ross School since its inception as well as the Chapin School in New York City. David had a boundless passion for life and was a lover of all things beautiful. He was curious about everything. There was never a dull moment in David's presence. After his retirement, he volunteered for many years with Learning Leaders of New York City mentoring and educating New York City public school children. David is survived by his loving wife of thirty years Patricia Walton Silver, his four children Michael, (Rebecca), Gabrielle, AiNhi, and Geige, as well as 10 grandchildren Johnny, Davis and Clint Silver, Maxwell, Wesley, Emma, MacKenzie and Raymond Morrison, Sen and Maia Horton. He was adored and beloved by his children and grandchildren all who surrounded him with love and laughter throughout his life and in his final days. A huge light has disappeared from our lives but his memories always bring smiles and laughter. Donations can be made to the "Y East Hampton RECenter, David Silver Fund." Service will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Friday, March 6, 11:30am. 1/3

DOCTERS--Gerard J. G. (July 4, 1922 -February 27, 2015). Born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Received his Doctorandus of Economics from the Netherlands School of Economics, 1947. Married to Ann Marree. Worked 31 years for Mobil Oil, retiring 1985 as President of Mobil Oil Europe. Bob was known for his sharp intellect, mastery of languages, daily jogs, world travels, love of swing jazz and skiing. Dearly missed by sisters Connie Van Erp, Jossy Hulman (Rotterdam), and Jeannette Hall (Sydney); children Robert and Pamela (Connecticut); grandchildren Kendric, Dominic and Alida Schefers; partner Mery Parra. 1/3

Stefanie's joie de vivre and gregariousness were a source of joy to all who knew her. Ellant--Arlene Friedman, died from complications of a stroke on March 3, 2015. She was the widow of Dr. Paul Ellant. Arlene was a graduate of Brooklyn College, and earned a Masters in Education from CW Post. She worked as a Master Teacher in the New York City Public School's from which she retired. A woman of valor and the center of her extended family, Arlene is survived by her children Tom and Elissa Ellant Katz, Howard Reiter and Jody Ellant, Jonathan and Devi Ellant and by her beloved ten grandchildren to whom she was known as Baba; Joseph, Peyton, Jacob, Gavriela, Aiden, Ariana, Bram, Gideon, Haley and Dylan Paul. Arlene is also survived by sisters-in-law Judy Ellenzweig and Marilyn Davis, brother Robert Friedman and many cousins and friends. Arlene will be profoundly missed by all. Services will be held Friday, March 6th at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Contributions may be sent in memory of Arlene to the Brooklyn College Foundation, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11210. Attn Courtenay Barton. Donations are for a scholarship that will fund a young woman who is the first in her family to go to college.

MOAK--Lester, 93, at home, on March 5, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Phoebe, devoted father of Roger Moak, Nancy Jane Boyajy and Mindy Ellen Moak, adored grandfather of Adam and Evan Boyajy. Service Sunday, March 8, 2015, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Wounded Warrior Project or the veteran's association of your choice. 1/3

ADAMKO--Margaret M. Died March 1 in Rancho Mirage, CA. Beloved wife of commercial banking executive Joseph M. Adamko; mother to Michael Adamko; Joanne Adamko Tatham and Chuck Tatham and "Grandmargie" to Trevor and Nicholas. Longtime resident of Colonia, New Jersey and snowbird in Palm Desert, CA. Visitation Friday, March 6, 2-4 and 7-9 pm, Gosselin Funeral Home, Edison, NJ. Funeral Saturday, 10:30 am, St. John Vianney, Colonia, NJ. Donations to Eisenhower Medical Center Foundation, Rancho Mirage, CA.

MARSHALL--Edith Paul. April 1, 1928 - February 16, 2015. One of the most remarkable women of the 20th Century has passed. Her impact will live on in those she touched. Celebration and stories at her home Friday, March 6th: 7-9pm. Sabrina Friend Jeremy Marshall

GETNICK--Stefanie E. Born December 9, 1940. Died March 1, 2015. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, niece, aunt, cousin, and friend. Retired middle school teacher of French, Spanish, culture, and art. Stefanie's joie de vivre and gregariousness were a source of joy to all who knew her. Gathering on Friday, March 6, at 12:15pm, with services to follow at 12:45pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Please no flowers. Contact "The Riverside" for memorial contribution information (212- 362-6600). 1/3

TRAUTFIELD--Lillian, of Woodbury, NY formerly of Plainview, on March 3, 2015, just shy of her 89th birthday. Daughter of Sadie and Harry Lichter of Middle Village. Predeceased by her older brother, Norman. Beloved wife and best friend of Irwin for almost 65 years. Cherished mother of Marcia (Todd), Debra (Tom) and Marilyn (Howard). Adored grandmother of Holly (Josh), Adam, Neil, Marc, Jessica and Bari. Fondly remembered sister-in-law of Estelle and Betty, and treasured aunt. She was smart, funny and above all, devoted to her family. Services are Friday, March 6th at 11am, Gutterman's , Woodbury, NY. 1/3

Ann led an active and adventurous life publishing over 50 children's books from around the world following a long career at Scholastic Magazines. Ann's many friends and family will miss her greatly. Services 2:30pm on Sunday, March 8, at "The Riverside" 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

PINES--Carol, on March 2, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Loyal friend, dedicated teacher, talented artist and most hopeful Mets fan. Greatly missed by loving husband Harvey Richmond, devoted daughter Erika Antin (Scott), grandson Drew and extended family. SHORSER--Helen, on March 3. Wife of the late Seymour. Mother of Bradley Shorser and wife Ellen and Joanne Gentile and husband Stephen. Grandmother of Leah Gentile and Isaac Shorser. Sister of Jerry Kirsch. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ on Sunday, March 8 at 1:30pm. 1/3

SILVER--David. Passed peacefully on March 3, 2015 surrounded by his loving family and many friends. David was born on March 26, 1939. He grew up in Worcester, MA and attended Babson College. David was the founder and CEO of Regency Home Fashions. He was the driving force in the success of this privately held company from its creation in 1968 until his retirement in 1997. He also partnered with Jerry Dellafemina in the Red Horse Market in the early 90's. David was blessed with an extraordinarily generous spirit of giving and spent five years of tireless effort raising four million dollars to build the East Hampton RECcenter. David believed deeply in giving to the East Hampton community that brought him and his family so many years of joy. David, along with his wife Patricia, supported the college education of 11 East Hampton students through the PDS scholarship fund. They also donated several playgrounds in honor of their parents. Additionally, they were generous benefactors of the Ross School since its inception as well as the Chapin School in New York City. David had a boundless passion for life and was a lover of all things beautiful. He was curious about everything. There was never a dull moment in David's presence. After his retirement, he volunteered for many years with Learning Leaders of New York City mentoring and educating New York City public school children. David is survived by his loving wife of thirty years Patricia Walton Silver, his four children Michael, (Rebecca), Gabrielle, AiNhi, and Geige, as well as 10 grandchildren Johnny, Davis and Clint Silver, Maxwell, Wesley, Emma, MacKenzie and Raymond Morrison, Sen and Maia Horton. He was adored and beloved by his children and grandchildren all who surrounded him with love and laughter throughout his life and in his final days. A huge light has disappeared from our lives but his memories always bring smiles and laughter. Donations can be made to the "Y East Hampton RECenter, David Silver Fund." Service will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Friday, March 6, 11:30am. 1/3
HOCHMAN--Andrew Tuck. Forever in our hearts. Missed every day. Love, Barbara 1/3

BREGER--William N. 92, died on February 23 at Weill Cornell Medical Center. Bill, born in the Bronx, attended Stuyvesant High School in New York City, and held a graduate degree in Architecture from Harvard University and a PhD in Philosophy from the New York University. He served in the Planning Department of the United States Army during World War II, and was discharged with honor. In the years shortly following the War he was the assistant to Walter Gropius at the Harvard University School of Architecture. Upon his return to New York he established his own architecture firm. Bill was a Chairman of the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute, a Visiting Lecturer in Health Care Design at Columbia University, a Lecturing Professor at the New York School of Interior Design, and a Lecturing Professor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, specializing in English and French Furniture. He was a fellow of the American Institute of Architects. One of his students, subsequently a prominent New York architect, remarked: "Bill was tough on us, but when I began practicing architecture in the real world, I realized the value of his approach: the clients were much tougher." Over a long career, Bill received many design awards; among others, he was a runner up in the 1948 national competition for the Gateway to the West in St. Louis, and the architect of the award winning Civic Center Synagogue in Lower Manhattan. His compassion and humanity was manifested by an architectural practice spanning his lifelong career, specializing in the health care field, in which he pioneered the environment as a therapeutic tool approach. His novel designs and methods were summarized in the book "Nursing Home Development" co-authored with William R. Pomeranz. Bill was an editor of the "Encyclopedia of Philosophy" published by Macmillan Publishing Co., and wrote numerous publications on nursing homes and extended care facility design. For 92 years family and friends enjoyed Bill's brilliant insight, sharp wit and honesty to fault. He was deeply loved and will be painfully missed. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Krystyna Piotrowska-Breger; his daughter Willow Harth of Madison, WI and a step-daughter Kinga Piotrowska-Meckier of Brooklyn, NY, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tribeca Synagogue, www.tribecasynagogue.org. 1/3

DEUTSCH--Suzanne Zeitlin, of Cambridge, MA, on March 2, 2015, age 98. Beloved wife for 63 years of the late Martin Deutsch, Ph.D., Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She is survived by her sons, L Peter Deutsch of Healdsburg, CA, and Nicholas A. Deutsch of Cambridge, MA. She is also survived by her former daughter-in-law, Prof. Barbara J. Grosz, of Brookline, MA. Suzanne received a Master of Social Work degree from Simmons College, Boston; and retired as a Social Work Supervisor at the Massachusetts General Hospital. Service private by the family. Donations in her memory may be made to the Martin Deutsch Presidential Fellowship at M.I.T. (please contact Bonny Kellermann at 617- 253-9722 or memorial-gifts- office@mit.edu). 1/3

Fundraiser extraordinaire, woman ahead of her time, who lived life fully, who adored and was adored by her family and friends. Funeral: Plaza Community Chapel (630 Amsterdam Ave), March 6th, noon. DUNBAR--Jane Autumn (Lewis), 82, beloved wife and mother, died February 18, 2015. Devoted daughter of Annette and Richard "Big Chief" Lewis of Massapequa, survived by husband Russell, three daughters and ten grandchildren. A proud Washington Irving High School, Pratt and Columbia grad, Jane loved to laugh, delighted in babies and thrilled to music and art. We will dearly miss our Janie. Memorial March 7, 2015 Grand Court, Farmington Hills, MI. 1/3

MARKOVITS--Audrey, died peacefully at home in White Plains on March 5 surrounded by her loving family. She was 85. Beloved wife and best friend of Stanley for 63 years, she is survived by her two children, four grandchildren, brother, and countless devoted friends. Services at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, on Sunday, March 8 at 11:30am.

ROGERS--Sylvia Deborah, passed away peacefully from brief complications of cancer on March 4th, 2015 in her Armonk, New York home of 45 years. She is survived by her husband of fifty-four years Steve Rogers, her three sons Ken (Katie), Greg (Dana) and Don (Danna), and her eight grandchildren, as well as her siblings Leonard Wolfe of New Haven, CT and Ruth Rabineau of Ruxton, MD. Sylvia was born in London, England July 1937 to her loving parents Henry and Tillie Rose Solomon Wolfe. Together with her siblings, their family survived repeated Nazi air raids during World War II. This was one of Sylvia's formidable experiences, and a lifelong source of inspiration and strength. It also began her deep admiration for Winston Churchill and the Queen Mother who she quoted often and who brought her comfort to the very end. In 1948, Sylvia and her family sailed the Queen Elizabeth from London to start a new life in America. Her first steps on the sparkling streets of New York formed an indelible image that began her love for America, and the freedoms and security it provided. She went on to graduate from Forest Hills high school in New York and attended New York University. At age 19, she met her husband-to-be on a blind date in Baltimore, Maryland. They married and began one of her life's most cherished and selfless works, the raising of her three sons. Sylvia was a patron of the arts, and was co-Chair of the Armonk Art Show for a decade. She was an active tennis player, calling herself "the Lobster" for her dangerous lob game, but ultimately converted full time to golf where she loved to compete and socialize with her many friends at Whippoorwill and Ballen Isles Country Clubs. Sylvia was a whirlwind of energy and a friend to all. She had an ability to make people laugh and feel at ease. She often said "love is the answer" and lived her life in constant motion in a celebration of life. She had an iron will and strong held beliefs, and naturally saw the best in everyone. She spent her final days smiling and laughing with her family, once again touching those around her with vibrancy and optimism, which lives on in her loving memory. Donations can be made in Sylvias name to Arts Westchester (www.artswestchester. org) and the Children's Room of the North Castle Public Library (www.friendsncpl.org). 1/3
McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Happy Birthday Mom! You are always with me. Love, Sissy 1/3

GALIN--Glenda, 82, of Manhattan, died on Thursday, March 5th from complications from a stroke. She was born on September 4, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY, to Libby and Leon Goldenberg. She attended Syracuse University and graduated from Brooklyn College. She was a volunteer at CASA, a Francophile, an arts enthusiast and crossword puzzle maven. She is survived by Miles Galin, her children, Amy, Liza, Scott and Jon, son-in-law Benjamin and daughter in-law Jodi, her 13 grandchildren, Emma, Sam, Max, Henry, Hannah, Danny, Libby, Lucas, Frances, Justin, Rebecca, Joe, and Elias, her brother Alan and sister-in-law Rena, and her cousins, Riki, Melanie and Candy. Funeral service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 9am on Sunday, March 8th. Visitors are welcome at 1735 York Avenue from 3pm-7pm. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Robert James, former White Plains City Court judge and longtime White Plains resident, died on Tuesday, March 4 at his home. He was 89. Bob lived and worked in White Plains for more than sixty years. Prior to his time on the White Plains City Court bench, he was a partner at Corwin & Friedman, a law firm established in 1953. Most recently, he was Of Counsel to Holden Brothers, P.C, also located in White Plains. Throughout his life, Bob volunteered in many organizations. He also served as a president of the White Plains Bar Association and as director of the Westchester County Bar Association. Bob was proud of his Citizen Extraordinaire award received from the White Plains Historical Society, but was even more proud of his family. He is survived by his ex-wife Florence, with whom he retained a close relationship over the years; two sons, Douglas and Andrew; and four grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains on Sunday, March 8, 3pm-7pm. 1/3

STONE--Jack, known to many as "Jerry," age 90, died peacefully on March 5, 2015. Preceded in death by his parents Irving and Dora, and his sister Gloria. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Doris, his children Mark, Barbara and David, their spouses and his grandchildren. He had a successful and innovative career as a professional mechanical engineer, having founded the MEP design firm of Jack Stone Engineers of New York City in 1959. His passion was flying his plane and being with his beloved wife, children and grandchildren, for whom he always had a smile. A funeral service is scheduled for Sunday, March 8 at 1pm at Star of David Memorial Chapel, 1240 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY. 1/3
BAUM--Phil. On my mind today -your birthday -and everyday. In my heart forever. Your Bette 1/3

BENSON--STANLEY R. 91, passed away March 6th surrounded by his loving family. Son of the late Dr Joseph & Gertrude Benson. Survived by his loving wife, Gladys, of 69 years. Adored by his devoted children, Franklin and Nancy, Mitchell and Ronda, Stuart and Kerri; Cherished by his Grandchildren, Jason & Jodi, Lisa & Eric, Nicole & Felix, Michael, Sean, Ryan & Dani, Tara & Dustin and 7 Great Grandchildren. A beloved dentist. Proud WW II veteran. The New York Times never made a crossword he couldn't solve with a pen. Always living life to: "Let the good times roll"! He will be sorely missed. Service Sunday, March 8 @ 9 a.m Star of David, N. Lauderdale, Fl.

SOMMER--Roberta "Bobbie" of Somers, NY, March 5. Retired social worker. Beloved wife of the late Bertram Sommer. Mother of Lorie (Alan) Mael and Jonathan (Elizabeth) Sommer. Adored grandmother and great- grandmother. 1/3

NIVES--Fred. March 4, 2015, 94 years old. Born Vienna Austria in 1921. Fred was a lover of life who lived every day to the fullest. This was not surprising for a man who in 1938, at the age of 17 in order to escape from the Nazis after Kristallnacht, walked from Austria at night hiding in the woods during the day to find refuge in Belgium. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1940, he proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946 in the European Theater in Paris under General Eisenhower's command. He was reunited with his father Bernhard and brother Ernest at war's end, but his mother Roza perished in Auschwitz. Fred Nives was truly one of a kind. Larger than life, he was an avid sportsman with unstoppable energy. He relished his early ski adventures in Davos and then his chalet in Meribel, France. His love of athletics included tennis, swimming and his treadmill. He was a voracious reader, classical music concertgoer and opera lover, especially Wagner. In his youth, he piloted his plane from Paris all over Europe, and ran his boat along the French Riviera to the Greek Isles. As an accomplished horseman for 50 years, he and his beloved wife Donna rode in Hunter-Pace events. In events where he was not riding, Fred became an official timer at the finish lines. He was also the Treasurer of the Greenwich Riding and Trails Association. He was proud that the GRTA's budget was perfectly balanced while he was the treasurer. His wide circle of friends and family reveled in his contagious enthusiasm, keen intelligence and marvelous sense of humor. He graciously brought everybody together for many holidays and occasions. Always generously entertaining guests with his hilarious jokes, wonderful stories, choice bottles of wines and love of fine foods. He had a strong will, strong opinions and strong mind. A successful entrepreneur with a brilliant and decisive business mind, Mr. Nives started a foreign currency service business in the 1950's and then a consumer finance company which was sold in 1963 to become Sterling Bancorp in New York. An accomplished Wall Street investor with a seat on the New York Stock Exchange until 1969, he was a general partner in investment partnership Apollo Associates until 1974. He left Wall Street to start Omni Financial Corporation, a very successful consumer financial company, in the early 70's. He wanted to help military personnel obtain consumer loans because he remembered how difficult it was for him to obtain a loan to buy his first car after the war. But, the greatest accomplishment of his life was his marriage to his extraordinary and beautiful wife Donna. He met the love of his life at the age of 37 in New York City and they married shortly thereafter. They shared a love of animals, which became a big part of their life together. In addition to their equestrian activities, they founded the 30+ year old Animal Rescue Group "Adopt-A- Dog" located in Greenwich, CT and Armonk, NY. "Fred and Donna also generously funded the Bronx Zoo's "Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavillion" Their love of animals and each other was apparent to all their friends and family. Mr. Nives also was a longtime Board member of The Center for Hearing and Communication. Member of the Greenwich Riding & Trails Association, The Graduate Club of New Haven, The Stamford Yacht Club, Goldens Bridge Hounds, North Salem, New York and Fairfield County Hounds in Bridgewater, CT. Mr. Nives is survived by Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. Funeral services will be held Monday, March 9 at 1:30pm at Temple Sholom, Greenwich Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family requests any donations be made to Adopt A Dog, 849 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831 or Center for Hearing and Communication, 50 Broadway, New York, NY 10004.

TELLES--Edna. January 26, 1926 - February 22nd, 2015 Widow of Sanford, mother of Matthew and Marcy, grandmother of four and great-grandmother of three. A vivacious presence laid low by disease. Rest in peace. In lieu of flowers, please donate to United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau.

Memorial services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, on Sunday, March 8th at 2:30 PM.

EGAN--Edward Michael Cardinal The Board of Trustees, leadership and staff of ArchCare, the Continuing Care Community of the Archdiocese of New York, mourn the passing of His Eminence, Archbishop Emeritus Edward Cardinal Egan. From his service as a hospital chaplain in the early years of his priesthood, to his leadership and support of our diocesan healthcare ministry, known as ArchCare, during his tenure as Archbishop of New York, Cardinal Egan's compassion and advocacy for the needs and rights of the elderly, sick and vulnerable were unflagging. His spirit will live on in all of us individually as well as through the countless healthcare programs and facilities throughout the Archdiocese of New York that will forever bear the mark of his vision and grace. Francis J. Serbaroli Chairman of the Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. Vice Chairman Thomas O'Brien Vice Chairman Scott P. LaRue President and Chief Executive Officer

FLATOW--Eugenia Mortlock. Age 93, of New York City, passed away at home on March 5th, 2015. Born in the Bronx, she was raised along with her brother Larry Mortlock, in Bronxville, NY. Beloved wife of Professor Paul Flatow and loving mother of Susan Weeks Jackson, Dr. Evan Flatow and Jonathan Flatow, she was grandmother to 10 and great-grandmother to 11. After graduating from the College of New Rochelle, she received an M.S. in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University. She held various public offices and served as management consultant, business proprietor, and citizen advocate in the areas of public housing, waterfront and environmental issues. Ms. Flatow was active in local politics, serving as chair of Community Planning Board #

O'MALLEY--Shaun Fenton, former Chairman of Price Waterhouse, died on February 25 of metastatic melanoma, surrounded by family at his home in Philadelphia. He married the late Sibyl Julia O'Malley of Annapolis, MD in 1965. He is survived by his wife, Lyn Buchheit; brothers W. Gresham O'Malley III and Hilaire J. O'Malley; sisters Mrs. Wallace Cooney and Mrs. Kristin Russo; children Brendan H. O'Malley, Sibyl H. O'Malley, and Aine O'Malley Pappas; step-daughter Megan K. McNamara; and grandchildren, Katherine G. O'Malley, Peter W. O'Malley, Ellen I. O'Malley, Chloe C. Pappas, and Samuel L. Pappas. A Memorial will be held on April 25, 2015 at 1:00pm at Our Mother of Consolation Church in Philadelphia. In lieu of flowers, a contribution in Shaun's memory can be made to Curtis Institute of Music, 1726 Locust Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103; or to support Cancer Research, Penn Medicine Development, Att: Laura Ferraiolo, 3535 Market St, Ste 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104. 1/3

ROBBINS--Gordon. Sculptor, fly fisherman, nationally ranked board sailor and snowboarder, and coach of Olympic medalists, Gordon A. Robbins of Winhall, VT died suddenly at home on Friday, February 27. Born in New York City on January 14, 1942, Robbins graduated from The Groton School and attended Cornell University. He subsequently moved to Paris where he studied architecture and art, becoming a prolific sculptor. He married artist and tapestry maker Claude Ohnenwald in 1965 and their works were jointly exhibited at Le Demeure in 1971. A skilled and enthusiastic sailor who was a longtime member of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, in the 1980's Robbins made a name for himself in the board sailing community as a coach, competitor, and as director of the U.S. Boardsailing Association. After moving to Vermont in 1988, he was hired by Marty Harrison to introduce snowboarding to the Okemo Mountain Resort in 1993. At Okemo he thoroughly embraced this relatively new sport, becoming one of two first full-time snowboard instructors and subsequently the first Director of the Okemo snowboarding program, most recently serving as a supervisor in the Okemo Ski + Ride School. Mr. Robbins was a founding father of the United States of America Snowboard Association (USASA), served as Executive Director of the International Snowboard Federation, Technical Director of the US Open of Snowboarding, and President of the USASA Foundation. He was a strong supporter of Adaptive Snowboarding and was revered by boarders of all ages and abilities. Mr. Robbins is survived by his wife of 49 years, Claude Ohnenwald Robbins, as well as by his brother Edward H. Robbins, uncle Edward H. Auchincloss, and a family of adoring nieces, nephews, and cousins as well as students, colleagues and friends around the world. Donations in his name may be made to the USASA Foundation. 1/3

MAYSLES--ALBERT. 88, died at home on March 5, surrounded by family. A legendary documentary filmmaker for over 60 years, he and his late brother David created such iconic films as Grey Gardens, Gimme Shelter and Salesman. Two new films Iris, a portrait of Iris Apfel, and In Transit will screen in New York this Spring. A generous guide to many filmmakers and a warm friend, he is survived by Gillian Walker, his wife of 40 years and their children, Rebekah, Philip, Sara, and Auralice. In the last 10 years, Albert dedicated himself to his beloved Maysles Documentary Center, the Harlem-based non-profit that shows documentaries and provides free and low cost film education. A memorial celebration is planned for the Fall. Contributions in Albert's memory may be made to the Maysles Documentary Center, www.maysles.org.

BREGER--William N. 92, died on February 23 at Weill Cornell Medical Center. Bill, born in the Bronx, attended Stuyvesant High School in New York City, and held a graduate degree in Architecture from Harvard University and a PhD in Philosophy from the New York University. He served in the Planning Department of the United States Army during World War II, and was discharged with honor. In the years shortly following the War he was the assistant to Walter Gropius at the Harvard University School of Architecture. Upon his return to New York he established his own architecture firm. Bill was a Chairman of the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute, a Visiting Lecturer in Health Care Design at Columbia University, a Lecturing Professor at the New York School of Interior Design, and a Lecturing Professor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, specializing in English and French Furniture. He was a fellow of the American Institute of Architects. One of his students, subsequently a prominent New York architect, remarked: "Bill was tough on us, but when I began practicing architecture in the real world, I realized the value of his approach: the clients were much tougher." Over a long career, Bill received many design awards; among others, he was a runner up in the 1948 national competition for the Gateway to the West in St. Louis, and the architect of the award winning Civic Center Synagogue in Lower Manhattan. His compassion and humanity was manifested by an architectural practice spanning his lifelong career, specializing in the health care field, in which he pioneered the environment as a therapeutic tool approach. His novel designs and methods were summarized in the book "Nursing Home Development" co-authored with William R. Pomeranz. Bill was an editor of the "Encyclopedia of Philosophy" published by Macmillan Publishing Co., and wrote numerous publications on nursing homes and extended care facility design. For 92 years family and friends enjoyed Bill's brilliant insight, sharp wit and honesty to fault. He was deeply loved and will be painfully missed. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Krystyna Piotrowska-Breger; his daughter Willow Harth of Madison, WI and a step-daughter Kinga Piotrowska-Meckier of Brooklyn, NY, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Tribeca Synagogue, www.tribecasynagogue.org. 1/3

DEUTSCH--Suzanne Zeitlin, of Cambridge, MA, on March 2, 2015, age 98. Beloved wife for 63 years of the late Martin Deutsch, Ph.D., Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She is survived by her sons, L Peter Deutsch of Healdsburg, CA, and Nicholas A. Deutsch of Cambridge, MA. She is also survived by her former daughter-in-law, Prof. Barbara J. Grosz, of Brookline, MA. Suzanne received a Master of Social Work degree from Simmons College, Boston; and retired as a Social Work Supervisor at the Massachusetts General Hospital. Service private by the family. Donations in her memory may be made to the Martin Deutsch Presidential Fellowship at M.I.T. (please contact Bonny Kellermann at 617- 253-9722 or memorial-gifts- office@mit.edu). 1/3

MacGUIRE--Alane. Alane Sauder MacGuire, a leading Jungian psychoanalyst, was born April 10, 1953 in Wichita Falls, Texas and has lived in Manhattan and in Lawrence, LI. She graduated from University of Texas, from Columbia University (MBA), and from NYU (MSW). Her true calling came after studying at the Jungian Institute in New York. She was in private practice for over 20 years and was beloved by her patients. She brought her knowledge of art, literature and myth to her work. She was a past Board member and president of the C.G. Jung Institute of New York, and a member of the Jungian Psychoanalytic Association at her death. She has been writing a ground breaking book on Persona which will be published posthumously. While Lanie was a committed New Yorker, she returned often to her family's ranch in Wise County, Texas. She cherished her family's pioneer ranching legacy and stewardship on this land. Lanie's passion for art took her all over the world and throughout New York City on her bicycle. She was an indomitable spirit, and her wonderful sense of humor and loyalty made her a best friend to a wide and devoted circle throughout her life. Her proudest accomplishment was her sons, Pierce and Rhoads, both who have become extraordinary young men. They embody her drive, kindness, spirit and generosity. She died of cancer on March 1st and is survived by her two sons Pierce and Rhoads MacGuire, her mother Johnnie Marie Waggoner Sauder and siblings. There will be a private service for her near the family ranch in Texas. A memorial service will be held in New York City at 11am on March 28, 2015 at the Church of the Transfiguration. Any donations in her name may be made to this church (www.littlechurch.org) or to Bladder Cancer Advocacy Network (www.bcan.org). Her family and friends are grateful for the extraordinary care she received from Dr. Dean Bajorin (MSKCC) and Calvary Hospice. 1/3

GREEN--Sylvia. Happy 102nd Birthday to my wonderful mother. Your words of wisdom are always with me. I miss you so much. Love, Barbara 1/3

FIREMAN--Robert. November 13, 1936 -March 2, 2015. Pre-teen Bob was a mail-order business "boy" selling fish supplies through ads in comic books. Too careless to pass engineering at NYU, he graduated CCNY with a BS in physics and MS from Stevens Institute of Technology. Acing a company's aptitude test, Bob was recruited into a burgeoning new field that wasn't yet widely labeled: computer systems analyst. His colleagues described his mind as "brilliant". The crafts zeitgeist of the 60s called him. Not being adept at any himself, he opened a crafts store. In time, this serial entrepreneur became a futon furniture designer and manufacturer, patenting three futon frame mechanisms. An intrepid sourcer, he developed factories in the US and South America. The last 12 years he fell in love with unusual hardwoods he found in Indonesia, where he was committed to sustainable harvesting. Products were sold in the Greenpoint Brooklyn FTS warehouse. Known for his love of family and wry wit, Bob leaves behind his wife of 49 years, his daughter, son in law, two grandchildren, brother, his wife's siblings and spouses and beloved nieces, nephews and cousins and friends from all over the world. 1/3

LIPKIN--Evelyn Appell. Resident of New York City, formerly of Chicago. Evelyn Appell Lipkin passed away at home on March 1, 2015. She was born February 12, 1921 aboard the S.S. Presidente Wilson at Governor's Island in the wave of immigrants arriving from Europe. She received her BA from Brooklyn College in Art and Art History and took classes at the New School for Social Research where she met Stan Lipkin, who became her life partner and cherished husband. She was a cryptographer during WWII in New York and later for the United States Navy, Bureau of Ships in Washington, DC. With her husband overseas, Evelyn relocated to Chicago to study for her Masters degree at the University of Chicago School of Social Service Administration. A social worker in the tradition of Jane Addams, she had a deep concern for those with limited resources who faced oppression and discrimination. Her career began at the Jewish Children's Bureau focused on adoption and foster care placement. After devoting her energies to raising three children (Ian, Joan, Laurel) she became a counselor in private practice and professor at George Williams College. She was beloved by faculty, students and patients. She retired in her late 80's after a courageous and successful fight against cancer and heart disease. Evelyn was among the founders of Women Strike for Peace, active in the antiwar movement, the League of Women Voters, the Urban League, as well as a proud and early member of the NAACP and a long-time supporter of the Southern Poverty Law Center. In Chicago she organized and began the first tot lots in Hyde Park, started and volunteered in the after school programs at the Hyde Park Study Center, and worked with teen mothers on the west side of Chicago at the Parent/Child Center. She was a long-time subscriber to many Chicago theater companies, Chicago and New York museums and other cultural venues. She was known for her sharp mind her children believed she forgot almost nothing. Playful and known for her edgy sense of humor, she loved to entertain and travel, was enormously engaging, and energetic. Always generous and caring, she welcomed many visitors of all ages and backgrounds to her home throughout her life. With her husband, she supported the work of writers, teachers, and visual artists establishing a number of prizes in New York and Chicago, and considered herself a passionate lover of all art forms, in particular dance, theater, music. She lived most of her adult life in Chicago's Hyde Park, a stalwart defender of integration and equal access to opportunities for all races and creeds; she set a strong example in resisting the white flight from the inner city to suburbia. In the last years of her life she returned to New York City as a resident of the Upper West Side where she kindled new friendships and maintained a cultural schedule that would challenge people decades younger and in better health. Her intellect, interest in others, will to live and generosity of spirit were intact to the very end. A resilient fighter, she tackled a number of very difficult health challenges and battled them all with fierceness and a tenacity to wring all she could from her time in this world. Evelyn and Stan were married 72 years. He survives her. Together, they raised three children and shared many adventures. She wished to be remembered as a loving wife, proud mother, loyal and good friend and an activist. Evelyn was an extraordinary woman whose like we will not see again. Her family and many friends adored her, will miss her always and keep her close. Services private. Donations may be made to the following organizations Evelyn selected: Doctors Without Borders, Lighthouse Guild International, Inc., the Sargent Shriver National Center on Poverty Law, Southern Poverty Law Center. A memorial will be held at a later date. 1/3

MANN--Peggy Lebair, died Tuesday at her home in Albany at age 94. A native of Woodmere, LI, she moved to Albany with her husband Jay D. Mann (deceased). She was the daughter of Harold Lebair, a longtime advertising executive for The New York Times. She was active in women's tennis, serving as the longtime coach of America's Marble Cup teams for women over 60. She also umpired at the U.S. Open for 50 years and at Wimbledon twice. She was an associate professor at SUNY Albany and coach of its tennis team for more than two decades. She is survived by her two sons James and Andrew Mann and by Karen Paxton, formerly the wife of Peggy's deceased son Ronald; and by her grandchildren Elizabeth, Ted, Jeffrey, Rebecca and Melissa Mann, and by Karen's children Rachel and Michael Paxton. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Planned Parenthood or to Equinox. 1/3

OPPENHEIMER--Miriam London, 98, of Wyomissing, PA (formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Westin, FL) died of natural causes on February 23, 2015. She was the widow of the late Donald R. Oppenheimer, Sr. who died in 1998 with whom she shared 59 years of marriage. Born March 24, 1916 and raised in Brooklyn, NY she was the daughter of the late Solomon and Katherine (Stein) London. Mrs. Oppenheimer graduated from Erasmus High School, Pratt Institute of Art, Brooklyn, NY. Three generations of London/Oppenheimer families had been members of Union Temple, Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, NY. Miriam was devoted to her family and family life. She is survived by two sons, Robert Oppenheimer Wyomissing, PA and John Oppenheimer Aptos, CA, four grandsons, three great-grandchildren, Other survivors include nephews and nieces, James Aiello, Southwest Ranches, FL and Marie Aiello, Clermont, FL and Mary Ann Oppenheimer, Franklin, MA. Memorial donations are appreciated: Union Temple, 17 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn NY 11238. 1/3

EGAN--Edward Michael Cardinal The Board of Trustees, leadership and staff of ArchCare, the Continuing Care Community of the Archdiocese of New York, mourn the passing of His Eminence, Archbishop Emeritus Edward Cardinal Egan. From his service as a hospital chaplain in the early years of his priesthood, to his leadership and support of our diocesan healthcare ministry, known as ArchCare, during his tenure as Archbishop of New York, Cardinal Egan's compassion and advocacy for the needs and rights of the elderly, sick and vulnerable were unflagging. His spirit will live on in all of us individually as well as through the countless healthcare programs and facilities throughout the Archdiocese of New York that will forever bear the mark of his vision and grace. Francis J. Serbaroli Chairman of the Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. Vice Chairman Thomas O'Brien Vice Chairman Scott P. LaRue President and Chief Executive Officer

HAMMERSTEIN MATHIAS-- Alice, the daughter of Oscar Hammerstein II and Myra Finn, died Thursday, February 26, at the age of 93. According to her daughter, Melinda Walsh, the cause was pneumonia. For many years, she was the Hammerstein family representative to The Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, and continued to be the spokeswoman for her father's work. With the insight of having seen the original production of "Show Boat" in 1927, she addressed the cast of the musicals New York Philharmonic concert performance last fall during rehearsals. As a young woman, she worked for her father doing research on specific subjects to support her father's lyrics, becoming immersed in the tradition of the New England clambake for the song "A Real Nice Clambake in Carousel." The material presented to her father often far exceeded what was necessary, something she attributed to what she termed "research poisoning". The recipient of several ASCAP Awards, she was the lyricist and co-author of "Babes In Toyland", an adaptation of the Victor Herbert Operetta, and she also wrote English lyrics to Franz Lehar's "The Merry Widow" and Johann Strauss' "A NightIn Venice", all of which were presented in the repertory of the Light Opera of Manhattan (LOOM). She was also associated with conductor Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society, for whom she translated lyrics of the American premiere of Richard Strauss' "Intermezzo" and adapted Mozart's "The Magic Flute" for presentation by puppets, both of which were performed at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. With her late husband Philip Mathias, she wrote and produced a musical Centennial tribute to Jerome Kern, "The Music Is Kern", in 1985, and was proud of having hired the then-unknown Susan Stroman to direct it. She enjoyed a lively correspondence with her father from 1928 until his death in 1960, and carefully saved the letters, which were warm, chatty, encouraging, and sometimes stern. Oscar treasured his daughter's precocious and painstakingly detailed notes and they were returned to her upon his death. Over the years, she worked on a book that included all the letters, which she titled, "From OH to AH." Her hope to publish the book was cut short by her death. She was a mainstay for family and friends, always knowing where she stood and wasn't afraid to say so, and what she said was worth listening to. We will miss her cockeyed optimistic view of the world and the future. Predeceased by her husband Philip Mathias in 2006, Alice Hammerstein Mathias is survived by her children, Melinda Walsh of Bedford Hills, New York and Peter Mathias of Monroe, Connecticut, a step-sister, Susan Blanchard of Roxbury, Connecticut, four grandchildren and two great- granddaughters. 1/3

KEANE--Mary Burdell. Born June 1st, 1931 in Columbus, OH, longtime resident of Gramercy Park. Died March 3, 2015 after a long illness, bravely fought. An avid runner and swimmer for much of his life and a true aesthete with a passion for music, art, reading and design. He was member of management of Hart Schaffner & Marx and The Greif Cos. in Chicago and New York during his long career in the fashion industry in the United States. He became an international luxury goods consultant for Tiffany & Co and Chaumet living in Japan and France for over thirty years. He will be profoundly missed by his wife, Anne, his sister Joy (Cem Cesmig), his children Gina (Alani Golanski), Adriana (Jeremy Payne), Hadrien and stepson,Charles Seydoux, and by his darling grandchildren, George, Lucia, Creely and Cy and his many friends around the world. A private service was held in Paris, France, on Friday March 6th, 2015. Donations may be made to the Jesse Owens Foundation. 1/3

SWERBILOV--Zarvin, age 87, passed away on February 26, 2015 in hospital in New York City, NY. He served honorably in the Navy during WWII and the GI Bill assisted his studies: BA at Queens College and MFA from Columbia University. A dedicated NYC teacher of 33 years, primarily at Haaron High School and Park West. Zarvin also taught art history at Queens College. Daily he sculpted or painted in his art studio. He showed his paintings between 1983 (Chuck Levitan Gallery) and 2014 (Noho Gallery). He felt privileged to have studied with Will Barnet (Art Students League) and Clay Spohn (SFAI). He was devoted to his wife of 47 years, Sally, who passed in 2007. Zarvin leaves his sons, Daniel and Nicholas; their wives, Diane and Beatrice; grandsons Justin, Nick Dan, Max, and Zusse; sister- in-law Dorothy; nieces Kate, Julie, Meg and Kathryn; and nephews Michael and Stephen. His brother Boris, brother-in-law John, nephew Ben, and sister-in-law Carol remained in his heart. Zarvin lived life his way. He was working on a new series of paintings--his plan was to live to be 100. He is deeply missed. 1/3

CUSTER--Elizabeth. October 1, 1910-March 1, 2015. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), mourns the passing of Elizabeth "Betts" Hawkins Custer, a prominent supporter of research in mental health and of our organization since its inception. Mrs. Custer and her late husband, Rear Admiral Ben Scott Custer (USN retired) were early leaders in the cause of improving life and prospects for people suffering from mental illness. She moved from her leadership in facilitating patient support at the New York State Psychiatric Institute which had begun in 1970, to playing a key role in forming the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill in 1979. She participated in the formation of the New York State Chapter of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI) and served on its board of directors and committees until her retirement from these responsibilities at the age of 100 in 2010. She worked closely with the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation from its formation in 1987. Her leadership was honored by this organization on the occasion of her 100th birthday with an award presented at the Annual Gala Research Awards Dinner. This Lifetime Achievement Award was presented by Dr. Herbert Pardes, President of the organization's Scientific Council. Her dedication and persuasive leadership did not stop when she passed her 100th birthday. She continued as a supporter and guide until her death at 104. We recognize that she enhanced the lives of many through her work for Brain & Behavior Research Foundation and have the deepest gratitude to her and to her children who supported her efforts. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President Herbert A. Pardes, M.D., President of the Scientific Council Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman of the Board 1/3

EMMOTT--Carol Burgess, Partner at Russell Reynolds Associates, died peacefully Feburary 25 at her home in Hillsborough, CA at the age of 68. Born in Bartlesville, Oklahoma, Carol earned a Bachelor's Degree from Southern Methodist University in 1969 and a PhD in Health Policy from Oklahoma University in 1975. Carol's career in public service is notable by her work as Special Assistant to Joseph A. Califano, then Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare in Washington, D.C. She later worked as Chief Deputy Director of the San Francisco Department of Public Health under Diane Feinstein. Carol then founded and was CEO of the California Association of Public Hospitals. She transitioned to a 25-year career in executive search as partner at firms Spencer Stuart, Heidrick & Struggles, and Russell Reynolds Associates. Carol was predeceased by her parents, Robert Banks Burgess and Mary Gary Bedwell. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, Cameron, son Parker, sister Betsy Wright, loving family, and dear friends. A memorial service will be held March 27, 2015 at 4pm at St. Paul's in Burlingame, CA. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Carol Emmott Fellowship at http:// www.carolemmott.org. 1/3

DISICK--Ellis R. 5 years and we continue to love him, miss him and share the beautiful memories. Laurie and Family 1/3

NIVES--Fred. March 4, 2015, 94 years old. Born Vienna Austria in 1921. Fred was a lover of life who lived every day to the fullest. This was not surprising for a man who in 1938, at the age of 17 in order to escape from the Nazis after Kristallnacht, walked from Austria at night hiding in the woods during the day to find refuge in Belgium. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1940, he proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946 in the European Theater in Paris under General Eisenhower's command. He was reunited with his father Bernhard and brother Ernest at war's end, but his mother Roza perished in Auschwitz. Fred Nives was truly one of a kind. Larger than life, he was an avid sportsman with unstoppable energy. He relished his early ski adventures in Davos and then his chalet in Meribel, France. His love of athletics included tennis, swimming and his treadmill. He was a voracious reader, classical music concertgoer and opera lover, especially Wagner. In his youth, he piloted his plane from Paris all over Europe, and ran his boat along the French Riviera to the Greek Isles. As an accomplished horseman for 50 years, he and his beloved wife Donna rode in Hunter-Pace events. In events where he was not riding, Fred became an official timer at the finish lines. He was also the Treasurer of the Greenwich Riding and Trails Association. He was proud that the GRTA's budget was perfectly balanced while he was the treasurer. His wide circle of friends and family reveled in his contagious enthusiasm, keen intelligence and marvelous sense of humor. He graciously brought everybody together for many holidays and occasions. Always generously entertaining guests with his hilarious jokes, wonderful stories, choice bottles of wines and love of fine foods. He had a strong will, strong opinions and strong mind. A successful entrepreneur with a brilliant and decisive business mind, Mr. Nives started a foreign currency service business in the 1950's and then a consumer finance company which was sold in 1963 to become Sterling Bancorp in New York. An accomplished Wall Street investor with a seat on the New York Stock Exchange until 1969, he was a general partner in investment partnership Apollo Associates until 1974. He left Wall Street to start Omni Financial Corporation, a very successful consumer financial company, in the early 70's. He wanted to help military personnel obtain consumer loans because he remembered how difficult it was for him to obtain a loan to buy his first car after the war. But, the greatest accomplishment of his life was his marriage to his extraordinary and beautiful wife Donna. He met the love of his life at the age of 37 in New York City and they married shortly thereafter. They shared a love of animals, which became a big part of their life together. In addition to their equestrian activities, they founded the 30+ year old Animal Rescue Group "Adopt-A- Dog" located in Greenwich, CT and Armonk, NY. "Fred and Donna also generously funded the Bronx Zoo's "Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavillion" Their love of animals and each other was apparent to all their friends and family. Mr. Nives also was a longtime Board member of The Center for Hearing and Communication. Member of the Greenwich Riding & Trails Association, The Graduate Club of New Haven, The Stamford Yacht Club, Goldens Bridge Hounds, North Salem, New York and Fairfield County Hounds in Bridgewater, CT. Mr. Nives is survived by Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. Funeral services will be held Monday, March 9 at 1:30pm at Temple Sholom, Greenwich Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family requests any donations be made to Adopt A Dog, 849 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831 or Center for Hearing and Communication, 50 Broadway, New York, NY 10004.

KRUPP--Irwin (Babe) Mitchell, 93, died on March 6th at Mt. Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach from complications due to Alzheimer's disease. He leaves Carolyn, his wife of 67 years as well as his son Spencer, daughters Katherine and Jane and four granddaughters. He was one of the Great Generation serving his country as a decorated B-17 pilot, shot down over Germany and imprisoned there for eight months until the war ended. He was an avid outdoorsman, an expert fisherman who loved to troll the waters of Long Island for his favorite catch, striped bass. He fought the good fight until the end and will be sorely missed. Funeral private. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Robert James, former White Plains City Court judge and longtime White Plains resident, died on Tuesday, March 4 at his home. He was 89. Bob lived and worked in White Plains for more than sixty years. Prior to his time on the White Plains City Court bench, he was a partner at Corwin & Friedman, a law firm established in 1953. Most recently, he was Of Counsel to Holden Brothers, P.C, also located in White Plains. Throughout his life, Bob volunteered in many organizations. He also served as a president of the White Plains Bar Association and as director of the Westchester County Bar Association. Bob was proud of his Citizen Extraordinaire award received from the White Plains Historical Society, but was even more proud of his family. He is survived by his ex-wife Florence, with whom he retained a close relationship over the years; two sons, Douglas and Andrew; and four grandchildren. The family will receive visitors at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains on Sunday, March 8, 3pm-7pm. 1/3

GALIN--Glenda, 82, of Manhattan, died on Thursday, March 5th from complications from a stroke. She was born on September 4, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY, to Libby and Leon Goldenberg. She attended Syracuse University and graduated from Brooklyn College. She was a volunteer at CASA, a Francophile, an arts enthusiast and crossword puzzle maven. She is survived by Miles Galin, her children, Amy, Liza, Scott and Jon, son-in-law Benjamin and daughter in-law Jodi, her 13 grandchildren, Emma, Sam, Max, Henry, Hannah, Danny, Libby, Lucas, Frances, Justin, Rebecca, Joe, and Elias, her brother Alan and sister-in-law Rena, and her cousins, Riki, Melanie and Candy. Funeral service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 9am on Sunday, March 8th. Visitors are welcome at 1735 York Avenue from 3pm-7pm. 1/3

KARP--Drina, died at age 60, a graphic and package landscape designer, who specialized in high style work. Talented, artistic, beautiful, she is mourned by her family and many friends. An admirer of all things Mexican, Drina loved to travel and mingle with other cultures. Starting at age four, she studied ballet, salsa and tango. Her musical tastes ranged from Enya to Marian Anderson to Maria Callas, with a heavy interest in Latin American music. She received an MFA from the School of Visual Arts.
