KARP--Drina. April 9, 1954 -January 26, 2015. Drina was one of a kind. Beautiful, sweet, quirky and generous of heart, she was easily one of the more interesting and interested people we ever knew. She immersed herself in her many loves which included dance, photography, art, design, gardening, history, travel, and her cats of course, all of which she would enthusiastically share with her friends. She was a true creative spirit, a lovely ball of energy with a true romantics heart. Drina made our lives more interesting, joyful, and beautiful. Drina made us happy. Bill McIntosh and Martin Raffone 1/3

MOAK--Lester, 93, a retired Air Force Lt. Col. Born December 10, 1921, died March 5, 2015. Col Moak, who lived in Chevy Chase, MD from 1955 until 2014, was born in Brooklyn, NY, where he resided till 1941. He enlisted in the Army Air Corps soon after Pearl Harbor was attacked. His pilot training was with the Southeast Command and after receiving his Pilot Wings and Commission, he was assigned as pilot of a B-25 bomber crew. He delivered his new plane and crew to India via South America, Ascension Island across central Africa and Arabia. On arrival in the China-Burma-India Theatre of Operations, he and his crew were assigned to the 83rd Squadron of the 12th Bomb Group (Med) of the 10th Air Force. After some missions with the Group, he was transferred to the Headquarters of the 10th Air Force as a staff pilot with a variety of missions including some in support of Lord Mountbatten's campaign to drive the Japanese from Burma. Finally, he was transferred to the US/British Headquarters of the China Theatre where he earned the Distinguished Flying Cross and Air Medals flying hazardous cargo and personnel flights over the Himalayan Mountains (known as the "Hump") which was critical to keeping Chang Kai-Shek and the Chinese Army in the war and tying down many Japanese troops that would otherwise be fighting our troops in the Pacific battles. As a reserve officer, he was recalled to active duty for two years during the Korean Emergency. After leaving active service, he moved his family to Chevy Chase where his three children attended school before their careers took them all to New York City. For the last 40 years he was engaged in real estate management in Bethesda, MD, and Alexandria, VA. On his 92nd birthday December 2013 he moved to New York City to be close to family. Survivors include his son, Roger M. Moak of NYC; his daughter, Mindy Ellen Moak of NYC; his daughter, Nancy Jane Boyajy of Boston, MA; grandson, Adam G. Boyajy of Boston and grandson Evan Ross Boyajy of NYC. His adored wife, Phoebe of 63 years of marriage passed away in 2008. Contributions in his memory may be made to Wounded Warrior Project or another Veteran's organization.

AZAPIAN--Asadur (Arturo) Elmassian, age 84, of New York City, passed away peacefully at home on March 5th, 2015 of natural causes. He was born in Montevideo, Uruguay. He was a graduate of the Escuela de Bellas Artes of Montevideo and came to NYC to continue his art studies. A painter, he also was a restaurateur, and owned the Peacock Caffe, the Greenwich Village landmark, until its closing in 1998. He is survived by his wife, Shelley, his daughter Jennifer, his brother Hagop Azapian, his sister Nuri Azapian de Ferrari and his nieces and nephews. He was a lover of classical music and his own work reflected his great knowledge and love of Renaissance art. His family and friends will remember his creativity and his playful sense of humor. Funeral services to be held at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, March 8th at 11:45am. Charitable Donations in his honor may be made to: The Armenian General Benevolent Fund and the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. 1/3

CAPRA--J. Donald "Don" MD. President Emeritus of the Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation, died February 24, 2015 at the age of 77. The cause of his death was a brain tumor, his wife said. He was born July 20, 1937 in Burlington, VT to Italian immigrants. He spent his youth in Barre, VT and went on to the University of Vermont in Burlington, earning a B.S. in 1959 and graduating from the UVM Medical School summa cum laude in 1963. His internship years were spent at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. His research career, which he began in Vermont with Dr. Thomas Tomasi, continued at the National Institutes of Health with Dr. Alan Peterkofsky. In 1967 he returned to NYC for a two year guest investigatorship with Dr. Henry Kunkel at the Rockefeller University. He then joined the first faculty of Mt. Sinai Medical School and continued there until 1974. At that time he joined the University of Texas Health Science Center in Dallas, TX as a full professor and then proceeded to do some of his most important work in antibody research, laying the foundation for the field of monoclonal antibody therapy in a number of human diseases. At age 60 he was asked to be the president of the Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation in Oklahoma City, OK, a non-profit medical research institution. He felt that this was the challenge of his lifetime, and during his nine year tenure he doubled the size of the institute and increased its NIH funding from $8 million to $27 million. For the last eight years of his life he consulted for universities and large and small pharmaceutical firms. In 1958 Don married Patricia Hollister, and they raised two sons. He was predeceased by his parents Mary DeMaio Capra and Richard Capra. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, his son Jay Capra, MD and wife Nancy of Abilene, TX, his son Tony Capra of Carrollton, TX, his grandson Donald Capra and wife Sally of Amarillo, TX, granddaughter Sarah Seltzer and husband Will and great-step grandson Cooper Seltzer of Fort Worth, TX, and by granddaughter Twig Capra of New York City. He is also survived by his sister Carolyn Sanderson of Sagamore, MA and his nieces Lisa Morgera of Shrewsbury, MA and Kathy Riedinger of Double Oak, TX. Don's research career was prodigious. He was Principal Investigator on 72 NIH grants and had 375 scientific publications, including chapters and books. He was a founding member and past president of the Henry Kunkel Society, was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, a member of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters, the Association of American Physicians, and of the American Society for Clinical Investigation, and served as an officer for the American Association of Immunologists. His love of science and teaching was only surpassed by his love of family and the Dallas Cowboys. A Celebration of Don's life will be held March 21, 2015 at the Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation at 2:00pm. All are welcome. A second celebration will be in Barre, VT at a time to be announced in late spring, where Don's ashes will be interred in Hope Cemetery. The family respectfully requests no flowers, but that donations be made to the Drs. Patricia H. & J. Donald Capra Scholarship Fund of the Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation, or to the educational institute of your choice. 1

NIVES--Fred. It is with great sadness that the Angellino family lost their friend, father and grandfather, Fred Nives on March 4, 2015. Mr. Nives was 94 years old. Like their "Grandpa Fred", James enjoys horse- back-riding and Nicholas is an avid skier. Annie and Jimmy Angellino cherish the many adventures, conversations and times that they shared. He will truly be missed and always be in our hearts. 1/3

SILVER--David. Passed peacefully on March 3, 2015 surrounded by his loving family and many friends. David was born on March 26, 1939. He grew up in Worcester, MA and attended Babson College. David was the founder and CEO of Regency Home Fashions. He was the driving force in the success of this privately held company from its creation in 1968 until his retirement in 1997. He also partnered with Jerry Dellafemina in the Red Horse Market in the early 90's. David was blessed with an extraordinarily generous spirit of giving and spent five years of tireless effort raising four million dollars to build the East Hampton RECcenter. David believed deeply in giving to the East Hampton community that brought him and his family so many years of joy. David, along with his wife Patricia, supported the college education of 11 East Hampton students through the PDS scholarship fund. They also donated several playgrounds in honor of their parents. Additionally, they were generous benefactors of the Ross School since its inception as well as the Chapin School in New York City. David had a boundless passion for life and was a lover of all things beautiful. He was curious about everything. There was never a dull moment in David's presence. After his retirement, he volunteered for many years with Learning Leaders of New York City mentoring and educating New York City public school children. David is survived by his loving wife of thirty years Patricia Walton Silver, his four children Michael, (Rebecca), Gabrielle, AiNhi, and Geige, as well as 10 grandchildren Johnny, Davis and Clint Silver, Maxwell, Wesley, Emma, MacKenzie and Raymond Morrison, Sen and Maia Horton. He was adored and beloved by his children and grandchildren all who surrounded him with love and laughter throughout his life and in his final days. A huge light has disappeared from our lives but his memories always bring smiles and laughter. Donations can be made to the "Y East Hampton RECenter, David Silver Fund." Service will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., on Friday, March 6, 11:30am. 1/3

COHN--Dr. Alice Ginott. Dr. Alice Ginott Cohn, a psychologist committed to nurturing empathetic communication, died on February 23, 2015 at her home in Manhattan, age 90. She had suffered a stroke three years earlier, which prevented her from expressing herself in any of the seven languages she spoke. A second stroke ended her life. Burial services and shiva were held privately. Alice was born in Presov, Czechoslovakia to Martin and Pearl Weinberger Grunfeld. Her adoring relationship with her father was a central part of her life, providing the foundation of love that enabled her to express love to others. She was saved from the Holocaust by her mother who, with the aid of a brother who had befriended a US Vice Consul in Prague and another who was already living in New Jersey, arranged for visas for the family to come to the US in November 1938. Had this not happened, she might have joined her Czech girlfriends who, as she later learned, were among the first to be gassed at Auschwitz. Arriving in America as a poor refugee "greener" during the Depression, Alice turned a hard life into a good life. Prevented from pursuing a career as a teacher of English literature at Montclair State Teachers College because of her accent, she transferred to Indiana University Bloomington on a scholarship, participated in the 1953 Kinsey Study, worked to desegregate Bloomington, and found her true calling in psychology. She received a Ph.D. in experimental psychology from the New School for Social Research in 1959. Alice had two daughters with her first husband, Arthur Lasker: Roz Lasker, a physician, and Mimi Kaough, an attorney. In 1969, she married Dr. Haim Ginott, a prominent child psychologist who she met at a yahrzeit memorial celebration for the Yiddish author Sholem Aleichem. The couple worked closely together until Ginott's death from cancer in 1973. In 1986 she married Theodore Cohn, a management consultant who she met in New Delhi at a professional conference. For 40 years, Alice maintained an active practice as a psychotherapist and world- wide lecturer, bringing knowledge, intuition, sensitivity, pragmatism and compassion to her work. She wrote a weekly column on parenting for King Features, published in 70 international newspapers. In 2003, with Dr. H. Wallace Goddard, she revised Ginott's classic, Between Parent and Child, which has sold 250,000 copies in 18 languages. Alice loved to ice skate, ski cross-country, dance, listen to music, and converse. After visiting Auschwitz in 1992, she and her husband established the Alice Field Cohn Chair in Yiddish Studies at Indiana University to foster the continuity of Yiddish. Alice wished to be memorialized in the form of gifts to the Borns Jewish Studies Program (Alice Field Cohn Chair in Yiddish Studies), Indiana University, Goodbody Hall 326, 1011 East 3rd Street, Bloomington, IN 47405. She is survived by her husband Theodore, two daughters, two grandchildren, three step-children and four step-grandchildren. 1/3

EGAN--Cardinal Edward M. Calvary Hospital mourns with great sadness the passing of the former Honorary Chairman of the Calvary Hospital Board, Edward Michael Cardinal Egan. Cardinal Egan was a steadfast advocate of Calvary's mission of palliative and end-of-life care, and his support sustained that mission throughout his tenure as Archbishop of New York. He shared his deep faith with our patients and their loved ones through his frequent visits to Calvary. Cardinal Egan served as a shepherd to all New Yorkers during the difficult days following 9/11, offering emotional and spiritual support at countless funeral Masses and memorial services. A firm leader, he ultimately ensured a strong future for the Archdiocese of New York. We will remain forever grateful for his guidance and wise counsel. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman, Calvary Hospital Carlos M. Hernandez, Chairman, Calvary Fund Frank A. Calamari, President & CEO, Calvary Hospital Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director, Calvary Hospital 1/3

LADERMAN--Ezra. New Haven CT. On Saturday night February 28th 2015, Professor Emeritus Ezra Laderman died at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Aimlee Laderman, and children Isaiah Laderman, Jacob Laderman, and Rachel Laderman, and grandchildren Lael Laderman LaRanger, Bezia Laderman, Irit Laderman, Ephraim Laderman, Shoshana Bar Asher, Ariel Donnette, Jason Donnette, and Sophia Laderman, and great-grandson Micha'El Bar Asher. Ezra was born in Brooklyn, New York, on June 29, 1924. The son of Polish immigrants, he began improvising at the piano at age four, and he began composing at age seven. He attended the Ethical Culture School, and then New York City's High School of Music and Art, where at the age of fifteen he performed his piano concerto with the school's orchestra. He served as a radio operator with the 69th Infantry Division during World War II from 1943 through 1946. While part of the army of occupation he wrote and conducted the "Leipzig Symphony". At Brooklyn College and Columbia University he worked with acclaimed composers Stefan Wolpe, Miriam Gideon and Otto Luening and Douglas S. Moore, graduating in 1952. He met Aimlee at the 116th St stop of the IRT, and married her the next year. He was Chairman of the American Music Center, Director of Music Programs at the National Endowment of the Arts in the Carter administration, and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, to which he was elected president from 2006-2009. Ezra served as Professor of Composition at Yale University from 1988 to his retirement last summer, July 1, 2014, and was Dean of the School of Music from 1989-1995. While raising his family, Ezra resided in Teaneck, New Jersey, and later moved with Aimlee to New Haven, Connecticut. Summers were spent in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, composing, playing tennis, attending scientific lectures, and relaxing with family and friends. Laderman's compositions reflect a fusion between tonally based materials and nontonal elements. In addition to operatic and symphonic works, Laderman also wrote numerous chamber music, concertos, string quartets, solo instrumental pieces, and vocal works. His works included twelve string quartets, eleven concertos, and eight symphonies; six dramatic oratorios, music for dance, seven operas, and music for two Academy Award-winning films. CBS TV commissioned numerous works. Ezra collaborated with authors Norman Rosten, Joe Darion, Archibald MacLeish, Earnest Kinoy, Robert Pinsky, and conductors Mistislav Rostropovich, Lawrence Leighton Smith, Alfredo Antonini, Sidney Harth, Sergiu Comissiona, Carlo Maria Giulini and others. He received commissions from the Philadelphia Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic, Gewandhaus Leipzig Orchester, Sao Paulo State Symphonic Orchestra, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the New York Woodwind Quintet, the National, Louisville, Dallas, Baltimore, Pittsburgh, Houston, CBS, RAI, Jerusalem and Chicago Symphonies and numerous other regional and national orchestras. He has written for such internationally renowned artists as Samuel Baron, Toby Appel, Leonard Arner, Eugene List, Erica Morini, Bernie Garfield, Peter Frankl, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Yo-Yo Ma, Ransom Wilson, Emanuel Ax, Elmar Oliveira, Frank Morelli, Jean Erdman, Jos Limn, David Shifrin, Aldo Parisot, Sherrill Milnes, Judith Raskin, the Beaux Arts Trio, and the Vermeer, Concord, Juilliard, Lenox, Alard, Colorado and Tokyo String Quartets, among others. His compositions can be heard on the New World, CRI and Albany labels. He is published by Oxford University Press, Presser and Schirmer. In the past year he has had many performances, among them Benjamin Verdery "On Vineyard Sound", Ole Akahoshi premiering "Partita for 'Cello Number Two", and he developed the oratorio "Voices" with poet Robert Pinsky. Committed to teaching, Laderman held positions at Sarah Lawrence College and the State University of New York at Binghamton before joining the composition faculty at Yale University. He held residencies at the Bennington Composers Conference, the American Academy in Rome, and at the Rockefeller Foundation at Bellagio. Among his numerous awards, Laderman received three Guggenheim Fellowships and the Prix de Rome. Ezra had a passion for life heard through his music and greatly appreciated by his family and many close friends. While he had many interests -he was an accomplished pianist, avid fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and dearly loved father and grandfather -the greatest passion of his life was his wife Aimlee, with whom he shared everything in a long and fulfilling life. Contributions may be made to the Yale School of Music for the Ezra Laderman Composition Prize. Yale School of Music, PO Box 208246, New Haven, CT. 1/3

Biles led from the start at the American Cup in Arlington, Tex., in her first competition since she took a second straight world all-around title last year.
Patrick, a former Massachusetts governor, is getting involved in Boston’s bid for the 2024 Summer Olympics.
Lavillenie of France won a fourth straight pole-vault title at the European Indoor Championships in Prague and cleared 6.04 meters in his second attempt to set the championship record.
Janine Weber scored in overtime to give the Blades a victory over the Montreal Stars in the Clarkson Cup women’s hockey championship game.
Brodeur, now working in the St. Louis Blues’ front office, participated in the Devils’ alumni game for members of the 1995 Stanley Cup-winning team.
The playoff-bound Islanders lost for the third time in four games while Florida stayed close to Boston in the battle for the second wild-card spot in the Eastern Conference.
Bargnani, who may not be in a Knicks uniform next season, has become the team’s go-to guy of late, but it wasn’t enough against the Pacers.

Holmes and Dustin Johnson had a hole in one on the par-3 fourth, but Holmes also strung together four consecutive birdies on the back nine to stay atop the Cadillac Championship leaderboard for the third straight round.

The president said he did not know until last week that Hillary Rodham Clinton was using private email while secretary of state, but said he was pleased that she was releasing the emails to be archived.

HAMMERSTEIN MATHIAS-- Alice. Our heartfelt sympathy to Melinda and Peter. Words alone cannot express our devotion to your wonderful mother and how privileged we are to have known her on such a personal level. We will always cherish her friendship. Lovingly, Gina, Lisa, Betty and Elizabeth 1/3
Silver--Joyce R. September 4, 1933, died March 5, 2015, the beloved wife of Fred Oser and mother to Shoshana Cook. Services, 10am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

EGAN--Edward Michael Cardinal The Board of Trustees, leadership and staff of ArchCare, the Continuing Care Community of the Archdiocese of New York, mourn the passing of His Eminence, Archbishop Emeritus Edward Cardinal Egan. From his service as a hospital chaplain in the early years of his priesthood, to his leadership and support of our diocesan healthcare ministry, known as ArchCare, during his tenure as Archbishop of New York, Cardinal Egan's compassion and advocacy for the needs and rights of the elderly, sick and vulnerable were unflagging. His spirit will live on in all of us individually as well as through the countless healthcare programs and facilities throughout the Archdiocese of New York that will forever bear the mark of his vision and grace. Francis J. Serbaroli Chairman of the Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. Vice Chairman Thomas O'Brien Vice Chairman Scott P. LaRue President and Chief Executive Officer
Hegemier--Janice. Age 41, died March 2, 2015. She is survived by her husband Marco Diaz and her two sons August (4) and Alexander (2). She loved travel, food, art, theater, and music.

EGAN--Edward Cardinal. The Board of Directors of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation is deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our esteemed member and cherished friend, Edward Cardinal Egan. A gifted and learned musician, the Cardinal loved opera and embraced those who performed it and produced it with great enthusiasm. We were privileged to have shared this part of his busy and accomplished life and we will miss his warm presence in all we do. May he rest in peace. Jeffrey Manocherian, Chairman Barry Tucker, President 1/3

HELLMAN--Jack, on March 6, 2015. Dear companion of Donna Lapkin. Loving father of Caryn, Mark and Nina, Jason and Jordan. Cherished grandfather of Avery, Lena, Owen and Lester. He was Chairman of the Board of Temco Facility Services for over 60 years. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Monday, March 9, 2015, 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Friars Foundation or the Icahn School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai. 1/3

NIVES--Fred. It is with deep sorrow that we note the passing of our dear cousin Fred Nives. He lived a truly inspirational life. We will miss him very much, but our memories of him will not be forgotten. Our condolences to his dear wife Donna and to the entire Nives family. The Erber & Sagiv Families 1/3

KEATING--Deirdre O'Brien Keating, of Plandome, NY on March 5, 2015. Beloved wife of Thomas, for 56 years, loving mother of Thomas and Amy and mother-in-law of Ann Marie. Grandmother of Colleen, Thomas and Kelly. Born December 4, 1934 in the Bronx to Mary Z. and Michael H. O'Brien. Sister of the late Enda Ryan and Francis Flannery. Graduated Marymount Manhattan College, Class of '56. Funeral Mass, Monday, March 9th at 12:30pm, St. Mary's Church, Manhasset with interment at Mt. St Mary's Cemetery, Flushing. Contributions would be welcome to the New York Foundling Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Thoracic Oncology Department. 1/3

NIVES--Fred. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Fred Nives, who along with his wife, Donna, was greatly committed to wildlife conservation and animal well-being. The generosity toward animals by Mr. and Mrs. Nives will be memorialized at the WCS Bronx Zoo's Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavilion. WCS was inspired by Mr. Nives's great love for horses, dogs, cats and all animals. The founding of the animal rescue group, Adopt-A-Dog, located in Greenwich, CT, and Armonk, NY, is a tremendous legacy to the couple's kindness and dedication to companion animals. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. 1/3

MANN--Peggy Lebair, died Tuesday at her home in Albany at age 94. A native of Woodmere, LI, she moved to Albany with her husband Jay D. Mann (deceased). She was the daughter of Harold Lebair, a longtime advertising executive for The New York Times. She was active in women's tennis, serving as the longtime coach of America's Marble Cup teams for women over 60. She also umpired at the U.S. Open for 50 years and at Wimbledon twice. She was an associate professor at SUNY Albany and coach of its tennis team for more than two decades. She is survived by her two sons James and Andrew Mann and by Karen Paxton, formerly the wife of Peggy's deceased son Ronald; and by her grandchildren Elizabeth, Ted, Jeffrey, Rebecca and Melissa Mann, and by Karen's children Rachel and Michael Paxton. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Planned Parenthood or to Equinox. 1/3
MAYSLES--Albert. Angel, hero, friend. There are no greater lessons than yours: to look, to listen and to love. Thank you, Al. Rachael Horovitz 1/3

KEANE--Mary Burdell. Born June 1st, 1931 in Columbus, OH, longtime resident of Gramercy Park. Died March 3, 2015 after a long illness, bravely fought. Deeply mourned by husband, Ted, children, Webb, Jennie and Metthea, and eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Graduate of Friends Seminary (1949) and Vassar College (1953). Taught at Friends Seminary for many years. Memorial service at a later date. 1/3

NIVES--Fred. March 4, 2015, 94 years old. Born Vienna Austria in 1921. Fred was a lover of life who lived every day to the fullest. This was not surprising for a man who in 1938, at the age of 17 in order to escape from the Nazis after Kristallnacht, walked from Austria at night hiding in the woods during the day to find refuge in Belgium. After immigrating to the U.S. in 1940, he proudly served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946 in the European Theater in Paris under General Eisenhower's command. He was reunited with his father Bernhard and brother Ernest at war's end, but his mother Roza perished in Auschwitz. Fred Nives was truly one of a kind. Larger than life, he was an avid sportsman with unstoppable energy. He relished his early ski adventures in Davos and then his chalet in Meribel, France. His love of athletics included tennis, swimming and his treadmill. He was a voracious reader, classical music concertgoer and opera lover, especially Wagner. In his youth, he piloted his plane from Paris all over Europe, and ran his boat along the French Riviera to the Greek Isles. As an accomplished horseman for 50 years, he and his beloved wife Donna rode in Hunter-Pace events. In events where he was not riding, Fred became an official timer at the finish lines. He was also the Treasurer of the Greenwich Riding and Trails Association. He was proud that the GRTA's budget was perfectly balanced while he was the treasurer. His wide circle of friends and family reveled in his contagious enthusiasm, keen intelligence and marvelous sense of humor. He graciously brought everybody together for many holidays and occasions. Always generously entertaining guests with his hilarious jokes, wonderful stories, choice bottles of wines and love of fine foods. He had a strong will, strong opinions and strong mind. A successful entrepreneur with a brilliant and decisive business mind, Mr. Nives started a foreign currency service business in the 1950's and then a consumer finance company which was sold in 1963 to become Sterling Bancorp in New York. An accomplished Wall Street investor with a seat on the New York Stock Exchange until 1969, he was a general partner in investment partnership Apollo Associates until 1974. He left Wall Street to start Omni Financial Corporation, a very successful consumer financial company, in the early 70's. He wanted to help military personnel obtain consumer loans because he remembered how difficult it was for him to obtain a loan to buy his first car after the war. But, the greatest accomplishment of his life was his marriage to his extraordinary and beautiful wife Donna. He met the love of his life at the age of 37 in New York City and they married shortly thereafter. They shared a love of animals, which became a big part of their life together. In addition to their equestrian activities, they founded the 30+ year old Animal Rescue Group "Adopt-A- Dog" located in Greenwich, CT and Armonk, NY. "Fred and Donna also generously funded the Bronx Zoo's "Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavillion" Their love of animals and each other was apparent to all their friends and family. Mr. Nives also was a longtime Board member of The Center for Hearing and Communication. Member of the Greenwich Riding & Trails Association, The Graduate Club of New Haven, The Stamford Yacht Club, Goldens Bridge Hounds, North Salem, New York and Fairfield County Hounds in Bridgewater, CT. Mr. Nives is survived by Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. Funeral services will be held Monday, March 9 at 1:30pm at Temple Sholom, Greenwich Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family requests any donations be made to Adopt A Dog, 849 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06831 or Center for Hearing and Communication, 50 Broadway, New York, NY 10004.

NIVES--Fred. You were the patriarch of our family. We will always remember our many happy times together, especially Thanksgiving and holiday celebrations with you and Aunt Donna. We will forever miss your exuberant presence and generous spirit. Julie Nives, Daniel Schwartzman, Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam Nives, Marisa Nives, Fanny Nives

PILLA--Robert A.,80, passed January 21, 2015. A kind, selfless and devoted father. Survived by three children and seven grandchildren. Villanova '56, career at Dean Witter. Memorial on March 14; 1pm Mahwah Sheraton.

GREENBERG--Reva M.,passed away at the age of 77 years at her apartment in Princeton, NJ on March 7, 2015. Born in 1937 in the Bronx to Lillian and Charles Messeloff, Reva attended George Washington High School and Vassar College, and received her Doctorate in Gerontology from Columbia University's Teacher's College. In 1959, she married Josh Greenberg and the couple raised their family in Scarsdale, New York where they resided for over 50 years. Reva had a career working for Westchester County's Office for the Aging. Her greatest achievement came after her diagnosis with Ovarian Cancer when she wrote the "Adventure's in CancerLand" and "A New Day and The Bird Sing" for her family and friends to enjoy. She is survived by her husband and three children, Betsy Ie of Princeton, New Jersey, Jim Greenberg of Weston, Massachusetts, and Annie Michaelson of Montgomery, New Jersey. She leaves eight loving grandchildren, Douglas, Andy, Hilary, Robbie, Tommy, Will, Kate, Zoe; also daughter-in- law Julie Greenberg and sons-in-law, Darma Ie and Gregg Michaelson and her many special friends. The service will be held on Monday, March 9, 2015 at 11:30am at her beloved Larchmont Temple and a burial will be held. John J. Fox Funeral Home of Larchmont is in charge of services. Visit their website at www.jjffh.com for details and to express a memory of Reva. The family has asked that donations be made to Larchmont Temples Social Action Fund. Reva and her family have many memories, some funny, some sad, some with angst, some with joy. The family is lucky to have a treasure box so full, and look forward to creating new memories that are sprinkled with a dash of Reva and her belief that everyone has a personal best. Thanks to Dr. William Tew and his amazing staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering, Dr. Jimmie Holland and Dr. David Bareli and the Princeton Care Center and to all the caring people who helped Reva over the past four years. 1/3

KROLL-GOFFNER-- Charlotte, died March 7, 2015 at 93. She was Owner and Director of Camp Na-Sho-Pa, a beautiful, innovative children's camp, created with her late husband Barney Kroll. She was lovely, elegant, always smiling, always a peacemaker; loving and affectionate, she brightened every room upon entering. Charlotte was married to Norman Goffner for 30 years and they were exceptionally devoted to one another. Charlotte was the beloved mother of Erik Kroll (Annette), Marilyn Minzer (Matthew), and Lili Chen, Grandmother of Laurel Steinberg (Russell), Brett Chen, Bonnie Tanguay (Jim), Glenn Kroll, Robert Goffner, Sarah Perret and Gabriel Perret and great- grandmother of Ryan Steinberg, Chelsea, Benjamin and Hailey Tanguay, and Brandon and Charles Kroll. Her extraordinary work ethic and love of life influenced everyone. Funeral services, March 9 at Baron Hirsch Cemetery in Staten Island. Shiva will be observed at her home. 1/3

MAYSLES--Albert. Albert Maysles said, "The real world is exactly what we need to better understand and therefore possibly to love one another." He made documentary films to make our world better. We admired his vision, his energy, his artistry, his generosity, his stories, and his smile. We send our love to his bountifully warm and creative family. Catherine Gund and Agnes Gund 1/3

HAMMERSTEIN MATHIAS-- Alice, the daughter of Oscar Hammerstein II and Myra Finn, died Thursday, February 26, at the age of 93. According to her daughter, Melinda Walsh, the cause was pneumonia. For many years, she was the Hammerstein family representative to The Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, and continued to be the spokeswoman for her father's work. With the insight of having seen the original production of "Show Boat" in 1927, she addressed the cast of the musicals New York Philharmonic concert performance last fall during rehearsals. As a young woman, she worked for her father doing research on specific subjects to support her father's lyrics, becoming immersed in the tradition of the New England clambake for the song "A Real Nice Clambake in Carousel." The material presented to her father often far exceeded what was necessary, something she attributed to what she termed "research poisoning". The recipient of several ASCAP Awards, she was the lyricist and co-author of "Babes In Toyland", an adaptation of the Victor Herbert Operetta, and she also wrote English lyrics to Franz Lehar's "The Merry Widow" and Johann Strauss' "A NightIn Venice", all of which were presented in the repertory of the Light Opera of Manhattan (LOOM). She was also associated with conductor Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society, for whom she translated lyrics of the American premiere of Richard Strauss' "Intermezzo" and adapted Mozart's "The Magic Flute" for presentation by puppets, both of which were performed at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. With her late husband Philip Mathias, she wrote and produced a musical Centennial tribute to Jerome Kern, "The Music Is Kern", in 1985, and was proud of having hired the then-unknown Susan Stroman to direct it. She enjoyed a lively correspondence with her father from 1928 until his death in 1960, and carefully saved the letters, which were warm, chatty, encouraging, and sometimes stern. Oscar treasured his daughter's precocious and painstakingly detailed notes and they were returned to her upon his death. Over the years, she worked on a book that included all the letters, which she titled, "From OH to AH." Her hope to publish the book was cut short by her death. She was a mainstay for family and friends, always knowing where she stood and wasn't afraid to say so, and what she said was worth listening to. We will miss her cockeyed optimistic view of the world and the future. Predeceased by her husband Philip Mathias in 2006, Alice Hammerstein Mathias is survived by her children, Melinda Walsh of Bedford Hills, New York and Peter Mathias of Monroe, Connecticut, a step-sister, Susan Blanchard of Roxbury, Connecticut, four grandchildren and two great- granddaughters. 1/3

MISHKIN--Grace, on March 7, 2015. Beloved wife of William. Devoted mother of Julia (Andrew Seear) and Ellen (Julie Hoffman). Also survived by nieces and nephews, David, Amy and Michael Starobin and Lauren and Peter Eulau. Donations in Grace's memory may be made to The Leukemia Society. 1/3

CLARKE--Griffith X.,72, of Sea Girt, passed away Thursday, March 5, 2015 at New York Presbyterian Hospital, Manhattan, NY. His life began on June 30, 1942, in Queens, NY. He was the only son of Thomas and Frances Clarke. Growing up in Jackson Heights, Griffith attended both St. Ann's Academy and Archbishop Molloy High School, graduating from the latter in 1959. In the summer of 1958, Griffith began his professional career working as a "runner" for Charles E. Quincey & Co. Throughout his years at Quincey, Griffith worked his way through operations and accounting before moving to the companys trading desk in 1964. There he worked his way up yet again, this time to a partnership that culminated in 1975. He became a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a primary dealer in U.S. Government Securities. During his successful years as a member of the NYSE, Griffith attended the evening division of the School of Commerce Accounts and Finance at New York University, from which he graduated in 1971 with a BA in economics. He distinguished himself at NYU by being admitted to the Honor Society of Economics, Omicron Delta Epsilon and Finance, and Phi Alpha Kappa before becoming an honorary inductee into Beta Gamma Sigma. Subsequently, he served on the Board of Overseers of the Stern School of Business at NYU. After his second graduation from the school in 1973, he completed a course of study at the Securities Industry Institute of the Securities Industry Association, which was held at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. His required paper was awarded third place honors. In January of 1979, Griffith founded his firm, G.X. Clarke & Company in New York City with his five partners. The company would later move to Jersey City, where he oversaw until his retirement in January of 2015. While Griffith accomplished so many amazing things within his professional career, he would always say his greatest accomplishment was his family. In 1977, Griffith married his love and life, Catherine Patricia Neilan. Together they raised their three children in Sea Girt, New Jersey and would later become blessed with six beautiful grandchildren. Griffith is survived by his devoted wife of 38 years Catherine. Their beloved children, Megan and Thomas Russoniello of Wall Township, Griffith Clarke of Sea Girt and Kara and Michael Matunas of Spring Lake Heights. He will be remembered as the most wonderful Pop by Lilly, James, Cole and Maya Russoniello and Reagan and Olivia Matunas. Relatives and friends are invited to call on Monday, March 9th from 4- 7pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall, NJ 07719. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Tuesday, March 10, 2015 at 9:30am at St. Mark's RC Church, 215 Crescent Parkway, Sea Girt, NJ 08750. Interment will be in St. Anne's Cemetery, Wall Township. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the Wounded Warrior Project, POAC (Parents of Autistic Children) Autism Services or the Food Bank of Monmouth County. For further information or to offer online condolences to the Clarke family, please visit: obrienfuneralhome.com. 1/3

KENT--Shirley Kent (born Breslof on November 3, 1921) died on Saturday, March 7, 2015 at 93. Shirley was married for 65 years to Mike Kent, her beloved husband, before his passing in 2008. Shirley will be missed by her son Gordon (and wife Maria) and her daughter Robin (and husband Jack), as well as her sister Rosalind, her five grandchildren, Mitchell, Darren, David, Eric and Andrea, and her two great-grandchildren, Evie and Zoe. Her children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren were her greatest joys in life. Shirley was known for being a great hostess and a friend to all of the family's youth and their friends. 1/3

KRAMER--Ruth Tantleff, 92, passed away March 7th with her family by her side at her home in South Orange, New Jersey. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, Julian Kramer; her children Dr. Sari Kramer and Orin (Hilary Ballon); and her grandchildren Sasha, Sophie and Charles. Raised in Brooklyn and a graduate of Rutgers University, she was a compassionate deep soul. Her life mission was her infinite love and non- judgmental devotion to her family. She now joins her daughter Joan, whose unspeakable loss in 1972 scarred her for life, and her adored parents, Sophie and Hyman. Funeral services at Bnai Abraham Park, 2600 Route 22 East, Union, New Jersey 11am, Monday, March 9th. 1/3

LADERMAN--Ezra. New Haven CT. On Saturday night February 28th 2015, Professor Emeritus Ezra Laderman died at age 90. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Aimlee Laderman, and children Isaiah Laderman, Jacob Laderman, and Rachel Laderman, and grandchildren Lael Laderman LaRanger, Bezia Laderman, Irit Laderman, Ephraim Laderman, Shoshana Bar Asher, Ariel Donnette, Jason Donnette, and Sophia Laderman, and great-grandson Micha'El Bar Asher. Ezra was born in Brooklyn, New York, on June 29, 1924. The son of Polish immigrants, he began improvising at the piano at age four, and he began composing at age seven. He attended the Ethical Culture School, and then New York City's High School of Music and Art, where at the age of fifteen he performed his piano concerto with the school's orchestra. He served as a radio operator with the 69th Infantry Division during World War II from 1943 through 1946. While part of the army of occupation he wrote and conducted the "Leipzig Symphony". At Brooklyn College and Columbia University he worked with acclaimed composers Stefan Wolpe, Miriam Gideon and Otto Luening and Douglas S. Moore, graduating in 1952. He met Aimlee at the 116th St stop of the IRT, and married her the next year. He was Chairman of the American Music Center, Director of Music Programs at the National Endowment of the Arts in the Carter administration, and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, to which he was elected president from 2006-2009. Ezra served as Professor of Composition at Yale University from 1988 to his retirement last summer, July 1, 2014, and was Dean of the School of Music from 1989-1995. While raising his family, Ezra resided in Teaneck, New Jersey, and later moved with Aimlee to New Haven, Connecticut. Summers were spent in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, composing, playing tennis, attending scientific lectures, and relaxing with family and friends. Laderman's compositions reflect a fusion between tonally based materials and nontonal elements. In addition to operatic and symphonic works, Laderman also wrote numerous chamber music, concertos, string quartets, solo instrumental pieces, and vocal works. His works included twelve string quartets, eleven concertos, and eight symphonies; six dramatic oratorios, music for dance, seven operas, and music for two Academy Award-winning films. CBS TV commissioned numerous works. Ezra collaborated with authors Norman Rosten, Joe Darion, Archibald MacLeish, Earnest Kinoy, Robert Pinsky, and conductors Mistislav Rostropovich, Lawrence Leighton Smith, Alfredo Antonini, Sidney Harth, Sergiu Comissiona, Carlo Maria Giulini and others. He received commissions from the Philadelphia Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic, Gewandhaus Leipzig Orchester, Sao Paulo State Symphonic Orchestra, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the New York Woodwind Quintet, the National, Louisville, Dallas, Baltimore, Pittsburgh, Houston, CBS, RAI, Jerusalem and Chicago Symphonies and numerous other regional and national orchestras. He has written for such internationally renowned artists as Samuel Baron, Toby Appel, Leonard Arner, Eugene List, Erica Morini, Bernie Garfield, Peter Frankl, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Yo-Yo Ma, Ransom Wilson, Emanuel Ax, Elmar Oliveira, Frank Morelli, Jean Erdman, Jos Limn, David Shifrin, Aldo Parisot, Sherrill Milnes, Judith Raskin, the Beaux Arts Trio, and the Vermeer, Concord, Juilliard, Lenox, Alard, Colorado and Tokyo String Quartets, among others. His compositions can be heard on the New World, CRI and Albany labels. He is published by Oxford University Press, Presser and Schirmer. In the past year he has had many performances, among them Benjamin Verdery "On Vineyard Sound", Ole Akahoshi premiering "Partita for 'Cello Number Two", and he developed the oratorio "Voices" with poet Robert Pinsky. Committed to teaching, Laderman held positions at Sarah Lawrence College and the State University of New York at Binghamton before joining the composition faculty at Yale University. He held residencies at the Bennington Composers Conference, the American Academy in Rome, and at the Rockefeller Foundation at Bellagio. Among his numerous awards, Laderman received three Guggenheim Fellowships and the Prix de Rome. Ezra had a passion for life heard through his music and greatly appreciated by his family and many close friends. While he had many interests -he was an accomplished pianist, avid fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and dearly loved father and grandfather -the greatest passion of his life was his wife Aimlee, with whom he shared everything in a long and fulfilling life. Contributions may be made to the Yale School of Music for the Ezra Laderman Composition Prize. Yale School of Music, PO Box 208246, New Haven, CT. 1/3

MAYSLES--Albert. A treasure beyond measure has been lost. Aldon James 1/3

NIVES--Fred. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Fred Nives, who along with his wife, Donna, was greatly committed to wildlife conservation and animal well-being. The generosity toward animals by Mr. and Mrs. Nives will be memorialized at the WCS Bronx Zoo's Fred and Donna Nives African Wild Dog Pavilion. WCS was inspired by Mr. Nives's great love for horses, dogs, cats and all animals. The founding of the animal rescue group, Adopt-A-Dog, located in Greenwich, CT, and Armonk, NY, is a tremendous legacy to the couple's kindness and dedication to companion animals. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Donna Nives, Julie Nives Schwartzman, Dan and Zoe Schwartzman, Miriam and Marissa Nives, Vivian and Richard Van Buren, Annie, Jimmy, James and Nicholas Angellino. 1/3

BOGIN--Heath, born July 6, 1977 died on March 8, 2015. Beloved husband of Lori, adored father of Audrey and Reese, perfect son of Jerome Bogin and Esther Bogin. Cherished brother of Andrew Bogin and Steven Bogin. 1/3

MAYSLES--Albert. Albert Maysles said, "The real world is exactly what we need to better understand and therefore possibly to love one another." He made documentary films to make our world better. We admired his vision, his energy, his artistry, his generosity, his stories, and his smile. We send our love to his bountifully warm and creative family. Catherine Gund and Agnes Gund 1/3
HOFFMAN--Charles H. 3/23/1938 -3/10/2005 Always in our hearts Hoffman/Lucey Families 1/3

FISCHLER--Edward. The Woodmere Club deeply regrets the passing of our good friend and longtime member, Edward Fischler. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family and friends. Board of Governors The Woodmere Club 1/3

LEWIN--Hanna, on March 7, 2015, in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Carl Heinz. Devoted mother of Judy Kossover (Jack) and Stanley. Dear sister of Ruth Knox. Service is Wednesday, March 11, at 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

SMOLER--Elsie Rubenstein, died in her sleep on March 7, 2015, a few weeks after turning 90. After graduating from Erasmus High and Adelphi College, Elsie worked at WNEW and Mademoiselle before marrying Irwin Smoler in 1950. For more than 50 years, the couple lived in Scarsdale where they raised their three children, Fred, Michael, and Arlene. In 1995, the Scarsdale Foundation awarded her the Scarsdale Bowl for service to the town, including presidency of the School Board. Services on March 10, 11am, at the Westchester Reform Temple. 1/3
Hegemier--Janice. Age 41, died March 2, 2015. She is survived by her husband Marco Diaz and her two sons August (4) and Alexander (2). She loved travel, food, art, theater, and music.
LAKHMAN--Margarita, May 11, 1946 -March 7, 2015. Survived by adoring husband Boris Lakhman and loving relatives and friends. Doting mother of the late Marina Lakhman. 1/3

KIER--Kathleen. Kathleen E. Kier (Hamm) (1935-2015). Lifelong of New York City raised in College Point by parents Kenneth and Catherine (Kerr) Kier. Earned BA (with highest honors) from Queens College; graduate degrees (M.A, M. Phil and Ph.D) from Columbia University. Served on faculty of English Department of Queens College, City University of New York (CUNY) more than 30 years until retirement 2010. Very popular professor, supported the College's Kay Kier Prize for an essay related to author Herman Melville. Author of two volume encyclopedia of names, places, historical references and other terminology from Melville's novels, dozens of scholarly articles on Melville and other literary matters. Love for Melville's work grew from vacations on Cape Cod, MA. and her love of her father, who served in the U.S. Navy and later proudly captained his own boat on Long Island Sound and the Hudson River. Ms. Kier was a staunch advocate for public higher education and devoted to her Alma Mater, Queens College. Awarded tenure at CUNY in 1990 after a protracted, contentious fight on her behalf by her union, the Professional Staff Congress. Taught at times at University of Paris; The State University of New York Maritime College; Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, NJ and Hudson County Community College. Ms. Kier was an enormous fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Mets, loved traveling and cherished days in Europe and the Middle East, loved dogs and cats, fond of the Opera at Lincoln Center. Preceded in death by her twin sisters, Virginia Neumar and Marie Stolz. Survived by four children from marriage to Thomas A. Hamm: David Hamm (Lynn) of Hampton, VA; Jane Hendricks (Allen) of Flemington, NJ; Peter Hamm (Judith Hedstrom) of Bethesda, MD; and Linda Hamm Grez (Joseph) of North Bend, WA; six grandchildren: Matthew and Rebecca Hendricks of Flemington, NJ; Paul Hamm of Virginia Beach, VA; Alec and Phoebe Hedstrom of Bethesda, MD; and Anna Grez of North Bend, WA. Services are private for details email the family at phammconsulting@gmail.com. 1/3
JONES--David L. March 10, 1953 -Jan. 26, 2014 Happy 62nd Birthday David! Celebrating with Joan, Lou and Pam. We miss you more than ever. All our love always, Danny & Bobby 1/3

KOCH--Lynn & Lizzie. Mommy I miss you. You are the best! The world is grieving. Lizzie you were cheated and your big brother misses you more than you would have ever known. I am lost without you both. With everlasting love, LJ 1/3

MIRZA--Muzzi. (3/2/58-3/10/07) Your inspiring spirit of love, humor, generosity, and accomplishment continue to fill us even after eight years without you. Your strong legacy is thriving through your family and the good being done in your name. We loved you immeasurably in life and that love will not diminish until we meet again. Sue, Alexander, Christina, and Sean And all your beloved family and friends 1/3

GAREY--Ira S. Irving Berlin had it right when he wrote: "I'll be loving you always." We think of you daily since one year ago, March 10, 2014 and will love you always. Carol, Matt, Josh, all your siblings, relatives and friends, coast to coast 1/3

KOPIT--Florence, on March 8, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Jerome. Loving aunt of Andrea Ornstein, Alexander Ornstein, Matthew Ornstein (Doris). Cherished great-aunt of Nikki, Paul and Joshua. Loved and treasured by her many friends and colleagues. 1/3

KENT--Shirley Kent (born Breslof on November 3, 1921) died on Saturday, March 7, 2015 at 93. Shirley was married for 65 years to Mike Kent, her beloved husband, before his passing in 2008. Shirley will be missed by her son Gordon (and wife Maria) and her daughter Robin (and husband Jack), as well as her sister Rosalind, her five grandchildren, Mitchell, Darren, David, Eric and Andrea, and her two great-grandchildren, Evie and Zoe. Her children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren were her greatest joys in life. Shirley was known for being a great hostess and a friend to all of the family's youth and their friends. 1/3

RICHARDS--Bernard, of Old Westbury, NY passed away March 9 at age 87, after a long struggle with Alzheimer's. Adored husband and dearest friend to wife Arlene for 66 years, he was a wonderful father to Carol (Steve Mermey), Patti and Lori, and grandfather to Jared and Sara. Born in Brownsville, Brooklyn, he attended PS 161 and DeWitt Clinton High School, served in the United States Navy, and graduated from Baruch College in 1949. Bernie was truly a self-made man. He started as an entry level accountant, and rose to become Chairman and CEO of Slattery Associates, which helped build some of New York's largest roads, bridges and tunnels. He was passionate about music, tennis, Napa Valley, the Yankees, and his Jewish heritage. He always lit up a room, made us laugh, loved us unconditionally and brought us great joy. Funeral services Wednesday, March 11th, 11am, at Temple Sinai, Roslyn Heights, NY. Contributions can be made to the Arlene and Bernard Richards Scholarship Fund at Baruch College or Planned Parenthood of Nassau County. 1/3

WALTZER--Selma Sterler, 90, passed way on March 8th. The beloved wife of the late Jack A. Waltzer for more than 50 years, she was the loving mother of Dr. Wayne C. Waltzer, Paul B. Waltzer, Lori W. Bernstein and Alice S. Cohen. She also leaves behind her nine adored and adoring grandchildren and her dear sister Lillian Falk. Known for her exceptional hospitality and culinary skills, she was also a graduate of C.W. Post College, a hospital volunteer, an accomplished painter and sculptor and she performed as a cast member of the Gilbert and Sullivan Light Opera Company of Long Island. Her ever present positivity, warmth and loving spirit will be greatly missed. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association. 1/3

WEINSTEIN--Ruth L. (nee Edelman) beloved mother Mark (Alice) and Janet, grandmother (Nara and Ben), aunt, passed away March 6. Dear wife to Reuben (deceased). We loved her deeply. Retired teacher, writer, leader in Hadassah and Na'amat. Funeral Wednesday at 12noon, Parkside Chapel, Rego Park. Memorial service To Be Determined in Pembroke Pines, FL. 1/3

BORGENICHT--Lillian Nacht, 97, passed away peacefully at home February 21, 2015. She was the beloved wife of the late Travis Borgenicht with whom she spent 50 years. They shared successful careers in the children's clothing industry as well as a lively social life centered at the Friars Club. Upon retirement, Lillian's creative skills were expressed in her beautiful sculptures and paintings. She mesmerized us with her colorful stories of New York City life in the early 20th century. She will be remembered for her wonderful sense of humor, exquisite style and fierce political opinions. Lillian is survived by her loving daughter Linda Rosen Schoenfeld, son-in-law Lester Schoenfeld, granddaughters Jennifer Gwen Schoenfeld and Dana Marisa Schoenfeld and sisters Rosalie Steier and Sylvia Luckom. We all will miss her dearly. 1/3

HELLER--Isaac. Isaac Heller, of Scotch Plains, NJ, passed away peacefully on Saturday, March 7, 2015 at age 88. He was the beloved husband of Helaine Heller for 61 years. Ike, as he was known, was father/father in law to Audrey and Jack Romberg, Laurie Kaufman, Hollie Heller and Ralph Joseph, Hillary and Luke Granfield. His legacy includes 10 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Mildred Galen and brother Paul Heller. The loss of his presence will also be felt by many nieces and nephews. Ike was a genuine American "rags to riches" story. After serving in the US Navy in World War II, he bought some army surplus radio parts, set up shop in the basement of his brother in law's store, and built the Remco Toy Company. Remco was one of the prominent toy manufacturers of the 1950's and 1960's. After leaving Remco in 1965, Ike began a second, even more successful business, Heller Industrial Parks. He served as chairman of the board and CEO until his death. While Ike was generous with many charities, providing scholarships to Jewish teens to study in Israel was particularly dear to his heart. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, March 11, 11:30am at Temple Emanu-El, 756 E. Broad St. Westfield, NJ. Services are being handled by Menorah Chapels at Millburn. For more information call Menorah Chapels, 908-964-1500 or visit: www.menorahchapelsat millburn.com 1/3

KEANE--Mary Burdell. Born June 1st, 1931 in Columbus, OH, longtime resident of Gramercy Park. Died March 3, 2015 after a long illness, bravely fought. Deeply mourned by husband, Ted, children, Webb, Jennie and Metthea, and eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Graduate of Friends Seminary (1949) and Vassar College (1953). Taught at Friends Seminary for many years. Memorial service at a later date. 1/3

MORRIS--Samuel, age 98, of Lake Hiawatha, NJ, formerly of Bronx, NY, passed away peacefully on Saturday, March 7, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Lilian Oberman Morris with whom he is now reunited. Devoted father of daughter, Karen Meyers and sons Craig, Kenneth and Jules Morris. Proud grandfather of Ross, Erica, David, Michael and Ilana and eight great-grandchildren. Samuel was born in New York City and attended New York University from where he received his JD shortly before World War II. He practiced civil and criminal law for many years. Before his retirement, Samuel became an Administrative Law Judge for the City of New York. Samuel loved sports, fishing and spending time with his children and grandchildren. He particularly enjoyed traveling and had many wonderful vacations at exotic locations all over the world with his wife, Lilian, and her brothers and their families. Services will be 1pm, Wednesday, March 11, 2015 at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Burial will follow at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ. 1/3

KRAMER--Ruth Tantleff, 92, passed away March 7th with her family by her side at her home in South Orange, New Jersey. She is survived by her husband of 72 years, Julian Kramer; her children Dr. Sari Kramer and Orin (Hilary Ballon); and her grandchildren Sasha, Sophie and Charles. Raised in Brooklyn and a graduate of Rutgers University, she was a compassionate deep soul. Her life mission was her infinite love and non- judgmental devotion to her family. She now joins her daughter Joan, whose unspeakable loss in 1972 scarred her for life, and her adored parents, Sophie and Hyman. Funeral services at Bnai Abraham Park, 2600 Route 22 East, Union, New Jersey 11am, Monday, March 9th. 1/3

FLANZER--Gloria. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend, board member and longtime benefactor, Mrs. Gloria Flanzer. Gloria, along with her beloved late husband Louis, contributed profoundly to our Hospital for more than 30 years, enabling the establishment of the Flanzer Pavilion, Flanzer Institute and the Flanzer Center for Emergencies and Critical Care. Gloria's endearing nature and vivacious spirit will be greatly missed, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board Jon B. Schandler, CEO Susan Fox, President 1/3

MARSH--Lee. Born December 2, 1918, died March 7, 2015. Lee Marsh, founder of Marsh Electric Co. in Berkeley, community leader, beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, died on March 7th at the age of 96 in Berkeley. Born in Brooklyn to Russian Jewish immigrant parents, Lee won the Latin medal at Boys High in Brooklyn and a Regents full scholarship to Cornell University. Lee's children and grandchildren like to brag about memorable experiences from his youth, including hitchhiking across the country with Pete Seeger and being invited by Eleanor Roosevelt to join her for a concert at Carnegie Hall. Lee was drafted into the Army in October 1941 and became a commissioned officer. He was sent to Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to study radar. His work served to improve a pilots ability to avoid enemy fire, for which he was awarded the Bronze Star. After the war, he met Dorothy, who was to be his life long companion. They were married in April 1946. Dorothy and Lee moved to Detroit in 1948. While in Detroit their daughters, Julie and Robin, were born. Lee learned the electricians trade and became an electrical contractor, while Dorothy pursued a Masters in Social Work. The family moved to Berkeley in 1961, where Lee founded Marsh Electric Co., a successful electrical contracting company, a union shop. Lee became a Bay Area leader in developing opportunities for minority contractors in the construction industry. Lee was the first President of the Jewish Community Center East Bay in the early 1980s and he and Dorothy have continued their support of the JCC East Bay since that time. Active in civic affairs, Lee served on the Berkeley Waterfront and Berkeley Planning City Commissions. An avid tennis player and lover of opera and literature, Lee stayed in good health well into his 90s. Moderation in all things, including moderation" he would say. He is survived by Dorothy, his wife of 68 years, daughters Julie and Robin, granddaughters Rebecca, Lily, Michelle and Roxanne, and his sister Laurel in New York. A celebration of Lees life will be held at the Jewish Community Center East Bay in late April. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the JCC East Bay or to an organization that supports social justice and equality. 1/3

CORDAY--Michael (Sheldon) December 4, 1930 - March 8, 2015. Brilliant, opinionated, loyal and determined. A Man of Letters; of Art, Music and Life. A fierce combatant to the end. Deeply loved, mourned and missed by his devoted wife Elizabeth and his many friends. 1/3

RICHARDS--Bernard. We have lost a dear friend of many years. We will miss all the wonderful moments and experiences we shared together. Our thoughts and condolences go to Arlene and family. We all loved Bernie, a very special person. The Kay Family The Goldsmith Family The Werfel Family 1/3

RICHARDS--Bernard K. It is with sorrow that the Baruch College community mourns the passing of Bernard Richards '49. Richards' commitment to the College included service as President of the Board of Trustees of the Baruch College Fund. Since 2002, he has been a Trustee Emeritus. In thanks, Baruch honored him as a Wood Fellow and twice as Outstanding Alumnus of the Year. Richards met his wife of 66 years, Arlene (class of '50), in the stairwell of the College's Field Building at 17 Lexington Ave. In 2009, Mr. and Mrs. Richards were recognized with the Annie and Bernard Baruch Couples Award. Together, they endowed scholarships and lecture series and named a classroom, among other initiatives. Their generosity daily impacts and inspires our students. We extend our deepest sympathy to Bernard Richards's wife, Arlene, his children and grandchildren, and to his many friends and admirers. Mitchel B. Wallerstein, President, Baruch College, Joel J. Cohen '59, President, The Baruch College Fund 1/3

SHEPARD--Irving A.,The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of our very dear friend, Irving A. Shepard of St. Louis. A dedicated and prominent leader of the American Technion Society (ATS) for decades, Mr. Shepard understood technology's vital role in Israel's future early on. He co-founded the ATS St. Louis Chapter and went on to serve nationally as the ATS President and Chairman of the Board. He was also a member of the Technion International Board of Governors. An engineer, long-time pilot, CEO and management consultant, he supported many Technion projects, including the St. Louis Region High Performance Parallel Computer, the Turbo Jet Engineering Laboratory, the St. Louis Advanced Aerodynamics Research Center, and student fellowships (including the Irving A. Shepard Endowed Doctoral Fellowship) and faculty recruitment. Together with his late wife Sue he was a Technion Guardian, having reached the highest level of support. Mr. Shepard was awarded the Albert Einstein Award, the highest ATS honor, as well as an Honorary Fellowship and Honorary Doctorate from the Technion. We extend our deepest condolences to sons Michael, Dr. David, and Andrew Shepard, and the entire Shepard family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

SELDIN--Doris Koteen, a clinical psychologist, professionally known as Dr. Doris K. Miller, died Sunday March 8, 2015 at the age of 93. A Memorial Service in her memory is being planned at The Quadrangle, Haverford, PA. for May of this year. McConaghy F.H., Ardmore, PA mcconaghfuneralhome.com 1/3

CLARK--Leonard (March 11, 1927 - September 15, 2014) Successful musician, entrepreneur, golfer, investor. Devoted husband and family man, Lenny did it his way. He lived life on his own terms, with a keen sense of style and class. Always looking toward the future. Lenny made life happen. On this, his 88th birthday, we celebrate his life and his great accomplishments. And we look ahead toward the future to instill a bit of his great success and wisdom in all of us. Always in our hearts - June, family & all of those that you loved 1/3

FLATOW--Eugenia Mortlock. Age 93, of New York City, passed away at home on March 5th, 2015. Born in the Bronx, she was raised along with her brother Larry Mortlock, in Bronxville, NY. Beloved wife of Professor Paul Flatow and loving mother of Susan Weeks Jackson, Dr. Evan Flatow and Jonathan Flatow, she was grandmother to 10 and great-grandmother to 11. After graduating from the College of New Rochelle, she received an M.S. in Industrial Engineering at Columbia University. She held various public offices and served as management consultant, business proprietor, and citizen advocate in the areas of public housing, waterfront and environmental issues. Ms. Flatow was active in local politics, serving as chair of Community Planning Board #

WEBB--Nola Poynton, age 91, on February 20, 2015, in New York, NY. Loving mother of Nell Kleinschmidt (Robert W.) and Winfield A. Foreman III, and grandmother of Lucy Kleinschmidt, all of New York City. The service is April 11th. LERNER--Jack, 95, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away in his home surrounded by his family on Monday, March 9, 2015. He was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY where he married his wife of 65 years, the late Gertrude Lerner. Jack was the founder of the Lerner Parking Systems of New York. He became a legend in the parking industry as his company grew and developed. He was very innovative in the evolution of urban parking business and parking structures. He is survived by his son William (Marcella) Lerner and daughter Wendy Ull, grandchildren Benjamin and Jacqui Lerner, and Richard, Jeffrey and Jennifer Ull. He will be forever remembered for his dedication and love to his family. He will be laid to rest next to his wife on Wednesday, March 11, at 11am at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Glick Family Funeral Home is in charge of services. 1/3

VARLOTTA--Gerard Anthony, of Great Neck, New York, died February 27, 2015 at age 87. Mr. Varlotta was born in lower Manhattan, attended St. Joseph's Parochial School and Stuyvesant High School. He served in the United States Navy and earned a degree in Civil Engineering from New York University. Mr. Varlotta was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship and studied engineering in Europe. He went on to earn his New York State Professional Engineering License and worked for the New York City Department of Water Supply prior to becoming a partner in Clem Construction Corporation. In 1960 he established GDL Construction Corp., then Varlotta Construction Corp., specializing is surface and subsurface construction. After retiring in 1992, he continued to consult for the construction industry. Highlights of Jerry's work included work on the Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands; introduced new technology to New York for repair of water mains that developed into Insutiform Metropolitan; installation of the water mains for the World Trade Center; underground utilities, infrastructure, street and sidewalks for the World Finical Center in Battery Park City; emergency water main repairs for the City of New York for almost 20 years.; and cleanup after the 9/11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. Jerry was a loving husband, father and grandfather. He will be remembered as a fair and compassionate human being who has left behind a lasting legacy of many loving friends, former employees and business associates. Jerry is survived by his wife of 58 years., Isabel, his children, Gerard Jr. (Angela), David (Barbara), Laurie (Thomas) and Lynda (Vincent), and grandchildren Michele, Richard, Kristen, Carolyn, Caroline, Christopher, Stephen, and Geena. He will be sorely missed. A private wake will be held at Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset, on March 12, 2015 with services on March 13, 2015 at St. Aloysius RC Church in Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the following charities: Garden of Dreams Foundation and Boomer Esiason Foundation for Cystic Fibrosis. 1/3

BRAMWELL--Elizabeth R. Elizabeth R. Bramwell, 74, Wall Street pioneer, devoted wife and mother, fierce competitor to the end. A native New Yorker and daughter of a church organist, she was graduated from Bryn Mawr in 1962, where she was captain of the field hockey team, and Columbia Business School in 1967. She thereafter embarked on a celebrated career as a Wall Street equity analyst. Her 1974 William D. Witter report on Walt Disney predicted earnings per share down to the cent. In 1987, she started the Gabelli Growth Fund, one of the top-performing mutual funds of its era, and, in 1994, founded Bramwell Capital Management. She was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, The Economic Club of New York, the Cosmopolitan Club, the Women's National Republican Club, Colonial Dames of America, The National Society of Colonial Dames, The Hillsboro Club, The Quogue Field Club, and The Badminton Club of the City of New York. She is survived by her husband, William M. Bramwell, Jr., her two children, Austin W. Bramwell and Hilary F. Bramwell, her grandchildren, William P. Bramwell and Eva v. A. Bramwell, her brother, Robert C. Reed, three half sisters, Analise Reed, Kari Reed, and Kirstin Reed, and her step-mother, Joanne Reed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Elizabeth R. Bramwell scholarship fund at Columbia Business School. A memorial service will be held at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on May 7 at 2 pm. 1/3

GALDAU--Alexandru A.,of Mt. Vernon on March 7, 2015. Beloved husband of Adriana A. Galdau, loving father of Andrew F. Galdau and grandfather of Jason A Galdau. FLANZER--Gloria Milstein. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Gloria Milstein Flanzer. Gloria was a wonderful person who cared deeply about other people, their families and their problems. Gloria was always concerned about her family and friends and was quick to lend a generous hand to those in need. She gave generously to her many charities and created many important institutions that will advance health care and social progress for generations to come. She gave good advice freely, and took great pleasure in the progress, health and happiness of her family and friends. A no-nonsense woman, Gloria tackled problems and adversity fearlessly. Her devotion to her late husband Lou was legendary. Gloria and Lou Flanzer were a team that couldn't be beat and we grieve their loss. Our deepest sympathies to the Flanzer and Milstein Families and all who loved her. Marcia & Eric Kaplan 1/3

FLANZER--Gloria Milstein May 23, 1927-March 9, 2015, died peacefully at home in Longboat Key, Florida on March 9, 2015 after a very brief illness. She was the loving daughter of the late Morris and Rose Milstein, a devoted sister to her brothers Seymour and Paul Milstein and, most of all, the beloved wife of Louis Flanzer, her husband of 66 years who predeceased her in 2013. Gloria's love for Lou was boundless - they were inseparable until his passing. Gloria lovingly supervised Lou's care during his illness. They traveled the world together, enjoying the experiences of learning about new cultures and making friends all over the globe. Besides her steadfast love and devotion to Lou, Gloria was a committed philanthropist, endowing many facilities in health care, social services and the arts. The Milstein Hospital Building, the Flanzer Cardiac Care Center, the Flanzer Eye Center, the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Vision Center at New York Presbyterian Hospital, the Flanzer Pavilion and the Flanzer Center for Emergency and Critical Care at White Plains Hospital and the recently dedicated Gloria And Louis Flanzer Campus of the Jewish Family and Children's Service of the Suncoast in Sarasota are just a few of Gloria's commitments to helping others of any faith or culture. She was generous to family and friends and was considered to be a great lady by all who knew and loved her. She will be deeply missed. Services will be private. 1/3
