ZAGOR--Howard S.,Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Howard Zagor, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President 1/3

WEISS--Mary Jane. Formerly of Garden City & Westhampton, NY passed away suddenly March 10, 2015 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in NY, NY on January 9, 1935. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Carl Weiss, her three children, their spouses and 8 grandchildren.

ZAGOR--Howard S. Beloved husband of the late Beverly Zagor, father of Stephen and Patricia Moger, grandfather of Max, passed peacefully on March 11, 2015. Born on October 21, 1919 he was a former resident of Norwich, VT and New York City, a graduate of Columbia Grammar and Dartmouth College, a recipient of the Bronze Star for his service in World War II, a past officer and current member of The Harmonie Club and president of Marcel Rochas US and later of Stricker and Zagor, Inc. Private services will be held for the family. 1/3

BREGSTEIN--John P.,of Scarsdale, NY, passed away quietly and at peace at age 87. Deeply loved by his devoted wife, Lois; his daughters and their families; Susan, Mark, Rebecca and Morgan Hembarsky and Linda, Elliot, David, and Adam Scherr; and by his sister and brother-in-law, Alice and Steve Haas. John was a partner at Mr. Witt, Inc., a specialty men's shirt manufacturer in New York City. A respected businessman, exceptional friend, loving parent and grandparent. The family will be at home Saturday and Sunday, March 14 and 15 from 2-7pm. Donations in John's memory may be sent to the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase, NY 10577. 1/3

HELLER--Isaac. The Brooklyn Tech Alumni Foundation mourns the loss of our friend and patron Isaac Heller, class of '43. Mr. Heller famously said "Brooklyn Tech made my life " when in effect, he made life at Brooklyn Tech a better place for all through his generosity and kindness. We extend our condolences to the Heller family.

ALPERIN--Morton passed March 3, 2012, age 88. Predeceased by wife, Anita. He leaves three children, Peggy Gerber (David), Alice Shaps (Moshe) and Fred (Iris); survived by 15 grandchildren, a brother Lee and good friend Sylvia. Morton joined the Navy at age 17 during World War II serving as a Corpsman and later a Pharmacist mate at Portsmouth Naval Hospital, VA where he cared for severely injured War causalities and civilian emergencies. After discharge he began a career in retail pharmacology when prescription compounding was the only way to provide medicine for the ill. Morton will be remembered as a gentle, kindly man loved by all who knew him. 1/3
SCHER--Doris. Beloved wife of Melvin I Scher, mother, grandmother, friend, teacher, born 28 April 1925, died 10 March 2015. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Friday, 2:15 pm.
BERNSTEIN--Marvin H.,age 88, died on March 5, 2015. He will be deeply missed by his loving wife Trudy, loyal brothers, and adoring children and grandchildren. 1/3
KING--William. We mourn the loss of William King, 1997 recipient of Guild Hall's Academy of the Arts Lifetime Achievement Award for Visual Arts. The Guild Hall Board of Trustees 1/3

NARYSHKIN--George, MD. The Tolstoy Foundation Rehabilitation and Nursing Center in Valley Cottage, NY mourns the passing of its long-time Vice Chairman George Naryshkin, MD on February 27, 2015 and extends its deepest sympathy to his loving wife Vera, his daughter Sonya Naryshkin, MD, his sons George F. Naryshkin, DDS DMD, Gregory Naryshkin, DMD and their families. Andrew Kotchoubey, PhD, Chairman; Cyril E. Geancintov, PhD, Treasurer; Gregory Kostura, Member of the Board; Don W. Lundquist, Secretary; Dorothy Corbett, LHNA, Administrator/Acting CEO 1/3

AUERBACH--Augusta, died at home on March 6, 2015, survived by her sons Howard (Mickey) and Richard, daughter-in-law, Andrea and beloved granddaughter, Joy. She was predeceased by her dear husband of 67 years, Philip. She was a graduate of Brooklyn College and Queens College, and was a successful teacher of reading. The family requests that donations, in any, be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

FLANZER--Gloria Milstein May 23, 1927-March 9, 2015, died peacefully at home in Longboat Key, Florida on March 9, 2015 after a very brief illness. She was the loving daughter of the late Morris and Rose Milstein, a devoted sister to her brothers Seymour and Paul Milstein and, most of all, the beloved wife of Louis Flanzer, her husband of 66 years who predeceased her in 2013. Gloria's love for Lou was boundless - they were inseparable until his passing. Gloria lovingly supervised Lou's care during his illness. They traveled the world together, enjoying the experiences of learning about new cultures and making friends all over the globe. Besides her steadfast love and devotion to Lou, Gloria was a committed philanthropist, endowing many facilities in health care, social services and the arts. The Milstein Hospital Building, the Flanzer Cardiac Care Center, the Flanzer Eye Center, the Gloria and Louis Flanzer Vision Center at New York Presbyterian Hospital, the Flanzer Pavilion and the Flanzer Center for Emergency and Critical Care at White Plains Hospital and the recently dedicated Gloria And Louis Flanzer Campus of the Jewish Family and Children's Service of the Suncoast in Sarasota are just a few of Gloria's commitments to helping others of any faith or culture. She was generous to family and friends and was considered to be a great lady by all who knew and loved her. She will be deeply missed. Services will be private. 1/3

GALDAU--Alexandru A.,of Mt. Vernon on March 7, 2015. Beloved husband of Adriana A. Galdau, loving father of Andrew F. Galdau and grandfather of Jason A Galdau. Alex had a long successful career as a builder in New York City. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville on Friday, March 13 between the hours of 10:30am to 12pm. Funeral Services will take place at the Funeral Home immediately following at 12pm. 1/3

APPELBAUM--Ann, MD. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Funeral services private; memorial to be announced. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director, CU Psychoanalytic Center Marvin D. Wasserman, M.D., President, APM

GREEF--Charles Edwin "Stormy" widely regarded as one of the preeminent attorneys for community bankers in the country, lost his fierce fight against cancer on March 10, 2015 at home. He worked until the week before he died. He was beloved by clients and friends in the banking industry for 40 years. Stormy was a loyal partner and co-head of the Financial Institutions Corporate and Regulatory Team at Hunton & Williams in Dallas. He spoke regularly to the Independent Community Bankers of America and the Independent Bankers Association of Texas (IBAT). He sat on the IBAT Education Foundation Board of Directors and is the only lawyer ever selected to the IBAT "Wall of Fame" in Austin. Stormy mentored many young lawyers who credit their legal careers to his tutelage. He was born January 16, 1949 in Amarillo, TX in the middle of one of the largest blizzards ever recorded in the Midwest and promptly nicknamed "Stormy" by the hospital nurses. He graduated in 1967 from Tascosa High School in Amarillo where he played for the varsity golf team and attained the distinction of National Merit Scholar. Stormy flew to New Haven to begin his freshman year at Yale University, sight-unseen, from which he obtained his AB in Political Science in 1971. He served in the United States Naval Reserve 1971-79 as a Lt. J.G. in the Judge Advocate General's Corps. Stormy received his J.D. with Honors in 1974 from The University of Texas School of Law where he served as Associate Editor of Texas Law Review. His legal career began at Hunton & Williams in Richmond, VA. He returned to Texas to join Kendrick, Kendrick and Bradley and began to build a specialized practice in community banking. The firm merged with Jenkens & Gilchrist in 1976 and became the Dallas-based office of Hunton and Williams in 2007. Underneath his unassuming demeanor and pronounced West Texas accent was a creative genius with a brilliant legal mind. Stormy served his clients with unmatched dedication. He loved baseball, especially the Houston Astros, and coached his children's and wife's teams. His long-time love of Northeastern New Mexico began with summers at Philmont Scout Ranch in Cimarron. He and Holly enjoyed entertaining family and friends at their home in Taos. He loved to discuss current events and seldom missed the Wednesday "Steak Night" political debates at Lakewood Country Club with his buddies. He faithfully ushered for 25 years at St. Matthews Cathedral and advised the Cathedral's Endowment Fund. Stormy is survived by his wife of 35 years, Holly; daughter Brennan Blair (Michael) and grandchildren Lucy, Jack, Hank and Charlie Blair; son David; father-in-law Bill Huber; in-laws Hilda and Jimmy Brewer and Hugh and Dana Huber; nephew Matthew Brewer; niece Ashley Huber; many Brennanergin cousins in Chicago as well as Kilkenny and Tipperary counties in Ireland, including Denis, Eilis, Mairin and Geraldine; and step-sisters Nancy, Carol and Gara. The family would like to thank Pat Dials, his executive assistant of 38 years, as well as everyone at Hunton & Williams. Stormy will also be sorely missed by his beloved dog Ace. The family respectfully requests no flowers but that donations be made to: IBAT Education Foundation, 1700 Rio Grande, Suite 100, Austin TX 78701; The University of Texas School of Law, 727 East Dean Keeton Street, Austin, TX 78705 (indicate in memory of Charles Greef); the Capital Campaign at the Cathedral Church of St. Matthew or to Aberg Center for Literacy. Services are set for 2pm on Saturday, March 14 at The Cathedral Church of St. Matthew, 5100 Ross Avenue in Dallas. Reception and family visitation will follow in the Great Hall. 1/3

SWERSEY--Burt L.,of Stephentown, N.Y., age 78, died unexpectedly on March 9. An inventor, entrepreneur, farmer, teacher and dreamer, he believed in the power of engineering to improve the world. He attended Bronx Science and Cornell and founded four medical technology companies and a plant nursery. He taught for 23 years at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute where his Inventors Studio course fostered creativity and innovation and spawned numerous successful companies. In 2009 it was named one of the best entrepreneurship courses in America. His latest course How to Save the World emphasized creative solutions to important problems. In addition to his wife Alice and brother Arthur, he is survived by a son, William, daughters Sarah and Rachel, and six grandchildren, to whom he was utterly devoted. 1/3

GOLDFARB--Morton, MD, a long-time urologist in Massapequa and former president of the Nassau County Medical Society, died March 11, 2015, in Boynton Beach, Florida, at the age of 88. He was born on June 5, 1926, in the Bronx to Frank and Mona Goldfarb. After completing his education at MIT and New York Medical College he served as a Lt. in the U.S. Navy. Dr. Goldfarb did his residency at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Baltimore, MD where he met his wife of 60 years, Dorothy Jean Johnston, who predeceased him. The couple raised a family in Massapequa before moving to East Hampton. Dr. Goldfarb is survived by Dr. Steven Goldfarb (Marilyn) of Laurel, M.D., Dr. David Goldfarb (Beth) of Cleveland, OH, Susan Ross (Matthew) of Scarsdale, NY, and Dr. Amy Goldfarb (Lisa) of Providence, RI. He leaves eight grandchildren: Maggie, Sara, Melissa, Jacob, Henry, Adam, Thomas and Rebecca. A gathering of family and friends will be held Sunday, March 15, from 2-5pm at the home of Susan Ross, 5 Barker Lane, Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made in his name to the Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation Inc. at hpbcf.org or the American Cancer Society at: cancer.org. 1/3

GREEF--Charles Edwin "Stormy" widely regarded as one of the preeminent attorneys for community bankers in the country, lost his fierce fight against cancer on March 10, 2015 at home. He worked until the week before he died. He was beloved by clients and friends in the banking industry for 40 years. Stormy was a loyal partner and co-head of the Financial Institutions Corporate and Regulatory Team at Hunton & Williams in Dallas. He spoke regularly to the Independent Community Bankers of America and the Independent Bankers Association of Texas (IBAT). He sat on the IBAT Education Foundation Board of Directors and is the only lawyer ever selected to the IBAT "Wall of Fame" in Austin. Stormy mentored many young lawyers who credit their legal careers to his tutelage. He was born January 16, 1949 in Amarillo, TX in the middle of one of the largest blizzards ever recorded in the Midwest and promptly nicknamed "Stormy" by the hospital nurses. He graduated in 1967 from Tascosa High School in Amarillo where he played for the varsity golf team and attained the distinction of National Merit Scholar. Stormy flew to New Haven to begin his freshman year at Yale University, sight-unseen, from which he obtained his AB in Political Science in 1971. He served in the United States Naval Reserve 1971-79 as a Lt. J.G. in the Judge Advocate General's Corps. Stormy received his J.D. with Honors in 1974 from The University of Texas School of Law where he served as Associate Editor of Texas Law Review. His legal career began at Hunton & Williams in Richmond, VA. He returned to Texas to join Kendrick, Kendrick and Bradley and began to build a specialized practice in community banking. The firm merged with Jenkens & Gilchrist in 1976 and became the Dallas-based office of Hunton and Williams in 2007. Underneath his unassuming demeanor and pronounced West Texas accent was a creative genius with a brilliant legal mind. Stormy served his clients with unmatched dedication. He loved baseball, especially the Houston Astros, and coached his children's and wife's teams. His long-time love of Northeastern New Mexico began with summers at Philmont Scout Ranch in Cimarron. He and Holly enjoyed entertaining family and friends at their home in Taos. He loved to discuss current events and seldom missed the Wednesday "Steak Night" political debates at Lakewood Country Club with his buddies. He faithfully ushered for 25 years at St. Matthews Cathedral and advised the Cathedral's Endowment Fund. Stormy is survived by his wife of 35 years, Holly; daughter Brennan Blair (Michael) and grandchildren Lucy, Jack, Hank and Charlie Blair; son David; father-in-law Bill Huber; in-laws Hilda and Jimmy Brewer and Hugh and Dana Huber; nephew Matthew Brewer; niece Ashley Huber; many Brennanergin cousins in Chicago as well as Kilkenny and Tipperary counties in Ireland, including Denis, Eilis, Mairin and Geraldine; and step-sisters Nancy, Carol and Gara. The family would like to thank Pat Dials, his executive assistant of 38 years, as well as everyone at Hunton & Williams. Stormy will also be sorely missed by his beloved dog Ace. The family respectfully requests no flowers but that donations be made to: IBAT Education Foundation, 1700 Rio Grande, Suite 100, Austin TX 78701; The University of Texas School of Law, 727 East Dean Keeton Street, Austin, TX 78705 (indicate in memory of Charles Greef); the Capital Campaign at the Cathedral Church of St. Matthew or to Aberg Center for Literacy. Services are set for 2pm on Saturday, March 14 at The Cathedral Church of St. Matthew, 5100 Ross Avenue in Dallas. Reception and family visitation will follow in the Great Hall. 1/3

BIRDOFF--Harvey. A wonderful man, who will be greatly missed. Goodbye dear friend. Joan and Bob. 1/3

KING--William. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, whose immense, long-legged sculptures and small portraits in wood or ceramics charm us all. 1/3

ISELIN--Lily Gantz, 85, died peacefully on March 9, 2015. Most loving and devoted mother to daughters Julie (Tony Turjoman), Diane, and Jenny; dear sister of Norma G. Sachs; loving and fun Nanny to Rachel Litt, Tess Chapin and Moses Chapin. Predeceased by her husband Herbert (April 8, 2013). A graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design (1951), Lily was creative from childhood, and excelled at every artistic medium from sculpture to painting to quilt-making. A voracious reader, talented cook, and unbeatable Scrabble player, Lily shared these passions with her family, instilling her belief that reading opened new worlds to anyone willing to step into books. Her eye for beauty taught her family to see all that is lovely in the world. As little girls, we loved to watch her get dressed for an evening out with Dad, which always included a splash of L'Air du Temps. We loved her, appreciated her, always looked forward to her company, and will miss her more than words can say. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: RISD Annual Fund, 2 College Street, Providence, RI 02903. Please note that your gift is "in memory of Lily G. Iselin." 1/3

SALMANOWITZ--Harold, 92, at Naples, Florida, previously from Scarsdale and Armonk, NY. Born May 31, 1922 in New York City to Jules and Rachel Goldberg Salmanowitz, Harold grew up in Manhattan, Scarsdale and Geneva, Switzerland, attending Fieldston School and College Calvin before becoming a member of the 1944 class of Dartmouth College. Serving in WWII, Harold was a recipient of the Distinguished Flying Cross for courage, heroism and devotion to duty in reviving and rescuing his tail gunner after their B-29 received a direct flak hit that opened a gaping hole in the fuselage during a bombing run over Kyushu, Japan. After the war, Harold (Bushy) married Betty Pollack of Brooklyn and went to work for Superintendence Company (now known as SGS) -- the world leader in inspection, verification, testing and certification -- founded by his father Jules and uncle Jacques Salmanowitz. After three years at the worldwide headquarters in Geneva, he returned to Superintendence Company in New York in 1948 and became its President in 1968. Harold moved to Naples, Florida in 1992 and with Betty (who predeceased him in 2005) traveled the world, enjoyed playing bridge and tennis, listened to Sunday Jazz Brunch and discovered country music and became an avid fan of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. He is survived by his four children: Barbara Fassbind (widow of Alois) of Geneva, Switzerland; Richard (Elisabeth) of Jerusalem, Israel; John (Kathy) of Menlo Park, CA and David (Wipada) of Bangkok, Thailand. He is also survived by six grandchildren who knew him as Poppy - Rebecca, Joshua, Michael, Jennifer, Rachel and Natalie - and 10 great-grandchildren as well as his 100 year old sister Violet Klosty. Between his navigation on commercial flights, marginal notations correcting Goren's bridge manual and his love of options trading, he was a man with a system that was clearly his own. We will all fondly remember him for his kindness, even temper, quirkiness and being himself. 1/3

BIRDOFF--Harvey. You were the best father, father-in-law and grandfather that anyone could ever ask for. Always with a smile and wanting to help. We will miss you tremendously. Love you with all our hearts. Rick, Vicki, Alix, Kayle and Reid 1/3

MacEACHRON-Allison Frances Bailey. 61, beloved wife of Frederick Grant MacEachron, died on March 8 at home in New York City, from breast cancer. She was born on January 5, 1954 to Avis Gilbert and Francis Wheeler Bailey in Bridgeport, CT. She attended Wheaton College, graduating in 1976 with Honors in Government. Allison grew up in Fairfield, CT, but her roots were in Maine where she spent summers on Echo Lake in Fayette. She loved her Maine heritage; her parents and several generations of grandparents were from Maine. Her great-greatgreat-great grandfather, Chase Elkins, was among the first settlers in Fayette following the American Revolution. Allison dreamed of being a New Yorker from the time she saw "Breakfast at Tiffany's" in her teens. She moved to Manhattan in 1979 where she worked in advertising for twenty-six years, the last seventeen of which were with Grey Group where she was Senior Vice President. In 2009, Allison transitioned to the non-profit sector where she was Director of the Business Council of the United Nations, a unit of the United Nations Foundation. Allison was a member of the Society of Mayflower descendants in the State of New York, having traced her roots back to four of the Pilgrims: William Brewster and Stephen Hopkins on her father's side and John Alden and William Mullins on her mother's side. She was a former treasurer of the New England Society in the City of New York, and she was a Director of the Off-the-Record (OTR) organization. She served on the board of her co-op apartment building for several years. Allison was an active Elder at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where she and her husband were married in 1993. She served on several committees there, including the Global Ministries Fellows Committee, and on two occasions, she traveled to Africa with her church. Allison traveled all over the world; she loved skiing in the Alps and the Rockies with her husband, Fred, and she enjoyed European trips with her sisters. She especially loved this country's National Parks. Allison was an avid runner, and she was an accomplished pianist. In addition to her beloved husband, Allison is survived by her father; two sisters, Christy Bailey and her partner, Herb Shumway, Anne B. Hoover and her husband, Hap Hoover; a brother, Cory Bailey and his wife, Nancy Lok Bailey; two sisters-in-law, Jane M. McCandless and her husband James, Patricia M. Cox and her husband, Daniel; several nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews and several dear and life-long friends. A Celebration of Allison's life will be held on March 28, 2015 at 2pm at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Outreach Programs at the church. 1/3

FRAWLEY--David John Devoted husband and father, "Dave" Frawley passed peacefully from this life on March 7th in Kingwood Texas with his son Timothy by his side. He was 91. His three children, Christopher, Timothy, and Margaret Anne and their families including eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren survive him. Dave was born on May 14th, 1923 in Whitestone, New York to John Joseph Frawley and Anna (Lynch) Frawley. He grew up in Harlem, graduating from St. Cecilia's Elementary School, Patrick Henry Junior High School, and the New York School of Printing. Dave served in the Army Air Corps in World War II as a bomber tail gunner, flying missions into Europe from Africa and Italy. After the war, he started his long career with Eastern Air Lines. Dave was the manager of Eastern's New York City Ticket Offices and ran the company's operation at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. During that time he married Margaret "Peggy" Raake of Audubon, New Jersey in 1953. They expanded their family to include three children and settled in Kendall Park, New Jersey. Dave commuted to Manhattan and Peggy worked for Princeton University. He retired from Eastern in 1985 and they both relocated to Clearwater Florida. His beloved Peggy died in 1994. In addition to his family, Dave's great loves were horseracing, cigars, and jazz. He helped found the non-profit Suncoast Dixieland Jazz Society to provide scholarships for young musicians. Dave's mental faculties began to slowly fade and in 2008, he relocated to Kingwood Texas to live near his son, Tim and daughter-in-law Barbara. All that were privileged to know him will miss his warm heart, bright smile, charm, and sense of humor. A funeral service will be held Saturday March 14th at 10:00AM at St. Denis Catholic Church in Havertown, PA. Donations can be made in Dave's name to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

SLUTSKY--Adele, of Baldwin, NY and Boca Raton, FL, died on March 10, at age 86. A beloved wife and mother, she is survived by her husband of 68 years, Edward "Eddie" Slutsky, and three children: Jay and his wife Joanie; Lorie; Mitchell and his wife Syndee; and four grandchildren: Jordan and his wife Emily; Jill Sanon and her husband Ron; Amanda and Peri; and two great grandchildren: Emmy Sanon and Dylan Slutsky. She also is survived by two sisters: Florence Kolodin and Gloria Amdur. Calling hours are 11am-12 noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre, immediately followed by the funeral at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Adele Slutsky Memorial Fund, The New York Community Trust, 909 Third Ave., New York, NY 10022. 1/3

ZAGOR--Howard S. Beloved husband of the late Beverly Zagor, father of Stephen and Patricia Moger, grandfather of Max, passed peacefully on March 11, 2015. Born on October 21, 1919 he was a former resident of Norwich, VT and New York City, a graduate of Columbia Grammar and Dartmouth College, a recipient of the Bronze Star for his service in World War II, a past officer and current member of The Harmonie Club and president of Marcel Rochas US and later of Stricker and Zagor, Inc. Private services will be held for the family. 1/3
